DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Decision on German NATO Membership Not up to Soviets
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 3rd graf; report of new U.S. nuclear proposal; INSERTS grafs 11-15 bgng: ``West Germany,'' with background
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Wednesday that NATO membership for a unified Germany should be up to the alliance, not the Soviet Union. But Baker said he is willing to consider the Kremlin's views when he meets with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze Friday and Saturday in Bonn. Partly to persuade the Soviet Union to accept a unified Germany in NATO, Baker will tell NATO foreign ministers that the United States will withdraw some nuclear artillery from Germany, and favors prompt negotiations to eliminate other ground-based nuclear weapons from Europe, The Washington Post said in Thursday editions. While Shevardnadze has recently signaled a willingness to drop the Soviet demand that a unified Germany be neutral, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said last weekend that his country's ``attitude toward unilateral, unbalanced proposals for the entry of a future German state into NATO remains negative.'' West Germany is the strongest U.S. ally in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Similarly, East Germany was the staunchest Soviet ally in the Warsaw Pact until its conversion to Western-style political democracy earlier this year. Shortly after Baker left Washington, officials of the two German states announced a tentative agreement on a plan for merging their economies, settling basic differences over how the nations should assess the costs of unification. Today's agreement, announced by officials in East Berlin, sets the stage for a full merger of the economies of the two nations on July 2. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has predicted political union by the end of 1991. Baker, launching a five-day European trip in which Germany's future will be the predominant issue, said the size of the German army is a legitimate topic for East-West negotiators meeting in Vienna. But, he said, ``The question whether the unified Germany should be a member of NATO is a question that is properly decided in NATO with the participation of a united Germany.'' West Germany has become more and more reluctant to be host for short-range nuclear weapons, because they would almost inevitably explode on German territory if used. Gerhard Stoltenberg, the West German defense minister, said in a speech in Washington on Tuesday that NATO might move to get rid of all ground-based nuclear weapons, leaving only air-launched missiles and bombs in its nuclear arsenal. According to the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, the United States and its allies in 1989 deployed 2,872 artillery pieces in NATO theoretically capable of firing nuclear shells, while Warsaw Pact powers had 2,070. The United States has been retiring some older 8-inch guns recently, and officials disclosed last month that the Pentagon had put on hold development of a new edition of the nuclear-tipped Lance missile. The United States has expected to begin talks with the Soviet Union on short-range nuclear weapons in Europe later this year, after conclusion of an agreement on convention weapons. Baker spoke to reporters aboard his Air Force jet en route to a refueling stop here from Washington. He then flew to Brussels for sessions Thursday with NATO and European Community foreign ministers. Last Saturday, the 12-nation Community took strides toward political union by 1993. France and West Germany led the drive. Britain, Denmark and Portugal are hesitant. The Bush administration has not taken a position, and Baker declined to be drawn into the matter. Baker will fly to Bonn on Friday for separate sessions with West German Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher and with Shevardnadze. On Saturday, the foreign ministers of the two Germanys and the four wartime allies _ the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ will meet. Among the issues Baker said they will take up is how to relinquish four-power control of Berlin, which they have held since Germany's defeat in 1945. But Germany's membership in NATO isn't a proper subject for discussion with the Soviets, Baker said. ``The fact of the matter is you can't take a decision of that nature without having the members of the alliance sitting at the table. ...'' At the meeting of the four wartime allies and the two Germanys, ``there will be, indeed, a very full and complete discussion of that issue, because that is one of the foremost issues right now that separate the alliance from the position of the Soviet Union,'' Baker said. The prospect of a united and stronger Germany in NATO has caused alarm in Moscow and stirred memories of World War II, in which an estimated 20 million Soviets perished. At times, Soviet leaders have called for dissolving both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Shevardnadze said last week that Germany should become ``a testing ground'' of new forms of East-West security cooperation. The Soviet foreign minister also has floated the idea of the unified Germany being a member of both alliances. The Western allies, meanwhile, have suggested keeping NATO troops out of what is now East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Town Mourns Loss of Three Teens to Suicide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to CORRECT name of funeral home to Buie, sted Bowie, UPDATE with graveside service, rocks thrown at press car; picks up 6th graf pvs, `On Monday, ...' INSERTS 1 graf after 14th pvs, ```Obviously school ...' to UPDATE with afternoon news briefing; picks up 15th graf pvs, `Some said..
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LR10,12
DOC.TEXT: A minister pleaded with mourners at a funeral Wednesday for one of three teen-age suicides to put aside questions about what led to their deaths, and focus instead on avoiding the same path. Thomas Smith, 17, was the first of three suicides among Sheridan High School students in two days, and counselors for their classmates were on 24-hour call. About 80 students missed classes Wednesday, about 30 more than usual, school officials said. Some of the absentees were among about 250 people packed into the Buie Funeral Home chapel to hear the Rev. Dennis Moon urge them to cling to God as they grieved over Smith's death. ``Bringing back Tommy is beyond our control, but going with him ... is still our choice,'' said Moon during the 20-minute service. ``We don't need to ask God why he would let this happen,'' said Moon, of the Landmark Baptist Chruch. ``We need to ask God what would he want us to do.'' A graveside service followed at a cemetery in Grapevine, some 23 miles from Sheridan. Five members of the school's ROTC, of which Smith was a member, stood at attention about five feet from the casket. A man walked up to each youth, removed a white flower from his uniform lapel and set it in the youths' white gloves. As the gathering broke up, four young men approached a reporter and three photographers and demanded their film. The photographers refused; two of the youths threw rocks at the car as it left. On Monday, Smith stood in front of his American history class, told a female classmate, ``I love you,'' pulled a gun out of his pants and shot himself. Later that day, Chidester, 19, of the Grapevine community, a friend of Smith's, died of a gunshot wound. He left a note that said ``I can't go on any longer,'' according to police. On Tuesday, the body of Jerry Paul McCool, a 17-year-old sophomore, was discovered in his home by his father. McCool, who also had been shot, knew Smith and Chidester, but wasn't close with them, officials said. All three deaths were ruled suicides, said Grant County Sheriff Cary Clark. In addition to those deaths, a 17-year-old classmate shot himself to death March 28. And three other county residents _ ages 22, 40, and 82 _ have killed themselves since Jan. 23. Hours after the latest shooting, parents and students packed the school's 1,000-seat auditorium to discuss the suicides. Some held hands. Some cried. About 60 counselors and clergymen from around the state had arrived at the normally quiet bedroom community 30 miles south of Little Rock. School Superintendent David Robinson said students met with counselors in group sessions and one-on-one Wednesday. ``Obviously school, as such, is not occurring at the moment,'' Robinson said. ``Actually, it's more like a massive counseling session.'' Later Wednesday, he said the mood had improved. ``The bottom line is we feel pretty good about how people are recovering. The kids have told us they're ready to try to get back to normal.'' Some said the atmosphere was less somber at the school Wednesday than earlier in the week. Lisa Deal, 18, a senior and president of the student council, said even though the mood had improved, the community had a long way to go to get over the series of deaths. ``It's scary knowing your friends ... would go to these extremes,'' she said. Ms. Deal said she was an acquaintance of Smith and Chidester. ``The students really opened up here today,'' she said of the counseling sessions. ``Yesterday was bad for us because it was newer. Everybody had just heard about it.'' Robinson, who held a news conference Wednesday morning, said he also felt the situation was getting better. ``I think the fact that our students were involved in a kind of organized session this morning and were able to express their feelings helped,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Officials Seeking Extradition of Man Involved in Abduction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with comments from Mexican attorney general, Thornburgh. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `One of...'
DOC.TEXT: Mexican officials on Wednesday asked for the extradition of a man who says he masterminded the abduction of a Mexican doctor accused of participating in the death of a U.S. drug agent. Mexican Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo said extradition papers are being prepared for Antonio Garate Bustamante, who claims to be a Drug Enforcement Administration operative who organized the kidnapping of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain in Guadalajara on April 2. U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh met with Alvarez del Castillo for more than an hour discussing drug enforcement efforts as well as the current controversy over the alleged abduction of Alvarez. ``We have in process a corresponding arrest order to solicit his (Garate's) extradition from whichever country he is found,'' Alvarez del Castillo said in Spanish after the meeting. Thornburgh refused to say whether Alvarez del Castillo asked for Garate's extradition during the meeting, adding that such requests would be made through the U.S. State Department. Thornburgh said the matter of Alvarez' arrest will be dealt with during a May 25 federal court hearing in Los Angeles. Garate, a former Mexican police officer, told the Los Angeles Times last week that he arranged the abduction of Alvarez with approval from the DEA. Garate said 10 Mexicans were promised $100,000 for Alvarez' capture and delivery to El Paso, Texas, according to the Times. Earlier, a spokesman for Alvarez del Castillo, Fernando Arias Alvarez, said Mexico would ask for the extradition of others who may have participated in the abduction of Alvarez. One of five men arrested in the abduction placed Garate at the scene, Arias said. That man, Jorge Cobarrubias, an ex-policeman from the Mexican state of Hidalgo, said he lined up the others to help grab the doctor, said Arias. The abduction of the doctor has strained relations between the United States and Mexico, which has threatened to stop cooperating in the fight against drug trafficking. Arias also said that Mexico wants an agreement with the United States that would allow Mexican drug agents to operate in the United States, the same way U.S. DEA agents work in Mexico. There are 41 DEA agents in Mexico, he said. The two country's ambassadors, John Negroponte of the United States and Gustavo Petricioli of Mexico, were at Wednesday's meeting, which was held as a three-day conference of border state attorneys general began in Santa Fe, Arias said. The two attorneys general were talking about possible formal charges against Garate and others, Arias said. Alvarez, a Guadalajara gynecologist, is charged in connection with the 1985 death of drug agent Enrique Camarena. Prosecutors allege that Alvarez gave Camarena drugs to revive him for additional torture before his slaying. His trial has been delayed pending a court-ordered May 25 hearing in U.S. District Court in Los Angeles on the matter of how he was brought to the U.S. from Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Lukens Apologizes, Says He Will Run
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Donald Lukens, convicted of a sex offense that threatens his career, is taking his case to the voters. ``I apologize. I made a dumb mistake. I'm sorry,'' the Republican said Wednesday in announcing for re-election less than a week before Tuesday's primary. The 59-year-old divorced congressman was convicted of a misdemeanor charge last year of contributing to the unrulinesss of a minor for having sex with a 16-year-old girl at his Columbus apartment in 1988. He was sentenced to 30 days in jail and fined $500 but is free on appeal. Robert Bennett, chairman of the Ohio Republican Party, said Lukens displayed ``a lapse of morals,'' and he repeated a call for the congressman to resign. ``This is not a political matter; it's a moral matter,'' he said. ``On May 8, I am sure the voters will do the right thing and say goodbye to Donald `Buz' Lukens,'' Bennett said. Ohio Democratic Party Chairman James Ruvolo said he ``wouldn't count (Lukens) out.'' He also said: ``I assume he's given Bob Bennett heartburn.'' Lukens is facing three Republican challengers _ former U.S. Rep. Thomas Kindness, state Rep. John Boehner and bond underwriter Mort Meier. Three candidates are running in the Democratic primary. Reaction to Lukens' re-election bid was mixed. Rita Hardman of Fletcher said she will vote for Lukens. ``I think he has a lot of undercover supporters that don't have the nerve to say, `I'm going to vote for him,' but will,'' she said. Dan Cook, a Republian, said Lukens' legal situation disqualifies him in his mind. ``I think he's embarrassing to the party. I think he's embarrassing to the whole government,'' he said. ``He's not the good example that you would expect.'' Lukens had said since his conviction that he wouldn't decide on his political future until after the outcome of his appeal. He filed for re-election but hadn't openly campaigned. Appearing with his mother, he made his announcement Wednesday before about 20 supporters outside the post office in this farming village of 515. ``I apologize for the situation I allowed to be created,'' Lukens said. ``I made a bad mistake. But the mistake was not evil and not criminal. I'm saying I'm not guilty of the charge.'' Boehner said he doesn't believe Lukens will be a factor in the race, and he called the congressman's announcement a ``last-ditch effort'' to save his job. ``I guess it surprises me that after all this time he would conveniently come to the conclusion that he ought to apologize six days before the election,'' Boehner said. Donald Birgel, chairman of the Butler County Republican Party, said Lukens could win. ``His supporters will be there at the polls,'' Birgel said. ``They're not going to stay home.'' Lukens served in Congress from 1967 to 1970, when he made an unsuccessful attempt to gain the GOP gubernatorial nomination. After 15 years in the Ohio Senate, he returned to Congress in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Bible Belt Prosecutor Pulls Plug on National Satellite TV Sex Films
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A Bible Belt prosecutor has pulled the plug on a national X-rated TV channel that beamed movies like ``Ramb-Ohhh! Sex Platoon'' and ``Hardcore Girlfriends'' to satellite dish owners. Civil libertarians are alarmed by the ease with which District Attorney Jimmy Evans, a Democratic candidate for state attorney general, drove New York-based Home Dish Satellite Networks Inc. out of business. ``What's happened is some little small town in the South is setting the standard for the rest of the country,'' said Martin McCaffery, vice president of the Civil Liberties Union of Alabama. ``It's a horrendous precedent.'' Evans says adult films have no First Amendment protection. ``These movies not only violate Alabama's obscenity law, they violate every state obscenity law and the federal obscenity law,'' he said. ``This is a national scandal.'' He said he began an investigation after parents complained that their young children were obtaining videotapes of pornographic movies broadcast on the American Exxxtasy Channel, which was operated by Home Dish. ``I know from experience that hardcore obscenity leads to the abuse of women and children,'' the Montgomery County prosecutor said. ``It's bad for our community and bad for our children.'' The American Exxxtasy Channel transmitted hard-core movies to home satellite subscribers, but it also operated the Tuxxedo Channel, a cable channel featuring R-rated ``soft-core'' porn. In February, a grand jury in Montgomery returned more than 500 indictments against Home Dish, three other out-of-state companies and 10 people on charges of distributing hardcore pornography via satellite into Alabama. The other indicted companies _ General Telephone and Electronics Corp., GTE Spacenet Corp. and U.S. Satellite Inc. _ provided the satellite capability for American Exxxtasy, but they pleaded ignorance and cut off Home Dish service. The Tuxxedo Channel soon met the same fate. Its broadcasts to local cable affiliates and dish owners were removed from a satellite owned by General Motors Corp. after a grand jury returned another indictment against Home Dish. Home Dish, which had reached 1.2 million cable customers and 80,000 satellite-equipped homes, had to lay off its 100 employees. Its president, Paul Klein, and three other company officials still face an Alabama extradition request. ``I can't fight it,'' said Klein, a former NBC executive. ``I'm small and very vulnerable. I'm out of business and they're still trying to extradite me.'' New York Gov. Mario Cuomo has the extradition request ``under review,'' his office said. ``Without proving that anything is obscene, Jimmy Evans has succeeded in bankrupting this company and keeping the rest of the country from seeing these movies in the privacy of their home,'' McCaffery said. Klein said his channels, which had 30 satellite customers in Montgomery and about 600 around the state, were ``meant for consenting adults.'' But perhaps thousands of others were stealing the service with illegal descramblers. Klein said many Tuxxedo affiliates switched their subscribers to one of two other soft-core cable channels, Rendezvous and Playboy. Evans said he knows nothing of those channels, which Montgomery's only cable company doesn't offer. Evans, Montgomery's chief prosecutor since 1973, went after adult magazines in 1986, while in his first, unsuccessful bid to become attorney general. Playboy and Penthouse magazines fought back, filing a lawsuit that accused Evans of arbitrarily listing about 50 adult magazines as obscene and then pressuring Montgomery-area merchants not to sell them. A federal judge sided with the publishers in a sharply worded order that barred Evans from bringing criminal charges against merchants for past sales of sexually explicit magazines. Despite the order, convenience stores and other merchants continued to refrain from selling hard-core sex magazines. Last year, Evans attacked adult videotapes. Thirteen businesses were charged with selling and renting allegedly obscene tapes. About 130 indictments were returned against the businesses, their managers and other store employees. The cases never went to trial. The stores agreed to pay fines and remove the offending tapes from their shelves. Evans denies that he's mixing politics with porn. But he'll be the first to admit that he's ready to expand his smut-busting campaign from the confines of Montgomery, a city of 180,000. ``When I get in the attorney general's office, there's not going to be a single hamlet or village or city in this state that's going to have that kind of stuff for sale,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Glasnost On Paris Runways: Velour-Clad Guns and Miniskirts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: After years as the butt of Western jokes, East Bloc fashion hit the Paris runways with a display of such glasnost-inspired styles as see-through culottes, minuscule minis and a velour-covered submachine gun. Four designers from the Soviet Union, Poland, Hungary and East Germany paraded their creations before a small group of invited guests at the Prince de Galles Marriott Hotel on Wednesday. It was a preview of a big fashion show-cocktail party for 700 guests to be held tonight at the Salle Wagram, a dance hall-turned-auditorium. A prize will be awarded by the Lalique crystal company to the most talented designer. Whoever wins will be happy, but all four designers were pleased to be showing in Paris, widely viewed as the West's fashion capital. Soviet designer Lena Zelinskaia, 25, startled the audience with shiny velour culotte suits in fire-engine red, turquoise blue and grass green _ accompanied by matching velour-wrapped submachine guns. She denied the guns were a ploy to attract photographers. ``The machine-gun accessory symbolizes the Russian Revolution, which is still very much in our minds,'' Zelinskaia said, taking a bow with the other designers after the show. Her clothes were a far cry from the Western image of Soviet fashion, perhaps most mercilessly parodied in a TV commercial for Wendy's, in which a matronly model in a drab dress for daywear merely adds a flashlight for evening, and a beach ball for swimwear. As for the future of Soviet design, she said: ``It won't be French. We're a different country with different religion and politics. But we have many tendencies, and I can't speak for the others _ only myself.'' ``I'm an old designer, in the business for 30 years,'' said Polish creator Jerzy Antkowiak, 50, who displayed the most variety in his preview. His clothes ranged from a flowing gray crepe de chine printed duster over a wide long pantskirt to a deep red taffeta mini-dress with several daring cutouts on the back and a transparent navy long-culottes outfit. ``We've got many problems in Poland,'' said Antkowiak, dressed in a loose charcoal linen suit and ochre scarf. ``For instance, we have to import all our fabrics. But we have hopes that we'll get investments from the West to set up better manufacturing and business.'' The show was organized by the Ecole Superieure de Commerce de Compiegne, a French business school north of Paris. Last year the school featured top Soviet designer Slava Zaitsev. This year's choice of designers evolved from embassy suggestions and from connections that one of the organizers, Boris Bostjancic, has with Moscow Contact, a new firm that seeks to set up East-West commercial agreements. East German designer Anja Wenzel showed attractive long looks, featuring some folklore-inspired fabric mixes and a black chiffon halter-necked jumpsuit with a metal snake slithering up back and front. Hungarian designer Katelin Berenyi, 24, has lived in Paris for the past two years, studying at the national decorative arts school. One of her outfits _ reminiscent of Pierre Cardin _ included a velvet micro-mini over thigh-high socks and cone-shaped, pleated gauntlets of white paper on the model's arms. ``I love crazy fashions,'' said Antkowiak, who admits that his clothes look way-out and are expensive for Poland _ about $50 a dress. He said they are usually purchased by privileged richer women, diplomats and tourists. ``So far, I have to keep prices high,'' he said. ``Because if I offer cheaper models, my old clientele asks why, and doesn't want to buy them. They want to be special.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Clash With Revelers at New York Park
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Rob Nunzio ...' with two grafs to CLARIFY guitarist was not performing; ADDS quote from other musician. Picks up 8th graf, `Later, about...'
DOC.TEXT: Police swarmed into a gritty park and clashed with squatters holding a May Day festival Tuesday night after people began throwing bottles to protest an abrupt end to a park concert, police said. The clash at Tompkins Square Park in the East Village left 12 officers injured, and several protesters were arrested, police said. Dozens of homeless people live in the park. Tensions have flared the past two summers when police moved to oust the squatters. Concert-goers began throwing bottles when police turned out the lights to the bandshell at 9 p.m. because the band had a permit to play only until then, said Police Capt. Charles Hanley. ``There were about 300 people there,'' Hanley said. ``They got angry, started throwing bottles. It was basically a riot.'' The injured officers suffered assorted head and hand injuries, said Hanley and Lt. Dave Fenton. Police apparently made their first charge after a Parks Department officer was hit in the face with a bottle. Rob Nunzio, 27, lead guitarist in the band Antidote, was on stage when the lights went out, said: ``When they shut the music off, people started protesting. The cops came in from Avenue A. It looked like hundreds of them. People started screaming at the cops...The cops grabbed whoever was in their way and threw them down.'' ``One cop got hit by a bottle while on stage and got very mad and started trashing our equipment,'' said another musician, Jason Goodrow. Later, about 50 police officers wearing helmets and carrying shields and nightsticks remained in the park. Dozens of people were walking around the neighborhood, knocking over garbage cans and setting trash on fire. Others sat down in the street by the park, chanting at police officers: ``The cops started the riot.'' About half hour later, at 11 p.m., a skirmish broke out when about four officers on scooters apparently tried to break through a line of 50 protesters. The protesters retaliated by knocking the officers off their scooters, prompting about two dozens officers to rush in, pushing aside the protesters and dragging one of them off. The ``Squatter May Day'' festival, featuring live music, contests and food, began Saturday and was scheduled to end Tuesday at the East Village park. On Aug. 6-7, 1988, the park was bloodied by a four-hour clash between demonstrators and police that left 52 people injured. Last summer, there were numerous arrests during several standoffs between police and the park's denizens that began July 5 when police tore down a tent city and evicted more than 130 people.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Considers Radical Idea: Paying Bills by Mail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The Post Office is proposing a revolutionary idea _ that the 150 million people of Latin America's largest country pay their bills by mail instead of standing in line. Brazil is modern in many ways, but you still cannot write a check for your electricity bill, put it in a stamped envelope and drop it in a mailbox. Virtually all bills are paid at banks, which are clogged with long lines of grumbling, sweaty people holding stacks of electricity, gas, and water bills; school, department store, health insurance and credit card accounts, auto license fees and statements of income or property taxes. A specialized commercial culture has sprouted around the practice. Companies and wealthy individuals hire young men, universally called ``office boys,'' to do their standing and paying. One company's office boy presented a check to pay the telephone bill, but the bank insisted on cash. He went to the company's own bank, which said it would take a check but must have a new one naming the bank as payee. In desperation, the office boy returned to the first bank, where the manager finally made an exception and accepted the check. The Post Office wants to make things simpler. Its press spokesman, Jose Valfranio Medeiros de Oliveira, said in an interview: ``There's nothing easier than paying bills by mail, and we want to make life easier for our citizens.'' Some newspapers have begun, rather timidly, to support the program. ``Yes, there is a long tradition here of not paying by mail,'' Oliveira said, ``but we have the infrastructure, we have credibility. There's no reason this won't work.'' This month, he said, the Post Office will run a test program allowing people in the northeastern state of Bahia, population 11.6 million, to pay telephone bills by mail. If that goes well, the experiment will be extended to other states and to bills for water, gas and federal taxes. ``All Brazil's 4,000-plus townships have post offices, whereas one-third don't have banks,'' Oliveira said. ``In addition, there are 22,000 public mailboxes and 3,000 rural collection points on farms and ranches. Post offices have longer hours than banks. Some post offices are open on weekends.'' Brazil's largest commercial bank, the government-controlled Banco do Brasil, announced plans for a ``Citizens' Comfort,'' a program that would allow even people without accounts at the bank to mail it their checks for water, electricity, gas and federal tax bills. Alberto Policaro, the bank president, said that would make life easier for Brazilians and ``free bank workers from receiving bills and let them get on with the bank's real business _ taking in deposits and making loans.'' Public acceptance of such a departure is far from universal. Luis Sant'Anna Mendes, a Rio teletype operator who used to work for the Post Office telegraph service, said: ``I'd rather wait in line at a bank. That way you have confirmation that you paid.'' At a bank, you get a stub with a machine stamp showing the amount paid. Oliveira said post offices could provide the same kind of receipt. That means bill payers would have to line up at the post office, of course, but the press spokesman said: ``Our lines move faster than bank lines.'' Surveys by Brazil's largest private polling company, known as IBOPE, indicate the Post Office is Brazil's most trusted public institution, but skepticism persists. ``You just don't know if the letter really will get there,'' Mendes said. Another problem is that Brazilian banks do not return canceled checks; they keep check records on microfilm. In the case of a disputed payment, the payer would have to line up at the bank to see his account record. ``There are technical details to be worked out,'' Oliveira acknowledged, ``but if you can pay bills by mail in the United States and Europe, there's no reason you can't do it in Brazil too.''

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Zoos Hunt for Ugly African Mammal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Looks aren't everything. If they were, zoo curators across the country wouldn't be scrambling to get their own colonies of naked mole rats. The fanged, 4-inch African mammals are desired for their subterranean social habits, not their pink, wrinkled, looks. ``They're not the most attractive mammal I've ever seen,'' said James Doherty, general curator at New York's Bronx Zoo, which plans to open an exhibit next winter. Since March 1989, the Cincinnati Zoo has had the nation's only display of the hairless mole rats, but the Brookfield Zoo near Chicago plans to open its exhibit May 18. Zoos in Philadelphia and London have mole rats that are not on display while zoos in Phoenix and Washington, D.C., are seeking colonies. ``It continues to be a popular attraction, because they catch your eye for one reason or another,'' said Randy Morgan, an entomologist who oversees the Cincinnati Zoo's 40-rat exhibit. ``I don't think of them as ugly. I think they come across as bizarre, animated and comical.'' Zoo curators and scientists say mole rats' beauty and significance are in their lifestyles. Virtually blind, they live underground and burrow in a constant search for food, tubers and roots they find by stumbling upon them. However, they are distinguished by their social system, Morgan said Tuesday. They live in colonies of about three dozen. Only one female in each colony breeds, using her sharp teeth to fend off challengers and secreting a scent that inhibits other females from developing into queens. Only one or two males mate with the queen and researchers are uncertain how they are selected, Morgan said. All other able-bodied mole rats search for food, for themselves and the queen. In exhibits, they scamper backward as easily as forward, yanking other mole rats out of the way by their tails and digging through wood and cork shavings within their home. They sleep in huddles, piling on top of each other for warmth. But a pile of naked mole rats is seldom still. If one twitches in its sleep, the entire huddle shudders, Morgan said. Documented more than a century ago, naked mole rats are found only under the desert of Kenya in eastern Africa. Zoos pay about $200 an animal, said Bruce Brewer, curator of mammals at the Brookfield Zoo. Zoo curators credit South African researcher Jennifer Jarvis with bringing mole rats to light, which piqued zoos' interest. The problem with zoo displays was the mole rats' extreme sensitivity to sound and vibration, Doherty said. The rats are easily panicked by the slightest sound or vibration and their huge incisors can rapidly scratch plexiglass into a frosted, opaque shield. ``We kind of whisper around them,'' Doherty said. Zoos have developed ways to shock-proof their mole rat habitats, some building mazes of glass tubes on tables embedded in sand and others erecting double glass walls that trap air as insulation. Reaction from zoo patrons varies when they first see naked mole rats, Morgan said. ``It varies from `Oh yuck' to `Oh my God,''' Morgan said. ``They see mole or rat on the display and think `these are the things in my front yard.' ``But for people who take time to read about them, they are amazed,'' he said. ``On busy days, people are lined up three to four deep.''

DOC.HEAD: It's the Culinary Craze of the Ozarks: Cashew Chicken
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Oriental food is king in this Queen City of the Ozarks, where even the burger joints serve the dish that all Springfield craves: Cashew chicken. Ozark cuisine may conjure up images of pan-fried trout and catfish, fried chicken, mashed potatoes and gravy. But just as surely as Bostonians bake beans and Chicagoans take pride in pizza, Springfield's culinary claim to fame is cashew chicken. More than 50 of Springfield's 375 licensed restaurants feature Chinese food. Another dozen or so Korean, Polynesian, Japanese and Vietnamese restaurants contribute to a gastronomic smorgasbord for Asian food lovers. ``I'm a Chinese food nut. With a Chinese restaurant on every corner, I'm in heaven,'' says Gary Wilson, an attorney and regular at the all-you-can-eat noon and evening buffets offered by many of the restaurants. But not just any Chinese food. Chinese restaurants here are judged not for their moo goo gai pan or egg rolls, but for their cashew chicken. And not just Chinese restaurants. Even cafeterias and burger shops serve up the dish. Springfield's unofficial nickname says it all: ``Cashew Chicken Capital of the Midwest.'' One newspaper columnist took calculator in hand and figured that Springfield restaurants serve a minimum of 6,697 to 8,554 orders of cashew chicken a day. That averages out to 2.4 million to 3.1 million orders a year. Springfield's variation on the dish isn't the standard cashew chicken dish found around the country, where stir-fried chicken and vegetables are mixed with cashews. Chefs here dip the chicken in batter, deep-fat fry it, smother it with a thick brown sauce made from chicken stock and soy sauce, add cashews and a few bits of green onion and serve the concoction beside a bed of fried rice. One aficionado fondly describes the meal as ``kind of like chicken McNuggets with gravy.'' So peculiar is the cashew chicken recipe to Springfield that Chinese restaurants in cities like Dallas, Chicago, Kansas City and St. Louis that try to imitate it identify the dish on menus as ``Springfield cashew chicken.'' But the cashew chicken served outside of Springfield, a regional trade and health center in southwestern Missouri, usually falls short of the dish current and former residents crave. ``I've never tasted the cashew chicken I loved in Springfield anywhere else,'' says Timolyn Skeeters, a flight attendant based in Charlotte, N.C., and a graduate of Southwest Missouri State University in Springfield. ``I miss it. Out here cashew chicken is just regular chicken and a few cashews. I think the secret must be in the sauce.'' The roots of Springfield's love affair with cashew chicken can be traced to 1963. That was when David Leong and his wife, Shau, left Florida to found Leong's Tea House, Springfield's first Chinese restaurant. At first, Ozarkers were skeptical of Chinese food. ``My father noticed that people here liked fried chicken,'' said Ling Leong, president of his family's restaurant and Chinese specialty foods company. ``So he cut it into bite-size pieces and served it with a special sauce and cashews and rice.'' Springfield cashew chicken was born and quickly became a hit among the meat-and-potatoes crowd. Soon more Chinese, then Vietnamese, began moving to Springfield, where minorities still account for barely 2 percent of the population. They opened restaurants, and virtually every one featured cashew chicken. ``I think one reason cashew chicken became popular is because this is chicken country,'' said Woodrow Sun, who with his wife, Aurora, owns four Chinese restaurants. ``People like to eat chicken. Eighty percent of my restaurants' sales are chicken dishes.'' The low price of cashew chicken _ ranging from about $2.50 for a carryout order to around $7 in full-service restaurants _ appeals to families and the 25,000 students attending four colleges in the city. Leong said he'd heard two more Chinese restaurants would open this year. ``If they asked me, my advice would be don't do it,'' Sun said with a wry smile. ``That's all this town needs is another Chinese restaurant.''

DOC.HEAD: Government, Rebel Forces Battle As Eritrean War Enters Decisive Stage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: The writer has just ended a nine-day journey behind rebel lines in Eritrea. Because of lack of transmission facilities, his story could not be filed until he left Eritrea.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Day and night, heavy artillery and tank barrages thunder along a 90-mile front, in what might be the decisive battle of the nearly 30-year-old Eritrean civil war, Africa's longest-running conflict. The battle raging between Ethiopian government troops and Eritrean rebels in Ethiopia's northernmost province is possibly the most destructive conflict in the world today, resulting in thousands of casualties on both sides. The rebels appear to have the upper hand in the fighting along what is called the Ghinda front. So fierce are the artillery and tank exchanges that their distant rumble can be heard clearly in the strategic Red Sea port of Massawa, about 37 miles away. Massawa, now in rebel hands, was the target of six Ethiopian air raids in April by Soviet-built MiG fighters. Rebel spokesmen say at least 110 people, many of them civilians, have been killed in the cluster bomb attacks. The antagonists in the fight are the Marxist government of President Mengistu Haile Mariam and rebel forces dominated by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, which seek independence for the province of 3.5 million people. The Eritrean Front is considered left-leaning, but its leaders say they reject any political identification tag. The government forces' immediate objective is to recapture Massawa, one of only two Ethiopian Red Sea harbors that have traditionally handled most of the country's trade and international relief supplies for millions of famine victims. The port was captured by the Eritreans on Feb. 11, three days after they launched a major new offensive in their 29-year-old war of secession. The rebels have their sights set on a bigger objective _ the capture of their ancient, hallowed provincial capital of Asmara and the end to a conflict that has claimed hundreds of thousands of lives. The Ghinda front straddles the only road from Asmara to Massawa, a two-lane ribbon of asphalt stretching 62 miles. The Addis Ababa government has issued few war communiques, but in a rare pronouncement acknowledged last Friday that the battle had ``reached a decisive final stage.'' The last previous government statement on the conflict came in mid-February, shortly after the fall of Massawa to the rebels. At that time, Mengistu told parliament that failure to recapture Massawa would mean the loss of his 2nd Revolutionary Army, Asmara, and Eritrea itself. That now seems likely. Mengistu's 2nd Army, more than 100,000 strong, representing almost a third of Ethiopia's military strength, is virtually surrounded in the highlands around Asmara. Its only remaining supply route is a tenuous air link from government-held territory far to the south and east. Another major rebel force, the Tigre People's Liberation Front, has tied up Mengistu's remaining armies in an offensive that has taken the Tigreans to within 100 miles of the capital of Addis Ababa. The Tigreans are seeking Mengistu's ouster. The Ethiopian government claims, and the Eritrean rebels freely acknowledge, that the two offensives by the separate rebel forces have been coordinated. The Tigrean rebels began their offensive last August, sweeping south and east out of their stronghold of Tigre Province, just south of Eritrea. Isayas Afeworki, the general secretary of the Eritrean rebel movement, says his strategy is to bleed Mengistu's 2nd Army dry on the Ghinda front, then retake the offensive. ``There is no hope for the dergue (government) to take back Massawa,'' Afeworki said. ``I think what they are doing is motivated by desperation.'' A new offensive, aimed at Asmara from the south, already is under way, but it is unclear if it is being pursued by the Eritreans or the Tigreans. Ethiopia claims a Tigrean force has pushed northward, overrunning three government garrisons south of Asmara and behind the Ghinda front. The Eritreans claim the new move as their own. On the Ghinda front, Afeworki said the Ethiopian army had made three major attempts to retake Massawa in the past month, but described it as ``a futile, suicidal effort.'' Afeworki and other rebel leaders said the 2nd Army's only access to the lowland plains leading to the Red Sea is through a few, narrow mountain roads that are easy to choke. ``They have to get through our artillery, tank and mortar fire, then our minefields. Then our fighters pop up out of their bunkers and chew up those that remain,'' Afeworki said. The rebels claim they have inflicted some 13,000 casualties on government forces in nearly a month of fighting along the Ghinda front, including 6,000 killed. They don't talk in specific numbers about their own losses, but Afeworki said they were less than a tenth of the government's. Ethiopia's armed forces are the largest in black Africa, numbering 315,800. The International Institute for Strategic Studies, based in London, estimates the Eritrean rebel force at 30,000, and the Tigreans at 20,000. The government and the rebels have made exaggerated battlefield claims which cannot be independently verified. But there is no doubt about the ferocity of the fighting. In recent testimony to a Senate committee in Washington, the assistant secretary of state for African affairs, Herman J. Cohen, described the conflict as ``possibly the largest in terms of combatants and the most destructive in the world today.'' The intensified fighting follows two unsuccessful rounds of peace talks held late last year between government and rebel emissaries under the mediation of former President Jimmy Carter in Nairobi, Kenya, and Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: May Day Melee Shows Public Anger Against Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev drummed his fingers as protesters in Red Square shouted, ``Resign!'' but he showed no anger over a demonstration that he himself authorized. ``Food is not a Luxury,'' read one sign, protesting the failure of Gorbachev's reforms to deliver economic benefits. ``A Dictator is a President Without an Election,'' said another slogan, referring to Gorbachev's appointment as president in March by a legislature that also granted him sweeping powers beyond those he enjoys as general secretary of the Communist Party. In a nation where pollsters have not published comprehensive opinion surveys on the leader's popularity, the May Day outburst was the clearest sign yet of rising public anger over a slowdown in reforms under Gorbachev. Such an outburst may have been just what Gorbachev had in mind when he signed a presidential order last month moving control over demonstrations in Moscow from the city government to the national Council of Ministers. The council, made up of Gorbachev's supporters, approved Tuesday's unofficial demonstration. ``They weren't surprised. They knew exactly what to expect,'' said Leonid Zhuralev, one of the tens of thousands of protesters who filed through Red Square. Gorbachev might use the protest to persuade reluctant hard-liners to agree to radical economic reforms that he has promised recently. He has used the tactic before. On Feb. 4, a crowd officially estimated at 200,000 gathered outside the Kremlin demanding a multiparty system. Three days later, conservatives on the Communist Party Central Committee bowed to Gorbachev's suggestion that the constitution be amended to deprive the party of its monopoly on power. In the five years since he became party general secretary, Gorbachev has managed to turn nearly every defeat into a victory, staying a step or two ahead of his opponents on the right and left. He could be in for the harshest test yet of his political agility in the coming weeks. The parliament of the Russian Federation, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics, convenes for the first time on May 16, and it could elect Gorbachev's populist rival Boris Yeltsin as president of the republic. The party is in turmoil. It opens a congress on July 2, and is widely expected to split into at least three factions, left and right, with Gorbachev supporters in the middle. After elections in March, radical reformers took over the Moscow and Leningrad city governments. Radicals, like many of the May Day protesters, want to move more quickly to a market economy. Conservatives, such as party apparatchiks and many military officers, oppose market reforms and fear the uncertainties of political change. ``Many wise men of economics are calling us to plunge headlong into a market economy, trusting our luck,'' said Yevgeny Kuznetsov, a union leader who addressed the May Day crowd before the protesters filed through Red Square. ``But we won't be able to trust our luck if we don't beforehand take into account the consequences: growth in prices, a fall in the standard of living, and unemployment,'' Kuznetsov said. The conservatives are also angry that Gorbachev allowed the collapse of the Soviet empire in Eastern Europe, and the declaration of independence by Lithuania. The May Day protesters, by contrast, shouted: ``Freedom for Lithuania!'' The domestic furor has deflected Soviet attention from an aspect of Gorbachev's policies that has made him popular in the West, the pursuit of arms control and the reduction of world tension. And that means Gorbachev may not get much of a boost at home from his planned summit meeting with President Bush at the end of what has already started as a very harried month of May.
EDITORS: Bryan Brumley has covered Soviet affairs for The Associated Press since 1981 from Warsaw, Moscow and Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Gives Texas a Reprieve in School Finance Overhaul
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Session begins 3 p.m. EDT; lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bill Clements called the Legislature into session today for a third try at school finance reform after a judge gave the state another month to devise a plan to send more money to poor schools. If the Legislature and Clements cannot agree on a plan this time, one will be written for them, state District Judge Scott McCown said Tuesday. ``The present scheme of public school finance is a great wrong. ... The poor have waited for too long,'' McCown said as he extended the Texas Supreme Court's Tuesday deadline for overhauling school financing to June 1. The reprieve allowed a $500 million state aid payment to be made in May and ensured schools will stay open through this school year. McCown warned there will be no further deadline extensions. The Texas Supreme Court ruled 9-0 last year in favor of property-poor school districts that challenged the current $13.5 billion-a-year system as unfair. School spending in Texas, as in many states, is based mostly on property taxes. State Education Commissioner William Kirby said he feared a third legislative failure would lead to a court-written plan. He said that the court can only shift money around, not raise taxes, and that any court-ordered solution would be a ``Robin Hood'' one _ ``taking from the rich, giving to the poor.'' Other school officials praised the ruling. ``If it needs to be corrected judiciously, so be it,'' said Charles Hohertz, superintendent of the Shallowater Independent School District, one of 54 school systems that took part in the suit. The second attempt to overhaul school financing failed over a proposed tax increase Tuesday. The Democratic-controlled Legislature had approved a $555 million reform plan. To pay for it, legislators proposed cutting $114 million from the budget and raising the state sales tax from 6 cents to 6{ cents on the dollar. But Clements, a Republican, vetoed the tax increase. He said the money should be taken from other programs. In case Clements and lawmakers fail again, the judge Tuesday said he would appoint a special master to get started on a finance plan of his own. At Edgewood High School in San Antonio, where many classrooms are not air-conditioned and lockers and bathrooms are in disrepair, educators and students said they were not optimistic about lawmakers solving the problem by June 1. But Pat Ramirez, an English teacher, said she knew how to make lawmakers deal with the issue. ``Just come and sit in a classroom with four fans blowing hot air, if you're lucky enough to be in a room that has four fans like mine, and you would come up with something very quickly,'' she said. Texas is one of a dozen states where courts have overturned school finance systems deemed unfair to poor districts. The others are Kentucky, New Jersey, Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Connecticut, Washington, West Virginia, Wyoming, Arkansas and Montana.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Tries to Sell Rejected Radar as Anti-Drug Tool
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon, touting the contribution its new radar could make in the drug war, is seeking money for the high-tech system that Congress wouldn't buy for its military value. The $242.8 million radar, which would scan deep into Mexico to find drug-smuggling aircraft, has resurfaced as the costliest item in the Defense Department's 1991 counter-drug budget. Congressional investigators question whether moving the system to the popular and growing anti-drug budget is a maneuver to save it. ``I categorically deny it,'' said Michael A. Wermuth, deputy assistant secretary of defense for drug enforcement policy. The Defense Department tried to sell a southern-facing sector of ``over the horizon backscatter'' radar to Congress in fiscal years 1989 and 1990 _ citing a potential bomber threat from Latin America. But lawmakers such as Rep. Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass., chairman of the House Armed Services investigations subcommittee, were unconvinced and declined to approve the project. Mavroules said there was ``absolutely not, in my judgment,'' a bomber threat from Latin America. The lawmaker said he wants to investigate the budget shuffle, but is willing to let the Pentagon prove the radar is an effective tool in drug interdiction. The first ``backscatter'' system became operational April 24 in Bangor, Maine, to protect the Atlantic coast. Wermuth said test results showed it could detect the slow-moving, low-flying drug planes that plod toward the U.S. southwest border. Other ``backscatter'' sites are under construction in the West, and Congress also has agreed to construction of the radar in Alaska. ``This is not a system that has been purchased exclusively for counter-narcotics,'' said the Pentagon's Wermuth, arguing there still is a long-term bomber threat from the south even if there's no current threat from Latin America. He said the southern-looking sector of ``backscatter'' was moved to the drug budget ``in recognition of the contribution that part of the system will make in the counter-narcotics effort.'' The central-southwest sector of ``backscatter'' comprises one-fifth of the Pentagon's $1.2 billion anti-drug budget for the coming fiscal year. This year, the military is expected to spend $887 million to combat illegal drugs, Wermuth said. A House Armed Services Committee staff member familiar with the decision not to fund the southern-beamed radar, said skepticism about a bomber threat from Latin America was the dominant reason the project was not approved. The staffer, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said it is a common ploy of the Pentagon to transfer controversial programs into ``the sacred cow of the day. Right now it's drugs.'' ``It raises the question of whether it's just a shuffle to get a system that may not be justified to meet a military threat,'' said Louis Rodrigues, who is directing a General Accounting Office investigation into the radar system's cost-effectiveness. The investigation was requested by the Senate Armed Services Committee. If ``backscatter'' works as planned, it would be able to spot even the smallest smuggler aircraft somewhere over Mexico, long before it reached the border. The high-tech system bounces powerful radio beams off the ionosphere, unlike conventional radars, whose beams are limited to line of sight. Return signals reach massive antennas and generate computer radar pictures of targets between 500 and 2,000 miles distant. Pentagon officials say the system's computers then would be able to feed tactical information on drug targets to law enforcement intelligence centers. The central-southwest sector would be located in North Dakota, South Dakota and Minnesota.

DOC.HEAD: Albanians In Kosovo Said To Forsake Blood Vengeance
DOC.TEXT: In a village in Kosovo province, tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians gathered to formally renounce the practice of seeking blood vengeance against rival families, Tanjug reported. The previously unannounced gathering Tuesday proceeded without major incidents or police intervention, the state news agency said. Kosovo repeatedly has seen clashes between the southern province's ethnic Albanian majority, which seeks greater autonomy, and massive security forces sent in to protect the Slav minority from alleged Albanian harassment. Tanjug said the ethnic Albanians waved flags without the Communist symbol of a five-pointed star, and shouted at any member of Kosovo's Serb minority passing by. The gathering in the village of Gornja Luka, close to neighboring Communist Albania, was the second such meeting in the past month in Kosovo. The tradition of ``blood vengeance'' dates from the Middle Ages and binds the head of an ethnic Albanian family to claim blood if a family member is attacked by any member of a rival family. Reconciliation is usually completed with the head of the family claiming blood vowing not to seek fresh blood. Women are exempt from blood vengeance, and traditionally have taken over the field work of any male relatives who feared their lives were in danger, and thus stayed inside family quarters. Tanjug estimated Tuesday's crowd at 100,000. Other sources who asked not to be identified estimated the number at tens of thousands. Tanjug said thousands of car, tractors, trucks, buses and cattle drawn carts clogged the roads around Gornja Luka from early morning until early afternoon. State-run television and radio made no mention of the ceremony, and it was not clear how many ethnic Albanian families buried their feuds at the gathering.

DOC.HEAD: Dozens of Private Vehicles Burned in Suspected Arson Near Airport
DOC.TEXT: Suspicious fires destroyed or damaged 32 cars at a parking lot near the New Tokyo International Airport before dawn today, and police blamed radical leftists opposed to the airport's expansion. Incendiary devices were found under the burned vehicles at a private lot about 3 miles north of the airport, said a local police officer. No injuries were reported. ``Judging from the circumstances, we suspect the fire was caused by radical extremists,'' said the officer, who requested anonymity. The airport, in Narita, is 40 miles northeast of Tokyo and many of the 68 cars at the lot were owned by travelers using the airport. The government plans to build a terminal and two new runways by the end of March 1991 to ease overcrowding and meet demands for more flights. Radicals have resisted plans to expropriate farmland to expand the airport, which opened in 1978. Eight farmers living on the expansion site refuse to leave.
