DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Quayle Learns International Diplomacy on the Fly
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle, who came to the job with his resume blank on foreign affairs, is learning international diplomacy on the fly. Literally. Quayle is outpacing President Bush in foreign travel. And that says a lot, since Bush _ who has been to 17 countries since taking office _ has traveled more than any previous U.S. president at a comparable time in his term. With Bush preoccupied with the upcoming Soviet and seven-nation economic summits and with events in Eastern Europe and on the hostage front, Quayle has been landing one foreign assignment after the other. Just back from Nicaragua and Mexico, Quayle will be in the air again next week with stops in Rome, London and Paris for festivities honoring the late President Eisenhower. Italy, Britain and France are countries Nos. 23-25 on Quayle's vice presidential passport. That's a lot of globe-trotting for a former Indiana senator who, aides say, doesn't like to travel. Quayle has just completed a major mission: a series of goodwill trips to mend fences with Latin American leaders uneasy over last December's U.S. invasion of Panama. In the process, he visited 14 Latin American countries and began establishing his credentials as a specialist on the region at a time of dramatic change. Quayle's performance as a goodwill ambassador in Latin America has won praise from senior White House officials and from many lawmakers, including Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., who accompanied Quayle on one of the trips. That's not to say that Quayle's visits have all been studies in smooth execution and good timing. For instance: _In Managua for the inauguration of President Violeta Chamorro, Quayle found himself short-handed when trucks bearing 1,000 tons of U.S. flour and vegetable oil didn't make it from Honduras in time for a kick-off food-distribution ceremony. He had to make do with the few bags of flour and cans of oil his delegation brought that morning from Washington. _In Paraguay, Quayle joyfully accepted on behalf of the National Zoo a gift of two prized jaguars, only to discover they were on the U.S. endangered species list. The cats stayed in Paraguay. _His goodwill tour ended on a frosty note last week with a tongue-lashing in Mexico from President Carlos Salinas, who registered anger at the abduction to the United States of a Mexican doctor accused in the 1985 slaying of a U.S. drug enforcement agent. _Then there was the matter of the doll. Quayle' purchase _ over wife Marilyn's protests _ of an X-rated wooden doll in Valparaiso, Chile, was widely reported, making Quayle the brunt of many Washington jokes. ``The problem with Quayle and the image business is every time he makes a miscue, you know it's going to be grist for late-night TV comedians,'' said Stephen Hess, a specialist on the presidency with the Brookings Institution. Still, Hess said Quayle's performance has helped counter his image as young and immature. ``As he travels and is perceived as someone with international experience, it has to rebound to his benefit,'' Hess said. ``He can now talk with some confidence about other parts of the world, about world leaders.'' Quayle seems less confident when he deals with some areas of the world. For instance, in a recent speech, he urged Israel to ``commit itself'' to the Arrow anti-missile missile being developed by U.S. and Israeli scientists. But when asked by members of the audience to elaborate, Quayle simply repeated the words of his speech. He denied that the level of U.S. funding was an obstacle to the project _ even though officials on both sides say funding is one of the main problems. And his office had to scramble on March 26 when a Soviet official quoted Quayle to support the Kremlin's crackdown on Lithuanian army deserters. Quayle had said ``a certain element of discipline'' was needed in any armed force. Quayle aides insisted the Soviets took the remarks out of context. Quayle still has a way to go to close in on Bush's frequent flier record as vice president _ 76 countries. But Bush took eight years to accumulate that, and Quayle's only been in office a little more than 15 months. In addition to his foreign travel, Quayle has been to 40 states as vice president. He will be on the road 19 days this month alone. Does Dan Quayle enjoy all the travel? ``He doesn't,'' said spokesman David Beckwith. ``He likes to be home with his family.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Moves Cleanup Crews into Alaska; Chemicals Given the OK
DOC.TEXT: Exxon workers hitting Alaska's beaches for a second summer of cleanup got approval from Gov. Steve Cowper to use potentially toxic fertilizer to remove oil. ``Everything's dead anyway,'' he said. About 100 Exxon workers in five teams Tuesday were sent to pick up oily debris on the shoreline in Prince William Sound. Three more squads of 20 to 50 each will go out later this week, said Exxon spokesman Jim Robertson. The cleanup from Exxon's March 1989 spill of nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude was suspended in September. The nation's biggest oil spill killed hundreds of otters and thousands of birds and other animals. More than 200 miles of shoreline still have some oil, according to an Exxon survey. State officials decided Tuesday to permit extensive use of fertilizers along the Prince William Sound shoreline. The urea- and phosphorous-based fertilizer speeds the growth of bacteria known to eat oil. ``We know direct application of these chemicals will have a toxic effect,'' Cowper said. ``But the flip side is these beaches have been heavily oiled and everything's dead anyway.'' Alaska's Department of Environmental Conservation had balked at the process, known as bioremediation. Environmentalists, fishing groups and recreational users of the Sound had expressed concern that incorrect application of the fertilizer could produce unwanted slime. Exxon has said it wants to use bioremediation on 160 of the 209 sites it had surveyed by last week. The state dropped its hesitation over the technique after reviewing Environmental Protection Agency data on toxicity and the effectiveness of Inipol, a French-made fertilizer developed especially for oily shores. Fertilizers will be used carefully to avoid exposure to mammals and will be monitored daily and reviewed in six weeks for effectiveness, officials said. Oily tar balls will be removed bhy hand on environmentally sensitive shores, said Coast Guard Rear Adm. David Ciancaglini, the government's on-scene coordinator for the cleanup. Priority will be given areas considered important for recreation and commercial fishing, officials said. Cowper said relations between the state and Exxon Corp. have improved significantly this year. ``Last summer we often had to rely on confrontational press in order to generate any kind of action,'' the governor said. ``I think a lot of the rough spots have been cleared away.''

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Resorts on opposite sides of the continent are battling to build the world's longest sand sculpture in a down and dirty fight. ``We shall fight them on the airwaves. We shall fight them in the newspapers. Most importantly, we shall fight them on the beaches,'' proclaimed a group of civic leaders in the tiny resort community of Long Beach, Wash. A similar coalition of civic leaders in Myrtle Beach, S.C., issued a declaration of war. Last June, about 2,000 people carved a world-record sand sculpture 15,063 feet long at Myrtle Beach. But the record fell in July when Long Beach sculpted a sea serpent of 16,040 feet _ just over three miles long. Myrtle Beach hopes to reclaim the record in a one-day attempt on June 1, while Long Beach, a community of about 1,300 year-round residents, begins work on a new sculpture May 31. Even before the first sand is turned, the contest has turned gritty. Both cities have toll-free hotlines to muster support for the battle and officials in Myrtle Beach, which has a year-round population of 60,000, hope 5,000 will take part. Long Beach expects about 1,500, but that doesn't concern City Manager Nabiel Shawa. ``One rugged Northwestern sand castle builder is worth a dozen East Coasters,'' he said.

All dressed up with no place to go, a covey of cab drivers looked on as city officials hailed a new cabbie dress code. ``What we have tried to do is make sure that cab drivers are clean and neat, and that they don't have objectionable odors,'' City Councilman Joel Wachs told reporters at a downtown taxi stand. Effective Tuesday, the ordinance forbids cab drivers from wearing tank tops, cut-off shorts and dirty clothes. White socks are out. Thongs are out. Chest hair, displayed beyond the second button, is out. Fines for dress code violations will be assessed by Traffic Department inspectors to taxicab companies under a complex formula that allows each company to amass a certain number of points before penalties would be imposed. Hollywood fashion arbiter Mr. Blackwell said in a telephone interview that he welcomed the change. ``I'm a little tired of getting into a cab, and they show up in an undershirt, and they've got armpits hanging out,'' Mr. Blackwell said. The cab drivers who watched the news event said they generally accepted the dress code, although a few objected. Nicolas Castellanos, wearing a red satin tie with an L.A. Taxi logo, shrugged as he said, ``If you don't like to dress well, you're never going to do it.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Sopranos Substituted in Met `Walkure'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: The Metropolitan Opera's last ``Die Walkure'' of the season was presented with new singers in the two leading soprano roles. The opera's two scheduled sopranos were felled, one of them literally. Hildegarde Behrens, scheduled to sing Brunnhilde, was hit on the head by a falling piece of scenery near the end of ``Gotterdammerung'' Saturday night. Jessye Norman, scheduled to sing Sieglinde, was ill. Both were replaced Tuesday night by their ``covers,'' the singer standing by in case she's needed to perform. Gudrun Volkert made her Metropolitan Opera debut as Brunnhilde. She has a beautiful middle range but her top notes aren't produced easily. Miss Volkert, who was born in Brno, Czechoslovakia, has sung Brunnhilde in seven European opera houses. She is tall and very thin. Hanna Lisowska of Warsaw, Poland, made her Met debut on April 21 as Gutrune in ``Gotterdammerung.'' She proved more of a disappointment, possibly partly because the audience expected not to hear Hildegarde Behrens but thought it was going to hear the lush vocal outpouring of Jessye Norman. Miss Lisowska has a smaller voice and was singing with two big-voiced men. Gary Lakes was in good voice as Siegmund, sounding warm and heroic. Matti Salminen as Hunding made his bass notes round, hollow and ominous. Miss Lisowska sang a competent Sieglinde but didn't make a listener's heart beat faster. James Morris was remarkable as Wotan, singing the long part with nuance and power, never tiring. Christa Ludwig sounded splendid as Fricka. As she left the stage, Maestro James Levine blew her a kiss. A program note said, ``This performance celebrates the 30th anniversary of Christa Ludwig's Metropolitan Opera debut.'' The Ring cycle operas aren't being presented at the Met next season. It's possible that Miss Ludwig may not sing Fricka at the Met again. Levine made instrumental tempos and Wotan's Act 2 monologue to Brunnhilde unusually slow. Sometimes during the evening, tempos were brisk. Miss Behrens and her doctor have not decided whether she'll be able to sing Brunnhilde in Thursday's ``Siegfried'' or in ``Gotterdammerung'' on Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Takes Up Case of Scientist Accused of Nazi Brutality
DOC.TEXT: An Ohio congressman is taking up the case of a German rocket scientist who worked for the United States after World War II but was later accused of having brutalized prisoners in Nazi slave labor camps. Rep. James Traficant is collecting files and information about Arthur Rudolph, who surrendered his American citizenship and left the United States in 1984 under an agreement with the U.S. government. Traficant ``believes pressure was put on Arthur Rudolph to renounce his citizenship,'' H. West Richards, a spokesman for the maverick Democrat, said Tuesday. He said the lawmaker will address supporters of Rudolph next week in Huntsville, Ala. Traficant's interest in the case appears to stem from his campaign against the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations, a unit that hunts suspected Nazis. He has sharply criticized the office for trying to discredit some witnesses in the case of John Demjanjuk, a retired Cleveland-area auto worker on death row in Israel after being convicted of committing Nazi atrocities. ``He believes they use questionable methods,'' said Richards. But Neal Sher, head of the OSI, said, ``It is absurd for anyone to claim that Rudolph was pressured or forced into renouncing his citizenship and leaving this country.'' ``The case against Rudolph was made in large measure by his own admissions. The fact is Rudolph simply did not want to be confronted with the damning evidence against him,'' Sher said. Rudolph, who joined the Nazi party in 1931, was production manager of a V-2 rocket factory attached to the Dora-Nordhausen concentration camp. He told OSI investigators that he knew camp prisoners he picked to work in the underground factory died of maltreatment, transcripts show. Rudolph was brought here along with more than 100 other German technicians and scientists after World War II to help the United States develop space and armament programs. He went to work for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, becoming the manager of the Saturn 5 rocket program that sent astronauts to the moon in 1969. Now 84, he lives in Hamburg, West Germany. In the agreement he signed, the OSI said Rudolph ``participated, under the direction of and on behalf of the Nazi government in Germany, in the persecution of unarmed civilians because of their race, religion, national origin or political opinion.'' Rudolph said in the agreement, a copy of which was obtained by The Associated Press, that he was familiar with the allegations and did not contest them. He also acknowledged that ``my U.S. citizenship was illegally procured and ... were I a non-U.S. citizen, I concede that I would be deportable ....'' The OSI is looking into the files of other former participants in the rocket program to see if any of them lied about their past and could be stripped of their citizenship, said one official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Rudolph's supporters in Alabama, some of them former German colleagues, maintain that he served the United States loyally, and when he was no longer needed, he was intimidated and harassed until he left the country. ``Mr. Traficant is the one man in Congress who has opened his eyes to the methods used by the OSI and called them into question,'' said the invitation issued by Friends of Arthur Rudolph to the May 12 event. ``He is coming to Huntsville because he ... wants to share his views with Rudolph's friends and all who are concerned with justice and fair play,'' the organizers wrote. Traficant prides himself of running against the pack. Several months ago he accused the CIA of failing to reveal that it knew in advance that Pan American Flight 103, that exploded over Scotland in December 1988, might have had a bomb aboard. A federal appeals court has ruled that Traficant owes the government more than $280,000 in back taxes, penalties and interest on a bribe he allegedly received as an Ohio sheriff.

DOC.HEAD: Dueling TV Movies? It Must Be Sweeps
DOC.TEXT: ``Caroline?'' on struggling CBS emerged the winner as the big three networks jumped into the spring sweeps season with competing made-for-TV movies. In Sunday night's TV movie free-for-all, Jim and Tammy Bakker's ``Fall From Grace'' on NBC didn't have a prayer against ``Caroline?'' the story of a woman supposedly dead who tries to convince her family she's very much alive. ``Caroline?'' _ starring Stephanie Zimbalist _ ranked fifth, pushing CBS into the top 10 for the first time in three weeks. ``Fall From Grace'' ranked eighth. ABC's ``Summer Dreams: The Story of the Beach Boys'' wiped out in the same time slot, coming in 48th according to figures Tuesday from the A.C. Nielsen Co. CBS remains in the ratings basement but got a boost at the right time _ the ratings during the sweeps period help set local stations' advertising rates. For the week ended April 29, NBC was still the No. 1 network, with an average of 12.9, followed by ABC with 11.4 and CBS with 11.1. Each ratings point represents 921,000 households. CBS also got a boost with Monday night's broadcast of the pilot for ``I Love Lucy'' _ a never-before-seen episode made in 1951. It had been lost nearly four decades. Preliminary estimates released Tuesday showed ``I Love Lucy: The Very First Show'' winning its time slot with a 21.7 average. ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' was the top-ranked show for last week, followed by NBC's beer-drinking customers on ``Cheers'' and the college kids of ``A Different World,'' also on NBC. Fox's ``The Simpsons'' finished 13th, despite some school principals having a cow this week over spiky-headed, 10-year-old anti-hero Bart Simpson, whose T-shirts read ``Under-achiever and proud of it, man.'' Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 22; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 21.2; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 19.5; ``Caroline?'' Sunday night movie, CBS, 19.4; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 19.2; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, tied with ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 18.4; ``Fall From Grace,'' Sunday night movie, NBC, tied with ``Wings,'' NBC, 17.6, and ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, 17.5. In the network news battle, ABC and Peter Jennings led with a 9.5. CBS and Dan Rather finished second with an 8.4, followed by Tom Brokaw and NBC with a 7.8.

DOC.HEAD: Adult Spelling Bee Aids Literacy Project
DOC.TEXT: What's the good word? According to the American Dental Association, it's ``jussive'' or maybe ``grisaille.'' A three-member team from the ADA spelled those words, as well as some others like ``cataclasm,'' ``oubliette'' and ``bireme,'' to beat 49 other corporate teams in an adults-only spelling bee. The ADA team spent nearly three hours late Tuesday beating out the rest of the top 20 teams in the second annual Olsten Corporate Great Grown-Up Spelling Bee _ an event that raised an estimated $20,000 for the Literacy Volunteers of Chicago. Officials said it was about 10 percent of the annual budget for the volunteers, who teach reading to adults. ``It's funny, but since we made the finals last week, we've been saying, `What's the word for today?' whenever we meet in the elevator or in the cafeteria, and someone always suggests some obscure word,'' said ADA team member David Curry, 48. ``A couple of days ago, I asked the question, and someone said, `grisaille.''' Someone else who said ``grisaille'' was Indianapolis newsman Lloyd A. Anderson, the pronouncer who conducted the spelling bee. He said it first to a three-man team from Van Kampen Merritt, an investment house, who misspelled it ``griseille.'' Curry and his teammates, Sheila Cassella and Lois Schuhrke, spelled it right, which led to ``jussive'' and the championship. A grisaille, by the way, is a monochromatic painting, usually done in shades of gray. ``Jussive'' means ``expressing or having the effect of a command,'' a cataclasm is a breaking down or disruption, an oubliette is a type of dungeon, and a bireme is an ancient ship with banks of oars on two levels. The winners were actually members of the ADA's ``Team No. 2.'' ADA ``Team No. 1'' was the first team eliminated Tuesday, misspelling ``cummerbund'' in the first round. The Van Kampen Merritt team, Jack Pace, Ray Hoffman and Rudy Wright, finished second. They were almost eliminated in an early round when they misspelled ``beneficent'' but were allowed back in on a protest when the judges ruled that Anderson had pronounced it in a misleading manner. ``I've conducted more than 450 spelling bees over the last 25 years, and I'll keep on doing it until I get it right,'' Anderson said. A team from the First National Bank of Chicago finished third. As bankers, they had no problem with ``forecloseable.'' They also managed words like ``perquisite,'' ``ostentatiously'' and ``schuss,'' but ``shih tzu,'' a small Chinese dog, spelled their ``Waterloo.'' The team from the Chicago Tribune, once the home of simplified spellings such as ``altho,'' ``thru'' and ``burocrat,'' lasted until the final rounds, correctly spelling words like ``misogyny,'' ``panegyrical'' and ``contumacious.'' What nailed the newsmen was a word that doesn't show up often in newspaper copy _ ``bombilation,'' defined as ``a buzzing, droning sound.'' The champions said they came by their spelling proficiency through their work. ``My title is manager of educational services for the department of professional relations, but basically I'm a speechwriter,'' said Curry. ``I work with words.'' Ms. Schuhrke, 45, is assistant secretary for the Council on Dental Education and said she prepared for the finals ``by going to dinner in Minneapolis and staying up late.'' ``I'm a proofreader, what more can I say?'' asked Ms. Cassella, 39. ``Actually, though, I'm a literacy volunteer myself, and teaching another adult who can't read makes you think a lot about the English language.''

DOC.HEAD: Newborn Sister Holds Only Hope For Sick 4-Year-Old
DOC.TEXT: Michael Sancilio's little sister represents the 4-year-old boy's best, and perhaps only, hope for life. Doctors on Tuesday drew blood from the girl's umbilical cord during birth in hopes of using it to save her leukemia-stricken brother. The blood was rushed to Indiana University to see if it matches Michael's. If so, scientists will try for the first time to use the unique cells of umbilical cord blood to grow healthy bone marrow in a leukemia patient. It will be several days before doctors know if there is a match, the chances of which were rated by doctors at 1-in-4. In March, Michael was diagnosed with chronic myelogenous leukemia, a rare, incurable form of the disease that strikes fewer than 1 percent of childhood leukemia victims, said Dr. Stephen Rodgers, the family's pediatrician. Children with the disease generally survive less than a year after diagnosis, he said. Leukemia patients normally are treated with bone marrow transplants. But because time is short and the chances of finding a compatible donor are 1-in-20,000, doctors are attempting the new treatment. On Tuesday, doctors at Virginia Beach General Hospital took the first step in delivering Christina Grace Sancilio by Caesarean section. They clamped off the umbilical cord and removed about a cup of umbilical cord blood. Rodgers said umbilical blood contains special cells called stem cells that develop bone marrow in babies in their first nine months. If Christina's blood matches Michael's, the cells will be grown at the university, which pioneered the procedure for the treatment of some forms of anemia. Once scientists have grown a sheet of the cells, they will inject them into Michael's heart after his diseased bone marrow has been killed by radiation. The new cells, in theory, will act as they do in a newborn, heading straight for the bone to produce bone marrow. With sons Michael and Tony in his arms, Anthony Sancilio, 35, tried to express his joy and hope at seeing his daughter. ``I'm speechless,'' he said. ``I'm thankful the baby is healthy and hopeful that we will have a match.'' Tests on 7-year-old Tony showed he was not a compatible donor for his brother. Dr. Leslie L. Wasserman, who delivered both Christina and Michael, said the collection of blood went smoothly, though the surgical team had to make sure none of the mother's blood was mixed with the umbilical cord blood. Wasserman said a Caesarean section was undertaken because of 33-year-old Denise Sancilio's difficulties in delivering Michael. He said mother and baby are doing fine. The procedure has been done twice before to treat forms of anemia. Because it has never been tried on a leukemia patient, doctors are unsure what to expect. ``This is most likely his only chance,'' Rodgers said. ``It's all going to take several months, and Michael will be close to the end of his disease when we try the transfusion.'' Even if the procedure is successful, Rodgers said, the child faces a lifetime of treatment to ensure the body does not reject the new bone marrow.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Urges Halt to US-Soviet Trade Agreement
DOC.TEXT: The Senate, upset over President Bush's decision not to punish the Soviet Union for its actions in Lithuania, is urging him to put the brakes on a new U.S.-Soviet trade agreement. By a 73-24 vote, the Senate passed a resolution Tuesday seeking a halt to any trade agreement that would grant the Soviet Union lower tariffs as long as the crackdown on Lithuania continues. The non-binding resolution urges Bush not to act on any trade agreements until the Soviets lift their economic blockade against Lithuania and enter into negotiations aimed at independence for the republic. In a political twist, the measure was introduced by a fellow Republican _ Sen. Alfonse D'Amato of New York _ and supported by most GOP senators. Only Republican Sens. John Warner of Virginia and Alan Simpson of Wyoming voted against the measure. The measure also split Democrats, with Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell of Maine supporting it and Sen. Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, opposing it. Bush decided last week not to take any action against Moscow for its blockade against the Baltic republic, where a new non-communist parliament declared Lithuania independent on March 11. The president's go-slow approach has drawn widespread criticism from members of Congress, particularly from those with large Lithuanian-American communities in their districts. Mitchell called for Bush to ``clearly demonstrate'' that the United States supports a free and independent Lithuania and opposes the Soviet economic sanctions. ``It would be unfortunate for all if the United States fails to make this position clear,'' he said. The Bush administration on April 26 announced ``substantial agreement'' with the Soviet Union on a trade agreement that would clear the way for the Soviets to obtain significantly lower tariffs on goods they sell in the United States. Officials expect the treaty to be ready for signing at the May 30-June 3 U.S.-Soviet summit in Washington, and it also must be ratified by Congress. ``Some of us feel that we are slipping and sliding into `most favored nation' status with the Soviet Union, while they are still taking aggressive, oppressive actions in the Baltic countries,'' said Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz. Secretary of State James Baker III said completion of the outline of a new agreement did not mean Bush would recommend to Congress a one-year waiver of high U.S. tariffs. But he said the U.S.-Soviet relationship ran deeper than the Lithuanian independence issue. ``We have a lot of interests at stake here that are very important interests to the United States of America,'' Baker said. Meantime, the White House announced that Bush will meet with Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene on Thursday. Ms. Prunskiene, an economist, is coming to the United States on a private visit, said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. She also will meet with State Department officials and members of Congress and will speak Friday at the National Press Club. Fitzwater called the meeting with Ms. Prunskiene ``a rare opportunity to get a firsthand analysis of the situation.'' He stressed, however, that Bush has not changed policy on Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: Remains of Apollo Capsule to be Entombed With Challenger Wreckage
DOC.TEXT: The Apollo capsule in which three astronauts died 23 years ago will be entombed with the debris of the space shuttle Challenger in an abandoned missile silo. The remnants of the capsule will be transferred from the Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., to the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida about May 20, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said Tuesday. Astronauts Virgil ``Gus'' Grissom, Roger B. Chaffee and Edward H. White II died when fire flared through the capsule during a countdown rehearsal for the first manned Apollo mission. The fire, in a cabin filled with 100 percent oxygen, was triggered by a spark when a broken or bruised wire beneath Grissom's couch contacted metal. The astronauts were trapped by a wall of flame and died within seconds. Grissom and Chaffee are buried side by side at Arlington National Cemetery, White at West Point, N.Y. The spacecraft has been kept in a container along with its heat shield, other hardware and investigative data at Langley, as directed by a board that investigated the fire. ``The container has been deteriorating and several small leaks have developed,'' NASA said. ``Routine repairs were made to the container, but due to its age it cannot be effectively maintained on a continuing basis.'' The remnants of the Challenger, which exploded after liftoff Jan. 28, 1986, were placed in the missile silo at the Cape Canaveral base after investigators were finished with them. NASA said the Apollo debris, including investigation data, take up about 3,300 feet of storage.

DOC.HEAD: Panama-Nicaragua Aid Bill Heads to Conference Committee
DOC.TEXT: A spending bill containing $720 million in ``emergency'' aid for Nicaragua and Panama is headed for House-Senate negotiations after senators added a sharp warning against Soviet punishment of Lithuania. The Senate late Tuesday approved its $3.4 billion version of the spending package on a voice vote, sending it to a conference with the House that could begin as early as Thursday. The House passed its $2.4 billion measure on April 3. Both bills include $420 million in aid President Bush sought for the new government in Panama and $300 million for Nicaragua's new democracy. But both versions took on dozens of additional provisions as they moved through the legislative process, raising numerous difficult issues. For example, the Senate bill includes language permitting the District of Columbia to use local money to pay for abortions for poor women, and Bush has vowed a veto if it remains in the bill. There also is likely to be a squabble over terms for $400 million in loan guarantees for Israel to build housing for Soviet emigres. The Senate version waives about $25 million in administrative fees, while the House version allows the full fees to be charged. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said he supported the guarantees but voiced concern over Israeli moves to place new settlers in the occupied territories and questioned whether concessions should be made. ``What is the justification?'' Dole asked, for waiving fees and other normal program requirements. ``We also have countless tens of thousands of homeless in this country,'' he said. ``We don't hear their voice much, but they might ask, `What about us?''' Another difference is in the Lithuania provision. On Tuesday, the Senate voted 73-24 for a non-binding provision urging Bush not to send Congress a U.S.-Soviet trade agreement for approval until Moscow rescinds economic sanctions against the independence-minded Baltic republic. In addition to foreign aid and $70 million for refugee programs Bush had sought, the bill became the vehicle for a long list of unrelated provisions. Lawmakers added hundreds of millions of dollars for disaster relief, fighting forest fires, food stamps, veterans' benefits and other domestic programs. Most of the spending would be offset by cuts in this year's Pentagon budget, representing the first major application of a ``peace dividend'' from reduced East-West tensions. Padding of a supplemental spending bill is common, but Bush complained about it on Tuesday, saying, ``None of it related to Nicaragua, none of it related to Panama; all of it related to other priorities they had.'' Panamanian President Guillermo Endara, in a speech at the National Press Club, was more understanding. ``This is the price we pay for democracy,'' he said. ``It's the best system ... and we want a democracy, (even) with all the delays.'' Endara said his country would use the $420 million to rebuild its battered economy and repair damage from the December U.S. invasion, which installed him in power. But he said Panama will not ask for more U.S. economic aid next year. By using part of the money to pay off past-due loans to international banks, Panama would again become eligible to meet future financial needs through new development loans, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Protest Bush Willingness to See Seidman Quit
DOC.TEXT: Member of Congress are protesting President Bush's willingness to see L. William Seidman, the straight-talking boss of the administration's savings and loan bailout, quit before his term expires. ``There are problems with the savings and loan bailout, but you don't solve that problem by shooting the messenger,'' said Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of a House task force overseeing the cleanup. ``We need more qualified individuals ... and fewer political `yes' men.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater indicated Tuesday that Bush would not resist a move by Seidman, 69, to leave before the October 1991 expiration of his term as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. The FDIC manages deposit insurance funds for banks and S&Ls, while the RTC conducts the administration's thrift bailout. ``Bill has indicated he's not going to stay the whole term, and we are interested in getting new leadership there that would carry on an aggressive program when the time comes,'' Fitzwater said. However, he denied a report in The Washington Post that Bush suggested in a meeting with the regulator two weeks ago that this would be a good time for him to leave. The newspaper quoted two unidentified administration sources. ``The president has not asked him to leave or suggested a specific departure,'' the spokesman said. Seidman, appointed by then-President Reagan in 1985, has made no secret of his desire to leave before the end of his term. However, despite periodic feuding with White House chief of staff John Sununu and Deputy Treasury Secretary John Robson, he had given no indication his departure was imminent. Reached by telephone from his hometown, Grand Rapids, Mich., where he was accepting a business award, Seidman declined to comment on the Post story or on his plans for the future. However, he noted that he has said he planned to leave after getting the bailout agency off to a good start. A month ago, he announced ambitious plans to sell or close 140 S&Ls by the end of June and, he said Tuesday, ``That would be a good start.'' Although he has riled administration officials with his independent ways, Seidman gets high marks on Capitol Hill for steering the FDIC through the unprecedented failure of more than 800 banks during his term and for his candor about the S&L industry's problems. ``Almost alone, he has been a tell-it-like-it-is, play-it-like-he-sees-it kind of guy,'' said Rep. Jim Leach, R-Iowa, a senior member of the House Banking Committee. ``But what is refreshing frankness to some on Capitol Hill has been grating on the nerves of some in Treasury and perhaps in the bowels of the White House.'' Twenty-four House Democrats, in a letter circulated by Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., called on Bush to urge Seidman to stay. They said his departure would paralyze the administration's bailout effort. ``It is intolerable that Chairman Seidman's early departure may be the result of his frustration with the internal bickering, bureaucratic interference and turf battles that have marked the first nine months of the thrift bailout effort,'' the Democrats wrote. Seidman's feud with Sununu dates to the first month of Bush's term, when he skewered an administration proposal to charge bank customers a fee for deposit insurance. He ridiculed the idea as the ``reverse toaster'' theory, in which the depositor would give the bank a toaster to open an account. Most recently, Seidman has irked Treasury officials by warning Congress that the administration likely will be forced to propose a second installment of the bailout after this year's congressional elections. Fitzwater said there has been no discussion of Seidman's possible successor. Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America, said that one of the leading candidates to replace Seidman is Comptroller of the Currency Robert Clarke. Clarke's office regulates federally chartered banks and he sits on the five-member FDIC board.

DOC.HEAD: Fugitive From Kent State-Related Charges Doesn't Want to Come Home
DOC.TEXT: Joe Schock is still on the lam, two decades after fleeing charges that he torched 29 National Guard trucks and Jeeps in reaction to the killing of four Vietnam War protesters at Kent State University. Yet, after an odyssey through the radical underground, Schock's life has evolved into an existence similar to that he fled. Today he is a paunchy suburban father of two daughters, teaching English to young accountants in Paris. And, much to the sorrow of his family, the 42-year-old fugitive vows never to return to the United States. ``I've gone down another road,'' he said in a recent telephone interview with the Idahonian newspaper in Moscow, Idaho. ``I don't feel good about the States. ... I don't want to re-adapt.'' He is a free man in France, shielded from U.S. authorities by a treaty that bars the extradition of political fugitives. He has become a French citizen. Schock served as a Marine in Vietnam, but he returned with growing doubts about his country's role. His skepticism intensified after he joined anti-war groups at Idaho and Washington State universities. On May 4, 1970, his parents and police say, the deaths at Kent State led him to go to the Lewiston armory with bolt-cutters and gasoline. ``He told me where the wire cutters and gloves were left, where he left them,'' said Ed Schock, his father. ``I can't say if he was alone, but I think he did it.'' Police said a witness saw Schock toss an object over the armory fence and run. Moments after a thunderous explosion, Schock flagged down a car, but he was arrested at a roadblock, his clothes reeking of gasoline, police said. Schock neither denies nor admits involvement with the sabotage. ``Some day I still may have to defend myself in a U.S. court,'' he said. He fled the country in July 1970 while awaiting trial on federal charges of destruction of property. His family did not hear from him for two years. Schock's sister, Lois Gibbens of Pasco, Wash., has not seen him since he left. His parents have visited him in France three times. ``It's a tragedy in our family,'' Gibbens said. Her brother agreed: ``My family most certainly has suffered from my problems.'' But Schock insisted he would not come home even if charges were not hanging over him. ``If they could give me a job in Lewiston at $200,000 a year, I wouldn't want to come home,'' he said. ``I don't want to be dominated by that economic system.'' Although a judge dismissed the indictment against Schock in 1979, prosecutors say it was merely a housekeeping chore to clear the books of old cases. Prosecutors and Schock's lawyer, Carl Maxey, agreed that charges could easily be reinstated. The charges carry up to 10 years in prison and a $10,000 fine. Schock said he would not be received warmly by most Americans if he came home. ``They'd still hold it against me,'' he said. ``They wouldn't justify that kind of action.''

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Guerrillas Attack Key Points In San Salvador
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT style on time, hotel SUB grafs 6-7 `The gunfire ... there said. Picks up 8th, `They said ...' ^By MARCOS ALEMAN
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas attacked strategic targets in the capital late Tuesday and automatic weapons fire and explosions could be heard in several neighborhoods. Much of the city was without power. There were no immediate reports of casualties. It appeared to be the most serious guerrilla attack since November, when the rebels launched a huge monthlong offensive in the capital. The rebels dynamited five high voltage utility towers along the road leading north to the city of Chalatenango, leaving at least half of San Salvador without electricity, the privately owned radio station YSKL reported. The station said a rebel group also attacked an electricity relay station north of the city on the slopes of San Salvador volcano. The gunfire began around 10 p.m. and continued sporadically until early Wednesday. Military helicopters could be heard buzzing several areas of the capital. Guerrilla groups shot it out with government soldiers near the former Sheraton Hotel in the western residential district of Escalon and the gunfight spilled over into the Tasumal neighborhood, residents there said. They said they heard automatic weapons fire and explosions that could have been from hand grenades or missiles. Guerrillas also trained gunfire on the police academy on the road to Santa Tecla, a small town 14 miles west of the capital, as well as a civil defense post in the southern neighborhood of Costa Rica, and the national elections board building in Escalon, according to witnesses. The fighting broke out hours before President Alfredo Cristiani's rightist government and the guerrillas' Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front were to hold indirect preliminary talks on seeking an end to the war. A representative of U.N. general secretary Javier Perez de Cuellar was due to arrive in San Salvador today to act as a go-between in setting up an agenda and arranging other details for the peace talks to begin. Two attempts to negotiate an end to the war ended in deadlock in 1984 and 1985, and a series of direct talks began shortly after Cristiani was sworn in as president in July but broke off as a result of the November offensive. More than 72,000 people have been killed, most of them civilians, since the civil war began in October 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Health-Care Discrepancies Between Blacks, Whites Unacceptable, Doctors Say
DOC.TEXT: The short shrift that blacks and other racial minorities get from the U.S. health-care system is intolerable and must end, an ethics panel for the American Medical Association said today. Studies dramatizing the disparities in medical treatment between the races go back decades, but blacks are still getting less frequent and less aggressive care, said the AMA Council on Ethical and Judicial Affairs. ``Whether the racial disparities in treatment decisions are caused by differences in incomes and education, socio-cultural factors, or failures by the medical profession, they are unjustified and must be eliminated,'' the council said. ``Not only do the disparities violate fundamental principles of fairness, justice and medical ethics, they may be part of the reason for the poorer quality of health of blacks in the United States.'' American blacks have twice the infant mortality rate of whites and a life expectancy six years shorter, the panel said in a report in the Journal of the American Medical Association. Black men under 45 years have a 45 percent higher rate of lung cancer and 10 times the likelihood of dying from high blood pressure than white men in the same age group, added the council. The panel said many of the disparities also exist for other racial minorities but are less well-documented. The panel recommended a triple-barrel approach to improve health care for blacks: greater access, greater awareness and concrete medical guidelines for what is acceptable care. Ensuring greater access should include requiring employers to provide health insurance to all their workers expanding Medicaid to all Americans below the poverty level, the panel said. The panel called for a state role in helping the poor obtain health insurance. Robert J. Blendon, chairman of the Department of Health Policy and Management at Harvard School of Public Health, said the recommendations, most of which the AMA already has made individually, represent ``really a step out for an association that has not taken a strong stand on this issue for many years.'' The panel said studies that document disparities in U.S. medical care have found the following: _While black men nationwide suffered a certain type of heart attack at three-fourths the rate of white men, the blacks were only half as likely to get special heart X-rays and only a third as likely to undergo bypass surgery. _Although blacks accounted for 33 percent of Medicare patients with end-stage kidney disease between 1977 and 1985, they accounted for only 21 percent of kidney-transplant recipients. _Among pneumonia patients in 17 hospitals from 1970 to 1973, blacks were less likely to receive medical services, particularly intensive care. _Black patients surveyed by telephone in 1986 were more likely than white patients ``to report that their physicians did not inquire sufficiently about their pain, did not tell them how long it would take for prescribed medicine to work, did not explain the seriousness of their illness or injury and did not discuss test and examination findings.''

DOC.HEAD: Study: Research Into Ills That Disable the Elderly Can Save Money
DOC.TEXT: Finding ways to prevent and treat diseases that disable the elderly can provide a cushion in the next century when aging baby boomers are expected to push health care costs into the sky, researchers say. While medical advances are keeping Americans alive longer, this may mean that more people will be at risk of becoming disabled in late life by such conditions as Alzheimer's disease and hip fractures. ``We can't afford not to invest more now in research on aging,'' said Dr. Edward L. Schneider, dean of the University of Southern California's Andrus Gerontology Center and coauthor of a study on the impact of aging baby boomers could have on the nation's heath-care system. The study, reported in this week's Journal of the American Medical Association, projected that Medicare expenditures, which were $71 billion in 1987, could soar as high as $212 billion in 2040, when the average age of a baby boomer is 85. Medicare costs for those 85 and older _ the fastest growing segment of the U.S. population _ could grow sixfold, the study said. Nursing home costs, now $31 billion for 1.3 million patients, could rise to as much as $139 billion with 5.9 million people living in these facilities, the study estimated. The number of Americans with conditions like Alzheimer's disease and hip fractures caused by osteoporosis, two of the biggest contributors to nursing home admissions, could quadruple unless ways are found to prevent or delay the onset of these conditions, the study said. Research is also needed for other diseases that afflict the elderly, including Parkinson's disease, osteoarthritis and vision and hearing ailments, researchers said. ``This is where the challenge of aging (research) lies,'' said Dr. Jack M. Guralnik, an epidemiologist at the government's National Institute on Aging and coauthor of the report. Cost containment will not be enough to offset the huge increases in health care that will be needed in the next century, the researchers said. The greatest savings will be found in preventing and delaying the onset of the debilitating diseases that rob the elderly of their independence and force them to rely on others for care, they said. A $1 billion annual investment in Alzheimer's research would likely yield advances that could at least delay the onset of the disease by a minimum of five years, which would save $500 billion in care costs in the two decades from 2000-2020, Schneider said. The federal government is spending about $148 million this year to research Alzheimer's disease, the most common form of dementia. ``In the last 100 years, we have extended life expectancy 29 years, but we've done precious little research into how to make those last 29 years quality years,'' Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, said at a briefing where the study was released on Tuesday. Harkin, chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee that deals with medical research, said he will introduce legislation to increase federal financing of aging research from the current $400 million to $1 billion annually. ``We're either going to invest now or pay later,'' he said. Joseph Califano Jr., once secretary of the old Department of Health, Education and Welfare and a national spokesman for Project Independence for Older Americans, said the study findings show that ``the most cost-effective research the United States can put money into now is in aging'' research.

DOC.HEAD: Government Plans to Restart Savannah River Reactor in December
DOC.TEXT: Nuclear weapons reactors shut down for nearly two years because of safety and environmental concerns would resume production early next year under a new Energy Department schedule. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins, announcing the planned restart of three reactors at the Savannah River plant in South Carolina, said his department also is reviewing a proposal to resume production this summer of plutonium warhead triggers at its Rocky Flats plant in Colorado. ``At this time, there does not seem to be any alternative for the nation other than keeping Rocky Flats on line to deal with warhead management,'' Watkins told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee Tuesday. He said the department plans to restart its K reactor at the Savannah River plant in December and, after a period of low-power testing, begin producing tritium for nuclear weapons in January. The P and L reactors at Savannah River would be restarted in March and September 1991, respectively, with production of weapons components from each to resume a month after their start-up, Watkins said. All three reactors at Savannah River have been shut down since mid-1988 and operations at the Rocky Flats plant were suspended last November, bringing the restocking of the nation's strategic weapons stockpile to a halt. Watkins said the government has spent $7.5 billion in the past three years on modernizing the Savannah River and Rocky Flats facilities to bring them up to current environmental and safety standards. Environmentalists and anti-nuclear activists _ particularly those living near the plants _ called for a continued moratorium and have vowed to fight reopening the plants in court. ``Several unresolved issues relating to restart of the Savannah River reactors remain on the table. It's much too soon for Secretary Watkins to announce a restart schedule,'' said Brian Costner, director of the Energy Research Foundation of Columbia, S.C., an environmental group. But Watkins expressed confidence his department can now defeat any legal challenges, saying it will release draft environmental impact statements this Friday on the resumed operation of the Savannah River reactors. ``A month ago, for the first time, I began to feel comfortable about Savannah River,'' he told the strategic forces and nuclear deterrence subcommittee. ``I hadn't felt that way before. Everything has turned around down there.'' Although the department and appointed outside experts have not yet completed their reviews and approved the schedule for resuming operations at Rocky Flats, Watkins said he anticipates making a formal announcement on it next month. He also said he was looking at opening the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant in New Mexico to its first shipment of military nuclear wastes in October or November. He said he envisions only a ``very modest amount of ... wastes'' moving to the New Mexico site initially, primarily for research testing its suitability as a permanent burial ground for such wastes. Despite lingering environmental concerns, senators at the hearing agreed that the United States cannot afford to continue forestalling a resumption of weapons production. ``I wish I could say we don't need any production of weapons material,'' said the subcommittee's chairman, Sen. J. James Exon, D-Neb. ``That is not the case. The Soviet Union is going to be relying on its nuclear deterrent as a strategy more than ever before.'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said the Soviets have 11 weapons production reactors in operation, including three for making plutonium, despite a ``marginally greater'' stockpile of plutonium than the United States. ``They have the capability to turn a switch on and make more. We don't,'' he said. Watkins declined to discuss in detail the state of the nation's tritium stockpile, other than to say it is deteriorating at a rate of 5.5 percent a year with the Savannah River reactors shut down. ``We're going through a very dramatic period now,'' he said before the hearing went behind closed doors for a classified briefing on the stockpile. ``In the near term, we can meet the majority of our national security requirements.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate GOP Unveils Campaign Finance Plan
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republicans are seeking to grab the initiative on campaign finance reform with a proposal to ban all political action committees but set no overall spending limits. Republican leaders on Tuesday unveiled a package supported by 34 of the Senate's 45 GOP members, as Democrats continued haggling behind closed doors on their proposal. ``Republicans are tired of being accused of obstructing reform,'' said Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., the primary author of the GOP package. ``The real problem in campaign finance is the source of political money, not how much spending is necessary.'' He accused Democrats of trying to railroad through Congress a bill with spending limits ``because it serves the partisan interests of the Democratic Party (by) ... curtailing Republican fundraising advantages.'' Leading Democrats responded with a willingness to consider the abolition of PACs _ whose donations in recent years have tended to benefit incumbent Democrats over GOP challengers _ but only in exchange for establishing ceilings on spending. ``The most important factor in any reform proposal must be limits on spending,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. He called the Republican package ``disappointing'' because it rejects such limits. ``There's plenty of room for negotiations,'' said Oklahoma Sen. David Boren, chief author of the Democratic bill, which Mitchell plans to bring to the Senate floor, possibly later this week. ``We're perfectly willing to eliminate PACs, too,'' Boren said, ``as long as it is within the framework of total, comprehensive reform, and that means overall spending limits. Without that, you'll just have this continuing chase for money ... in other forms.'' However, several Democrats, including a large number up for re-election in 1992, have vigorously defended PACs, as have some Republicans. Mitchell and Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas said they believe a bipartisan consensus can be found. ``We can either get serious or continue to make speeches and protect the status quo on Capitol Hill,'' Dole said. ``We're serious about this. We're willing to work out any differences with the other party.'' But in the last week, both party caucuses in the Senate have moved away from the concept of flexible spending ceilings proposed as a compromise in March by a panel of experts appointed by Mitchell and Dole. It would have placed fixed limits on how much a candidate can solicit from individuals and PACs outside his or her state but imposed no ceiling on small contributions from in-state residents. Republicans, in their package, were willing to cut the current $1,000 limit an individual can give to a campaign to $500 for out-of-state donors but rejected any limit on the totals that can be raised from either source. Democrats are still insisting on an overall ceiling that also would cap the amount of allowable in-state contributions. But they disagree among themselves on how much to curb PAC activities. ``There must be 15 versions,'' said Alabama Sen. Howell Heflin, one of the two Senate Democrats who defected from the party's position and helped Republicans sustain a filibuster against a campaign reform bill two years ago. Republicans acknowledged the courts likely will reject their call for a ban on PACs as an unconstitutional abridgement of freedom of speech and association. As a fallback position, their package includes a provision abolishing corporate and union PACs but allowing so-called non-affiliated ``issue'' PACs, such as those maintained by groups on both sides of abortion, gun control and environmental issues. However, the ceiling on contributions from those non-affiliated PACs would be cut from a total of $10,000 for both primary and general elections to $2,000. The GOP package also would ban so-called ``soft money'' _ unreported expenditures by corporations, unions, trade associations and public interest groups. The GOP bill, however, would continue to allow contributions by individuals to state party organizations to go unreported.

DOC.HEAD: HUD Embezzler Sentenced to Six Years, Fined $2 Million
DOC.TEXT: A real estate broker who embezzled $2 million in federal housing money to live like a playboy drew six years in prison from a judge who observed, ``No wonder we have the national debt we do.'' Cy Walker, 50, was also fined more than $2 million Tuesday and ordered to make $2 million in restitution. Walker stole from the Department of Housing and Urban Development in 1986-87 and bought $180,000 in sports cars, an $18,000 speedboat, furs and jewelry. U.S. Attorney Jim Wilson said Walker was not connected to high-level HUD officials. But, he said, ``The fact that Walker could have pulled this off is indicative of the weaknesses'' in HUD under the Reagan administration. The agency is under investigation for alleged fraud, embezzlement, influence-peddling and political favoritism under then-Secretary Samuel Pierce. Walker had pleaded guilty to embezzlement and tax charges. As part of the plea bargain, he served as an informant in a drug sting that led to the conviction of a racehorse trainer. ``The tragedy of this case is not only that you committed the crime, but that you were able to get away with it for so long,'' U.S. District Judge Joel Dubina said. ``I hope that since this happened, HUD has established a system of quality control. ... The court is shocked to think how much money was embezzled nationwide. No wonder we have the national debt we do.'' Walker had a HUD contract to handle closings of agency property in the Montgomery region. A HUD audit found that he diverted closing money to a personal bank account, then depleted it when the scheme was discovered.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo-Seoul Agreement Fails To Drop Fingerprinting Of Ethnic Koreans
DOC.TEXT: Ethnic Koreans are disappointed with a new agreement on their legal status because it ends fingerprinting for only the youngest descendants of Koreans brought over during World War II for forced labor. The agreement reached in Seoul on Monday between the foreign ministers of South Korean and Japan clears the way for President Roh Tae-woo of South Korea to visit Japan in late May. It allows third- and succeeding-generation Koreans to live in Japan permanently and exempts them from fingerprinting, a requirement now for all foreign residents of Japan. There are fewer than a dozen third-generation Koreans in Japan, all of them infants. Japan ruled Korea as a colony between 1910 and 1945, when the war ended with Japan's defeat and the Korean peninsula was divided into the capitalist south and the communist north. ``Among the 700,000 Koreans living in Japan, boys and girls under the age of 15 number about 120,000. The agreement means that they still have to have their fingers printed when they reach the age of 16, like criminal suspects,'' said Hwang Young-man, secretary general of the pro-Seoul Korean Residents Union. Japan retained the right to keep such records on first- and second-generation Koreans, who were granted permanent resident status under the 1965 Japan-South Korea normalization treaty. Similar status has been granted to the roughly 200,000 members of the pro-North Korea organization, the General Association of Korean Residents in Japan. Japan and North Korea have no diplomatic relations. When bilateral talks on the issue were reported to have hit snags earlier this year over the fingerprinting issue, Roh came under pressure from opposition and human rights groups to cancel his scheduled May trip. Roh will be the second South Korean president to visit Japan. His predecessor, Chun Doo-hwan, visited Tokyo in September 1984, when the late Emperor Hirohito told him at a state dinner, ``It is indeed regrettable that there was an unfortunate past between us for a period in this century and I believe that it should not be repeated again.'' Pak Jae Ro, a vice chairman of the pro-North Korean group, said he believed the agreement would bring ``little change'' to the legal status of Korean residents. He noted that the Seoul agreement calls for a new registry to replace the present alien registration card for the third- and succeeding-generation Korean residents. ``It means that Japan will invent a new method of registration and will continue surveillance of Koreans,'' he said. Japan's Alien Registration Law requires all foreign residents over the age of 16 to carry a registration card that contains a copy of their fingerprint. Many Korean residents in Japan complain that they have the same tax and other obligations as Japanese but do not have the same rights to education, job opportunities, social security and welfare programs.

DOC.HEAD: American Kidnapped in Ecuador
DOC.TEXT: An American who works for a gold mining company is believed to be held in Colombia after he was kidnapped by guerrillas in a remote area in northern Ecuador, U.S. officials say. A companions was killed, officials said Tuesday. Scott Heimdal, 28, formerly of Peoria, Ill., was abducted Saturday while traveling by boat with three Ecuadorans and a Colombian near the Ecuador-Colombia border. Heimdal was seeking medical treatment at a support camp for bronchitis and an infected foot. Guerrillas armed with automatic weapons ordered the boat to stop, then opened fire when the craft's pilot tried to flee, said Gregory Lagana, a spokesman for the U.S. Embassy in Quito. One Ecuadoran was killed, one was wounded, and Heimdal and Ecuadoran geology student Edwin Teneda, 29, were kidnapped. The kidnappers later released Teneda. Lagana said the guerrillas claim to be part of the Popular Liberty Army, a Colombian group. Air and land searches for Heimdal by the Ecuadoran military were unsuccessful. The kidnappers have made no demands for the release of Heimdal, an Army veteran and electronics specialist for the International Mining Co. A government official in Quito said Heimdal had sent letters to his wife and employer with Teneda. He declined to release the letters. Several foreigners have been kidnapped by Colombians guerrilla groups to ransom to raise funds for their insurgency.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Loggers Start Cutting
DOC.TEXT: Wisconsin's Chippewas, already under attack from sportsmen for taking advantage of 19th century treaties letting them spear fish off the reservation, have begun exercising their right to cut timber as well. Four Indians began logging in a state forest Tuesday, but it was more ceremonial than commercial. They ``cut a couple of trees for the TV cameras,'' said Ralph Hewett, a state Department of Natural Resources spokesman. ``They really couldn't get started because they were waiting for some shearing equipment,'' Hewett said. The Mole Lake Chippewa band was authorized to begin cutting wood for free in the Northern Highland-American Legion State Forest north of Minocqua. The forest is among those used by the state's $8 billion-a-year paper industry. Federal courts since 1983 have said that the Chippewas, according to 19th century treaties under which the tribe ceeded northern Wisconsin to the U.S. goverment, may hunt, fish, trap and cut timber on public property. Since 1983, they have exercised only the right to spear fish, encountering sometimes violent protests by fishermen who fear game fish will be depleted. If non-Chippewas were to cut the timber made available Tuesday, they would have to pay about $160,000 for it. The wood is free to the Chippewas. So far, the Mole Lake band is the only one of Wisconsin's six Chippewa groups seeking to cut timber. Hewett said the logging is under interim rules adopted by the department. A federal judge is expected to issue a complete ruling later this year. ``It's not like they can come in here and cut anything they want,'' Hewett said. ``That's why we're happy with the plan.'' Chippewa leaders said that most of the timber will be sold to pulp paper companies and that the band will eventually build its own mills. ``This is something to get our feet wet and see how the process goes,'' Jim Landru, Mole Lake treasurer. He said the enterprise would help generate jobs on reservations where unemployment commonly exceeds 50 percent. Non-Indian loggers are concerned about the effect on the state's forest products industry, which employs about 77,000 people, Hewett said. Thomas Schmidt, president of the Wisconsin Paper Council, said the 33 pulp and paper companies in the trade group were watching the situation but have taken no position on it.

DOC.HEAD: Showers in North Carolina, Big Hail in Georgia
DOC.TEXT: Rain doused the North Carolina coast this morning after hail and high winds struck from Alabama through the Carolinas. A tornado touched down near Huntsville, Ala., late Tuesday and thunderstorm winds gusted to 60 mph at the Huntsville airport. Damaging gusts also swept southwest of Chattanooga, Tenn., over northern Georgia, at Raleigh, N.C., and near Westminster, S.C. Hail bigger than baseballs fell east of Rome, Ga., while golf ball-sized hail hit south of Gadsden, Ala. Smaller hail showered Trimble, Ala., and an area north of Fingerville, S.C. Heavy snow was forecast over the southwest mountains of Colorado and in the central mountain chain and northeast highlands of New Mexico. On Tuesday evening, snow fell over north-central Minnesota and eastern Upper Michigan, and over the mountains of central Colorado. Rain and thunderstorms extended from southern Virginia across western North Carolina, Tennessee and northern parts of Georgia, Mississippi, and Alabama through Arkansas, Oklahoma and parts of Texas. Rain also fell Tuesday from southwestern Colorado to northwestern New Mexico and central Arizona. Rain extended along the northern coast of Washington. The high of 96 at Jacksonville, Fla., broke the city's record for the date. Other record highs Tuesday included Atlanta, 90, Baton Rouge, La., 91, Charleston, S.C., 91, and Oakland, Calif., 85. The high temperature for the nation Tuesday was 98 at Fort Myers, Fla. DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd item to CORRECT name to Frances sted France in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Jose ``Tony'' Deleu, a butler who claimed he was fired by a Manhattan socialite because he had AIDS, died Friday at age 47. Deleu had filed a $1.5 million discrimination lawsuit against Frances Scaife, wife of an heir to the Mellon family fortune and a committeewoman on the Pittsburgh AIDS Task Force. The claim was recently dropped because of a loophole in the state anti-discrimination law that exempts domestic workers. Deleu worked as butler in Mrs. Scaife's apartment for seven years. Hours before his death, Deleu said he forgave his employer, according to his brother, Carlos.

DOC.HEAD: Vessel To Beam Pro-Democracy Radio To China Arrives In Singapore
DOC.TEXT: The Goddess of Democracy, the converted trawler that intends to broadcast pro-democracy messages into Communist China, arrived today for provisions. The 1,200-ton ship with 20 people aboard was to leave later today for Taiwan and was to be positioned in international waters off the Taiwanese coast, said Christophe Nick, a French journalist and an organizer. China on Sunday accused Taiwan of trying to foment unrest on the mainland by promising to help the ship. The Beijing government has refused to rule out the use of force to stop the planned broadcasts. The Goddess of Democracy is named after a statue erected by pro-democracy students in Tiananmen Square last spring before it was destroyed in the June military crackdown that left hundreds dead. The ship, which left France on March 17, has radio and television studio facilities. It plans to broadcast music, news and pro-democracy reports to China. Nick said the ship has 10 crewmembers and 10 journalists. It is sponsored by a coalition of groups headed by the French news magazine Actuel and backed by the Federation For A Democratic China, a Paris- based dissident organization. Taiwan and China have been enemies since the Nationalists lost a civil war to the Communists in 1949 and fled the mainland.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We know direct application of these chemicals will have a toxic effect. But the flip side is these beaches have been heavily oiled and everything's dead anyway.'' _ Alaska Gov. Steve Cowper, on the state's decision to allow Exxon to use potentially toxic fertilizer to remove oil from stained beaches.

``The tragedy of this case is not only that you committed the crime, but that you were able to get away with it for so long. ... No wonder we have the national debt we do.'' U.S. District Judge Joel Dubina in Montgomery, Ala., after sentencing real estate broker Cy Walker to six years in prison and $2 million in fines for embezzling $2 million in federal housing money.
