DOC.HEAD: Berlin Clashes Leave 200 Police Injured, 135 Protesters Arrested
DOC.TEXT: About 200 police officers were hurt in clashes with youths, many of them leftists and some wearing masks, who hurled rocks and bottles at them after a May Day march, city officials said today. Four of the injured officers were taken to a nearby hospital for treatment, said West Berlin police spokesman Peter Glaser. Police arrested 135 of the youths and used tear gas and truncheons to contain the protests to the working class district of Kreuzberg. The violence began late Tuesday after a May Day march in the district by an estimated 10,000 to 20,000 leftist demonstrators from East and West Berlin. It lasted into early this morning. In the East German city of Leipzig, a group of leftist youths brawled on Tuesday with a band of neo-Nazi youths in the market square, the East german government news agency ADN reported. Three people were slightly hurt and 21 were arrested in that disturbance, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher, Gold Also Rises
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against all major currencies except the Japanese yen and British pound in moderate European trading this morning. Gold prices were steady at a slightly higher level, dealers said. ``The dollar is slightly higher, but it's looking very, very calm,'' said a Milan trader. ``The general level of uncertainty, especially for the (West German) mark, is keeping people cautious.'' Traders said they expected the dollar to trade within a narrow range this week, ahead of the weekend meeting of the group of seven major industrial nations in Washington. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.35 yen to a closing 158.55 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 158.05 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _ 1.6855 West German marks, up from 1.6785 _ 1.4600 Swiss francs, up from 1.4545 _ 5.6530 French francs, up from 5.6365 _ 1.8935 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8892 _ 1,235.50 Italian lire, up from 1,231.25 _ 1.1665 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1435 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6410, compared with $1.6385 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $370.25 an ounce, up from $368.50 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $370.50. In Zurich, the bid price was $370.40, up from $367.00 late Monday. Zurich markets were closed Tuesday for the May Day holiday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.15 to close at a bid $371.98. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.01 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $4.97.

DOC.HEAD: Riot in Park: 27 Arrested, 15 Police Hurt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people clashed with police in riot gear in gritty Tompkins Square Park overnight after the city pulled the plug on a concert. Twenty-seven people were arrested and 17 reported injured. Concertgoers and homeless people living in the park taunted police, hurled bottles, lit fires and overturned trash cans in five hours of skirmishes that spilled over into the streets of the East Village. The melee came at the end of a ``Squatter Mayday'' concert, part of a festival of food, music and contests begun Saturday in the park, where about 200 homeless people live. Parks Department officials cut electricity to the bandshell at 9 p.m. in keeping with the city permit, and police went on stage to remove band members. ``People started screaming at the cops. ... The cops grabbed whoever was in their way and threw them down,'' said Rob Nunzio, a band member. Jason Goodrow, a guitarist in the band performing at the time, said, ``One cop got hit by a bottle while on stage and got very mad and started trashing our equipment.'' ``There were about 300 people there. Some threw bottles. It was basically a riot,'' said Capt. Charles Hanley. Police reinforcements were called in and at one point 250 officers were on the scene, police said. Fights broke out as protesters tried to goad police or as officers cleared the way for firetrucks to douse burning trash cans. By early today, calm had returned and about 125 police in riot helmets ringed the park. The injured included 15 officers, who were slightly hurt, authorities said. A photographer for the photo agency Gamma Liaison, Michael Hirsch, said he was jabbed in the back with a nightstick as he photographed an arrest. He was taken away in an ambulance. Police arrested 27 people, mostly for disorderly conduct, police spokesman Sgt. Ed Burns said. In August 1988, the park was the scene of a four-hour melee that left 52 people injured and led to the filing of more than 110 claims of police brutality. Thousands of police were retrained in riot control techniques. Last summer, there were numerous arrests and standoffs after police tore down squatters' tents and evicted more than 130 people.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Danbury, Conn.-dated 2nd item in rdp to CORRECT spelling of Katharine, Ullmann.
DOC.TEXT: Sylvia Sidney, recuperating at home from double pneumonia, still plans to attend a New York ceremony that will honor her with a lifetime achievement award. The 79-year-old actress, who was released from Danbury Hospital on Monday, is scheduled to appear at Radio City Music Hall on Saturday for NBC's ``Night of 100 Stars,'' where she will be honored along with Katharine Hepburn, Helen Hayes, Liv Ullmann, Sidney Lumet and Joseph L. Mankiewicz. ``It's to benefit the Actors' Fund, and she's determined to go,'' said Sidney's spokesman, John Springer. ``She told me, `I may not be able to walk, but other people like Joseph Cotton and Orson Welles went in wheelchairs. I can, too.''' Her most recent film role was as the cigarette-smoking case worker in ``Beetlejuice.''

DOC.HEAD: Zaire Denies Report That Police Killed Two Protesters
DOC.TEXT: The government denied a news report that riot police killed two people at an unauthorized opposition demonstration that occurred one week after the president lifted a 20-year ban on opposition parties. The official Zairean news agency AZAP on Tuesday disputed the report, which was carried by a French news agency and confirmed by opposition sources. At the same time, the government reportedly demanded that the news agency's reporter prove that his report was true. Also Tuesday, the government canceled its annual May Day labor parade an hour before it was scheduled to start. The official May Day march, joined for the first time by unions independent of the official National Union of Zairean Workers, was canceled for ``technical reasons,'' authorities said. No other explanation was given, but it appeared that the authorities feared the parade might turn into an anti-government rally. The march was expected to include several thousand people. One week ago, President Mobutu Sese Seko lifted the ban on opposition parties and announced that multiparty elections would be held next year in this sprawling central African nation of 32 million. Mobutu took power in Zaire since 1965 and outlawed opposition parties five years later. AZAP denied that police killed two supporters of the nation's largest opposition group during a demonstration on Monday. Sources within the group, the Union for Democracy and Social Progress, later confirmed the news report, saying the killings occurred when police broke up a rally by 300 people outside the home of one of its leaders. The rally had not been officially approved by police. Authorities decided Sunday that political rallies in the capital be subjected to police permission. Zaire's Foreign Ministry summoned France's ambassador and the French news agency's correspondent in Kinshasa, Jean Claude Fiol, saying the reporter must prove his report about the killings, said Agence France-Presse. AFP said that Fiol also was summoned by the Zairean communications minister about the report, which quoted witnesses.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Die After Being Overcome by Unknown Fumes
DOC.TEXT: A volunteer firefighter trying to pump out a contaminated well was asphyxiated by fumes and two others died trying to rescue him, state police said. James F. Chestnut Jr., 20, and Richard L. Hershey, 40, both of Hustontown, were overcome Tuesday while trying unsuccessfully to save Thomas L. Lane, 39, of McConnellsburg, state police said. A fourth firefighter, Larry Trexler, 20, also of Hustontown, was hospitalized at Fulton County Medical Center in McConnellsburg, but officials refused to release information on his condition today. All four were members of the Hustontown Volunteer Fire Company. Lane was on a ladder in the 38-foot-deep Husontown well, which was believed to be contaminated by a dead animal, when he was overcome by fumes, Trooper Denton J. McLaughlin said. Trexler entered the well to help, but also was overcome, McLaughlin said, so Hershey went down to help extract Trexler, but was overcome. Chestnut died while trying to help the others, the trooper said. The fumes were believed to be methane gas, McLaughlin said, adding, ``We won't know for sure until the coroner gets blood test results.'' Trexler was pulled out by another firefighter. Authorities were unable to recover Lane's body until about 10 p.m. because he had fallen into the water, McLaughlin said.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopters Attack Hot Spots in Big Forest Fire
DOC.TEXT: More than six dozen firefighters in central Pennsylvania fought flareups today in mopping up the state's largest forest fire since 1932. ``It's mostly a nuisance now,'' said Susan Woomer of the state forestry bureau. The wind-fanned fire burned 11,800 acres from Saturday morning to Sunday afternoon, destroying six private camps on the state-owned lands. The forestry bureau was helped by nearly 500 firefighters during the weekend. ``It was the wrong spark at the wrong place at the wrong time,'' said John Berst, the state's chief of operations for forest fire protection. Helicopter pilots bombed state lands with water Tuesday as hot spots deep in the forest brush continued to smoke, Woomer said. The cause of the fire was under investigation. A northern Pennsylvania fire in 1938 burned 7,000 acres and six fires in early 1932 burned 87,000 acres, Berst said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf of BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.-dated first item to CORRECT date to Tuesday sted Monday, delete reference to `cop.'
DOC.TEXT: Zsa Zsa Gabor has been slapped with an extra 60 hours of community service for serving most of an earlier sentence at her mansion. Municipal Judge Charles Rubin on Tuesday said fund-raising from the Bel-Air mansion was not what he had in mind last year when he sentenced Miss Gabor, 72, to 120 hours of community service for smacking a Beverly Hills motorcycle policeman. The judge tacked on the extra time after Vern Davis, executive director of a shelter in Venice, said Miss Gabor had spent about 50 hours there and the rest of the time at home, organizing a June 8 fund-raiser for the shelter. ``(It) means nothing to Miss Gabor, buying community service hours. She is a wealthy person,'' the judge said after meeting with Miss Gabor. He said the actress was more interested in self-promotion than paying her debt to society. Miss Gabor later told reporters: ``I served food. Why do I have to promote myself? I'm so damned famous it's sickening.''

DOC.HEAD: Volcanic Destruction Continues in Kalapana
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `About a ..., to include background on church.
DOC.TEXT: Ruth Duff was in Palm Springs, Calif., last week when she turned on the television and saw her home here consumed by molten rock. On Tuesday, she came back to look at the lava where her home used to be. ``I was in my house watching the news when I saw my house burning,'' she said. ``Then I thought maybe it was just as well I wasn't here.'' Duff lived in the Kalapana Gardens subdivision for 23 years, after she and her husband bought most of the land from a developer in 1968. She and her husband, John, purchased about 600 lots, put in roads and began to sell and lease them. On Tuesday, she pointed across the street to six lots, the first of which was not more than 50 yards away from the lava. ``These lots here, we bought them from the Catholic Church a few years ago,'' she said. ``They must have known something we didn't.'' Kilauea, the world's most active volcano, has destroyed 126 homes since its latest eruption began in 1983. Civil Defense spokesman Lanny Nakano said the 2,000-foot-wide lava flow was spreading out and moving east across Kalapana Gardens subdivision. Five homes burned down Tuesday as the lava flow moved about 300 yards from the Kalapana Store and Drive-In, the town's meeting place. Molten rock had moved to within 15 feet of three more homes late Tuesday, Nakano said. A second lava flow poured in from the north. Nakano said it was moving downhill 1,000 feet from homes and could reach homes by the weekend. About a hundred yards from the Kalapana Store, workers dug up ground around the Star of the Sea Church, preparing to pick up and move the ``painted church'' _ so dubbed by locals because of its brightly decorated interior. Behind the church, some newly homeless families frolicked in the ocean, seemingly oblivious to the molten rock heading their way. A woman at the store watched the workers and shook her head. ``It's sad,'' she said. ``They don't have any faith. A lot of people don't want to move it.'' Gov. John Waihee arrived by helicopter Tuesday to meet with county and federal disaster officials, visit workers at the church and say hello to the owner of the store, whom he sends Christmas cards every year. Waihee said the federal government needed to change the way it was looking at the calamity. The governor has declared the Kalapana a disaster area in hopes the federal government will do the same and open the door to aid. ``They see this and say, `How can you call this a disaster?''' he said. ``But we've lost more than 100 homes now. ``It's happening slowly, but continuously.''

DOC.HEAD: Reed Reunited with Family with Tears and Laughter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to change first name to nickname `Fifi,' per her preference. INSERTS 1 graf after 4th, ``We were ..., to UPDATE with `Today' interview.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Hostages-Reed
DOC.TEXT: Frank Reed greeted his family with tears and laughter and tried to lift his 9-year-old son into the air _ but was too weak after more than than 3{ years as a hostage in Lebanon, his wife says. Fifi Reed said she, her husband and their son, Tarek, fell into each other's arms at their reunion Tuesday in West Germany. ``Nobody spoke a word, we just hugged each other. Then he started breaking up. He cried. He broke down and cried,'' she told Boston TV station WHDH in an interview from Wiesbaden. The Reeds live in Malden. ``We were there to cheer Frank. But Frank was cheering Tarek, trying to make him laugh, and we ended up laughing, the three of us.'' In an interview with NBC's ``Today'' show this morning, she was asked if her husband felt anger for his captors. ``It's hard to say,'' she said. ``I mean, he's angry at everybody right now.'' Asked if that included U.S. officials, she replied: ``He didn't specify that. He just said, everybody.'' Reed, who was freed on Monday, could not sit still and his concentration was erratic, his wife said. ``That's because he was chained and sitting constantly so he wanted to move around. I had to keep following him with my eyes,'' she said. Mrs. Reed said her husband had no idea he was going to be released ``because he was told so many times that he was going to be released that he stopped ... taking that into consideration.'' His daughter, Marilyn Langston, said her father told her he had been blindfolded for much of his 42 months in captivity and had lost 60 pounds. ``And he said he hadn't been able to talk for 3{ years,'' said Langston, who spoke to Reed by telephone from this Boston suburb. ``He talked most of the time. He just wanted to talk. I could barely get a word in edgewise.'' On Monday night, Reed made a brief call to his 91-year-old mother, Leota Sprague. ``He said `Hi, Mom.' I said, `Hi, Frankie,''' Mrs. Sprague said. ``I knew his voice right away. I was thrilled.'' A Malden native, Reed converted to Islam before marrying his wife. He made two trips to Lebanon before leaving his post as school principal in Whitefield, N.H., to become director of elementary education at Beirut's International College in 1977. At the time of his abduction Sept. 9, 1986, Reed was running the private Lebanese International School, which he founded after the International College was bombed out.

DOC.HEAD: Student Kills Self by Driving Motorcycle into Side of School
With PM-Suicide Town, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A senior at Hayfield High School committed suicide by driving his motorcycle into the side of the school, authorities said. As morning classes were under way Tuesday, Jerry Minnick took the motorcycle on the school running track, cast off his helmet and raced full-speed into the outside wall of the boys' locker room. He died instantly. Suicides are not new to the 130,000-student Fairfax County school system, but this is the first time that a student has killed himself on the grounds of a school, police and school officials said. Natasha Reid, 17, a Hayfield senior, said Minnick, who transferred to the school a year ago from a high school in Franconia, ``didn't come to school much lately.'' Ms. Reid said Minnick, 18, had been in a car accident in front of the school about a month ago and a motorcycle accident earlier in the year. County police spokesman Michael Proffitt said Minnick was ``distraught over personal problems.'' Police refused to elaborate or say whether Minnick left a note. Tests will be done to see if Minnick died under the influence of alcohol or drugs, Proffitt said. Minnick was a ward of the state and under the care of the Fairfax County Department of Human Development. Cathy Wetherby, a spokeswoman for the department, said no information about his case would be released. Dolores Bohen, spokeswoman for the school system, said the site of the suicide is bound to deepen the students' grief. ``We do what we can to provide support, but the impact of it happening on school grounds when the students were attending school has to make it a more stunning reality,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy To Take Tutor For Tough Test
DOC.TEXT: John F. Kennedy Jr., his job as a assistant district attorney on the line, is turning to a tutor for help in passing the bar exam, according to a published report. ``We'd like to help him pass the bar exam,'' said Stanley Chess, the director of Bar-Bri, which specializes in training law school graduates for the bar, the Daily News said today. ``He intends to begin his preparation shortly and we're going to assign a specific attorney in our office _ Erica Fine _ to assist him,'' Chess said. ``She's probably the best tutor available.'' Kennedy, only son of President John F. Kennedy, learned last week that he failed the bar examination for the second time. If he fails a third time, the 29-year-old will automatically lose his job at the Manhattan district attorney's office. Fine, a 33-year-old lawyer and the service's assistant director, said she spoke with Kennedy after he learned he failed February's test by 11 points. ``He's not going to give up,'' Fine told the News. ``He's not a quitter. He's a really nice guy. I think he's very intelligent. He may have a problem with the standardized exam, but this is do-able for him.''

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Government Protest Enters 11th Day
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of anti-government protesters continued to occupy a downtown square today, and the country's interim leadership tried to defuse a threat by opposition parties to boycott elections later this month. About 500 anti-government demonstrators occupied University Square in an ongoing protest that entered its 11th day today. The protesters are demanding that interim President Ion Iliescu resign because of his Communist past. Their ranks included 25 demonstrators who have vowed to continue a hunger strike until Iliescu steps down. Seventeen of the hunger strikers said they have only taken sips of tea since they began their fast Monday night. Eight others joined the fast later. ``I will continue until I die,'' said Viorel Popa, a 25-year-old worker from the southwestern town of Turnu Severin, who was among the group of hunger strikers huddled under the balcony of a Bucharest University building. The oldest hunger striker, 66-year-old Nicolae Bucsenescu, said: ``We will not give up until the clique of Reds is removed.'' The protest has also caused a diplomatic row with France. The government officially protested today the actions of two French Parliament members who addressed the crowd on University Square on Tuesday. The University Square protest, which has occurred virtually round-the-clock since April 22, is the most visible against the interim government as the country prepares for its first free elections in more than 50 years on May 20. Five major opposition parties threatened on Monday to boycott the elections, saying more time is needed to prepare for the vote. They accused Iliescu's National Salvation Front, which dominates the provisional governing coalition, of monopolizing power. On Tuesday, the interim government guaranteed equal chances to all parties contesting the election and offered to meet the opposition parties to discuss their criticisms. The government said claims that the Front was harassing opposition activists and using facilities left by the deposed Communist Party ``can be discussed with representatives of the government to eliminate any kind of suspicions and to ... improve some organizational aspects'' of the elections. The opposition parties, which repeatedly have accused the Front of using public funds for electioneering and unfairly dominating the national media, had no immediate reaction to the government statement. On Tuesday, 8,000 anti-Communist protesters gathered in University Square to demand Iliescu's resignation. They protesters claim the Front is filled with former Communist Party members who advocate ``neo-Communism.'' Iliescu is a former Communist Party official who became a critic of deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The Front has dominated the interim coalition government that came to power during the December revolution that resulted in Ceausescu's execution. Two visiting French Parliament deputies, Jean-Claude Mignon and Jean-Pierre Ferrand, both from a right-wing party, spoke to the crowd occupying University Square Tuesday. Government spokesman Cristian Unteanu told The Associated Press that only Romania's ``very good relations'' with France saved the two French deputies from being expelled from the country. ``They should have been declared persona non grata, as in any civilized country,'' Unteanu said. He said Prime Minister Petre Roman had strongly protested the deputies' behavior in a telephone call today to French Prime Minister Laurent Fabius.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary's New Interim President A Former Political Prisoner
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD background on Goencz, quotes. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The new democratic Parliament today cemented Hungary's break with its Communist past by choosing as interim president a writer who was jailed for six years after the anti-Soviet revolt of 1956. Arpad Goencz, 68, was elected house speaker and interim president after Hungary's rival main parties, the center-right Hungarian Democratic Forum and the liberal League of Free Democrats, forged a surprise agreement. The Forum controls 164 seats and the Free Democrats 94, but Goencz needed the backing of other parties for the two-thirds majority required to win election in the 394-seat legislature. When the vote was announced after a secret ballot, Goencz won 339 votes of the 370 votes cast. The post of president is largely ceremonial in Hungary. Goencz replaces interim president Matyas Szueroes, a member of the Socialist Party that grew out of the old Communist party and governed until being roundly defeated in free elections in March and April. Szueroes was elected one of three deputy speakers. Historian Gyoergy Szabad, 66, and a founding member of the Democratic Forum, was voted Goencz's chief deputy with 348 votes. Vince Voeroes, leader of the Smallholders Party, was the third deputy elected. Goencz promised to uphold Hungary's new democratic system, saying: ``I know that confidence cannot be returned, only lost.'' His spoke in a brief thank-you address to Hungary's first democratic Parliament in more than 40 years. Before the vote, a year to the day after Hungary opened the Iron Curtain and paved the way to Eastern Europe's revolt against communism, deputies filed into Parliament's lofty chamber, newly stripped of its Communist coat of arms. The insignia of the old ``People's Republic,'' renamed simply the ``Republic of Hungary'' in October, was removed just last week. In another gesture symbolizing Hungary's transition from communism to democracy, many deputies arrived from St. Stephen's Cathedral, reviving a long-lost tradition of attending Mass before opening Parliament. The deputies also bid a formal farewell to the caretaker government of Socialist Miklos Nemeth, likely to be replaced this month by Jozsef Antall, leader of the Hungarian Democratic Forum, which won the elections. Goencz, a lawyer who entered politics after World War II as a member of the then dominant Smallholders' party, has headed the Hungarian Writers' Union since last December. He spent six years in jail after the 1956 revolt against Stalinism before winning a reprieve on his life sentence in the general amnesty of 1963. At a news conference before the vote , Antall said his party and the rival Free Democrats also had agreed that Parliament _ and not the nation as a whole _would choose the final president. Goencz is likely to get that post once a coalition government is formed by mid-May and the constitution is amended, likely in early June, Antall said at a joint news conference with Free Democrat leader Peter Toelgyessy. Unlike other East European nations, where the move away from communism was swift and dramatic, Hungary shifted toward democracy in gradual steps led by reform-minded Communists over the past two years. One of its boldest moves was to begin demolishing Iron Curtain fortifications along the border with Austria exactly one year ago. The move encouraged a westward exodus of East Germans. Despite the reforms of Hungary's Communists, four decades of repressive rule built up so much popular anger that their Socialist successors won only 33 seats in the recent elections. Hungary's politics are now dominated by the center-right and strongly nationalist Forum and the liberal League of Free Democrats, founded by former dissidents. The Forum wants to form a majority coalition with the like-minded agrarian-based Independent Smallholders, who have 44 deputies, and the Christian Democrats, who have 21. The session's opening minutes were laden with gestures intended to link Hungary's new democracy with spells of past liberty. An actor gave a stirring rendition of a poem by Sandor Petoefi, the firebrand leader of the failed 1848 revolt against Austrian Hapsburg rule, in which the poet called on Hungarian lawmakers ``to build a new country, better than the old.'' Otto von Habsburg, the former crown prince of Hungary and a member of the European Parliament, was present.

DOC.HEAD: Germanys Agree on Economic Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more details on economic plan, background on recent protests over unification procedure. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The two German states agreed on a plan today for merging their economies, settling basic differences over how the nations should assess the costs of unification, officials said. The tentative agreement sets the stage for a full merger of the economies of the two nations on July 2. The nations have been negotiating for weeks over how West Germany can absorb the decimated East German economy without threatening the strength of the powerful West German mark. The agreement was confirmed by Mathias Gehler, spokesman for East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, and Rudolf Seiters, chief of staff for West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The plan calls for exchanging the nearly worthless East German marks at a 1-1 rate for the West German mark, which will become the currency of East Germany in July. The rate would cover wages, rents and pensions but would only apply to small savings accounts. In a concession to East German demands, the West German government agreed to a higher ceiling on the bank accounts of elderly East Germans. Several protests have been held in recent weeks by East Germans demanding protection from the widespread unemployment expected to occur when East German enterprises are forced to compete in the free market. East Germans, who still only will earn about one-third of their West German counterparts, also fear rising prices and the loss of subsidies when the nations are united. West Germans, meanwhile, fear that absorbing the East German economy will dilute the power of the mighty West German currency and lead to higher taxes and inflation. Savings accounts above $2,300 would be exchanged at a 2-1 rate. However, the 1-1 rate would apply to accounts of up to $3,530 for East Germans aged 60 and older, and up to $1,180 for those of East Germans aged 14 and younger. Debts owned by East German enterprises _ estimated to total $153 billion _would be converted at a 2-1 rate. Some economists say the debts should be forgiven so East German businesses and factories can have a fresh start when they enter the free market. Chief West German negotiator Hans Tietmeyer, a director of the West German central bank, said the Bundesbank was in agreement with the proposal. The Bundesbank previously had said that a basic 1-1 conversion could lead to higher interest rates. The former East German government valued the East German mark at a 3-1 rate, but it truth it was virtually worthless in Western markets. A full political merger between the Germanys likely will take place next year. The four World War II allies that divided the country, the Soviet Union, United States, France and Britain, are to meet this Saturday in Bonn to discuss the international implications of unification.

DOC.HEAD: US Influence in Europe Would Drop Sharply Without Troops: German
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf of 2nd item, bgng, The six ... to CORRECT that the crewmen have been identified
DOC.TEXT: The United States will suffer a sharp loss of influence in Europe if Americans withdraw their troops, West German Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg says. ``In the past, American cooperation and influence on European policy was helpful, and in future, American policy and influence in Europe can be helpful,'' Stoltenberg said Tuesday evening. ``But without any soldiers or significant (numbers of) soldiers, your influence in all matters of security policy will sharply decline,'' he added. ``And I doubt whether this is desirable.'' Stoltenberg said in a speech before the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies of the Johns Hopkins University that Americans should maintain a substantial military presence for the foreseeable future. He said the United States might be able to reduce its forces in Central Europe beyond the 195,000 troops proposed by President Bush, if that could be coordinated with European allies and the Soviet Union. The defense minister met with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney earlier Tuesday, and they discussed German unification and other European issues, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said. A Pentagon source who spoke on background said the officials discussed problems with East-West talks in Vienna to cut conventional forces in Europe. He declined to say what the problems were. Stoltenberg called on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to retain nuclear forces in Europe, but said their numbers should be greatly reduced.
DOC.HEAD: Army Seeking Next of Kin
DOC.TEXT: The Army is looking for the next of kin for six crewmen who died when their B-17 was lost on a 1942 patrol over the Coral Sea, officials say. Although the aircraft was found and the crew list confirmed after several research missions to Papua New Guinea in 1986 and 1987, relatives of six of the eight crewmen haven't been found, Shari Lawrence, spokeswoman for the U.S. Total Army Personnel Command, said Tuesday. The plane disappeared after leaving from Townsville in Queensland, Australia. The Army believes the crew encountered the enemy because the Battle of the Coral Sea occurred in the days immediately after its disappearance, the statement said. The six crewmen whose next of kin haven't been found are: _2nd Lt. Jim Sam Grant, born Jan. 28, 1918. Last known next of kin: father Walter C. Grant, Malvern, Ark., and mother Marian P. Grant, Tucson, Ariz. _2nd Lt. Robert R. Meyer, Jr., birthdate unknown. Last known next of kin was father Robert R. Meyer, Birmingham, Ala. _Staff Sgt. Elton J. Rose, birthdate unknown. Last known next of kin was wife Gladys Strickland Rose, Coleman, Texas. _Sgt. Joe A. Carter, born May 10, 1910. Last known next of kin was mother Hazel Williams, La Jolla, Calif. _Sgt. Edward L. Hargrove, birthdate unknown. Last known next of kin were wife Evelyn W. Hargrove, Albuquerque, N.M., and grandfather, Manuel E. Flores, El Centro, Calif. _Sgt. Paul Reimer, born June 21, 1918. Last known next of kin was mother Eva Reimer, Reedley, Calif. Anyone with information may call Doug Howard collect at (703) 325-7960 or (703) 325-0811.

DOC.HEAD: First West German Head of State to Visit Poland Arrives
DOC.TEXT: West German President Richard von Weizsaecker arrived today on an official four-day visit, as Poland seeks guarantees for its borders in upcoming negotiations on German unification. Von Weizsaecker, the first West German head of state to visit Poland, began his trip just days before the two Germanys and the four victorious World War II allies _ the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France _ are to meet in Bonn to discuss the international implications of German unification. Von Weizsaecker was greeted at Warsaw's airport by President Wojciech Jaruzelski and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, the head of the Solidarity-led government. He is scheduled to hold talks with both Polish leaders as well as other dignitaries, including Solidarity leader Lech Walesa and Cardinal Jozef Glemp, the Roman Catholic primate. The West German president will also visit the former Nazi death camp at Treblinka, and the city of Gdansk, where the first shots of World War II were fired. Von Weizsaecker's trip marks a new stage in the difficult, and sometimes bloody, relations between Poland and Germany. West Germany is Poland's largest Western trading partner, and its support is critical to the success of the economic and political reforms undertaken by the new non-Communist government. But with an older generation that recalls the devastating World War II invasion and Nazi occupation, Poland harbors feelings of bitterness and distrust toward Germany that has come to the fore in the rush toward unification. Poland is seeking a seat at unification talks to guarantee its postwar western border, and wants a treaty with the two Germanys and the new government of a united Germany making the boundary permanent. Drawn along the Oder and Neisse rivers, the post-World War II boundary incorporates into Poland 40,000 square miles of land that was former German territory. This week, Poland submitted a draft treaty to the two Germanys and the four World War II allies. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and foreign ministers from the other countries will meet in Bonn on Saturday to discuss German unification. On the eve of his visit, von Weizsaecker offered assurances to Poles on the border issue. ``The essence of the border problem has been unequivocally settled. We cannot argue over territories and borders in Europe any more,'' von Weizsaecker told Polish television Tuesday. Today's issue of the pro-Solidarity newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza welcomed von Weizsaecker's visit with the headline, ``This German inspires confidence,'' over a profile outlining the West German president's long support for Poland's border concerns. Kohl made a historic, emotional _ and at points controversial _ visit to Poland in November. The trip was interrupted for a day when Kohl returned to Germany for emergency meetings as the East Germans began to dismantle the Berlin Wall.

DOC.HEAD: Counselor in Lake Tragedy Used Marijuana Five Hours Before Death
DOC.TEXT: A camp counselor who drowned trying to save three teen-agers in icy Convict Lake in February had used marijuana within five hours of his death, forensic toxicologists said. Randall Porter, 41, was lauded as a hero for his dying efforts to save the youths. But investigators have questioned whether the youths were properly supervised when they went onto the thin ice of the Sierra Nevada lake. The toxicological tests of a sample of Porter's blood don't indicate whether his judgment was impaired by the drug, said Dean Warden, a forensic toxicologist with the state Department of Justice. The test, however, indicates Porter had used marijuana within five hours of his death, Warden said Tuesday. Results of toxicological tests on the other victims of the Feb. 19 tragedy were negative, according to the Mono County Sheriff's Department. Three juvenile offenders housed at Camp O'Neal fell through the ice and drowned during an outing. Four adults, including Porter and another counselor, drowned trying to save the youths. Mono County prosecutors declined to file criminal charges in the drownings, but the toxicological test on Porter could be a factor in possible civil suits. The state Department of Social Services suspended Camp O'Neal's license in March for allegedly failing to provide proper supervision and care for the 34 teen-age boys sent to the camp by probation and social service officials.

DOC.HEAD: Telephone Worker Receives $1 Million Award
DOC.TEXT: A telephone company worker who claimed racial harassment forced her to quit after 13 years with Southern Bell has been awarded $1 million by a federal jury. Mary Ann Vance claimed that twice in 1984 she found a noose hanging from her work station at the company's Jacksonville warehouse. The award Tuesday came in a second trial after a $3.5 million jury award in 1987 was thrown out as unreasonable and excessive. ``Thank you, Jesus, thank you,'' Mrs. Vance said as she embraced friends in the courtroom when the verdict was announced. Dana Bradford, a Southern Bell attorney, said the company will appeal the verdict by the all-white jury. Mrs. Vance, 41, charged she received inadequate training and was subject to unfair disciplinary actions from managers because she is black. She testified that she heard after finding the nooses that one of her supervisors had placed them at her work station ``to increase productivity.'' Southern Bell attorneys contended Mrs. Vance created the noose incidents and suffered from a severe behavioral disorder that caused much of the stress she attributed to Southern Bell. They said the stress from five failed marriages and financial troubles _ not racial harassment _ was the cause of her problems. Jurors deliberated more than four hours before reaching a verdict. They awarded Mrs. Vance $500,000 in punitive damages and $511,500 in compensatory damages to cover past and future wages as well as medical costs. Mrs. Vance has been undergoing weekly therapy for anxiety since late 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Press Accuses Protesters of Insult Gorbachev, Warns of Possible Backlash
DOC.TEXT: A leading Soviet newspaper said today that columns of angry protesters who marched through Red Square on May Day insulted President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and may engender a backlash. Anti-government demonstrators were allowed to parade past Lenin's Mausoleum for the first time Tuesday in the traditional May Day ceremony. They shouted ``Shame!'' at the Soviet leadership, unfurled Lithuanian national flags and carried signs bitterly critical of the leadership. The extent and content of the public criticism was unprecedented for Gorbachev in his five years as Soviet leader. He and the other leaders gathered on top of the Mausoleum left after about 20 minutes of the protest, but it was not immediately apparent whether they left because of it. However, the Tuesday evening edition of the government newspaper Izvestia said that in those conditions, Gorbachev and the rest of the leadership ``had to leave Red Square.'' Today was the last day of a three-day holiday for Soviets, and there was no comment on the May Day protest by Soviet officials. But Izvestia said the informal groups who gathered at least 100,000 protesters for the march ``for some reason ... thought that only by completely running down the government, only with direct insults of the president could they show their bravery and speed up changes in the country.'' ``We don't exclude that in the end they may achieve some kind of acceleration,'' it added. ``But the whole question is, to what side will the changes be?'' The protesters were pressing for more rapid change than Gorbachev has allowed, but the Soviet leader also is under pressure from more conservative people who think he is moving too fast. Those forces, the article implied, could cause a conservative backlash. Speakers at a rally organized by trade union officials before the May Day march warned of inflation and unemployment if the government goes ahead with plans to develop a market economy. Gorbachev impatiently tapped his fingers during the protest, but otherwise showed no emotion. Izvestia accused the leaders of the demonstration of ``elementary political illiteracy.'' It added that some of the banners and chants were ``aimed at direct confrontation with constitutional authority.'' Pravda, the Communist Party daily, carried a report on the May Day parade on its front page, but buried any comment on the protest in one paragraph near the end. The informal groups, it said, ``unfortunately did not restrain themselves from extremist slogans, containing provocative, gross and insulting attacks against constitutional authority.'' Nationwide television showed less of the May Day festivities than usual, and the coverage was cut off before the unofficial protest began. Other Soviet newspapers carried reports only about the official part of the celebration.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa Opens Talks with ANC, Pledges to End Apartheid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more quotes about the talks and their prospects. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President F. W. de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela pledged today to abolish apartheid as they launched historic talks on ending white minority rule. De Klerk and Mandela said the government and the rival ANC would seek to quickly clear the way for full-scale constitutional negotiations on bringing the 28-million black majority into the national government. Mandela, standing next to de Klerk in front of a palatial Dutch colonial mansion where the talks will take place through Friday, said swift progress was vital and the patience of blacks was running out. ``We must succeed in the endeavor to remove these obstacles so that we can together move forward as rapidly as possible to end the inhuman system of apartheid,'' Mandela said. The ANC has been seeking discussions with white-led South African governments since the organization was founded in 1912. De Klerk also called for rapid progress. He challenged the ANC to help end a wave of violence that has claimed hundreds of lives in recent months, and said all political parties must make every effort to restore peace. ``The vast majority of South Africans desire the negotiation process aimed at a new constitution to get started in all earnest,'' de Klerk said. The ANC is demanding the government end a state of emergency, release all political prisoners, and allow the return of all ANC exiles as preconditions for full-scale constitutional talks. De Klerk stressed that the white government was acting on behalf of all South Africans and wanted to create a multiracial democracy where the right of all individuals would be equally protected. But he said growing violence and racial division was a threat to hopes of peace. ``Confrontation will get South Africans nowhere. Our joint destiny demands that all of us steer clear of it,'' he said. De Klerk expressed hope that the two sides would make quick progress and overcome the obstacles blocking full negotiations. ``There is cautious optimism, as well as faith and conviction that our problems will be solved by negotiation. ``The government has accepted the challenge of doing everything possible to achieve this,'' he said. Mandela, who complimented de Klerk on his speech, said the talks were an important step toward ending apartheid. He cautioned that black South Africans wanted immediate change and the two sides had to make rapid progress. The black nationalist leader denounced the policies of white minority rule, saying racial superiority and segregation could never again be the basis for politics and society in South Africa. He said blacks would never again accept that they had to be inferior to whites. ``The pace at which we move to arrive at a just solution should be informed by the fact that the black masses of our country demand and expect fundamental change now and not tomorrow. The people as a whole want the peace and stability which can only come about as a result of the total abolition of the apartheid system,'' Mandela said. Mandela attempted to reassure whites by saying there would be no discrimination against them in a future, multiracial democracy. In a gesture the majority of whites who are of Dutch heritage, he made the assurance in the Afrikaans language. The subject of violence on both sides was expected to be a major point of discussion. The ANC demands that the government control police violence and end the national state of emergency that gives officers wide powers and makes them almost immune from prosecution for any act. De Klerk and other government officials have asked the ANC leaders to stop their calls for armed struggle and have expressed displeasure at the continuing recruitment of guerrillas into the ANC's military wing, which was founded by Mandela. Joe Modise, commander of the military wing, said on Tuesday night that ``Spear of the Nation'' would continue recruiting members inside South Africa, because the South African Defense Force and white right-wing groups are continuing to recruit. Modise, who is a member of the ANC delegation in the talks, said he was not surprised that the government team did not include Defense Minister Magnus Malan. ``I nearly didn't come myself,'' said Modise. ``The army is the enemy on one side. (The ANC guerrilla wing) is the enemy from their point of view.'' Modise and Joe Slovo, the white leader of the South African Communist Party, could both be charged with capital crimes under South African law because they have headed the ANC's military wing. De Klerk assured them they would not be arrested so they would come to the talks from their exile headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia.

DOC.HEAD: China Authorized to Buy Additional Wheat
DOC.TEXT: China has been authorized to buy an additional 2 million metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department announced today. Undersecretary Richard T. Crowder said the wheat will be available to China under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The new subsidy line was on top of 5,050 tons left from an EEP allocation of 1 million tons made on Feb. 8. Since the subsidy program began five years ago, China has used it to buy about 15.2 million tons of U.S. wheat, exceeded only by the Soviet Union at 20.8 million tons. Under EEP arrangements, private exporters can sell U.S. commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in selected overseas markets and then collect free government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses, or subsidies. The subsidies have averaged from around $4 per ton, to more than $40 per ton of wheat, or in the range of 11 cents to about $1.10 per bushel. Purchases of U.S. wheat for 1989-90 delivery total about 5.7 million tons, much of it without subsidies. In 1988-89, China bought nearly 8.1 million tons, all of it carrying EEP subsidies. China's wheat orders under the program for the 1990-91 marketing year that will begin June 1 are reported at 1 million tons.

DOC.HEAD: PM-Obit-Franchi, 2nd Ld - Writethru, a0477,0247
Singer Sergio Franchi Dead of Cancer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to DELETE incorrect references to Tony award; Franchi did NOT win a Tony award. Deletes reference in 4th graf, `He made...', to to `Wind Beneath My Wings' and `Memory' as `hits'. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Born in...'.
DOC.TEXT: Sergio Franchi, a singer with operatic ambitions who had a hit with ``O' Sole Mio'' and crooned in TV commercials for the Plymouth Volare in the 1970s, has died of cancer. The Italian-born tenor died Tuesday at his estate. He never publicly revealed his age, although some sources list it as 57. Franchi performed around the country and was a headliner in Las Vegas in the 1960s and '70s, blending popular standards and operatic arias. He made 25 albums including such songs as ``O' Sole Mio,'' ``Wind Beneath My Wings'' and ``Memory.'' In the mid-1970s, Franchi crooned, ``Volare, ohhhhhhhh,'' in commercials for the Volare automobile. Born in Cremona, Italy, Franchi studied to be an engineer while training in opera. He performed in South Africa in ``La Traviata,'' ``La Boheme'' and ``Carmen'' before leaving to advance his operatic career. In Italy, England and later the United States, he encountered difficulty getting parts. Instead he became a frequent guest on ``The Ed Sullivan Show.'' His film credits included a supporting role in ``The Secret of Santa Vittoria'' in 1969. Survivors include his wife, Eva; a daughter; a son; and two sisters. Funeral services will be private.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead of STONINGTON, Conn.-dated 2nd item to DELETE incorrect reference to Tony Award. Franchi did NOT win a Tony.

DOC.HEAD: Writer Chosen Interim President Spent Years Fighting the Communists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Arpad Goencz is pronounced AH-pahd Gernts
DOC.TEXT: Arpad Goencz, the writer and former political prisoner chosen interim president of Hungary on Wednesday, dedicated his life to fighting the hard-line Communist leaders who were ousted last year. In 1948, when the Communists seized control, Goencz lost his job as a prominent editor and was forced to work as an unskilled laborer. In 1956, he was at the forefront of Hungary's short-lived revolt against Stalinism, and paid for his involvement with six years in jail. He won a reprieve on his life sentence under a 1963 amnesty. Once free, Goencz began translating British and American novels into Hungarian, and later published several of his own novels and short stories. By the 1970s, he became associated with dissidents who signed petitions and published underground literature in a campaign to get the Communist authorities to be more democratic and respect human rights. He joined with them in founding the League of Free Democrats, now Hungary's second-largest political party, in May 1988. A stout, balding grandfather, Goencz was born in Budapest in 1922. He trained as a lawyer and graduated in 1944 from the city's respected university. He immediately entered politics under the then-dominant Smallholders' Party. The Smallholders won control of Parliament in 1946. Goencz, then editor of a Budapest weekly, seemed set for a prominent career with the conservative party that drew its strength from the farmers running Hungary's agrarian-based economy. The Communist takeover in 1948 changed his fortunes. While evidently failing to dent his commitment to democracy, the twist of fate apparently made Goencz philosophical about his newfound political stardom. ``I would not call myself a professional politician,'' Goencz said when elected head of the Writers' Union in December. ``The homo politicus and the writer in me are one. What is now taking place is the realization of my political dreams _ not of my career wishes,'' he said of Hungary. After Vaclav Havel in Czechoslovakia, Goencz is the second writer-president in newly democratic eastern Europe. ``There is a great conspiracy of international writers,'' Goencz joked to Western reporters after his election. Goencz was a surprise choice for interim president in a May Day agreement hammered out by the Free Democrats and the victors of last month's free elections, the Hungarian Democratic Forum. The conservative Forum, expected to forge a center-right coalition government with two like-minded parties later this month, apparently wanted to stress national unity as Hungary faces a mounting economic crisis. Goencz is expected to be named to a full four-year term as president once the coalition is formed and Parliament in June passes constitutional amendments that would give the legislature _ not the nation _ the task of naming a full president. As interim president, Goencz's powers are largely ceremonial and in line with those of the presidents of many west European states. The president is commander in chief of the armed forces and is empowered to initiate a plebiscite, negotiate international agreements and exercise clemency for prisoners. Under the current constitution, the president may serve a maximum of two four-year terms.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Bomb Explodes at Army Base, Seven Injured
DOC.TEXT: An Irish Republican Army bomb exploded today at a military base in this town southwest of Belfast, injuring seven people, police said. The Royal Ulster Constabulary said one civilian employee was seriously injured and six other people, including two children, were treated for minor injuries and shock. A Constabulary spokesman, who was not named in keeping with British custom, said the bomb exploded under a Land Rover as the civilian employee was moving it in the garage or parking area of the Territorial Army base in Lisburn, seven miles southwest of Belfast. The Territorial Army is a reserve force that is locally recruited. Earlier today, a mortar bomb exploded in a Londonderry police station and a second device was defused by bomb disposal experts, police said. No one was injured in the attack. A hijacked van, from which the mortar bomb attack was launched, was found 200 yards away from the police station, the Constabulary spokesman said. Police said two gunmen, who identified themselves as IRA members, held a family hostage while they hijacked the van. The family was released unharmed. The latest bombing incidents follow a public warning last week by Northern Ireland's police headquarters, which said it had received intelligence reports that the IRA planned to step up its offensive to end British rule. The IRA claimed responsibility for the blast at the army base in a telephone call to the British domestic news agency, Press Association. The IRA said its men breached the security fencing around the base and planted a five-pound, booby-trap bomb under a Land Rover. The telephone caller said the bomb was made of Semtex, the Czechoslovakian-made plastic explosive. The Irish Republican Army wants to unite mostly Protestant Northern Ireland with the mainly Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland, under socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Iranian Officials Meet, Say Hostages Not Discussed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD background on Syria and Iran wanting Western aid, officials questioning Reed, CORRECTS spelling of Shah's name. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With US-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. government sources say there has been no discussion of the hostage issue in meetings this week between U.S. and Iranian representatives, even though two American hostages have been released. The meetings began Tuesday in the Hague between the State Department's legal adviser, Abraham Sofaer, and his Iranian counterpart, Jaromi Eftekhar to discuss claims disputes. The Iran-U.S. Claims Tribunal is the only official forum where the two nations meet. The meetings take place almost monthly in The Hague, a U.S. source said on condition of anonymity. He decribed Tuesday's meeting as ``routine.'' President Bush has praised both Iran and Syria for their roles in the release of Robert Polhill on April 22 and Frank Reed on Monday. The men were among eight Americans believed held in Beirut by pro-Iranian groups. Iran and Syria have said all 16 remaining Western hostages in Lebanon should be freed. Both countries reportedly are anxious to establish closer ties with the West. But Bush has said he won't deal to free the hostages. A special State Department team was questioning Reed for a second day today in a search for inforamtion about the remaining Western captives. The private U.S.-Iranian talks were believed to center on a settlement of all so-called ``Small Claims'' of under $250,000. Those claims comprise the bulk of the caseload of the tribunal, charged with settling billions of dollars in claims between the two nations arising from the 1979 Iranian revolution. So far, the arbitration panel has presided over the settlement of more than $2.2 billion in financial disputes stemming primarily from expropriations by the Iranian government. U.S. and Iranian tribunal officials have repeatedly denied reports that their negotiations touch on the hostage issue. ``The officials, as they have in the past, are here to discuss legal and technical issues concerning tribunal cases,'' U.S. Embassy spokesman Leonardo Williams said. The 9-year-old claims tribunal was set up as part of the 1980 Algiers Accords that brought freedom to the U.S. diplomats held hostage in the U.S. Embassy in Tehran for 444 days. Secrecy is a hallmark of the proceedings, which occur in a converted hotel on a quiet residential street. The claims are handled by three so-called chambers, each of which has an Iranian, an American and a third-nation arbitrator who acts as chairman. Ninety-five percent of the claims were filed by American companies against Iran. A small number were filed by Iranian commercial entities against U.S. companies and the U.S. government. The largest is Iran's claim against the United States for military-related items ordered by the pre-revolutionary government of Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi. The claim, known as B1, amounts to up to $11 billion. Various Iranian officials in the past have tied progress on the hostage issue to progress on that claim, as well as the return of frozen Iranian assets. But the U.S. government says much of the military equipment was never paid for, and is being held by contractors over which the United States has no influence. The tribunal source said $11 billion has so far been transferred to Iranian control. About $6 billion of that was used by Iran to pay Western bank loans. The amount of Iranian funds still frozen in accounts runs only into the millions, the tribunal source said. The tribunal is seeking a way to settle the small claims together and wipe out the remaining caseload of 2,450.

DOC.HEAD: American Worker Kidnapped Near Colombian Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT that man who was killed was one of the Ecuadoreans, sted the Colombian. Fixes style on `Ecuadorean,' preferred spelling, throughout.
DOC.TEXT: An American mining company employee has been kidnapped and a Ecuadorean national killed by guerillas in Ecuador, government officials said. U.S. Embassy spokesman Gregory Lagana, in Quito, Ecuador, said the kidnap victim, Scott Heimdal, 28, has been missing since Saturday, the Peoria Journal Star reported Tuesday. Heimdal, formerly of Peoria, was traveling by boat along the Bermeja River on the Ecuador-Colombian border when he was taken by rebels, according to the newspaper. Ecuadorian Armed Forces launched an air-and-land search Sunday, but U.S. officials said they believe Heimdal was being held in Colombia. Lagana said Heimdal was working in Ecuador for the International Mining Co. He was traveling with three Ecuadoreans and a Colombian boat pilot to a support camp seeking medical treatment for an infected foot and bronchitis. Lagana said the boat was ordered to stop by a small band of guerrillas armed with automatic weapons. When the boat pilot tried to flee, the newspaper reported, the guerrillas opened fire, killing one Ecuadorean, wounding another and kidnapping Heimdal and Ecuadorean geology student Edwin Teneda, 29. The kidnappers later released Teneda, with two letters written by Heimdal, one to his wife and the other to his company. The letters' contents were not revealed. Authorities said Heimdal was put on a boat moving up the Rumiyacu River, which crosses into Colombia. Lagana said the guerrillas claim to be part of the Popular Liberty Army, a Colombian group. The kidnappers have made no demands for the release of Heimdal, a U.S. Army veteran and an electronics specialist for the mining company.

DOC.HEAD: Top Military Official Chosen as New Prime Minister in Taiwan
DOC.TEXT: President Lee Teng-hui today chose the country's top military official to be the new prime minister in a surprise move that opposition leaders denounced as a setback for democracy. Defense Minister Hau Pei-tsun, the country's only four-star general, said he accepted the offer to head the government during a meeting with the president. The 71-year-old Hau would replace Lee Huan, 73, in about two weeks. ``President Lee said the country needs me,'' Hau said in a television interview. ``I thought I should not defy him.'' Hau, who would be the first general to become prime minister in 27 years, said the proposed appointment does not mean the military will interfere in politics. ``There are many such precedents in democratic countries,'' he said. Lee is expected to formally announce Hau's appointment May 20 when he is sworn in as president for a new six-year term. The nomination must then be approved by the Parliament, which is controlled by members of the ruling Nationalist Party. Opposition leaders reacted to Hau's nomination with suspicion and expressed concern about its impact on recent moves to liberalize the country's political system. Chen Shui-pien, a lawmaker from the Democratic Progressive Party, denounced the appointment as ``a move to drive Taiwan's democracy backward.'' Another opposition leader, Jiang Peng-chien, called Hau's nomination ``odd and inappropriate ... an apparent compromise with the military.'' He expressed concern that the military would take it as a signal to interfere more in politics. ``The military has mistaken our society's newly emerged pluralism as social chaos and wants to stamp out opposition voices,'' Jiang said. The Nationalist Party has gradually eased its authoritarian grip in recent years _ lifting martial law, allowing opposition political parties and bringing more of the native Taiwanese who account for 85 percent of the island's 20 million people into government. But Hau belongs to the Nationalist Party's Old Guard that fled to Taiwan with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek after losing a civil war to the Communists on the Chinese mainland in 1949. Some politicians also wondered how Hau's appointment would affect the gradual easing of restrictions on contact with mainland China that has resulted in hundreds of thousands of Taiwan residents traveling to the mainland. The government now also tolerates indirect investment and trade with the Chinese mainland and is under pressure from businessmen to further broaden contacts. Hau is among the Nationalist conservatives who still dream of returning to China to overthrow the Communists, and he may be expected to take a fairly hard-line stance on relations with Beijing. However, he may still be an acceptable choice to Chinese Communist officials because he shares their view that Taiwan is part of China and should not abandon the goal of eventual reunification. Political observers say Lee's move to appoint Hau represents an attempt to broaden his power base and stem criticism among aging Nationalist conservatives who have questioned his pragmatic policies toward their enemies in Beijing. Lee is the first native Taiwanese to serve as president and head of the ruling party. He succeeded Chiang Ching-Kuo, Chiang Kai-shek's son, who died in office in January 1988. Hau was appointed defense minister last year after being chief of the 500,000-member armed forces for eight years.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Hospital Prescription Errors Average 2{ Daily
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 10th graf pvs, `In New York...' to UPDATE with comment from outside researcher. Pickup 11th graf pvs, `The Albany...'.
DOC.TEXT: Efforts to cut U.S. medical costs should leave in place the safety mechanisms that catch mistakes doctors make in prescribing drugs, says a researcher who documented hundreds of such errors at a New York hospital. The study in today's Journal of the American Medical Association found an average of 2{ errors a day in written prescriptions at 640-bed Albany Medical Center Hospital in 1987. One in five mistakes could have been serious or fatal. ``Medication errors are an all too common occurrence in the provision of modern health care and one of the many `hazards of hospitalization,''' the researchers said. Doctors at Albany wrote 289,411 prescriptions in 1987, and errors occurred in 905 of them, including 182 mistakes that could have caused severe harm or death if they had gone undetected, the researchers reported. However, ``quality assurance procedures operative within our hospital and in most health-care systems ... appear to be quite effective,'' said Timothy S. Lesar, assistant pharmacy director for clinical services and the study's co-author. ``All these errors were averted. They never put a patient at risk,'' he said in a telephone interview Monday. Five years ago, an error by two doctors in administering a drug to a pregnant cancer patient at Albany led to better drug-control procedures there, the researchers said. The patient was left comatose and near death, and her premature baby later died; the hospital was cited by the New York Health Department for lacking effective policies to control dangerous drugs. Now, for written prescriptions, the hospital's pharmacists enter doctors' orders into a computer that checks them again against patient data about drug allergies and other information, researchers said. In New York hospitals overall in 1984, drugs accounted for 20 percent of the 27,000 treatment-related patient injuries, according to Dr. Howard H. Hiatt, head of a Harvard Medical School study released last month. The study did not identify the number of injuries that might have been caused by physician errors. ``Things do fall between the safety net,'' Neil M. Davis, professor of pharmacy at Temple University School of Pharmacy in Philadelphia, said today. He said the Albany study documented ``what pharmacists have always known.'' ``Hospitals better have good pharmacy units,'' Davis said in a telephone interview, adding that pharmaceutical services tend to need strengthening in intensive care and newborn care units. The Albany study found an error rate of 3.13 per 1,000 orders written. Of the 905 errors, 522, or 57.7 percent, were ``significant,'' meaning they could have caused adverse consequences, the researchers said. Mistakes varied from ordering too strong a tranquilizer for the size or age of a patient to prescribing penicillin or a related drug to a patient allergic to it. Researchers found higher error rates in obstetrics-gynecology and surgery-anesthesia than in other services, possibly reflecting less time or emphasis on nonsurgical aspects of patient care during training programs, they said. Error rates were higher among first-year residents and declined with successive years of training, the researchers said. Mistakes were highest during daytime hours, when large numbers of prescriptions were being written, and lowest during evening hours, suggesting fatigue is not a factor in prescription errors, the researchers said.

DOC.HEAD: Mugger Nets Millions in Financial Certificates
DOC.TEXT: A knife-wielding mugger held up a messenger Wednesday and escaped with $475 million in financial certificates, police said. The Bank of England immediately issued a warning to banks and money market firms, but said it would be ``extraordinarily difficult'' to use the certificates of deposit and Treasury Bills to raise money. A Bank of England spokesman said there was a ``remote'' chance the certificates and bills could be used illegally to secure a bank loan. The messenger was attacked while walking from Sheppards money brokers to another finance house in London's financial district, the City of London. Sheppards money brokers refused to comment on the incident and police were interviewing the messenger, who was not identified.

DOC.HEAD: Fishing Trawler With 17 Crewmen Sinks, Three Confirmed Survivors
DOC.TEXT: A Korean fishing trawler with 17 crew members aboard sank off the northern New Zealand coast Wednesday, and defense officials said rescuers found three survivors and two bodies. The boat Sam Seung 35 sank west of Auckland after sending out a distress signal at 3:20 a.m., Defense spokesman Peter Fry said. A Royal New Zealand Air Force plane started a search of the area shortly after dawn. More than 12 hours later, the Soviet fishing boat Druzbha picked up three survivors who were clinging to floating wreckage amid 25-knot winds, said a spokeswoman for the National Rescue Coordination Center. The Soviet vessel also recovered two bodies spotted by the plane. One survivor was badly burned, but the extent of his injuries was not immediately known. There was no immediate word on why the ship sank.

DOC.HEAD: One Filipino Killed, Five Wounded in Explosion at U.S. Base
DOC.TEXT: An explosion inside the U.S. Subic Bay naval base training range Wednesday killed a Filipino and wounded five of his companions, the U.S. Navy said. A Navy statement said the group was scavenging for unexploded ammunition at the live-fire area a day after a training exercise inside the facility, 50 miles west of Manila. The wounded scavengers were brought to the American naval hospital inside the base for treatment. The statement did not say what type of ammunition or explosive caused the death and injuries. U.S. and Philippine authorities were investigating the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Robbers Make Off With $1.9 Million in Jewelry
DOC.TEXT: Four robbers held up a shop in one of Hong Kong's best-known hotels Wednesday and escaped with jewelry worth $1.9 million, police reported. Police said the three men and a woman posed as customers. Two of the men pulled out guns and threatened three women employees of the shop, located in the shopping arcade of the Mandarin Hotel in downtown Hong Kong. They grabbed several diamond necklaces and bracelets before escaping on foot, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Dead, Several Injured In Ski Resort Fire
DOC.TEXT: Fire swept through a hotel at a ski resort in northern Finland Wednesday, killing two people and injuring five, the national radio reported. Authorities said they suspect the fire was started by a guest smoking in bed, and the flames spread from the man's pajamas to a corridor. There was no alarm system in the old part of the hotel where the blaze broke out. All of the 40 guests at the resort were hotel personnel who had been celebrating the end of the skiing holiday season in Lapland prior to closing the hotel until the summer season.

DOC.HEAD: Reed Held With Four Other Hostages During Captivity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 17 grafs to UPDATE with Reed quotes; Pickup 19th, `On Tuesday...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former hostage Frank Reed said today he was held for months at a time with four other Westerners, including two Americans, and that he is angry they have not been freed. Reed was released to Syrian officials in Lebanon on Monday after 3{ years in the hands of Shiite Moslem fundamentalist kidnappers. He is now at the U.S. Air Force Hospital in Wiesbaden for medical tests and debriefings. ``I tell you, I'm very, very angry that Anderson ... Tom and Terry ... are not free,'' 57-year-old Reed said from a hospital balcony. Reed referred to Terry Anderson, The Associated Press chief Middle East correspondent and the longest-held hostage in Lebanon, and Thomas Sutherland, an American educator. Anderson was kidnapped on March 16, 1985, while Sutherland was seized on June 9, 1985. ``For God's sake, it's nearly the sixth year for these men. I'm absolutely embarrassed I'm out before they are,'' Reed said. ``I spent two years wih Tom and Terry.'' ``I have not seen Tom and Terry for awhile and I don't know where they are,'' Reed said. Reed also said he spent three years in the intermittent company of John McCarthy of Britain and Brian Keenan of Ireland. Reed said he had been kept in the same house with them since October and the three were also together periodically for three years. McCarthy, 33, a journalist for the London-based Worldwide Television News agency, WTN, was kidnapped April 17, 1986 and Keenan, 39, disappeared six days later. No group has claimed to be holding either McCarthy or Keenan. Earlier, Reed's wife, Fahima, said her husband was kept with up to six other Western hostages during his captivity. A special State Department team was to resume questioning Reed for a second day today. They seek clues about the 16 remaining Westerners held hostage in Lebanon, six of whom are American. Mrs. Reed, a 39-year-old Syrian Moslem, said that whenever a hostage was taken away her husband thought that captive was being freed. She said that upon his release, Reed was surprised and angered to learn others remained captive. ``Our joy will not be complete until every single one of them is free,'' Mrs. Reed told a news conference. While the educator underwent medical tests, Mrs. Reed disclosed details of her husband's imprisonment. She said he was blindfolded and bound for almost his entire captivity, except for 90 minutes during the evenings. Mrs. Reed said during that time, Reed was allowed to watch television or read magazines or books, but he refused. ``These things were so trivial compared to the things that were snatched away,'' she said. Mrs. Reed said her husband was ``moved around a lot.'' Upon his release, Reed telephonedrelatives of several Western hostages. In London, a group pressing for the release of McCarthy said Reed told them of McCarthy and Keenan: ``They are both well. They have some minor health problems. They exercise daily and read voraciously.'' Peggy Say, Anderson's sister, said Reed told her ``Terry was in reasonably good health, although he had been having physical problems ... He said Terry's attitude was still feisty, as far as the guards go, and he was always screaming for something to read.'' On Tuesday, Reed was flown from Damascus, Syria, to West Germany for the medical tests and debriefings and was reunited with Fahima, his second wife, and their 9-year-old son, Tarek. He celebrated freedom with a steak and a beer and showed no initial signs of serious health problems, though doctors said he lost ``significant weight and muscle mass'' during his 43 months in captivity and felt tired and weak. A hospital statement said Reed would probably be at the hospital ``for the next two to three days.'' The founder of a private school in Beirut, Reed was the second American hostage to be freed in nine days. Robert Polhill, freed April 22, went through the same battery of medical tests and questioning last week. The Wiesbaden hospital has become the ritual stop for freed American hostages on their way home. Hospital specialists are experts at comforting freed hostages and helping them with post-captivity psychological shocks. The first group of ex-captives to go through the Wiesbaden hospital were 52 Americans held in Tehran until their release in January 1981. At the time of his abduction Sept. 9, 1986, Reed ran the private Lebanese International School, which he founded after the International College had been bombed out.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Prevents Fractures in Elderly Women
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: A drug can reverse the loss of vertebral bone and prevent fractures in older women with osteoporosis, a common cause of disability among the elderly, according to a study. Danish doctors who tested the medicine, called etidronate, found that while it halted the loss of bone in the spine, it did not affect bones in other parts of the body. An estimated 15 million to 20 million Americans have osteoporosis. The condition is blamed for 1.3 million fractures annually in people over age 45. It is especially common among older women, when their bodies make less estrogen after menopause. The research, directed by Dr. Tommy Storm at Sundby Hospital in Copenhagen, was published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. It was financed by Procter & Gamble's Norwich Eaton Pharmaceuticals, which makes etidronate. The doctors performed a three-year comparison study on 66 women who ranged from age 56 to 75. When it was over, they found that the vertebral bone mineral content of those who got the drug increased 7 percent. But it decreased 3 percent in a comparison group who got dummy pills. The number of vertebral fractures also decreased substantially in the etidronate group. ``Although we do not know whether the dose and treatment regimen used in our study are optimal, our results are encouraging,'' the researchers wrote. The medicine has been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for treatment of Paget's disease of bone.

DOC.HEAD: Legislators Call for Faster Efforts on Environmental Problems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout
DOC.TEXT: Legislators at an international conference on the environment today passed a resolution calling for nations to commit themselves to a 50 percent total reduction in global-warming pollutants over the next 20 years. The legislators from 42 nations also called for other stepped-up efforts to deal with the environment, including creation of a ``global Marshall plan'' to help developing countries cope with environmental concerns. The three-day conference concluded with overwhelming approval of a reduction timetable for global-warming pollutants pushed by the U.S. congressional delegation which hosted the conference. The resolution contrasts with Bush administration policy, which has advocated more research before specific pollution controls are proclaimed. The resolutions and goals approved by the Interparliamentary Conference on the Global Environment are not binding on any nation, but some participants said they hoped to use the conference report to sway fellow legislators back home about the need to take specific actions on environmental matters. ``I hope that this is going to be the beginning, the beginning in which we can have a global survival dialogue,'' Attiya Inayatullah, a member of the Parliament of Pakistan, told reporters. More than 200 lawmakers from 42 nations including the Soviet Union, most European countries, Japan and many developing nations participated in the conference.
