The conference agreed to establish a broad range of environmental goals, including actions aimed at protecting the ozone layer, reversing the loss of forests and committing greater resources to population control. The policy statements, however, provided few specifics on how some of these efforts would be funded, including the proposed plan by industrial nations to help developing countries deal with the environment. This so-called ``global Marshall plan for sustainable development and the environment'' would be patterned on the post-World War II economic assistance efforts by the United States that help European recover from the war, officials said. Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., one of the organizers, and other U.S. delegates had pushed for a consensus in a closing policy declaration that ``the time to act is now'' to deal with such issues as global warming. One resolution that was approved calls for immediate action on setting specific goals for reducing man-made pollutants, including carbon dioxide, that cause global warming, or the greenhouse effect. ``Delay exposes us, our children and their children to calamities which we will have made irrevocable by inaction in the present,'' the draft resolution declared. The strong statement for action, drafted by the U.S. delegates to the conference, is in sharp contrast to the Bush administration's position that additional research into global warming and its potential economic impact is needed before specific pollution curbs should be set in concrete. Nevertheless, Gore and Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., stressed that the gathering was not intended to embarrass President Bush. Two weeks ago he caused rumblings among delegates to a White House conference on global warming by emphasizing the need for study over development of specific response strategies. In contrast, the legislative delegates drafted a global-warming resolution that scarcely refers to the need for more research and calls for setting a timetable for specific cuts in global warming pollutants by the year 2010. The resolution calls for a roughly 20 percent reduction in carbon dioxide, a product of burning fossil fuels; total elimination of chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, and a variety of other ozone-depleting chemicals; and a 10 percent reduction in methane emissions. Altogether that would amount to about a 50 percent reduction in global-warming pollutants by 2010.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. April 26 The Westerly (R.I.) Sun on Michael Milken: Michael R. Milken ... pleaded guilty to federal charges of securities fraud and conspiracy and agreed (nice of him) to pay fines and penalties of $600 million. That amount of money would seem to be indicative of one of the most serious white-collar crimes of our time. For the crime of this significance, lawyers say he faces a prison term that will not exceed five years. The fines and penalties seem as stiff as the prospective term is lenient.

April 28 The Arizona Republic, Phoenix, on the automobile industry: Not too long ago the American-made automobile was a cherished symbol of national power and the envy of the world. Times have changed. Today the U.S. auto industry is under siege, and those shiny models of what was right with America have come to symbolize what is wrong. The numbers tell the story. In 1960 General Motors, Ford and Chrysler made more than half the world's cars. Today they account for less than a third. What went wrong? The London Economist offers a simple answer: ``the Japanese.'' But more is involved than just the talents and enterprise of Toyota, Honda and Nissan. Detroit's complacency, along with what the Economist calls ``a string of badly designed, badly made'' cars in the late '70s, invited disaster. The Japanese took advantage by raising quality and lowering prices. By almost any measure, Detroit has improved. But so have the Japanese, and at much lower cost, even though production has been shifted to the United States. If Japanese car makers expand their U.S. operations as expected, predicts the Brookings Institution, 110,000 new American jobs will be created by 1992. America's auto industry has used the import quotas, as the Economist says, ``to fatten executives' bonuses and to help delay painful reform.'' Staring again into the face of economic death, Detroit has a choice. It can learn from its competitors, streamline its operations and become responsive to market demand, or it can stand pat and anguish over the loss of the American edge.

April 30 Los Angeles Daily News on the Camarena slaying: (N)o matter how important (the arrest of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain to stand trial in Los Angeles in the 1985 torture-slaying of Enrique Camarena of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration) was to the DEA, the manner in which the agency reportedly brought Alvarez into the United States, arranging his abduction by offering a reward to Mexican kidnappers who seized him in Guadalara on April 2, was out of bounds. It subverted Mexico's legal process and violated that country's sovereignty. ... While Mexico has been victimized by many acts of corruption, it is insulting for the United States to treat its neighbor as though it were so thoroughly and incorrigibly corrupt that American authorities could not depend on it to bring criminals to justice through legal channels. Furthermore, the United States cannot expect other nations to follow due process of law _ which means, among other things, giving fair treatment to American citizens suspected of crimes _ if it goes on making end runs around Mexico's legal system.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: legal system.
DOC.TEXT: April 30 The Telegraph, Nashua, N.H., on Lithuania:. It looks like Lithuania has gotten the message. No country will come to the Baltic country's defense in its present confrontation with the Soviet Union. Not even the United States, which we all know likes to sound off that there's nothing better on earth than democracy and freedom. President Bush last week began by sounding tough on the Soviet Union's plan to make Lithuania knuckle under by shutting off supplies of oil, natural gas and other vital materials to the small republic. But when the time came to enact trade sanctions against the Soviets in support of Lithuania, Bush did a repeat of his Beijing waltz. He finally declared it was not in the best interest of further U.S.-Soviet Union peace moves to help Lithuania, despite all his earlier sympathetic talk about Lithuania's desire for independence.

April 30 Las Cruces (N.M.) Sun-News on Lithuania: A lot of people want President George Bush to get tough with Mikhail Gorbachev about Soviet pressure on tiny Lithuania. We think Bush has been wise to adopt a cautious and restrained stance. He is really not in a position to help Lithuania very much, but he could do great damage to the progress toward democracy in Eastern Europe. We doubt that the most vocal critics of Bush's policy have really thought much about the consequences if their advice was followed. Some, we suspect, are just posturing in support of what they conceive to be a popular cause. It is easy to sympathize with the Lithuanians, annexed by force to a huge nation that oppressed and impoverished them. But in a time of soaring expectations it is easy to expect too much. The peoples of Eastern Europe have made tremendous strides toward freedom that were unimaginable little more than a year ago. Things are moving swiftly in the right direction. It would be unwise to throw a monkey wrench into the process at this point. What would be gained by doing so?

April 26 The News and Courier, Charleston, S.C., on Lithuania: By playing tough guy, Mikhail Gorbachev is winning important points with Moscow hard-liners, who view any attempt to leave the federation as a dire threat to the integrity of the USSR as a whole. President Bush's decision _ outward decision, that is _ to keep hands-off gives ... Gorbachev carte blanche to do whatever is necessary, short of invasion, to keep Lithuania in the fold. Helping ... Gorbachev maintain his political equilibrium may satisfy Washington's geopolitical interests, but it does not address the moral dilemma the United States faces. An angry (Lithuanian) President Landsbergis raised serious questions when, responding to ... Bush, he said: ``Can the freedom of one group of people be sold for the freedom of another? What, then, is the idea of freedom itself?'' Surely these same questions were asked by congressional leaders as they met ... with ... Bush prior to his announcement. The president's answers obviously satisfied a broad cross-section of America's political leaders. We hope, however, that what ... Bush said was transmitted also to ... Landsbergis. At the very least, he is owed that much.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Another Shock Wave Hits Quake-Ravaged Watsonville: Loss Of Jobs
DOC.TEXT: The city of Watsonville, still trying to recover from the October earthquake, has suffered another blow when its third-largest food processor announced plans to lay off 370 workers. Green Giant Vegetables said the company will spend $3.4 million to modernize its Watsonville plant, which employs 520, but cut production in half. Green Giant will shift frozen cauliflower and broccoli production to plants in the Midwest and Mexico, bringing the production closer to markets in the East and Midwest, said plant manager Duane Larson. But officials of Teamsters Local 912 said they believe the move is related to Mexico's cheaper labor costs. The lowest-paid worker in the union earns $7.61 an hour, while workers in Mexico earn less than $4 per day, said Sergio Lopez, secretary-treasurer of Local 912. ``This couldn't have come at a worse time,'' said Lopez. ``After the October 17 quake, this community was devastated. The loss of more jobs will be horrible.'' Green Giant, a unit of Grand Metropolitan PLC, plans to lay off 220 full-time workers and 150 seasonal workers early next year.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: that much.
DOC.TEXT: April 26 The Parkersburg (W.Va.) News on racism: Professional baseball player Jose Canseco's claim he's a victim of racism should outrage every American. ... Canseco plays ... for the Oakland Athletics. After signing a new contract for the coming year, he had a few words to say to the press. He was upset the A's didn't agree to pay him more. Canseco is a Hispanic who came to the United States from Cuba. The reason he didn't get a better contract is racism, opined Canseco. His contract is for $2 million. For one year. Various adjectives could be used to describe accurately a $2 million a year contract for a baseball player. ``Racist'' isn't one of them. People who have been victims of racism should be enraged at Canseco's idiotic, insensitive comment. Leaders of civil rights groups fighting ... true racism should condemn Canseco for his egotistical outburst. Baseball fans should display their displeasure, perhaps by letting A's management know they don't appreciate Canseco. Such expressions of concern might be particularly appropriate coming from members of minorities who have trouble scraping up the increasing price of admission to a professional game. Racism? Hardly. With $2 million to invest and produce enough income to keep him on easy street for the rest of his life, Canseco never will experience some of the most difficult aspects of real racism. That's a shame. It might make him more sensitive to the plight of people who have real problems instead of imagined ones.

April 28 The World, Coos Bay, Ore., on baseball: It's going to be interesting to see whether professional baseball collapses under its own greed or survives to maintain its place as America's favorite game of summer. Fresh on the heels of the ... strike-lockout this spring comes news that television viewers across the nation are going to be short on chances to watch their favorite games this summer. ... (T)he Saturday Game of the Week, an American tradition as deep as hot dogs and Cracker Jacks, is gone. It was murdered in the crossfire of a corporate bidding shoot-out between NBC and CBS. The winner, CBS, plans to give sports fans only 16 games this season _ and it might have been only eight if the public hadn't complained. ... How long can baseball survive with fans who can only see occasional games on regular TV or cable TV, or have to shell out lots of money for a satellite system, or have to find time for long-distance travel to a game? Baseball has been a game of the common man _ a slow summer respite from the busy American lifestyle. Its history is one of being open to all; exclusivity has never been a factor. But greed seems to be leading baseball astray.

April 27 The Journal Times, Racine, Wis., on the America's Cup: Perhaps it was appropriate that the final decision on the winner of the America's Cup, the Super Bowl of sailing, was made in a courtroom far removed from the sea. It epitomized the fact that the America's Cup has been made a mockery as a premier sailing event and _ like so many other sports _ has become primarily a legal exercise. For the record, the New York ... Court (of Appeals), sitting in Albany, awarded the America's Cup to the San Diego Yacht Club, in effect ruling that the catamaran used in the last races was not an illegal craft. The appeal of the San Diego Yacht Club victory had been filed by the loser, New Zealand's Mercury Bay Club. The race was sailed in September 1988 and the outcome has been filling lawyers' pockets ever since. So San Diego has the cup and we can look forward to another America's Cup race in 1992. Supposedly, possession of the Cup is vital to a city because it means millions of dollars in revenue to the host city during the races. But we can't help wondering if the legal skirmishes, and the ruling which pretty well opens the race to virtually any kind of vessel, haven't severely tarnished the cup. We won't be surprised if, when 1992 comes around, many sailing enthusiasts simply shrug and say, as we are tempted to, ``who cares?''
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Reed Reportedly Saw British and Irish Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from Keenan's family, Runcie. Pickup 5th, `In interviews...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Hostages-Reed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with quotes
DOC.TEXT: Freed U.S. hostage Frank Reed says he recently saw Briton John McCarthy and Irishman Brian Keenan in captivity and they were well, the Friends of John McCarthy said today. Reed telephoned McCarthy's father, Pat McCarthy, and his friend, Jill Morrell, today and, according to the members of the group, told them: ``They are both well. They have some minor health problems. They exercise daily and read voraciously.'' ``Mr. Reed said John had grown a beard and keeps fit by performing squat thrusts and press-ups (push-ups), and as far as his captors could be they are quite good. He is not being tortured,'' said Joan Willows, a spokeswoman for the Friends of John McCarthy. She said Reed, who was freed on Monday, last saw McCarthy and Keenan on Saturday. Keenan's sister, Elaine Spence, said: ``I don't think the gut feeling can be expressed. It is one of the happiest days you could have. It makes us more determined to fight to eventually, hopefully, to get Brian released.'' His other sister, Brenda Gillam, said: ``It is the best hope we have had in the whole four years'' since Keenan was kidnapped. Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie said Reed had no news of his envoy, Terry Waite, 50, who disappeared Jan. 20, 1987, after leaving his Beirut hotel to negotiate the release of hostages. No group has claimed to be holding Waite. ``Even though Mr. Reed appears to have no direct news of Terry Waite, I am encouraged both by the release of the two American hostages and by the good news of Brian Keenan and John McCarthy,'' Runcie said in a statement. In interviews with BBC TV and radio, Ms. Morrell said Reed told her McCarthy was kept blindfolded most of the time, but that he ``was getting news about the campaign (for his release) and was getting the messages that we put to him in the newspaper in Beirut.'' ``It's just the best thing I've heard in four years. It's amazing,'' she said. McCarthy, 33, a journalist for the London-based Worldwide Television News agency, WTN, was kidnapped April 17, 1986, as he drove to Beirut Airport to leave Lebanon. Keenan, 39, is from Belfast in British-ruled Northern Ireland. An English language teacher at the American University in Beirut, he disappeared while walking to work April 11, 1986. He is a dual Anglo-Irish national, and was traveling on an Irish passport. No group has claimed to be holding either man. Another McCarthy supporter, Catherine Comerford, said Reed had been with the two ``for quite some time, I'm not sure exactly how long... he says that John is fit and well, and able to walk about and do press-ups, have a bit of exercise, so he seems to be in good shape. ``It is fantastic news. We've waited so long to hear anything as concrete as this so obviously we're over the moon.'' Ms. Morrell said she had spoken to the British Foreign Office about the news and hoped the British government would now talk to the Syrian and Iranian governments about releasing the hostages. ``If they (Britain) didn't know it before, then they certainly know it now, that this is the way to go.'' Britain has no diplomatic relations with Syria and Iran and says it will do no deals for the release of the Britons missing in Lebanon. Jack Mann, 75, an ex-pilot, has been missing in west Beirut since May 12 last year. A group called the Cells of Armed Struggle claimed that day to have kidnapped a Briton, but did not name him. Alec Collett, 68, a New York-based journalist was kidnapped March 25, 1985. The Revolutionary Organization of Socialist Moslems, believed linked to the Abu Nidal Palestinian terrorist group, claimed to have executed him in April 1986 but no body was found.

DOC.HEAD: Conference on `Curing' Homosexuality Through Sports And Therapy Draws Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to add when conference is scheduled.
DOC.TEXT: A conference on curing homosexuality through sports and therapy has drawn fire from some health professionals and gay activists who say homosexuality cannot cured because it is not a disease. The Utah chapter of the National Association of Social Workers voted 6-5 last week not to allow social workers who attend the conference to receive academic ``continuing education'' credit for doing so. The conference is set for Friday and Saturday. Evergreen Foundation, a group describing itself as a non-profit organization of former homosexuals and friends, is sponsoring the event. Evergreen president Alan Seegmiller, a licensed clinical social worker, said organizers believe homosexuality is caused by ``a gender inferiority complex originating in early childhood'' that can be turned around if a homosexual wants to change. But psychiatrist R. Jan Stout said the American Psychiatric Association dropped homosexuality as a mental disorder in 1973. ``No one knows the causes of homosexuality, but biological factors seem to be the most important, whether you're homosexual or heterosexual,'' Stout said. ``Most professionals have a consensus view that psychological and social factors don't cause homosexuality.'' ``We no longer talk about treatments or cures for homosexuality,'' said Stout. ``Homosexuals can change behavior sometimes through will power but that doesn't change their sexual orientation.'' Robert Austin, Utah AIDS Foundation, said homosexuals will explain their concerns during registration sessions, but they won't be disruptive. ``You don't change people's minds by stopping discussions,'' he said. Seegmiller said his group has no scientific studies to back up the group's program ``because we're more interested in helping people.'' He said he knows of at least six individuals who changed their sexual preference from participating. Seegmiller said the group advocates therapy to deal with ``healing the inner child of the past.'' The organization also sponsors activities traditionally associated with men, such as basketball and softball. ``The men learn skills that enable them to participate in athletic games they never learned before,'' said Seegmiller. ``Some have found it helpful to seek training in automobile mechanics, whatever they feel is a deficient in their role that seems helpful to them.''

DOC.HEAD: 1940s Cowboy Movie Star Dies at 63
DOC.TEXT: Sunset Carson, a 1940s cowboy movie hero, died one day after winning a settlement in a 3-year-old lawsuit over money earned from some of his old pictures. He was 63. Carson died Tuesday at Washoe Medical Center after apparently suffering a heart attack in his room at the Ponderosa Hotel. Carson, who was a rodeo star at age 17, appeared in more than 40 westerns, including ``Bandits of the Badlands,'' ``Oregon Trail'' and ``Bells of Rosarita.'' In 1978, he created a series of 78 classic westerns featuring himself and other stars like Ken Maynard and Roy Rogers. He filed suit in 1987 complaining that South Carolina Educational Television Producers Inc. and Ken Heard Releasing Inc. helped in the production and distribution of the ``Six Gun Heroes'' series but had not paid him for video cassette sales and promotional materials sold on the show since 1982. Carson's Reno attorney, Larry Dunn, said the lawsuit was settled out of court in Carson's favor Monday. Dunn would not give a money amount. Carson had spent recent years crusading against drugs and violence, and sex and language in movies and on television. He is survived by his wife, Jeanne, a son and a daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Lafontaine Released From Hospital
DOC.TEXT: West German opposition leader Oskar Lafontaine was released from the hospital Wednesday, one week after a woman stabbed him in the neck during an election rally. ``My first thanks go to all those people who helped me get over the attack,'' Lafontaine, the 46-year-old Social Democratic candidate for chancellor, told reporters when he left the University Clinic in Cologne. The woman who stabbed Lafontaine, Adelheid Streidel, has been sent to a psychiatric clinic. Officials said she has had a history of mental disorders. Lafontaine, governor of Saarland state, said he would continue his recuperation at home and would not resume his duties until later. Doctors said Lafontaine's wound was healing well but urged him not to work until he is fully recovered. Lafontaine plans to challenge Chancellor Helmut Kohl in West Germany's federal elections in December.

DOC.HEAD: Police Begin Investigation of Deadly Gambling Feud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-8 pvs, bgng `Gov. Mario...' with 7 grafs to UPDATE with governor saying National Guardsmen provided support but did not enter reservation; other details. Picks up 9th graf, `Garrant said...' ^LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: State police sealed off a Mohawk reservation to outsiders and posted officers to keep the peace today after two Indians were shot to death in a 9-month-old battle over casino gambling. The slayings were the first fatalities in the dispute that has torn apart the 14,000-member reservation with gunfire and arson. Up to 600 Mohawks fled to a refugee center in Ontario last week after a week of nightly violence. ``We're trying to maintain some type of stability,'' state police Capt. Richard Garrant said today. ``We're trying to ease some of the tension.'' Early Tuesday, 22-year-old Matthew Pyke, a casino opponent, was slain while walking in the reservation in Snye, Quebec, during a gun battle between pro- and anti-gambling factions. The reservation straddles the U.S.-Canadian border. Later Tuesday, J.R. Edwards, 30, a member of the pro-gambling Warriors Society, was found dead next to his house, not far from where Pyke was shot. In response, Gov. Mario Cuomo sent more than 100 state police troopers to escort 95 to 100 Canadian police through the New York section of the reservation. At a late morning news conference, Cuomo said he has also ordered National Guard troops to be on standby. Canadian military and some New York National Guard units provided support services Tuesday night, but ``no military force was used,'' Cuomo said. Asked why he was not sending the National Guard onto the U.S. portion of the reservation, Cuomo said: ``My position is we will not send in the military force because of the risk of bloodshed.'' Cuomo said one of his aides, Henrick Dullea, was en route to the reservation to meet with Mohawk leaders, Cuomo said. Negotiations to settle the dispute could begin as early as next week, he said. Late Tuesday, police sealed off all roads leading onto the reservation but later permitted residents to enter on the condition they stay in their homes. Garrant said an unspecified number of troopers would remain stationed throughout the reservation until formal negotiations between the governor's office and the Indians begin. ``The whole community is being held hostage,'' said Diane Lazores, spokeswoman for the Warrior Society. She said hundreds of troopers were stationed in the reservation and were not allowing Indians to move about. She said people weren't allowed back on the the reservation to deliver food. ``We have a hundred people here who haven't eaten in 18 hours,'' she said. Garrant denied Lazores' accusations. ``They say a lot of things,'' he said. Although there have been nightly confrontations between Indian factions, including a hand grenade attack on a Mohawk police station last week that injured three people, state police have seldom entered the reservation. Police had treated the dispute as an internal matter. Some Indian leaders consider the reservation sovereign territory over which only Mohawks have law enforcement powers. ``Thousands of rounds go off every night here,'' said Rudy Hart, who owns a duty-free store on the reservation. ``It got to the point where people thought somebody had to die. Nobody's willing to compromise. They won't give in.'' The issue of gambling on the reservation has been at the center of escalating violence since last summer, when an FBI-led gambling raid triggered a 12-day standoff between a pro-gambling group and state police. The FBI had claimed the Mohawks had violated federal gaming regulations; the Mohawks claim they are not bound by state or federal gambling laws. Pro-gambling forces say the reservation's six casinos, which draw busloads of patrons from the Northeast with their slot machines, craps tables and other games, are an economic boon. Opponents argue they encourage prostitution and drug use and threaten traditional ways. Anti-gamblers blamed the Warriors Society, an armed group, for the first slaying and said Cuomo had let the situation get out of hand. ``After my house has been shot at and two deaths, now is the time for the governor to get off of his fingers,'' said Barbara Montour. ``Governor Cuomo finally woke up and realized that there are some grave afflictions here,'' said Barbara Barnes, a spokeswoman for the anti-gambling faction. Minnie Garrow, answering calls at the Warriors' headquarters, denied the group was responsible for the slaying and added, ``We feel badly about the loss of life.'' Last summer, a mob of angry anti-gamblers burned down a casino. Sporadic shootings and other violence were reported in the fall and winter, but tensions mounted in March when gambling opponents blockaded roads leading to the reservation to keep outsiders away from the high-stakes casinos. Last week pro-gamblers tore down the blockades in a hail of gunfire. The first injuries came Thursday when one of the barricade leaders was beaten and suffered a fractured skull.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Committee Approves Democratic-proposed $l.2-Trillion Budget
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf, The package..., to change vote total after votes by 2 late arriving senators; SUBS 3rd graf, The proposal..., to note that negotiations are possible
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Budget Committee today adopted a Democratic-proposed $1.2-trillion budget for 1991 that cuts defense spending $9.9 billion below what President Bush wants. The package was adopted on a vote of 14-9, with all of the committee's Democrats joined by a single Republican _ Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, in voting for the measure. The proposal mirrors the plan passed by the Democratic-controlled House Tuesday. Both packages are seen by many lawmakers as a prelude to possible negotiations between the White House and the Democratic majorities in Congress on a spending plan for the next fiscal year. Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., said the budget would address ``a new era in which economic vitality will be the true measure of strength of the nation, rather than just solely military strength.'' The proposal would set defense spending at $293.9 billion in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. That is $9.9 billion less than the figure Bush has proposed and about $2 billion below this year's spending. The proposal claims to reduce next year's deficit by $43 billion by taking credit for $13 billion in defense cuts, $13.9 billion in new tax revenues, and $6.2 billion in new user fees and other receipts. The growth of benefit programs such as Medicare would be slowed by $5.6 billion while other domestic and foreign aid efforts would be cut by $3.5 billion. The Senate action came a day after the House adopted its own Democratic-written budget on a party-line vote that also attacks Bush's defense programs. With all 174 voting Republicans oposing the package, the House adopted its own $1.24 trillion spending plan on a 218-208 vote. The plan's key contrast with Bush's proposal was its defense figure: $295.5 billion, $8.3 billion less than the president. It also spent more for social programs than the president requested. Republicans accused Democrats of forcing through a plan that excessively weakens American military power. ``All you have to do is say, `I'm really mad about Lithuania and I'll prove it. I'm going to gut the Navy,''' said Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the No. 2 House GOP leader. But Democrats said their proposal merely acknowledged the obvious: the Cold War has eased and it is time for the government to focus on domestic issues. ``The key problems we face as a nation are addressed in this budget,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. After the vote, Democratic leaders said they viewed their budget as a strong bargaining position for future talks with the Senate and the administration. Foley, House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., and others conceded that negotiations with the administration will be needed for the budget's priorities to be translated into future spending and tax laws. The budget merely maps the government's fiscal plans. The House-passed package claims to slice $36 billion off the deficit, relying on defense cuts, $13.9 billion in new taxes and other savings. This allows it to meet the Gramm-Rudman law's requirement of a 1991 deficit of no more than $64 billion. Meanwhile, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney ordered a review of 207 military projects for possible cancellation. He complained that some members of Congress ``want to cut the defense budget even as they plead to save the projects in their own states and districts.'' Cheney also extended a worldwide freeze on military construction projects _ affecting $7 billion in new contracts _ until June 15.

DOC.HEAD: Rival Christian Forces Shell Passenger Ferries
DOC.TEXT: Maronite Catholic religious leaders appealed for a maritime cease-fire Wednesday as rival Christian forces fired on passenger ferries near each other's ports. Police said no casualties were reported in the latest round of fighting. The ferries, which operate out of Cyprus, provide the only regular link to the outside world for Christians trapped in their 310-square-mile enclave north of Beirut, which is ringed by hostile Syrian troops and their mainly Moslem militia allies. On Wednesday, rebel troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces militia led by Samir Geagea continued their maritime battle, the latest flareup in their 3-month-old power struggle for control of the Christian enclave. A police spokesman said an armed speedboat manned by Lebanese Forces militiamen intercepted the Virgin Butterly, a hydrofoil ferry, before dawn Wednesday off of Aoun's only sea outlet, the makeshift port of Dbaye, seven miles north of Beirut. The spokesman, who cannot be identified under existing regulations, said the militiamen did not try to seize the hydrofoil, but fired warning shots from a 14.5mm machine gun to prevent it from heading for Aoun's port. The spokesman said the Virgin Butterfly was not hit by the gunfire, but sailed back to the Cyprian port of Larnaca. Aoun's gunners responded by shelling another ferry, the Sunny Boat, as it waited to pick up passengers in the Geagea-controlled port of Jounieh, five miles north of Dbaye. The Sunny Boat raced for the open sea as shells exploded in the water around it, the police spokesman said. There were no reports that the ship had been hit. The maritime fighting has flared up since Geagea imposed a naval blockade April 23 on the three-mile stretch of coast controlled by Aoun in a bid to prevent seaborne supplies of weapons and ammunition from reaching the general's forces. Geagea's militia, with 6,000 fighters and 30,000 reservists, has one gunboat and about 20 speedboats armed with machine guns and rocket launchers. Aoun's 19,000-man army lost most of its naval force when Geagea's forces seized the naval base at Jounieh in February. The general has two crippled gunboats trapped near Dbaye. The ferry attacks prompted Maronite Catholic religious leaders to seek a maritime cease-fire. To that end, Bulos Naaman, former head of the Order of Maronite Monks, met with Aoun and planned to see Geagea later, radio stations reported. Naaman refused to comment to reporters after his meeting with Aoun. By police count, 920 people have been killed and 2,448 wounded since Jan. 30 when the inconclusive battle began between Geagea's militia and Aoun's troops, the worst conflict between Christians in Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Aoun has refused to recognize the Syrian-backed government of President Elias Hrawi, objecting to the 40,000 Syrian troops in Lebanon. Geagea supports the Hrawi government. On Wednesday, the rival Christian forces dueled with howitzers and mortars in east Beirut and Kesrouan Province to the north. But the fighting did not spread to the shell-shattered resort town of Kleiat in the mountains northeast of Beirut where civilians have staged a sit-in under a huge tent in the main square to protest further violence. The sit-in began Tuesday evening after the expiration of an 81-hour cease-fire called by the Maronite church to allow local townspeople to salvage what was left of their property.

DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles Mayor Proposes Water Rationing; Surcharge for Excess Use
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Tom Bradley today proposed a water rationing program that would require citizens to cut water use 10 percent below 1986 levels to cope with the fourth year of drought in California. The measures Bradley has asked the City Council in the nation's second largest city to adopt include penalties in the form of surcharges for excess water use, and hiring of more Department of Water and Power employees if needed to enforce the cutbacks. The mayor proposes to change the city's five-phase drought ordinance. The city has been in phase 1 _ voluntary water conservation _ since 1988, but there has been little compliance. Modifications to phase 2, which requires mandatory conservation, include: a recommended $3 surcharge per billing unit plus 15 percent of the water bill; allowing DWP to assess penalties for chronic violators and installation of flow restricters and service shutoff; having customers use 1986 as the base year for determining at what level each household will conserve water. Under existing law a City Council resolution is needed to implement the penalty aspects of the ordinance. The Bradley plan was outlined today in a statement from the mayor's office prior to a news conference at City Hall. Last month, Bradley called for a voluntary 10 percent cutback in water use. But he told reporters on Monday that ``the public has not gotten the message,'' and said he was determined to ``go forward with a water-rationing program.'' A plan involving possible fines for violators would mark the most drastic step yet to confront a water shortage estimated at 10 percent by the regional Metropolitan Water District. ``This may well set the tone'' for Southern California, said Carl Boronkay, MWD general manager. ``I think the mayor is taking a leadership position.'' The MWD supplies 60 percent of all water to Los Angeles and the six-county area stretching from the Mexican border to Ventura County. Like other agencies, its water supplies have been reduced by the fourth consecutive year of drought in California. City water officials have said it could take several months to get a rationing plan rolling.

DOC.HEAD: Census Counters Spread Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs to CORRECT that 374, sted 484, districts remain
DOC.TEXT: The door-to-door portion of the 1990 census spreads out to the nation's smaller cities and towns Thursday. Census workers who began their household count in 110 larger cities April 26 are expanding to the remaining 374 census districts across the country, according to bureau spokesman Ray Bancroft. Only about 63 percent of the nation's households have returned census forms mailed in late March. The bureau had hoped for a 70 percent response and the shortfall will raise the price of the count by millions of dollars because of the expanded door-to-door effort. The national count every 10 years is required by the Constitution for use in reapportioning seats in the House of Representatives. The figures also are used to apportion seats in state legislatures and divide hundreds of billions of dollars in federal and state aid. Minority groups say past counts have missed more poor and minorities than whites and higher income people. Lower educational and income levels, larger household sizes and the more frequent presence of distant relatives in households are major factors in these undercounts, population analyst David J. Fein said in Demography, the journal of the Population Association of America. Fein, of Abt Associates in Bethesda, Md., estimated that as many as 15 percent of Puerto Ricans, 12 percent of blacks and 9 percent of Mexican Americans were omitted in the 1980 census. Census Bureau figures were lower than that, but the agency did estimate that while it missed about 1.4 percent of all Americans the rate may have been as high as 6 percent for young black men. The possibility of adjusting the 1990 figures to account for this undercount has been proposed and debated by politicians and statisticians. The Commerce Department, parent agency of the Census Bureau, has said it is trying to do a complete count and will consider adjustment only after the basic census effort is done. A coalition of cities and interest groups has filed suit against the bureau seeking to force a statistical adjustment of the final census figures. Forms for millions of Americans were delayed by addressing mistakes, while millions of others simply haven't mailed theirs back. The problems, including large apartment buiildings and whole blocks and small towns seemingly overlooked, have drawn heavy criticism for the census bureau. In the last few decades the system of mailing census questionnaires and asking people to return them has become common practice. It replaced the traditional, but labor-intensive process of having someone visit every home. Now, the door-to-door count is reserved for sparsely populated areas and follow-up on people who don't answer by mail. Originally expected to cost $1.3 billion this year, the price of counting Americans could well increase by $180 million or more, according to congressional sources. In rural areas, which were not included in the mailed portion of the count, personal visits by census takers have been going on since March.

DOC.HEAD: Former HUD Official Says Bush's Office Helped Get 1985 HUD Grant
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 5th graf pvs, Gilliam said... to CORRECT spelling of Barreto
DOC.TEXT: A former federal housing official, who admits taking bribes, testified today that a federal HUD grant was arranged for a project after its developer appealed to then-Vice President George Bush. DuBois L. Gilliam, an imprisoned former deputy assistant secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, resumed testimony today about scandals at HUD and described in detail how officials there steered projects to political friends, including members of Congress. Gilliam, who is serving an 18-month federal prison sentence, was testifying under a court grant of immunity from further prosecution. Under questioning by Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., chairman of the House panel investigating HUD, Gilliam said HUD officials engaged in a grant swap in order to provide $500,000 requested in 1985 to conduct a feasibility study for a Hispanic trade center in Kansas City, Mo. Gilliam said that Hector Barreto, then president of the U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, sought a HUD grant for the project, but that he first told Barreto it was not qualified under Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr.'s discretionary fund for special projects. He said he got a call that afternoon from Deborah Gore Dean, assistant to Pierce, saying Barreto had met with Bush and that ``she had received a call from the vice president's staff asking about the grant, and indicated her desire to try to help get the project funded.'' As a result, Gilliam said, he persuaded a Kansas City assistant city manager to provide the grant from the city's Community Development Block Grant funds, provided by HUD, and that in turn he arranged to have a special grant go to Kansas City to replace that money. ``In other words, let's make a deal _ you do this and I'll do this,'' Gilliam said. He did not name the person in the vice president's office. Gilliam said he was unclear about the connection to Bush's office, but said Dean had ``indicated something ... about Mr. Barreto going on the vice president's plane.'' Lantos, before the meeting, described the case this way: ``We will hear testimony from Mr. Gilliam about special projects _ how a particular project was funded at the request of `someone' in the office of the vice president, in order to get a Hispanic leader to accompany the then-vice president on a plane trip to Puerto Rico.'' Once a trusted assistant to Pierce during the Reagan administration, Gilliam painted a picture of rampant political abuse at the agency during his initial appearance before the House Governmental Operations subcommittee on employment and housing. His second round of testimony involved so-called HUD ``special project'' grants, which were made from the secretary's discretionary fund. The program was established to provide aid in cases of natural disasters and other unexpected needs, without a competitive application process. Subcommittee staff director Stuart Weisberg said before today's hearing that although the money was administered at the secretary's discretion, political use of the fund would constitute an abuse. ``Discretion does not mean political,'' Weisberg said. ``There was no intent (by Congress) that it be treated like a political action committee ... to reward political friends.'' On Monday, Gilliam disputed Pierce's assertion before the panel last year and in a subsequent magazine interview that he didn't decide who got federal grants and was a hands-off administrator. Gilliam said Pierce himself ordered federal grants for particular projects. He said Pierce kept notes of which members of Congress and political friends supported projects, which he used when funding decisions were made. His testimony was the first by a top HUD insider in more than a year of investigation by the panel into allegations of fraud, influence-peddling and political favoritism at the department. Gilliam pleaded guilty to felony charges of accepting illegal gratuities while at HUD and conspiring to manipulate a housing grant to benefit friends. Pierce's attorneys attacked Gilliam's testimony as motivated by a desire for early release from prison. Attorney Paul L. Perito accused Lantos' subcommittee of an ``insatiable appetite for publicity.'' Gilliam's testimony was not the first time Bush's name has arisen indirectly in the HUD scandal. A former New York regional official of HUD, Alexander Naclerio, testified last fall that he had been sent by HUD officials to visit and facilitate funding of a Puerto Rico project proposed for a federal grant and that he understood that its developer, Delio Rojo, was a prominent backer of Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Counselors Assigned to Classrooms as Third Suicide Reported
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with quote from superintendent, student body president today; picks up 11th graf pvs, `In addition...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LR3 of May 1
DOC.TEXT: Parents and teen-agers cried and held hands and counselors were placed on 24-hour call as a shocked community attempted to recover from the apparent suicides of three high school students in two days. Counselors were assigned to every classroom at Sheridan High School today after a 17-year-old was found dead of a gunshot wound Tuesday. On Monday, two of his classmates shot themselves to death. One of them killed himself in front of a history class after professing his love for a girl. Scott Stamper, 16, said the latest suicide shook up most students. ``People who didn't even know him were crying,'' he said. ``It was quiet. I walked in school today and saw zombies.'' ``I can't tell you how tough it's been,'' school Superintendent David Robinson said. Lisa Deal, 18, a senior and president of the student council, said the mood at the campus was better today. But, she said, the community still has a long way to go. ``It's scary knowing your friends ... would go to these extremes,'' she said. Ms. Deal said she was an acquaintance the two students who died Monday. The body of the latest victim, Jerry Paul McCool, a 17-year-old sophomore, was discovered in his home by his father Tuesday. His family said they thought the shooting was accidental, but Lt. Lenard Lewis of the Saline County sheriff's office said the county coroner, Sam Ballard, and other officials believe McCool's death was a suicide. The state medical examiner's office was expected to make a formal ruling later today. ``The mother, talking to the neighbors, was a little upset and said it was an accident and he was cleaning his gun,'' Lewis said. ``There wasn't anything there to indicate he was cleaning his gun. Everything appears it was suicide. The family doesn't want to accept it.'' Hours after the shooting, parents and students packed the school's 1,000-seat auditorium to discuss the suicides. Some held hands. Some cried. Robinson said school would go on because routine is important ``when things begin to crumble. They need something to hang on to.'' Today, he said that meetings this morning between students and counselors were helping calm the situation because the students ``were able to express their feelings.'' In addition to calling in counselors, school officials also handed out a list of phone numbers for nearly three dozen counselors and faculty members on call around the clock. ``Our community and our school is just in the middle of a tremendous tragedy that we're all trying to deal with and get a handle on and improve,'' Robinson said. McCool's death was the fourth suicide in little more than a month by high school students in the community of about 3,000, about 25 miles south of Little Rock. A 17-year-old killed himself March 28, authorities said. ``It's just too much for a town like this. This is something you hear about in a big city,'' said Ethel Sanders, a police clerk. Police said the two students who died Monday had at least one class together and had been friends for years. Thomas Smith, 17, shot himself after declaring his love for a girl. Thomas M. Chidester, 19, was killed by a shot to the head late Monday. Lewis said McCool knew the other boys but was not in any of their classes. He had spoken with his father about the boys' suicides. ``His Dad said he said something like, `How could somebody do that? Why would they do it?''' Lewis said. McCool had stayed home from school Tuesday, complaining of pain from a hernia operation two weeks ago, Lewis said. The boy was at school Monday when Smith killed himself but wasn't in the classroom where the shooting occurred. Sheriff Cary Clark said the deaths of Chidester and Smith appeared connected. Both teen-agers participated in the school's junior Reserve Officers' Training Corps and were classmates for several years. Chidester's body was found Tuesday by his grandmother, who lived with him. He apparently died Monday night, leaving a note that read, ``I can't go on any longer,'' Clark said. The grandmother told police that Chidester was upset that he couldn't get to Smith after the shooting. Police and teachers held him back, Clark said. ``It's not a police problem. It's not a school problem. It's a community problem,'' said Police Chief David Hooks, ``and we've all got to stick together.''

DOC.HEAD: Subcommittee Votes to Raise Penalty-Free Earnings Limit
DOC.TEXT: A House Ways and Means subcommittee voted Wednesday to allow people aged 65 through 69 to earn more money without losing any of their Social Security benefits. A bill approved by the Social Security subcommittee also includes a provision removing the Social Security Administration from the Department of Health and Human Services and creating it as an independent agency. That provision is opposed by the Bush administration. The legislation also would require the Social Security Administration to improve telephone access to local offices. The administration cut local telephone service last year, preferring to rely on a nationwide toll-free number for most beneficiary problems. The proposed increase in the amount Social Security recipients may earn without losing benefits is considerably less generous than tax-writing committees of the House and Senate approved last year. Congressional Republicans have made outright repeal of the earnings limitation a top goal, contending it reduces incentives for older Americans to work. Present law allows a person aged 65 through 69 to earn up to $9,360 this year without penalty. Each $3 earned above that amount reduces Social Security benefits by $1. An automatic inflation adjustment built into the law will raise the limit to $9,960 next year and to $10,440 in 1992. The bill approved without dissent by the subcommittee would raise the figures to $10,200 in 1991 and $10,920 in 1992. The bill makes no change in the $6,840 earnings limit on people under age 65. Neither does it affect those 70 or older; they could continue to earn an unlimited amount without losing any Social Security benefit.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Attacks Wind Down in San Salvador
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with attacks fading today, guerrilla statement, rebels still willing to hold with peace talks. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas dynamited power stations and attacked strategic targets in the capital early today to protest human rights violations they blame on the armed forces. The attacks began shortly before midnight Tuesday and faded after several hours of pre-dawn fighting. The armed forces said it suffered five dead and six wounded, and that 12 civilians were also wounded. Half the city was without electricity and automatic weapons fire and explosions ripped through several neighborhoods, including the wealthy Escalon district. Rebels had dynamited five high-voltage utility towers and a power plant on nearby San Salvador volcano, the privately owned YSKL radio station reported. There was no fighting in the capital during the morning, but skirmishing was reported in several areas outside the capital, including the town of Ilobasco, 40 miles to the northeast. No casualty figures were available. The attacks were a protest of ``the total immunity that exists in this country for members of the armed forces who violate human rights,'' the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front guerrillas said in a statement sent by fascimile. The statement cited the ``stalled investigation and evident cover-up of the intellectual authors of the crime against the Jesuits,'' referring to the killings of six Jesuit priests at Central American University in November. President Alfredo Cristiani has admitted the six priests, including the university rector, were killed by members of the armed forces, but critics have said the investigation should go farther. One high officer, Col. Guillermo Benavides, has been charged in the killings of the Jesuits, along with three lieutenants and five soldiers. Despite years of death-squad killings, no officer has ever been convicted in a human rights-related crime. The House Foreign Affairs committee voted last week to cut U.S. military aid to El Salvador in half from $85 million. The other half would be cut if the government fails to properly investigate the Jesuit killings or negotiate in good faith with the guerrillas. The attacks also appeared timed to coincide with the scheduled start of preliminary peace talks today. Indirect preliminary talks were to begin today between Cristiani's rightist government and the guerrillas. A presidential spokesman said a representative of U.N. General-Secretary Javier Perez de Cuellar was expected to arrive today to act as a go-between in setting up an agenda and arranging other details for the negotiations. The guerrilla statement said they were still disposed to ``continue with the negotiating process.'' The first guerrilla attack _ on the power line towers _ began at about 10 p.m. Tuesday, hours after about 40,000 people attended a huge May Day rally organized by labor unions and opposition parties to criticize Cristiani's economic austerity program and urge peace talks. At the peaceful rally, militant leftists joined the moderate Christian Democrats whom Cristiani succeeded in one of the largest opposition protests in a decade. Guerrillas shot it out with government soldiers near the hotel in Escalon where Americans had been trapped for a time during the November offensive and the gunfight spilled over into the Tasumal neighborhood, residents there said. Attempts to negotiate an end to the war ended in deadlock in 1984 and 1985, and a series of direct talks began shortly after Cristiani was sworn in as president in July. They broke off as a result of the monthlong November offensive. More than 72,000 people have been killed, most of them civilians, since the war began in October 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Mecham Campaign Office Damaged By Arson Fire
DOC.TEXT: Someone set former Gov. Evan Mecham's campaign headquarters on fire this morning, causing an estimated $35,000 in damage, officials said. ``It's very suspicious the fact that nobody was around when we got here. It's definitely not electrical,'' Glendale Fire Capt. Kevin Pool said. ``We're calling it arson.'' Mecham, a Republican who was removed from office by impeachment conviction two years ago, said he doubted there was a political connection. ``I don't think we can draw any conclusions of that kind at all,'' Mecham said. ``It was arson, but there has been a couple of houses set on fire out here in northwest Phoenix,'' he added. In April 1988, the state Senate convicted Mecham of obstructing an investigation of a death threat against an aide and of loaning his auto dealership $80,000 from a protocol fund. His removal from the governorship after less than 1{ years in office capped one of the stormiest tenures in Arizona history. He is now attempting to make a political comeback. He said the quick work of firefighters limited interior damage, although there was heavy damage to the roof of the 7,300-square-foot building, his former residence. Investigators said three spots outside the building had been blackened, indicating three starting points for the fire. There was no evidence of burglary, police said. A newspaper carrier for The Arizona Republic spotted smoke near the entrance of the structure about 3:15 a.m., Pool said. Firefighters had the blaze under control by 4 a.m. The property, appraised at about $500,00 by a real estate information service, faces foreclosure unless Mecham works out a settlement with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. An auction on the property is set for May 18. Mecham said he had no idea who would want to burn his headquarters, which also is home of FAZPAC, a political action committee, and MP Press, a publishing arm of Mecham's campaign. He called the arson a minor setback and predicted that his sixth campaign for governor would rebound. He ran unsuccessfully four times before winning the office in November 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Veterans Department Open to Review of Agent Orange Findings
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Veterans Affairs opened the door Wednesday to independent scrutinity of its effort to determine whether there is a link between exposure to Agent Orange and a variety of diseases. The offer follows years of challenges to the credibility of the VA, Centers for Disease Control and the Defense Department. Critics have charged the government with ignoring the scientific evidence of a connection between exposure and cancers and other diseases. The offer came during testimony by VA Deputy Secretary Anthony J. Principi before a House Veterans Affairs subcommittee. Principi told the subcommittee on compensation, pension and insurance that the department would agree to a review by the National Academy of Sciences, to having its own panel of outside scientific advisers enlarged, or to subjecting its work to outside review. Two Agent Orange compensation bills pending in Congress call for establishment of a scientific review procedure through the National Academy, an independent group of scientists that advises the government. ``Should Congress conclude that the process would be lent credibility by our consulting with additional outside experts ... we would be pleased to do so if that kind of consultation would not unduly delay our progress,'' Principi said. But Principi also asked the subcommittee to put off consideration of a compensation bill. The bill would award service-connected disability payments to Vietnam War veterans who contend they suffer due to exposure from one of four kinds of cancer or from a skin disease known as chloracne. The bill would also pave the way to compensation for other ailments as the evidence comes in. Principi asked that the law be held in abeyance until the VA comes up with final regulations Oct. 1 on who should be compensated and for what diseases. Those regulations depend in part on the recommendations of VA's Advisory Committee on Environmental Hazards, a 15-member panel of scientists and lay persons. The committee meets later this month. Veterans Affairs Secretary Edward J. Derwinski has appointed his personal adviser on the Agent Orange issue, retired Adm. Elmo Zumwalt, to fill a vacancy on the committee. Zumwalt ordered spraying of Agent Orange during Vietnam and also lost a son who served in Vietnam to cancer. ``We have, I believe, more than demonstrated our good faith,'' Principi said, saying the VA set its course a year ago when it decided against appealing a federal judge's order that it draft new Agent Orange regulations. But the House sponsor of the compensation bill, Rep. Lane Evans, D-Ill., suggested the VA was trying to further postpone delivering benefits to veterans. There is no guarantee the department will decide to award compensation in its final rules. ``I think you are proceeding on a good-faith basis, but I believe the veterans who suffer from Agent Orange can't wait,'' he said. Evans' bill would compensate exposed veterans who suffer from non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, soft-tissue sarcoma, melanoma, and basal cell carcinoma, as well as chloracne. The measure is expected to cost $89 million a year. About 35,000 veterans have filed claims asserting a connection between exposure to Agent Orange and a host of ailments. Only a handful of benefits have been granted, for those suffering chloracne. Dioxin, labeled by the Environmental Protection Agency as a ``probable human carcinogen,'' is suspected as the primary but not the only ingredient causing ailments among veterans exposed to Agent Orange.

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin to Apologize for 1832 Massacre of Sac and Fox Indians
DOC.TEXT: For years, only a plain, iron historical marker has stood at the site of the 1832 Bad Axe Massacre, where hundreds of Indian warriors, women and children were chased into the Mississippi River and shot. Now, the state, facing unrest over relations with the Chippewa, is apologizing to the Sac and Fox Indian Nation, who according to one historian endured ``one of the bloodiest tragedies in the sad history of American-Indian relations.'' The apology, to be issued Saturday, finally ``recognizes the mistakes of the past,'' said Sister Toni Harris, a Roman Catholic nun and member of the Indian rights group Honor Our Neighbors Origins and Rights. ``If we recognize what was done in the past, we make different choices for the future,'' Ms. Harris said. ``A failure to recognize, whether it's the Holocaust or other kinds of abominations of people against people, only threatens the possibility of repeating those abominations.'' HONOR, based in Milwaukee, urged the Legislature last year to pass the resolution formally apologizing for the Army's action on Aug. 1-2, 1832. State Rep. David Clarenbach hopes Saturday's ceremony in the village of Victory _ named by residents years ago to celebrate the massacre _ could set a ``very important tone'' for resolving a modern-day dispute with Wisconsin's six Chippewa Indian bands. ``The purpose of this kind of reconciliation is to draw strength from a new bond that replenishes old distrust,'' said Clarenbach, who sponsored the apology approved by the Legislature last October. Tribal leaders from the Sac and Fox Nation in Iowa, Oklahoma and Kansas have been invited to Wisconsin to accept the apology. The ceremony is planned at the historical marker erected in 1955. Chief Elmer Manatowa of the Sac and Fox Nation in Oklahoma said he was pleased with the apology, but admitted having ``second, third and fourth thoughts about it.'' ``Why us? Why not the present day Indian people in Wisconsin that need the help now?'' he asked, referring to the fact that members of the Sac and Fox Nation long ago left the state. His Oklahoma band has 2,220 members. ``To have the state of Wisconsin publicly apologize is something we look at,'' Manatowa said. ``I am going to ask the state of Wisconsin to do the same thing for the Chippewa, to do something to ease the relationship up there.'' Headlines about Indian relations in Wisconsin in recent years mostly have focused on hostilities over the Chippewa's special treaty rights to spear fish, hunt and cut timber off reservation in the northern third of the state. Since 1983, when a court affirmed that the Chippewa retained the rights under 19th century federal treaties ceding their territory, Chippewa and non-Indians have clashed over the tribe's right to spear fish in spawning season. Last year, 200 protesters were arrested at lakes where Chippewa were fishing. Clarenbach said the state's willingness to apologize to the Sac and Fox Nation won't solve unrest over Chippewa treaty rights, but it symbolizes the beginning of a new atmosphere of freedom and trust. According to the Assembly resolution, more than 1,000 Sac and Fox Indians, following the leadership of Black Hawk, were attempting to cross the Mississippi River at a point that is now the southeastern corner of Minnesota and restore their villages in 1832. The Army, aided by an armed steamboat, set out to stop them. Estimates of how many Indians died range from 850 to 1,400. ``The Black Axe Massacre was one of the bloodiest tragedies in the sad history of American-Indian relations,'' historian Ray Allen Billington wrote in ``Westward Expansion: A History of the American Frontier.'' Manatowa said the apology won't erase his people's pain over the massacre or other injustices. But he calls it a first step toward bringing future generations of Indians and non-Indians together. ``The people who followed Black Hawk and didn't make it, maybe this will help put them to rest,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: ``Worst is Over'' as Factory Orders Recover in March
DOC.TEXT: Orders to factories for manufactured goods have rebounded from January's worst decline in 16 years, the government said Wednesday in a report analysts interpreted as another sign the industrial sector is recovering from months of weakness. The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and non-durable goods rose 3.8 percent in March, to a seasonally adjusted $240.4 billion, after advancing 1.8 percent in February and thus recovered from the 5.5 percent decline in January. Robert G. Dederick, chief economist with the Northern Trust Co. in Chicago, said the weakness ``is behind us and we now have a flat, slightly upward bias.'' ``I think the worst is over,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Co. ``The question now is what kind of rebound and whether the (long-term) interest spike over the last month or so will abort what appears to be a recovery.'' The January drop was the steepest since a 7 percent decline in December 1974. The March increase was the largest since a 4.7 percent gain in December 1988. The department said most of the overall March increase was in durable goods, up 6.6 percent to $128.7 billion after a 2.4 percent increase the previous month. Durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ have borne the brunt of high interest rates since they often are financed through loans. But most of the durable goods increase was concentrated in the transportation category. It was up 22.4 percent to $36.6 billion due in large part to a 63.2 percent increase in aircraft orders. Transportation orders had risen 10.1 percent in February. Excluding transportation, orders were up 1 percent. Other durable goods categories posting gains were primary metals, up 7.3 percent to $11.7 billion after a 4.2 percent decline in February, and non-electrical machinery, up 1.2 percent to $22.6 billion after falling 0.6 percent in February. Electrical machinery orders, on the other hand, fell 1.6 percent to $19.6 billion after rising 2.8 percent the previous month. Non-durable goods orders also rose, up 0.8 percent to $111.7 billion on top of a 1.1 percent gain the previous month. Food and chemicals accounted for most of the advance. In the key category of non-defense capital goods, a barometer of business investment plans, orders advanced 14.4 percent to $41.3 billion after declines of 5.9 percent in February and 13.6 percent in January. But defense orders dropped 3.9 percent to $7.4 billion after jumping 18.3 percent in February. Excluding defense, orders gained 4 percent, the largest such increase since a similar advance in April 1989. The department also said shipments were up 1.1 percent to $236.8 billion after gaining 3.4 percent a month earlier. They were the first back-to-back gains since January 1989. Inventories fell 0.3 percent to $371.9 billion, their third decline in four months. ``Inventories are in extremely good shape and that points positively,'' Dederick said. Inventories are watched closely because if they increase without a corresponding gain in new orders, production cutbacks could occur in the future as factories try to get rid of goods stored on shelves and backlots.

DOC.HEAD: Precede WASHINGTON
Baker Heads for Talks in Europe on Lithuania, Germany's Future
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 5 grafs Baker comments on unified Germany; picks up 2nd graf pvs, Baker's first...
DOC.TEXT: Members of NATO, not the Soviet Union, must decide whether a unified Germany should be part of the Western alliance, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today. Baker, who stopped here briefly on his way to a NATO meeting in Brussels, Belgium, on Thursday, said however that he was willing to consider the Soviet position in talks with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Schevardnadze later in the week. ``The question whether the unified Germany should be a member of NATO is a question that is properly decided in NATO with the participation of a united Germany,'' Baker told reporters on the flight from Washington. ``The fact of the matter is you can't take a decision of that nature without having the members of the alliance sitting at the table as a party to the decision,'' Baker said. Baker said that, at a meeting Saturday of the four wartime allies and the two Germanys, ``there will be, indeed, a very full and complete discussion of that issue, because that is one of the foremost issues right now that separate the alliance from the position of the Soviet Union.'' Baker's first stop is Brussels for separate sessions Thursday with NATO and European Community foreign ministers. This will give the administration a chance to say how fast it wants moves toward the political union of Western Europe to proceed and what the alliance's future role should be. Britain, with some support from Denmark and Portugal, is trying to slow the pace being set by France and West Germany. The United States has kept its distance from what is essentially a European decision, but it intends to keep close ties to its old allies. Shortly after Baker departed Washington, officials of the two German states announced tentative agreement on a plan for merging their economies, settling basic differences over how the nations should assess the costs of unification. Today's agreement, announced by officials in East Berlin, sets the stage for a full merger of the economies of the two nations on July 2. Ahead for Baker on Friday in Bonn is a round of talks on how the union of East Germany with West Germany will affect the security of neighboring European nations, such as the Soviet Union and Poland. Baker is intent on promoting membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for the reunified Germany, but the Soviets are uneasy about their former ally, East Germany, slipping into the Western military camp. There will be meetings of the Big Four allies that stopped the Nazis in World War II _ the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ and separate talks by Baker with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Lithuania's drive for independence, and the Soviet economic blockade of the breakaway republic, is high on the agenda. On Capitol Hill Tuesday, Baker came under pressure from several senators on the cautious stance President Bush is taking toward Moscow. Last week he withheld economic sanctions while U.S. and Soviet negotiators in Paris completed the framework of a new trade agreement. Sens. Alfonse M. D'Amato, R-N.Y., Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and others urged the administration not to lower U.S. tariffs for Soviet goods as long as the Soviets continue the blockade of Lithuania. ``Some of us feel that we are slipping and sliding into `most favored nation' (trade) status with the Soviet Union, while they are still taking aggressive, oppressive actions in the Baltic countries,'' DeConcini said. Going beyond Lithuania, the senator also criticized the administration as being too lenient to China, which suppressed pro-democracy students in 1989, and to Iraq, which threatened to use chemical weapons against Israel. ``We must not lose our moral compass,'' DeConcini told Baker. Similarly, Sen. Frank R. Lautenberg, D-N.J., said, ``We urge you and expect that you will keep the kinds of pressure on the Soviet Union that you can, short of totally disrupting a relationship that has been developing of recent years.'' Baker said the administration still hoped for a dialogue between Soviet and Lithuanian leaders over the Baltic republic's drive for independence. He offered assurances that completion of the outline of a new U.S.-Soviet trade agreement did not mean Bush would recommend to Congress a one-year waiver of high U.S. tariffs. Lower tariffs depend also on the Soviets completing legislation to permit free emigration by its citizens, Baker said. He stressed, however, that the U.S.-Soviet relationship ran far deeper than problems in the Baltics. He cited negotiations for treaties to sharply reduce Soviet tanks and troops in Europe and the Soviet arsenal of long-range nuclear missiles. Besides, Baker said, ``we want to see a continued approach by the Soviet Union that will permit us to hopefully bring freedom and democracy to other areas of the world.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: A man who allegedly sent threatening letters to George Harrison was arrested Wednesday, police said. The 47-year-old ex-Beatle received the letters at his mansion in Friar Park near Henley, 35 miles west of central London, where he lives with his wife and son. The Daily Mirror reported that Harrison has been haunted by fear of an assassin's bullet ever since another former Beatle, John Lennon, was slain in 1980. Harrison is constantly accompanied by a bodyguard, the paper said. Thames Valley police swooped on a south London address to detain the man after an examination of the letters' postmarks found they were all sent from that area, a police spokesman said. ``We have traced the person who sent the letters. Papers will be submitted for consideration for prosecution,'' said a police spokesman, who was not identified in keeping with British custom. The newspaper reported that Harrison had received five anonymous handwritten letters in recent weeks threatening death.

Pop star Belinda Carlisle has withdrawn from appearing at the Cheyenne Frontier Days Rodeo, saying livestock at such events are mistreated. ``Watching people roughly rope terrified calves is not my idea of entertainment,'' Carlisle said in a statement Tuesday. Frontier Days officials denied animals are mistreated. Terry Bridwell, head of the event's public relations committee, said the singer's views ``appear to be based on misinformation.'' Carlisle, a spokeswoman for People for Ethical Treatment of Animals, said she was offered $35,000 to appear July 23, but turned it down when she learned events would include a rodeo, chuckwagon racing and bullfighting. Her statement said rodeos involve the use of testicular bucking straps, electric prods, sharp sticks, caustic ointments and other devices. None of those items can be used in Professional Rodeo Cowboy Association-sanctioned rodeos such as Frontier Days, Bridwell said. Carlisle has been replaced by Michael Damian of ``The Young and the Restless.''

A lawyer for Johnny Carson said the talk-show host's first wife is hoping negative publicity for her ex-husband will force him to increase her alimony. ``Simply put, this is a baldfaced holdup _ a vehicle to generate unfavorable publicity in an attempt to extort money,'' Carson's lawyer, Stanley Arkin, said in court papers filed Tuesday. Joan Wolcott ``Jody'' Carson, 62, is asking the court to order Carson to pay her $120,000 a year. She gets $13,500 yearly. ``For him, that's like paying carfare,'' she said. The Carsons were married in 1949 and divorced in 1963. In 1970, Mrs. Carson agreed to the annual amount, which was to be paid even if she remarried. She remarried the same year as the settlement. Her attorney, Raoul Felder, stressed that he is not asking to nullify the agreement, only to ``adjust her income so that she can live adequately.'' Arkin said the first Mrs. Carson's ``flawed and baseless position'' is that Carson owes her because he happened to prosper many years after their divorce. Carson, 64, and his fourth wife, Alexis Maas, 41, have been married since 1987.

Country music performer Reba McEntire will return to the concert stage Thursday night for the first time in more than four months. McEntire, who took time off her career to give birth Feb. 23 to her first child, is scheduled to begin a tour in Louisville, Ky., as part of the Kentucky Derby celebration. The concert will be her first since December and her first of a 115-city tour this year, spokeswoman Jennifer Bohler said Wednesday. McEntire was voted female vocalist of the year by the Country Music Association from 1984 through 1987. Her hit records include ``Whoever's in New England'' and ``Cathy's Clown.''

Maverick Soviet politician Boris Yeltsin got up from his hospital bed and walked Wednesday for the first time since undergoing surgery for a slipped disc two days earlier, his doctor said. The 59-year-old opposition figure recovered ``90 percent of the movement in his right foot and is recovering satisfactorily from the operation,'' said Dr. Josep Llovet Tapies of Barcelona Hospital. Yeltsin arrived Sunday to appear on a Catalonian regional television talk show. On Monday, he canceled his activities after complaining of back pains and was later taken to the hospital for surgery. Llovet Tapies indicated Yeltsin was to remain hospitalized for two to three days, but full recuperation after his return to Moscow was expected to extend for a month. Yeltsin began to gather mass support in 1987, when he spoke out for a faster pace of reform. The criticism cost him his post as Moscow Communist Party chief, but he later won election to the People's Congress of Deputies.

Celebrity divorce lawyer Marvin Mitchelson conceded misconduct in seven allegations involving client relations, and the state bar's has dismissed more serious charges. Mitchelson's agreement with the State Bar of California came Tuesday, on the eve of a misconduct hearing. No date for a disciplinary hearing was set. Penalties could range from a warning to disbarment. The flamboyant attorney, who gained fame in 1976 with his landmark ``palimony'' lawsuit against actor Lee Marvin, accepted allegations that included failing to adequately supervise the filing of two appeals and not promptly repaying disputed fees to a client. ``They're not serious charges,'' Mitchelson said. ``There's nothing involving moral turpitude.'' The Bar agreed to drop charges that included misappropriation of funds. Mitchelson faces other misconduct charges filed recently that include allegedly mishandling a client trust account, writing bad checks and keeping poor records. He will seek to have those charges dismissed.

DOC.HEAD: Students at Elite, All-Female College Oppose Co-Ed Plan
DOC.TEXT: Tiny, exclusive Mills College has never been where the boys are, but a vote by trustees of the 138-year-old women's school may admit male undergraduates for the first time. The trustees of Northern California's only women's college meet privately Thursday at an undisclosed location to decide whether to go coeducational 101 years after graduating the first women west of the Mississippi. Students say they feel powerless to affect the board's decision, although most of the 777 women undergrads at the quiet, tree-lined campus in East Oakland oppose the plan designed to boost enrollment and revenues. ``I think the board of trustees is going to vote to go co-ed no matter what we say. They've shown that so far,'' said Nina Schneider, a 22-year-old art major who will graduate this year.
