Mills has admitted male graduate students since the 1930s, when the program began, said Lindsey Beaben, a Mills spokeswoman who noted that schools can lose federal funds if they exclude graduate students because of race, sex or national origin. Nearly 20 percent of the 264 graduate students are men. Its undergraduate school is one of three in the state and 98 nationwide that exclude men. Although most students and faculty oppose admitting male undergraduates, administrators say going coeducational ultimately will save the prestigious liberal arts school from a growing financial crisis. ``Of course it will be an unpopular decision. It will be a heartbreaking decision,'' said the trustees' chairman F. Warren Hellman, whose family members have attended Mills and held positions on its board for 75 years. Hellman, a San Francisco investment banker, said the college must go co-ed to avoid relying too much on its $70 million endowment, which provides one-fifth of the school's $24 million annual budget. ``We had a deficit last year and we'll have a deficit this year and the next,'' Hellman said. ``It's not working any longer. I don't want to see us eat away at the endowment until we're in real trouble.'' Opponents argue that admitting men would violate tradition at the institution that began as the Young Ladies Seminary high school in Benicia before moving 35 miles southeast to Oakland as a college in 1871. Opponents also contend that letting men into undergraduate classrooms could spoil the atmosphere that allows women to take leadership roles in discussions and on campus. ``There's a sense of empowerment women get from attending this college because of the climate in the classroom,'' said Robyn Fisher, the 21-year-old senior president of the Associated Students at Mills. Enrollment in Mills College's 33 undergraduate programs is down 4.2 percent from three years ago and 29 percent below the 1,000 students needed to balance the budget. Peak undergraduate enrollment was 810 students in 1987. Frank DeToma, dean of the faculty, said he's not sure if trustees will heed last week's 57-26 faculty vote against admitting male undergraduates. ``Many women do demonstrably better in this teaching environment,'' said DeToma, who came to Mills in 1989 after 19 years at all-woman Mount Holyoke in Massachusetts. ``But I personally feel going co-ed will help maintain the liberal arts programs at the high standards we have now.'' Sociology professor Ted Thomas headed the panel that proposed the co-ed idea after rejecting ideas to attract more women students. ``Going co-ed is the least risky option for the future of the college,'' said Thomas, who's been at Mills for 26 years. ``There are two ways to look at this, in a funereal way or as a challenge to build upon something that has a great tradition.'' Even the numbers seem to favor a change. Only 4.2 percent of California students taking college entrance examinations say they want to go to an all-female college. And the $11,900 tuition, which usually increases 8 percent a year, is 10 times more expensive than the University of California's public colleges and universities.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk And Mandela Open Talks on Black-White Power Sharing
LaserPhotos CPN1,2
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela on Wednesday urged the swift abolition of apartheid and began historic talks aimed at ending white-minority rule. The three days of meetings are to remove obstacles to full-scale negotiations on a new constitution that would give the 28-million black majority a voice in national affairs for the first time. De Klerk and Mandela, standing on the lawn of a Dutch colonial mansion where the talks were held, said South Africans of all races want swift change. All political parties must work toward a peaceful solution to racial and political divisions, they said. Nearby, the pro-apartheid Conservative Party walked out of a debate in Parliament to protest the talks. The Conservative leader, Andries Treurnicht, said the government should not negotiate with an organization that has carried out guerrilla attacks and still was committed to armed struggle. ``South African law forbids all these actions,'' said Treurnicht, whose party is the main opposition in Parliament's white chamber. The tri-cameral Parliament also has chambers for people of mixed-race and Indian descent. Blacks are excluded. Mandela, in a statement before the talks began, said: ``The pace at which we move to arrive at a just solution should be informed by the fact that the black masses of our country demand and expect fundamental change now, and not tomorrow.'' ``The people as a whole want the peace and stability that can only come about as a result of the total abolition of the apartheid system,'' he said. But de Klerk warned that violence that has claimed more than 500 lives in the past three months threatens such change. Much of the violence has been among black groups with differing views of a future South Africa. ``The vast majority of South Africans desire the negotiation process, aimed at a new constitution, to get started in all earnestness,'' de Klerk said. ``The government wishes this to happen as soon as possible and is consequently approaching the talks with the utmost earnestness.'' The ANC demands the release of all political prisoners, lifting of the state of emergency and the return of exiled activists as preconditions to constitutional negotiations. The government, meanwhile, is demanding the ANC, a guerrilla movement, renounce its largely dormant armed struggle. The talks are the first between a white government and an ANC delegation since the organization was founded in 1912. The discussions are being held at the Groote Schuur estate, once the official home of South African presidents. Security for the meeting was strict. Scores of uniformed police and plainclothes security agents guarded the house and grounds. The two sides said they plan to make no further comment on the talks until they adjourn Friday. In his statement before the talks began, Mandela attempted to calm white fears about a black government, saying whites would enjoy full rights in a non-racial democratic state. He made part of his remarks in Afrikaans, the language of the Dutch-descended Afrikaners. They comprise 3 million of the country's 5 million whites and dominate the government. Mandela, the ANC's deputy president, was released in February after 27 years in jail for helping to launch the ANC's armed struggle. He is the de facto leader of the group, whose president, Oliver Tambo, last year suffered a stroke. Mandela called the talks a historic turning point marking the end of a ``servant and master'' relationship between blacks and whites. South Africa, he said, would never again base its political and social systems on racial superiority and segregation. ``The idea that the color of a person defines their place in society must, to all of us, be as frightening as the plague,'' he said. Mandela also stressed the need to improve the economic conditions of millions of blacks who live in desperate poverty while whites control most wealth. The two sides are expected to make progress this week, but government and ANC officials say further preliminary talks may be necessary to remove all obstacles to constitutional negotiations. De Klerk has promised to end white rule, but he opposes a simple one-person, one-vote system. He says such a system would replace white domination with black domination. The ANC says it is committed to a fully democratic system with no special rights for any minority. The ANC also wants a radical restructuring of the economy that could include nationalizing banks, gold mines and other leading industries. Both sides are under pressure from black and white extremists who oppose any settlement. Pro-apartheid whites want to preserve white rule while radical black groups want to end all forms of white control and privilege.

DOC.HEAD: List of Western Hostages of Lebanese Kidnappers
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of the six Americans and other Western kidnap victims still missing in Lebanon: 1. Terry A. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, kidnapped March 16, 1985. 2. Thomas Sutherland, 59, acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, abducted June 9, 1985. 3. Joseph James Cicippio, 59, acting comptroller at the American University in Beirut, kidnapped Sept. 12, 1986. 4. Edward Austin Tracy, 59, west Beirut resident. Revolutionary Justice Organization claimed on Oct. 21, 1986, to have abducted him. 5. Alann Steen, 51, a communications instructor at Beirut University College, kidnapped Jan. 24, 1987. 6. Jesse Jonathan Turner, 42, professor of mathematics and computer science at Beirut University College, kidnapped Jan. 24, 1987. OTHERS: 1. Terry Waite, 50, British envoy of the Anglican Church, disappeared Jan. 20, 1987. 2. Alec Collett, 68, British journalist, kidnapped March 25, 1985. 3. John McCarthy, 33, British television journalist, kidnapped April 17, 1986. 4. Alberto Molinari, 70, Italian businessman who lived in Beirut, kidnapped Sept. 11, 1985. 5. Brian Keenan, 39, an Irish teacher of English at the American University of Beirut, kidnapped April 11, 1986. 6. Jack Mann, 75, British missing in west Beirut since May 12, 1989. 7-8. Heinrich Struebig, 49, and Thomas Kemptner, 28, West German relief workers, kidnapped May 16, 1989. 9-10. Elio Erriquez, 24, and Emmanuel Christen, 33, Swiss Red Cross workers abducted Oct. 16, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Study Boosts Evidence That AIDS Virus Gene Promotes AIDS-Related Cancer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have found new evidence that a single gene of the AIDS virus promotes an AIDS-related cancer called Kaposi's sarcoma. The gene tells cells to produce a particular protein, and the new test-tube study found that this protein spurred the growth of Kaposi's sarcoma cells taken from AIDS patients. Scientists also found that the protein was released by cells infected with the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Kaposi's sarcoma is a generally uncommon cancer that appears unusually often in people with AIDS. It can be controlled medically and it rarely kills AIDS patients. The study focused on a gene called tat, which helps regulate growth of the AIDS virus. In previous research, scientists had found that when mice were given a copy of this gene, they developed a skin disease that closely resembled Kaposi's sarcoma. Combined with that finding, the new work indicates that once the gene's protein escapes from an AIDS-infected cell, it may promote the development or progression of Kaposi's sarcoma elsewhere in the body, researchers wrote in Thursday's issue of the British journal Nature. The work was reported by Dr. Robert Gallo and colleagues at the National Cancer Institute and Dr. Flossie Wong-Staal of the University of California, San Diego.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Says Peace Effort Should Be Expanded to Arab States
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is emphasizing the need for broader-based negotiations with the Arab world in place of the Palestinian-Israeli dialogue promoted by U.S. officials. Shamir, who appears likely to head Israel's next government, has played down the importance of holding talks with Palestinians in Cairo as proposed by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ``One should not expect us in Israel to always agree with everything the Americans offer us, just as the Americans would not always agree with our proposals,'' Shamir told reporters Wednesday. Instead, he and others in his caretaker government have emphasized that the focus of peacemaking efforts should be shifted toward Arab states such as Iraq, Syria and Libya, which pose a greater threat to Israel than the 28-month-old Palestinian uprising. The shift in emphasis appears to have been provoked by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, who last month warned he would destroy half of Israel with binary chemical weapons in response to any Israeli attack. ``I think that something is perhaps understood today that was not understood before Saddam Hussein spoke, that the Palestinian part of the Arab-Israeli conflict is only one of the parts and not the most important one, compared to the other parts,'' Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said on Israel TV this week. In recent months, violence has tapered off in the occupied lands, whereas concern about chemical warfare was brought home to every Israeli by the army's plan _ provoked by Saddam's remarks _ to distribute gas masks nationwide. In an interview Wednesday, Brig. Gen. Nachman Shai, the army spokesman, said the danger posed by Arab states outweighs that of riots in the occupied lands. ``People understand now ... that the argument is not now on the West Bank. It has gone back to square one. What is the overall solution? You cannot settle the Nablus riots and be happy, (neither) us (nor) them,'' he said. He said Israel's main concern now is radical Arab regimes. ``What do Iraq and Syria intend to do? To look for the right moment to start a war,'' he said. But Moshe Maoz, a Hebrew University Middle East expert, argued that Israel should start peace negotiations with the Palestinians now if it does not want the Arab world to unite against Israel. Noting the Egyptian-Syrian summit in Damascus and signs of a Syrian-Iraqi rapprochement, Maoz said that for Israel to be stubborn ``would reach an opposite goal and strengthen unity in the Arab world.'' Sources say Shamir also was put off the Baker plan because he felt the United States encouraged his Labor Party rival, Shimon Peres, to provoke the current political crisis. Peres brought down a Shamir-led coalition March 15 after Shamir refused to endorse Baker's proposals. But he failed to put together a government, opening the door for Shamir. Officials of Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc say Shamir will not formulate a specific policy until he has assembled a ruling coalition, and his hard line could be modified if the center-left Labor Party is included. Shamir has been grumbling for some time that U.S. proposals focus only on his offer of Palestinian elections and ignore other aspects of his five-point plan, which the government approved May 14, 1989. The plan called for an end to the state of war with Arab states, aid to resettle Palestinians living in crowded refugee camps, peace with Jordan and a ``statement of principles'' opposing talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization or creation of a Palestinian state. ``We have voted in the Cabinet on the five points ... and I see these five points, together with our assumptions, as one unity,'' he told reporters. But the Arab world is unlikely to accept broader negotiations except in the context of a U.N.-sponsored international conference. Shamir has rejected that idea because he feels the conference would be biased against Israel. Shamir's refusal to accept the Baker approach is seen by many Palestinians here and by Arab leaders abroad as foot-dragging. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak said after a May Day speech that Shamir does not appear to seek peace. Responding Wednesday, Shamir said: ``Peace is not something you say today and it will happen tomorrow. It is a long process.''

DOC.HEAD: Liz `Doing Fine' Recovering From Pneumonia
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Taylor has improved considerably but doctors wouldn't speculate on how much longer the actress will be hospitalized while she recovers from pneumonia, her publicist said Wednesday. ``She's doing fine. She has improved significantly,'' said her New York City spokeswoman, Chen Sam. ``We don't know how much longer she will be hospitalized.'' Twenty-four days earlier, Miss Taylor entered Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital with a sinus infection. But her condition worsened and she was moved to the intensive care unit at St. John's Hospital and Health Center. During a news conference at the hospital last week, doctors said the 58-year-old Oscar-winning star of ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' and ``Butterfield 8'' was near death at one point.

DOC.HEAD: Stars Call for TV Sets Required to Display Closed-Captioning
DOC.TEXT: Actors from the ``L.A. Law,'' ``Cosby'' and ``Sesame Street'' TV programs gave their support Wednesday to a bill that would require all standard-sized television sets to be able to display captions for deaf or hearing-impaired viewers. Witnesses at a House hearing, including TV stars Richard Dysart, Geoffrey Owens and Linda Bove, said millions of Americans are being excluded from access to broad-based communications systems, particularly TV. Transmitting so-called closed captioning services on most TV sets would benefit not only the estimated 24 million Americans with hearing disabilities, but some 18 million youngsters learning to read and millions more foreigners and illiterate adults trying to learn English. ``I think captioning should be a standard feature on the television signal _ that's how important it is,'' said Owens, a co-star on NBC-TV's ``Cosby Show.'' A TV manufacturers' representative, however, said it would be unfair to require that everyone, particularly the poor or low-income senior citizens, be required to bear the costs of sets with closed-captioning capability. The bill by Rep. Major Owens, D-N.Y, and a companion measure by Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, would require all sets with screens 13 inches or larger be able to display captions. Cost of such circuitry has been estimated at $15 to $20. Making such circuitry mandatory ``amounts to a regressive excise tax on all purchasers of television sets in order to benefit a small, albeit deserving, minority,'' said Thomas P. Friel, a vice president with the Electronic Industries Association. He urged the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on telecommunications and finance to require that only some TV sets be capable of closed-captioning. Beginning with the 1989 season, ABC, CBS and NBC were offering closed-captioning on all their primetime programs, noted subcommittee Chairman Rep. Edward Markey, D-Mass. But witnesses said most local and syndicated programs are not closed-captioned, and that only 90 of some 1,500 local news broadcasts are closed-captioned. ``It's a cost decision,'' said I. King Jordan, president of the Gallaudet University school for the hearing impaired. He said he feared the major television networks would stop offering closed-captioning unless a way was found to enlarge the audience for such services. He said the government already has spent $45 million on closed-captioning since the late 1970s and the closed-captioning bill ``would ensure that this money will not have been wasted.'' Dysart, who is co-star of NBC-TV's ``L.A. Law'' and 1990 chairman of the Council for Better Hearing and Speech Month, dismissed the economic arguments. He said the prices for the closed-captioning circuitry would drop dramatically when all sets had the closed-captioning circuitry. Dysart said most people cannot afford to buy set-top devices that currently provide closed-captioning. Only about 300,000 of the set-top decoders are in use, primarily because of the $160 to $200 per-unit cost, he said. Bove of the ``Sesame Street'' children's show, said captioning was very important in helping children with normal hearing learn to read. She said it cost between $1,500 and $2,000 to caption a 30-minute TV program.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf of last item in rdp to CORRECT name of team to Chicago Cardinals sted St. Louis Cardinals.
DOC.TEXT: Charles D. Ewart, general manager of the Philadelphia Eagles when they won their first championship and an FBI agent whose assignments included security for the Manhattan Project, died Monday at age 74 after a long illness. Ewart, a quarterback at Yale, held football coaching jobs at Wesleyan and Dartmouth from 1938 to 1941. From 1942 to 1946, he was an FBI agent assigned to espionage cases and security assignments, including the Manhattan Project, which built the atom bomb. He joined the Eagles staff in 1946 as backfield coach and was promoted to general manager in 1948. That year the Eagles defeated the Chicago Cardinals 7-0 for the championship. In 1954 he left football and began work as a businessman.

DOC.HEAD: Landsbergis Agrees to Consider Suspending Some Laws
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's president said Wednesday his Baltic republic would consider suspending temporarily some of the pro-independence laws that drove the Kremlin to impose an economic embargo two weeks ago. President Vytautas Landsbergis agreed to the step in a letter to French and West German leaders who last week proposed that such a compromise would help start negotiations between the republic and Moscow. ``Everything is negotiable which does not question the matter of restored independence of the Lithuanian state on March 11, 1990,'' Landsbergis said in his letter to French President Francois Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The letter was read to Lithuania's parliament, the Supreme Council, which gave its approval without a vote, said Aidas Palubinskas, a spokesman for the parliament. ``Putting our confidence in France and the Federal Republic of Germany, as well as in other Western democracies, and in their support of Lithuanian democracy, we are asking you to transmit to the Soviet authorities our consent to consider a temporary suspension of the effects of the decisions taken by the sovereign parliament of the Lithuanian Republic that could trouble the Soviet authorities,'' Landsbergis wrote. The idea behind the proposal from France and West Germany was that if Lithuania temporarily suspended those laws, the Soviet Union, in return, might ease its pressure on the republic and also agree to talks on secession. Palubinskas stressed that the proposal from Kohl and Mitterrand did not ask for rescinding the declaration itself, but urged the suspension of laws passed to implement the independence declaration. Lithuania declared independence on March 11, trying to restore the freedom it enjoyed before 1940, when the Soviet Union forcibly annexed it along with Latvia and Estonia. It has since passed laws designed to back the independence drive, including ending conscription of Lithuanians into the Soviet army, issuing identity cards for non-Lithuanians and seizing Communist Party property. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has declared the independence declaration invalid and rejected negotiations with the republic, saying such talks are reserved for foreign countries. He demanded that Lithuania rescind those pro-independence laws. Gorbachev imposed a partial economic blockade, cutting supplies of fuel and other commodities to Lithuania. As of Wednesday night, no resumption of any of the fuel supplies has been reported. The republic of 3.8 million people has been struggling economically ever since the embargo was imposed. At least 10,000 people have been thrown out of work due to factory closures, Palubinskas said, with that number expected to increase to 35,000 by the end of the week. Rationing of gasoline and food has begun, and medicine is in short supply in some hospitals. Soviet officials have welcomed the French-German proposal, contained in a letter to Landsbergis and Gorbachev. Gorbachev's spokesman, Arkady Maslennikov, told a briefing in Moscow on Saturday that the letter ``is not far from the line that the Soviet leadership has been pursuing.'' The republic's prime minister, Kazimiera Prunskiene, is scheduled to meet Thursday with President Bush in Washington. Bush has urged the Lithuanians and Soviets to negotiate their dispute but has refused to impose sanctions on the Kremlin or recognize the republic's independence. ``We hope that Mrs. Prunskiene will more completely inform President Bush about the situation in Lithuania in the days of blockade,'' Landsbergis told parliament Wednesday, according to Eduardas Potashinskas of Lithuanian television. In another development, the independent news service Postfactum in Moscow reported Lithuania is trying to revive oil wells to help make up for the April 18 cutoff of oil supplies by the Kremlin. Interfax, a news service affiliated with Moscow Radio, said the wells would be able to produce only enough oil for agricultural needs. Lithuanians are rebuilding facilities at the port of Klaipeda to allow it to receive imported oil later this month, Interfax said. It did not say who would supply the oil, which would have to be bought with foreign currency that Lithuania lacks. Wednesday was the first workday in Lithuania under the food rationing system. Most stores were closed Tuesday, when the system went into effect, because of the May Day holiday. Daina Kalendra, a worker at the Supreme Council's information office, said that for May and June, each person is limited to the following: sugar, 4.4 pounds; macaroni, 2.2 pounds; grains, 4.4 pounds; salt, 2.2 pounds; flour, 4.4 pounds; grease or margarine, about a half-pound. Lithuania supplies most of its own meat and dairy needs. The crisis threatened to expand to Latvia on Thursday, when that republic's parliament will convene to consider declaring its independence. Unlike Lithuania, where native Lithuanians make up 80 percent of the population, native residents make up about 54 percent of Latvia's 2.7 million residents, with the rest largely Russians who frown on the idea of secession. Despite their ethnic disadvantage, Latvian nationalists have been pushing for the parliament to emulate Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Ambushes Bike Rider, Wounds 2 Police Officers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Everyone here...', to CORRECT Kramer's title to executive editor sted managing editor.
DOC.TEXT: A gunman ambushed and killed a bicycle rider, seriously injured a driver and wounded two police officers before he was shot in a sidewalk gunbattle outside a crowded shopping mall, police said. Paul Bellazain was wounded in the thigh Tuesday during a shootout with officers near the Westlake Mall in Daly City, just south of San Francisco, said Daly City police Detective Jim McHenry. One of the officers tackled Bellazain, who carried a pistol, as he tried to flee, ending a 45-minute rampage in which a gunman in a brown Cadillac cruised a freeway and side streets in San Francisco, fatally shooting the bicyclist and firing at cars. Daly City police said Bellazain would be booked for investigation of two counts of attempted murder. San Francisco police said Bellazain was under investigation in connection with the shootings here. Bellazain, 46, was in fair condition Tuesday night at Kaiser Hospital. Bellazain, a veteran San Francisco transit driver, has been off work the past five months, receiving workers' compensation because of a hand injury. The shooting spree apparently began in San Francisco shortly before 9 a.m., when officers received reports of shots fired on Alemany Boulevard, said police spokesman Dave Ambrose. A short time later, James Newman was struck by a bullet that entered his arm and lodged in his chest as he was driving on I-280 in San Francisco. Newman, 41, was in serious condition Tuesday night at San Francisco General Hospital. At 9:10 a.m., police received a call that a bike rider was shot to death at McLaren Park near the Daly City border. He was identified by the coroner's office today as James Vaszko, 43, a copy editor at the San Francisco Examiner. ``Everyone here was just shocked,'' said Larry Kramer, executive editor of the Examiner. ``He was just one of those really nice, intellectual type of guys. He was a sweetheart.'' The gunman apparently continued south into Daly City, where between 9:10 a.m. and 9:35 a.m., chiropractor Gene Martin and his receptionist, Stephanie Ryan, were taken hostage in their office. ``(He) said `Get over there, doc,' and then he started to rant and rave how the system was messing him up,'' a shaken Martin said. ``He had three guns when he came in and he said he was sorry he didn't have an Uzi,'' Martin said. ``I thought I was going to die, but he was really after the cops.'' Bellazain gave Martin tapes containing what he said were messages to his children proclaiming his love for them. He told the hostages he wanted to get back at police because they were reportedly investigating him for alleged child abuse. San Francisco and Daly City police said they knew of no such investigation, but Bellazain had been under a restraining order sought by his ex-wife, Shirley Ann Bellazain, who said he abused her and their children during their 17-year marriage. The gunman let the receptionist go after she lied, saying she was pregnant, according to Martin. He said Bellazain told him to call police before storming out of the office to confront officers with a volley of shots. ``It seemed like the shooting went on forever,'' said Alfredo Aguirre, manager of the San Mateo County Mental Health Clinic near the shopping center, where horrified shoppers witnessed the gunbattle. Two officers, Sgt. Ralph Warren and Gary Smith, were each shot in the arm during the gunbattle. Police said it was not clear who shot Bellazain.

DOC.HEAD: East and West Germany Agree on Economic Merger Plan
DOC.TEXT: The two German states agreed on a treaty for merging their economies Wednesday after West Germany agreed to give elderly East Germans more financial protection from the throes of the free market. The tentative agreement, which still has to be approved by the parliaments of both countries, settles major differences between the two Germanys over how to assess the high costs of unification. It clears the way for a full merger of their economies by July 2, when the West German mark will become the official currency of East Germany. In a major compromise, West Germany said it would allow senior citizens in East Germany to convert more of their savings at a favorable 1-1 rate to the West German mark. The plan comes just three days before a meeting between the two Germanys and the four World War II allies that divided Germany _ the Soviet Union, United States, Britain, and France _ to discuss the international ramifications of German unity. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III was to join foreign ministers from the other countries for the historic ``four-plus-two'' talks in Bonn, the West German capital. A full political merger of the two Germanys is expected next year. But first some thorny issues must be resolved, including membership of a unified Germany in NATO and new European security arrangements. The economic merger agreement was confirmed Wednesday by Mathias Gehler, spokesman for East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, and Rudolf Seiters, chief of staff for West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. ``I want to emphasize that what (the Germanys) have agreed upon is tied with the responsibility of the economic and social developments in both parts of Germany and the stability of the (West German) mark,'' Seiters said in a statement in Bonn. The two Germanys have been negotiating for weeks over how West Germany can absorb the crippled East German economy without threatening the strength of the powerful West German mark. The East German mark is officially valued at 3-1 against the West German mark, but is virtually worthless outside the country. However, East German officials said they needed a near-equal conversion rate to make up for removing subsidies which kept down prices under the former socialist system. Under the agreement, all salaries earned by East Germans would be converted at a 1-1 rate. The agreement also will allow East Germans to obtain ownernship shares in state-owned enterprises. The plan also provides that people aged 60 and older will be able to convert up to $3,350 in personal savings at the 1-1 rate, while East Germans 14 and under would be able to convert only up to $1,180 dollars. Everyone else would be able to convert $2,300 at the 1-1 rate. Any savings above the ceiling levels would be changed at a 2-1 rate. West Germany originally had proposed a $2,300 ceiling for all Germans, but East Germany demanded a higher limit. The Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, had advocated a 2-1 conversion rate, warning that a 1-1 rate would cost the West German economy billions of dollars. Pensioners will receive the most protection under the plan. Elderly East Germans will have their monthly pensions raised to West German levels when the economies are merged. West Germany also has agreed to allow some still-undefined financial protection for students and renters who may not be able to afford rents once they are set by the free market. Several protests have been held in recent weeks by East Germans demanding protection from unemployment and competition from Western businesses. East Germans, who still will earn only about one-third of their West German counterparts, also fear rising prices when the nations are united. West Germans, meanwhile, fear that absorbing the East German economy will dilute the power of the mighty West German currency and lead to higher taxes and inflation.

DOC.HEAD: Captain Says $2 Million Vessel Caught in U.S.-Mexican Dispute
With AM-Mexican Doctor
DOC.TEXT: A yacht captain says his vessel was seized by Mexican agents and his crew members were beaten and jailed in retaliation for the alleged U.S. kidnapping of a Mexican physician accused of murder. Both crew members remain in a Mexican jail, he said. Robert Ambrosius, captain of the Rusalka, said Tuesday he and his wife managed to escape April 24 in a pre-dawn dash through Cuban water. ``I was scared to death,'' he said. Ambrosius and the boat's owner, California developer Igor Olenicoff, theorized that Mexican authorities were seeking revenge for the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration's capture last month of a Guadalajara gynecologist. Dr. Humberto Alvarez was indicted by a grand jury in Los Angeles in the 1985 torture-slaying of Enrique Camarena, a DEA agent. ``This is just retaliation'' for the Alvarez arrest, said Olenicoff, who was not on board when the yacht was seized. He said the Mexican agents told his captain: ``You have one of ours. Now we have yours.'' On Wednesday, DEA chief Terrence M. Burke denied that his agents played a role in the abduction of Alvarez. ``We did not have any agent actively participate in the planning and execution'' of the operation, Burke told a Senate hearing in Washington, D.C. State Department spokeswoman Frances Jones said the Mexican government insists it seized the $2 million, 83-foot yacht because it was carrying illegal guns and had two crew members who did not have visas. Jorge Reyes, a spokesman for the Mexican Embassy in Washington, said he could not comment because his office knows nothing about the incident. Ambrosius and his wife, Tammy, gave this account of the seizure: He was hired as captain of the yacht in February, when the vessel was in Panama, midway through a cruise from California to Fort Lauderdale. On April 20, the ship landed in Cozumel and notified Mexican customs, he said. Two crew members, Polo Herrera of Panama and Eddie Tovar of Colombia, had problems because they did not have visas, but Mexican officials said the problem could be cleared up easily, according to Ambrosius. The next day, about 15 men who said they were Mexican drug agents but had no identification or uniforms boarded the ship and found guns used for skeet shooting. Ambrosius said he should have declared the guns. On April 22, he said, the ship was searched for drugs and contraband by the Mexican navy. On April 23, the self-described drug agents returned. Ambrosius said he heard them beat one of his crew members. The agents told him his ship had been seized and they arrested Herrera and Tovar, who he said are still in jail. The boat remained anchored off the coast that day and night, watched by patrol boats, Ambrosius said. Early the next day, the patrol boats returned to port and Ambrosius and his wife weighed anchor and drifted away for a half-hour before starting the engine. He said 15-foot seas kept the patrol boats from following. Later, off the coast of Cuba, he noticed boats on radar that were mirroring his every move. The boats ``were closing in out there in the middle of nowhere,'' he said. Ambrosius said he made a sharp turn between two boats and briefly moved into Cuban waters. He then made it safely to Key West. Coast Guard officials in Key West said they believed Ambrosius' story but did not see any Mexican patrol boats.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary's New Parliament Breaks With the Past
DOC.TEXT: Parliament made a firm departure from its Communist past Wednesday, choosing as Hungary's interim president a writer jailed for his role in the 1956 anti-Soviet revolt. Arpad Goencz, 68, replaced Matyas Szueroes, a member of the Socialist Party, formerly the Communist Party, which ruled for 42 years. He received 339 of the 370 valid votes cast by secret ballot. Goencz's nomination was the result of a pact between the two largest rivals _ the center-right Hungarian Democratic Forum, which will most likely form the new government, and the liberal League of Free Democrats. His first deputy, Gyoergy Szabad, 66, a founding member of the Democratic Forum, became acting speaker of the new freely elected Parliament. Goencz is officially speaker but will act as head of state until a new president is elected. Goencz, a trained lawyer who entered politics after World War II as a member of the then-dominant Smallholders' Party, has headed the Hungarian Writers' Union since last December. He spent six years in prison on a life sentence for his role in the 1956 revolt before winning a reprieve in a 1963 general amnesty. During Wednesday's session, historic figures from the last freely elected Parliament _ before the Communists took power _ were called to the podium. The session also declared the 1956 uprising a revolution and a battle for freedom. The Democratic Forum and the Free Democrats agreed that the permanent president should be elected by Parliament rather than in a direct popular vote. Goencz appeared likely to get that post, which in Hungary is largely ceremonial. Forum leader Jozsef Antall said the presidential election could happen by early June if the necessary constitutional amendments are passed and the government is formed. He said he expects the new government to be formed by mid-May. The Forum is the largest party with 164 seats. The Smallholders and Christian Democrats have 44 and 21 respectively. The government of Socialist Miklos Nemeth formally submitted its resignation Wednesday, but will continue as a caretaker government until the new cabinet is formed. In a speech, Nemeth noted Hungary's gradual transition to democracy, which, unlike that of other East bloc countries, was led by the ruling party. ``Many (think) we committed political suicide and (in return) for dismantling the party-state we were pushed from power,'' Nemeth said, referring to his Socialist Party's poor showing at the polls. The Socialists won only 33 seats in the new parliament. Goencz was expected to ask Antall to form a new government when Parliament resumes on Thursday. Wednesday's session was 10 deputies short of a full house. Eight seats set aside for minority representatives have yet to be filled. Exactly one year ago, Hungary began dismantling its borders, sparking an exodus of East German refugees to the West. That exodus precipitated the fall of communism in East Germany and later, the rest of the East bloc. ``We must be proud that our country was the pioneer in all the changes of Eastern Europe,'' Szueroes said in a farewell address. ``Dictatorships have been removed, walls have fallen and become pieces in museums.'' Among those who listened as a guest was Otto von Habsburg, the former crown prince of Hungary and a member of the European Parliament. The house also formally declared it would join the European Parliament. In another symbolic gesture of Hungary's return to democracy, the old Communist coat of arms that had adorned the ornate parliament chamber was removed.

DOC.HEAD: Counselors Help Grieving Students After Bizarre Suicide
With AM-Suicide Town
DOC.TEXT: A team of psychologists and social workers Wednesday counseled and consoled classmates of a senior who committed suicide by driving his motorcycle into the side of his high school. Dolores Bohen, spokeswoman for the Fairfax County public schools, said a counseling crisis team also was sent to Edison High School in Franconia, where Jerry Minnick was a student last year. ``We are trying to keep as much structure in the routine as possible,'' Ms. Bohen said. ``At the same time, we are providing everyone an opportunity to break away from the routine and sit in on counseling sessions.'' While classes were in session Tuesday at Hayfield High, Minnick took his motorcycle on the school running track, removed his helmet and raced full-speed into the outside wall of the boys' locker room. He died instantly. County police spokesman Michael Proffitt would not estimate how fast the 18-year-old Minnick's motorcycle was traveling when it slammed into the brick wall. In Sheridan, Ark., officials put counselors on 24-hour call, as grieving teen-agers tried to cope with the apparent suicides of three classmates in two days, including one who killed himself in class after declaring his love for a girl. Ms. Bohen said Minnick's suicide was the first on school grounds in the 130,000-student school system. ``Because he was killed instantly, police had to conduct the investigation there on the spot before the body was removed. The school remained the focal point, which was tough,'' she said. Proffitt said Minnick was ``distraught over personal problems,'' but he refused to elaborate or say whether Minnick left a note. He did not know when tests would deterine whether Minnick died under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Natasha Reid, 17, a Hayfield senior, said Minnick had been in a car accident in front of the school about a month ago and a motorcycle accident earlier in the year. She said he had not attended classes much lately. Arthur Sullivan, whose son Chris was a friend of Minnick, said Minnick apparently gave no outward sign Monday night that he was about to take his life. ``All his friends were talking to him, and he was fine,'' Sullivan said. ``It's difficult to know what personal problem might have been ticking over.'' School officials said Minnick's parents are dead, and for the past year he lived in the foster home of Air Force Lt. Col. Edward Seward, who declined to comment.

DOC.HEAD: Former FBI Agent Defeats Longtime Sheriff
DOC.TEXT: A former FBI agent said Wednesday the reputation he established during the investigation that ousted Gov. Ray Blanton was one reason he defeated Nashville's indicted incumbent sheriff. Hank Hillin received three votes to every one for incumbent Sheriff Fate Thomas, who faces a 38-count indictment alleging he used his office to funnel $500,000 in goods and services to himself. The sheriff's race was one of four Tuesday in which incumbents and appointed officials were ousted by newcomers. ``I think it was just a feeling that the community was fed up with machine politics,'' Hillin said. Circuit Judge Harry Lester, who was defeated by lawyer Marietta Shipley, said it seemed voters were picking on anyone in office. ``It was just `throw 'em out' and they did it in a big way,'' Lester said. Thomas, in office for 18 years, said Tuesday night after conceding defeat: ``I'm sorry we didn't win _ maybe I didn't work hard enough.'' Thomas was known for a political organization that was effective in getting out the vote and for his grass-roots barbecues, voter mailing lists and ability to raise funds for himself and other candidates. Hillin led the investigation into the so-called ``clemency for cash'' scandal of the late 1970s. Although Blanton, who was governor from 1975 to 1979, was never convicted on charges that state prison inmates could buy their freedom, two of his aides were sent to prison. Hillin also aided the later investigation that resulted in Blanton spending two years in federal prison for a 1981 conviction on mail fraud, extortion and conspiracy charges resulting from a scheme to sell liquor licenses. The Internal Revenue Service led that investigation, Hillin said. Blanton's mail fraud conviction was thrown out on a legal technicalityafter he was released from prison. He has appealed the other convictions. ``I had a background of spending five years investigating the Blanton administration. Political corruption is so difficult to ferret out, a long and hard paper trail to follow. I think that did establish me,'' Hillin said. The office of Metro Davidson County sheriff in the consolidated county-city government is not an investigative law enforcement post. The sheriff's major role is running the county jail and workhouse. The Metro Nashville Police Department handles law enforcement and investigative functions. Unofficial Democratic primary vote totals showed Hillin winning with a count of 64,023 votes, or 71 percent, to Thomas' 22,304, or 25 percent. Hillin now faces Davidson County Republican Party Chairman Doug Reynolds and two independent candidates in the Aug. 2 election. Thomas faces trial this summer on a federal indictment charging him and six other department employees with a violations ranging from racketeering and mail fraud to obstruction of justice and tax fraud.

DOC.HEAD: Hills Predicts `Dimished Prosperity' with Trade Talks Fail
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills tried Wednesday to impart a sense of urgency to stalled trade talks by predicting ``gravely diminished prosperity for all'' if negotiations fail. Hills' warning came at the start of three days of negotiations with trade ministers from Japan, the 12-nation European Community and Canada. The officials gathered at a resort north of here to search for ways to break an impasse in a four-year effort to overhaul the rules governing the world trading system. The talks, involving almost 100 nations, are designed to lower a variety of barriers to trade in agriculture, textiles and other manufactured goods, and services such as banking and investment. The positions of opposing parties have become so entrenched that many fear failure for the talks being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Such an outcome would deal a blow to the administration's hopes for expanding export opportunities for U.S. farmers and businesses as a way of whittling down America's huge trade deficit, which has topped $100 billion for six years. Hills, speaking to a group of business writers before the talks opened, called the negotiations ``the last, best chance this century to create the trading rules we so sorely need for the next century.'' Calling 1990 a ``pivotal year for the world economy,'' Hills painted failure of the talks in stark terms of diminished living standards for both industrial and developing countries. ``Down one path lie open markets, expanded trade, economic growth and prosperity. Down the other lie closed markets, nations turned inward and gravely diminished prosperity for all.'' Hills said she hoped the discussions, being held in a wine country resort in Napa, would provide enough guidance so that lower-level negotiators will be able to reach preliminary agreement in at least some of the 15 broad areas under discussion at a July 23 session in Geneva, Switzerland. It is expected the talks will be high on the agenda when President Bush is host for the seven-nation economic summit this summer in Houston. A chief aim of the United States is an elimination of all trade-distorting agricultural subsidies. Hills estimated that ending the costly subsidies could boost U.S. farm exports by $11 billion annually _ equal to an extra $3,400 for every American farmer. However, the European Community is fighting efforts to reform the subsidy program that is politically popular with European farm groups. The United States has encountered resistance among Third World countries to its demands for strengthened rules to prevent patent and copyright piracy, which costs U.S. businesses an estimated $60 billion annually. Third World nations, led by India, are fighting a U.S. proposal to expand the GATT market-opening rules to cover trade in services, such as banking, investment and insurance. U.S. companies excel in the service field, where 90 percent of new American jobs are being created. Developing countries fear their infant service businesses would be no match for huge multinational companies. Developing nations are pushing for the GATT talks to scrap trade barriers for textile products. But the United States, bowing to pressure from American textile groups, wants a less comprehensive phase-down of existing textile tariffs and quotas. The current GATT trade talks, launched in Uruguay in 1986, are scheduled to conclude in Brussels on Dec. 3-7. Hills told members of the Society of American Business Editors and Writers that she hoped the obstacles will be resolved by December and that a comprehensive agreement can be presented to Congress next year. ``I am an optimist. I couldn't hold this job unless I was,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Family Awarded $41 Million in Malpractice Settlement
DOC.TEXT: A hospital has agreed to a $41 million malpractice settlement to the parents of a boy who suffered severe brain damage after his temperature soared to 108 degrees. Freddy and Katie Williams, of Springtown, made the agreement Tuesday with the former Fort Worth Children's Hospital, now Cook-Fort Worth Children's Medical Center, in return for the hospital's promise to drop all appeals. Travis Williams, now 14, suffered permanent and severe brain damage seven years ago while recovering from a 1983 operation. A jury found hospital nurses had allowed the child's fever to rise to 108 degrees without adequately informing his doctors of the gravity of his condition. Travis's brain injuries have stripped him of his ability to move or talk. The child's neurological pediatrician and neurosurgeon were exonerated by the jury. The hospital's insurance company will cover the cost of the settlement package, which includes cash payments and the purchase of annuities that will pay dividends to Travis and his parents over the next 50 years, said medical center President Russell Tolman. ``The medical center continues to believe the care in this situation was adequate and there was no negligence on the part of Fort Worth Children's Hospital or its doctors,'' Tolman said. The Williamses intend to use the money to build a home designed for a disabled person and to hire a full-time nurse, said the family's attorney, Darrell Keith. They are also planning to purchase a van with a wheelchair lift, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Says Proposed Constitutional Reforms to Limit King's Power
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the pro-democracy movement now governing this Himalayan kingdom said Wednesday that a new constitution soon to be drafted would sharply reduce the king's power. Prime Minister Krishna Prasad Bhattarai criticized the near absolute power wielded by the monarchy for the past 29 years under the partyless system of government known as the Panchayat. Bhattarai told a meeting organized by the Nepali Journalists Association that the proposed constitutional reforms would ``review the powers of the king and the active role the king has played.'' The meeting was called to honor journalists jailed during the recent seven-week campaign to restore multiparty democracy. The protests forced King Birendra to lift a 29-year ban on political parties last month and turn over the government to an interim coalition made up of pro-democracy forces. Bhattarai, whose centrist Nepali Congress Party is the largest group in the new coalition government, said ``the active role given to the king during the Panchayat system was not appropriate.'' Ganesh Man Singh, the head of the Nepali Congress Party, indicated that the king's role would be reduced to that of a constitutional monarch. The ``king will have to remain under the constitution,'' Singh told the journalists' meeting. ``We will not allow him to go either an inch above or an inch below the constitution.'' Bhattarai said the new government's main priorities are to draft a new constitution and prepare for free elections that will be held within a year. He said a constitution drafting committee would be set up soon, and would be expected to complete its work within three months. In his other remarks, Bhattarai reported progress in efforts to resolve a trade and transit dispute with India. He said Indian Prime Minister V.P. Singh had expressed his willingness to settle the dispute as soon as possible during a meeting in New Delhi with Nepal's finance minister, Devendra Raj Pandey. Pandey was in the Indian capital to attend the annual meeting of the Asian Development Bank. India has closed all but two of the 15 crossing points along its border with landlocked Nepal since March when a trade and transit treaty expired. The move has caused a sharp increase in Nepal in the price of essential imports, including gasoline and medicine. So far negotiations between the two countries on a renewal or new treaty have been unsuccessful. Bhattarai's coalition government, which also includes members of a leftist coalition, independents and two Birendra appointees, took power April 19. That ended the nearly three decades-long hold on power by the monarchy under the Panchayat system, which was introduced by Birendra's father, King Mahendra. The partyless system was imposed in December 1960 after Mahendra dismissed the democratically elected Nepali Congress Party government, accusing it of corruption and poor administration. The recent pro-democracy campaign climaxed on April 6 when police fired at pro-democracy demonstrators marching on the royal palace in Katmandu. Witnesses said at least 200 people were killed, but Birendra's government maintained that only 10 people were killed in the entire country on that day. The public outcry of the shooting forced Birendra to restore multiparty democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Aging Ship to Head for New Port
LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Ship lovers on Wednesday feared the SS Milwaukee Clipper would ride its last wave into a junk heap, sold for scrap. Instead, the 85-year-old landmark steamer is headed for a new dock. At an auction in U.S. District Court, officials of Hammond, Ind.'s Port Authority outbid their only other competitor, buying the former grande dame of Great Lake ferries for $335,000. The SS Clipper had fallen on hard financial times, ousted first from Chicago's Navy Pier over a rent dispute, then from its mooring on the Chicago River. In recent times, it has languished at a dock on Lake Michigan in downtown Chicago. Creditors were knocking on the door of its former owner, James Gillon. The 361-foot ship was subject to a maritime mortgage lien and, by mutual agreement of owner and creditors, was turned over to federal authorities in February for sale, said attorney Alan Amos, who helped in the auction. Wednesday's auction, conducted by U.S. marshals, required a minimum of $100,000 for the ship, which has been designated a national historic landmark and boasts one of the few remaining quadruple expansion steam engines. Six bidders submitted the required $25,000 deposit to take part in the auction. But only Hammond and one other group, Specialty Restaurants Inc. _ which wanted to turn the ship into a floating nightclub _ vyed for the vessel. Robert Kenney, chairman of the Hammond Port Authority, said the ship would anchor a new yacht harbor being developed in the northwestern Indiana city. Once transported from Chicago, the Clipper will be revamped to accommodate a restaurant and pavillion for the harbor, Kenney said. The SS Clipper has made its home in the Great Lakes since its construction in 1905 in Cleveland. The ship, which carried 900 passengers and 120 automobiles, was first used as an excursion liner between Buffalo, N.Y., and Duluth, Minn., said Thatcher Waller, collections manager at the Chicago Maritime Society, which runs a small maritime museum. It was restored in 1940 and, during the summer, would carry passengers and their cars between different Lake Michigan destinations. ``This was a liner that went out for a crossing of six hours. It had state rooms on board, the whole bid,'' said Waller. During winter, when tourist use slacked off, the ship was enlisted to carry new cars from Detroit to cities on Lake Michigan's southern shore, he said. The ship was taken out of service in 1970 and moved to Chicago by its former owner, Gillon, who began a second restoration. Gillon hoped eventually to sail it again, said Waller, who worked on the restoration. But the Coast Guard sought massive work before the ship could be declared ready to steam, and Gillon eventually settled for using the ship as a floating banquet hall before financial problems led it onto the auction block. Several scrappers inquired about buying the Clipper for junk, but the steamer instead will soon be towed by another ship to Hammond, said Kenney. ``I don't think Chicago was really ever aware of the gem that it had,'' Waller said. ``People need an awareness of their history.''

DOC.HEAD: After 78 Years Of Trying, The ANC Meets The Government
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Banned and vilified by white leaders, the African National Congress has achieved a goal sought throughout its 78-year history: talks with the government on ending white domination. The ANC, South Africa's most powerful opposition group, began meeting with the government Wednesday to clear the way for negotiations on a constitution that will give the voteless black majority a voice in government. Even before the talks began, ANC leaders described the meeting as a triumph for the organization, founded in 1912 to fight for black political rights. ``It is a new lease of life,'' said ANC leader Reg September, who returned to South Africa last week after 27 years in exile. ``We will take full advantage of this and move forward to a new South Africa.'' In this divided country, the ANC and its close ally, the United Democratic Front, are the largest political organizations with a multiracial leadership. The ANC's rank-and-file is overwhelmingly black and male, but the 11-person delegation meeting with the government is comprised of six black men, two black women, two white men and an Indian man. The government side is made up exclusively of male Afrikaners, descendents of Dutch who account for 3 million of the country's 5 million whites. The ANC has millions of black supporters in South Africa and an estimated 15,000 members in exile. Many exiles are expected to return this year and most observers believe the group would win elections if the country's 28 million blacks were allowed to vote. Several ANC rallies have attracted crowds of more than 100,000 people since February, when President F.W. de Klerk legalized the organization after a 30-year ban and freed Nelson Mandela after 27 years in prison. Before de Klerk assumed power last August, government officials frequently denounced the ANC as a Communist-inspired terrorist group that would be barred from any negotiations. But de Klerk has initiated reforms, saying he wants to negotiate an end to apartheid, which has allowed the white minority to maintain political and economic control over blacks. However, he opposes the outright black majority rule favored by the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups. Throughout its history, the ANC has been led by older, well-educated blacks who have sought a negotiated solution to the country's race and political conflicts. Albert Lutuli, ANC president in the 1950s and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, repeatedly wrote to white leaders requesting a meeting. The government never consented, instead outlawing the then-peaceful ANC in 1960. A year later, Mandela, a lawyer, helped launch the ANC's guerrilla campaign, saying it was the only way to oppose apartheid. Most of the leadership was soon arrested or went into exile, and headquarters were established in Lusaka, Zambia. The armed struggle, which the ANC still embraces, has never posed a serious threat to the government. But it has won the support of black youths who have received their political education in street clashes with security forces. One of the ANC's biggest challenges will be to maintain control of its young supporters as the anti-apartheid movement moves from confrontation to negotiation. During nationwide unrest in the mid-1980s, the ANC publicly stated that it wanted to make South Africa ``ungovernable.'' Now, Mandela and other ANC leaders are sending mixed signals, urging supporters to be peaceful and disciplined, but saying the armed struggle should continue. In the southeastern province of Natal, fighting between ANC supporters and Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu group, has claimed 4,000 black lives since 1986. The conflict has intensified in recent months despite pleas for peace by both factions and the government. The government has urged the ANC to formally suspend its largely dormant armed struggle. But should the ANC do so, it would risk losing young supporters to more militant groups such as the Pan Africanist Congress.

DOC.HEAD: No Signs Other Hostages Will be Released: Fitzwater
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Wednesday it has seen no signs pointing toward release of another American hostage in Lebanon. Meanwhile, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush will meet with Frank Reed if the ex-hostage wants to when he returns to the United States. Questioned about the message Reed reportedly was asked to carry to Washington by his captors, Fitzwater said, ``I'm not aware of anything.'' Bush administration officials indicated Tuesday there was nothing new in the oral message another freed hostage, Robert Polhill, relayed to Bush in a White House meeting Monday. Fitzwater, asked Wednesday about reports that Iranian officials were still working to seek freedom for Western hostages, said, ``We don't have any other indications of a release.'' Reed, recuperating at a U.S. Air Force hospital in Wiesbaden, West Germany, said Wednesday he was ``very, very angry'' that Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland were still hostages. Both were kidnapped in 1985. ``Mr. Reed is free to say whatever he wants. I'm sure he was reflecting briefings he has received about the status of events, but he is free to say whatever he likes,'' said Fitzwater. Of Reed, the spokesman said, ``I'm sure if he wants to come in and see the president, a meeting will be arranged. He certainly has every right to do that. ... He has not indicated to us what his preferences are.'' At the State Department, deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said the United States is making indirect contacts with Iran through third parties, including Switzerland, which represents U.S. interests in Tehran. ``We continue to hope that further hostages will be released,'' said Boucher. Sixteen Westerners, including six Americans, remain hostages in Lebanon. Polhill was freed April 22 after 39 months in captivity; Reed on Monday after 43 months. On Tuesday, Fitzwater said all American hostages must be freed before the United States can move beyond the ``small gestures'' of thanks already shown to Iran.

DOC.HEAD: Two Bombs Explode in Colombia, Four Policemen Wounded
DOC.TEXT: Bombs exploded Wednesday in two Colombian cities where major cocaine cartels are based, and authorities said four policemen were wounded. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the blasts. However, since drug traffickers offered rewards three months ago for each policeman killed, 122 officers have been slain, most of them by bombs. In other developments: _The People's Liberation Army, a leftist guerrilla group, kidnapped a federal senator, a radio station said. _Another guerrilla group, the National Liberation Army, reportedly said it wants former President Jimmy Carter to mediate peace talks with the government. Two bombs were hurled from a speeding car at a police station in the western city of Cali at 5:30 a.m. Wednesday, police said. Four policemen were wounded, Lt. Erik Bendec of the national police force in Cali told The Associated Press. In the northwestern city of Medellin, a bomb exploded before dawn just outside the local national police headquarters, a police spokeswoman said. The bomb left a crater 20 feet deep and 30 feet wide but caused no injuries, a woman identifying herself only as Lt. Drusila told the AP. The nation's two largest cocaine cartels are based in Cali and Medellin. Before Colombia declared war on the traffickers, the two cartels reportedly were responsible for 80 percent of the cocaine smuggled into the United States. Sen. Roman Gomez Ovalle was abducted Tuesday near the northern town of Villanueva, in the state of Guajira, radio network RCN said Wednesday in a report that quoted members of the family. The guerrillas later told the family that the senator was kidnapped as part of the rebel group's attempt to start peace talks with the government. Colombian guerrillas frequently kidnap government officials or journalists and release them with messages for the government. Gomez was abducted by the People's Liberation Army, RCN quoted the family as saying. The group recently proposed peace talks with the government. The National Liberation Army, a hard-line Marxist guerrilla group that had said it would never give up its struggle, now wants Carter to mediate in talks with the government, reporters taken to a rebel encampment said Tuesday. In addition to mediating peace talks in Ethiopia's guerrilla conflict, Carter played a prominent role in certifying that Nicaragua's recent presidential election was fair. He also has been invited to oversee elections in Hungary, Romania and the Dominican Republic. The Colombian government already has rejected the idea of mediation by Carter or President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela. However, the fact that the National Liberation Army offered to hold peace talks for the first time is significant and could lead to other offers acceptable to the government. The National Liberation Army proposal was relayed by three reporters, a television camerman and a lawyer who were kidnapped by guerrillas. The five people were taken to a guerrilla encampment on Monday, the group said Wednesday in broadcast interviews. All five were released unharmed Tuesday. The National Liberation Army has been the most anti-American of the guerrilla groups in Colombia. It has concentrated most of its attacks on Colombia's oil industry, including American oil companies. The group also said it was declaring a unilateral cease-fire through the May 27 presidential elections, the reporters said. Past cease-fire offers from guerrilla groups often have been violated.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf of 1st item, `Smirnoffs were ...' to CORRECT spelling of `liqueurs'; a version moved on financial wires
DOC.TEXT: Smirnoff, the vodka of czars that was banished during the Bolshevik Revolution, is going back to the U.S.S.R. as the distillation of ``all that is chic and fashionable about America.'' What a country. ``From a lifestyle point of view, Russians look to Smirnoff as an American symbol, which in a way is ironic,'' said Vivian Brooks, public relations director for Heublein Inc., which distills the Russian-born spirit. Heublein, the Farmington-based liquor and wine company, is taking advantage of easing East-West trade restraints to ship Smirnoff back to the Soviet Union, where it was first distilled in Moscow in 1818 by Peter Smirnoff. It's not like shipping coals to Newcastle, Brooks said. Smirnoff will be marketed to compete with hundreds of vodka brands in the Soviet Union. ``Smirnoff has really reached the point where it represents all that is chic and fashionable about America,'' Brooks said. Smirnoffs were official suppliers of vodka and liqueurs to the Imperial Court until the family business was seized by the Red Army in 1917, and proprietor Vladimir Smirnoff was jailed under a sentence of death. Freed by the White Army, Vladimir escaped to France and sold the family formula to fellow emigre Rudolph Kunett, who made his way to the United States, set up his distillery in Bethel and sold out to Heublein in 1939.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts from Reed's Remarks
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some excerpts from remarks made Wednesday to reporters by freed hostage Frank Reed at the U.S. Air Force hospital in Wiesbaden: ``I tell you, I'm very, very angry that Anderson ... Tom and Terry ... are not free.'' (Reed was referring to two of the six remaining American captives in Lebanon _ Terry Anderson, The Associated Press chief Middle East correspondent and the longest-held Western hostage, and Thomas Sutherland, an American educator). ``I spent the good part of two years with Tom and Terry. Those were the only people I knew. I have not seen Tom and Terry for a while and I don't know where they are. ... For God's sake, it's nearly the sixth year for these men. I'm absolutely embarrassed I'm out before they are.''

Reed also said that he spent three years in the intermittent company of John McCarthy and Brian Keenan, two British hostages. ``I have been with John and Brian since last October. I've spent almost three years either with John and Brian or having them somewhere in the house with me. ``I can assure you and the people of England that John and Brian are well and alive.''

Reed also described his attitude to the U.S. government. ``I thought I was (angry with U.S. officials), but I don't think I am now. On the basis of information I have received ... it appears to me perhaps we are on the right track to getting these people out.''

Reed also talked about his stay in the hospital and plans for going home. ``I'd like to stay another week or two, but they want me out of here on Friday. ... Actually, it's not very good here (at the hospital), and I don't recommend you come in. ``I'd like to have a big Maine lobster, about three pounds (when he gets home).''

DOC.HEAD: Palme Suspect Receives Damages
DOC.TEXT: A Swede whose conviction in the 1986 murder of Prime Minister Olof Palme was overturned last October was awarded $49,000 in damages Wednesday for the 10 months he spent in custody. Christer Pettersson had sought $325,000. Attorney General Hans Stark, in setting the award, said he was influenced by Pettersson's long criminal record and lifestyle as an admitted alcoholic, the TT news agency said. Pettersson was arrested in December 1988 and charged with the shooting. He was sentenced the following July to life imprisonment but then was freed in October by an appeals court that cited a lack of evidence. ``I thought he'd get more, but the government is rather miserly with compensation for psychological suffering,'' said Pettersson's lawyer Arne Liljeros. He said his client was ``marked for life.'' Police investigating the murder have said Pettersson remains a suspect. Palme, a four-term prime minister, was fatally shot while walking home with his wife from a movie. The gunman escaped down a dark street.

DOC.HEAD: ``Father of Television'' Honored With U.S. Capitol Statue
DOC.TEXT: American inventor Philo T. Farnsworth, a pioneer of television, was accorded what many believe was long overdue glory Wednesday when a 7-foot bronze likeness of the electronics genius was dedicated in the U.S. Capitol. With his 81-year-old widow, Elma Farnsworth, looking on, the inventor was extolled as the father of television and his statue was placed in the pantheon of famous Americans of the Capitol's National Statuary Hall. ``I think it's an honor long overdue,'' said Bruce Barnson, who headed a commission that raised $250,000 to place Farnsworth near the likeness of a better-known Utahn, Brigham Young. ``I want to thank you all from the bottom of my heart ... for this great honor,'' Mrs. Farnsworth told an audience at the Capitol dedication. The ceremony included songs from the school choir from Ridgecrest Elementary School in Butler, Utah. Students from Ridgecrest started the drive for the statue after they surveyed Utah residents and recommended to the state legislature that Farnsworth be the second Utahn honored in Statuary Hall. The statue by Utah sculptor James Avanti depicts Farnsworth holding an image dissector tube that was the heart of the electronic television system that he first conceived as a 15-year-old high school student in 1922. Farnsworth is called in an inscription at on the base of the statue the ``Father of Television.'' Farnsworth gained the first patent on his system, the precursor of today's television, in 1934 after winning a patent battle with the powerful RCA corporation, which later paid him $1 million to use his many patents. Most history books list Farnsworth only as one of many early pioneers of television. He died in 1971 while working on fusion research. He had contributed more than 160 inventions, including radar and the electron microscope. He was named to the National Inventors Hall of Fame in 1984. Each state is allowed to honor two of its famous citizens with statues in Statuary Hall. But Utah had placed only Young in the hall.

DOC.HEAD: Space Telescope Resumes Work After Mistake Shuts it Down
DOC.TEXT: An error by a ground controller put the Hubble Space Telescope to sleep again overnight but the $1.5 billion instrument was re-awakened Wednesday and was functioning normally again. It was the third time since the telescope was put into open space April 25 that its electronics were powered down to prevent damage. NASA said the controller at the Goddard Space Flight Center failed to send a signal telling the telescope's lens cover not to close during a testing operation. The 10-foot diameter cover shut and its motion caused the telescope to go into a ``safe-mode.'' ``The spacecraft operated just as it should have,'' the space agency said in a statement. ``The problem was caused by ground controller oversight.'' In the safe-mode, the telescope automatically maintains its position, points its solar arrays to the sun to receive power and activates other functions to protect the spacecraft. The system is designed to safeguard the telescope for 72 hours without ground control. It happened the first time on Friday when engineers sent commands to open the lens cover, formally known as the aperture door. Cautious engineers had set the software to accommodate only a slight bit of motion and the movement of the door exceeded that limit. The second time was also Friday, when one of the telescope's two high-gain antennas was put through its movements. A counterweight on the dish antenna brushed against a cable and the efforts by a motor to overcome the resistance again shut the system down. The biggest impact of Tuesday night's events, NASA said, was that 10 hours in the lengthy start-up and calibration process were lost. But spokesman Jim Elliott said no delay was expected in getting the first picture from the telescope early Saturday. When the telescope first went into its safe-mode last week, the recovery process was a lengthy one. But NASA said Wednesday that problems of that nature are expected during a start-up process that will take more than six months before the first real scientific returns.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Survey Finds Continued Slow Economic Growth
DOC.TEXT: A Federal Reserve survey of regional economic conditions released Wednesday found continued slow growth in April and little sign that industrial prices were rising too fast. ``Overall economic activity continues to expand slowly,'' the central bank said in a survey known as the ``Beige Book,'' prepared by its 12 regional banks for a May 15 monetary policy meeting. The Fed's evaluation of the economy was similar to its last two surveys in March and January, which also reported slow but continued expansion and moderate inflation. However, two separate Commerce Department reports Wednesday indicate economic activity may be rebounding at a faster pace than shown by the Fed survey. The government's Index of Leading Economic Indicators jumped 0.9 in March, the biggest gain in 21 months. Meanwhile, factory orders rose 3.8 percent in March for the largest increase in more than a year. Based on the survey alone, the Fed would appear to be unlikely to move interest rates either up or down, said economist Robert G. Dederick of Chicago's Northern Trust Co. However, Fed policy-makers likely will perceive more danger of inflation than indicated by the report, he said. They likely will be especially concerned with consumer prices, which advanced at an 8.5 percent annual rate during the first three months of this year, compared with a 4.6 percent rate for all of 1989, he said. ``This particular report does not point to the need for any tightening (of credit). This says `Stay as you are.' However, my own view is the odds are they will tighten,'' Dederick said. For most of 1988 and early last year, the Fed nudged rates higher to slow the economy and combat inflation. During the last half of 1989, it permitted rates to fall in an effort to avoid a recession. Since then, it's held short-term rates steady. In the latest survey, most districts report that manufacturing, which had been particularly affected by the higher rates, has either improved or is expected to improve. Despite that, ``no general upward pressure on industrial prices is noted,'' it said. Responding to recent concerns expressed by business groups and members of Congress about a regulatory crackdown on bank lending, the Fed said its regional banks found ``little evidence that a general credit crunch is developing.'' However, it noted, ``virtually every district cites some specific cases of credit tightening by banks, with the most significant action taken by New England banks. ... Still, the majority of businesses say they have not seen any change in credit terms and have not had trouble getting loans.'' Real estate, particularly apartment construction, remains weak, the Fed said. Housing prices continue to fall in the New York metropolitan area and in New England, but there are ``pockets of strength'' in parts of California, in Minneapolis-St. Paul and in upstate and western New York. The central bank survey also pointed to some resilience in the consumer sector, which accounts for two-thirds of the nations' economic activity. ``Retail sales ... reflect slow, positive growth. ... Apparel has been especially strong in most districts,'' the report said. Agriculture, particularly apple and peach crops, was damaged by the cold, wet weather early in the spring, the Fed said. Farmers are optimistic because recent rains have diminished drought fears, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Probing Proposed Swap of Coal for Scenic View
DOC.TEXT: A congressional panel is investigating the proposed swap of coal-rich Wyoming land for a scenic view in Grand Teton National Park _ a deal the panel's chairman calls a ``fire sale'' that will hurt taxpayers. Federal and state governments could lose up to $180 million because of the low value Interior Department officials placed on the coal it is trading, according to documents compiled by the House Government Operations environment subcommittee. The department wants to trade a 2,500-acre tract with 207 million tons of coal for a ``conservation easement'' _ basically a scenic view _ on a ranch in Grand Teton park owned by businessman-conservationist Laurance S.
