Rockefeller. Rockefeller has donated the easement to a New York cancer institute, which would gain the coal tract under the swap. Rockefeller would retain ownership of the land. The government gets a ban on development, preserving the view. The Interior Department denied the deal is a bad one for taxpayers. ``There's no mystery to how we did it,'' said Jay Guerin, a spokesman for Interior's Bureau of Land Management. ``It's the same as other evaluations. It compares to other kinds of tracts and leases involving the federal government.'' The committee plans to question Interior officials on the deal at a hearing Thursday. Panel Chairman Mike Synar, D-Okla. is questioning the decision to value both the easement and the coal at $5.6 million, saying the value of the coal is much higher. Synar said Wednesday it ``strains credulity'' that the department valued the 207 million tons of coal it will give up at 2.7 cents a ton. ``At a time of staggering federal deficits, the Department of the Interior should abandon any thought of disposing of publicly owned assets at fire sale prices,'' Synar said. The 2,500-acre Youngs Creek Tract is located near Sheridan, Wyo. The J-Y Ranch is the largest privately owned section of the park. Rockefeller in 1987 donated the scenic view to the Sloan-Kettering Memorial Institute for Cancer Research. While the department said 2.7 cents a ton is the right value for undeveloped coal in the ground, with no certain market, Synar believes the value should be based on the price that mined coal would bring. When coal is mined on federal land, the government and the state where the vein is located share a royalty of 12.5 percent of the of the selling price. In March 1989 Paul R. Cleary, deputy commissioner of the Wyoming State Land and Farm Loan Office, wrote another state official: ``Assuming a value of $7 per ton and a royalty rate of 12.5 percent, development of the federal coal would generate over $180 million in royalties, of which the state would receive ... some $90 million.'' According to the publication Coal Week, which follows current prices, similar, mined coal in Wyoming sold in mid-April for $4.60 per ton on long term contracts (usually 15-25 years) and $3.80 to $4.60 for contracts under a year. At $4.60, the federal-state royalty would be about $119 million. At $3.80 it would total some $98 million. Guerin, the Interior Department spokesman, said, ``The 2.7 cents is the value of undeveloped, speculative coal with no mine nearby. Speculative means there is no current market for the coal.'' ``The 2.7 cents is a raw product. To make money off that product, you have to put in all kinds of money to develop it,'' he said. To bolster the argument that the deal is unfavorable for taxpayers, the committee released documents indicating the coal would be mined and not sit in the ground. Bruce A. Bugbee, an attorney who will represent Sloan-Kettering at Thursday's hearing, wrote Interior officials last November: ``Sloan-Kettering has identified parties interested in purchasing the coal who are willing to provide assurances they will proceed immediately ... with the goal of obtaining permits prior to 1995.'' In addition, Ash Creek Mining Co., of Tulsa, Okla., has protested the exchange to the department, saying it had sought a federal lease to mine coal on the tract. Synar's office said the investigation has no connection to the fact that Ash Creek is headquartered in his state.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Forces Departure of Americans from Liberia
DOC.TEXT: More than 380 American officials and their dependents have left Liberia in recent days as rebel forces have moved to within striking distance of the capital, the State Department said Wednesday. Deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said he expects that by this weekend, 400 of the 500 official Americans and their dependents will have left the country. He said the exodus was not an evacuation but an ``authorized voluntary departure.'' All those who have left have done so on regular commercial flights. Before the departures got under way, there were about 5,000 Americans in Liberia. There are no precise figures available on the number Americans in unofficial capacities who have left. The government of President Samuel K. Doe has come under increasing pressure since late last year from a rebel group believed to have received financial support from Libya. International relief agencies estimate 250,000 Liberians have been uprooted from their homes since the fighting started. Many have gone to neighboring Guinea or the Ivory Coast. U.S. officials blame excesses by both government and rebel forces for the large number of displaced persons. The fighting had been confined largely to the interior of the country but the rebels recently have been able to advance to areas along the Atlantic coast, encountering minimal resistance from government forces. The Liberian-American Co. rubber plantation, 60 miles east of the capital of Monrovia, is in rebel hands. ``The Liberian armed forces have evaporated outside of Monrovia,'' one official said. The State Department has called on the government and the rebel movement, led by Charles Taylor, to cease the violence. It also has asked the government to create conditions that will permit displaced Liberians to return to their homes. U.S. authorities have asked the opposing sides to pursue a policy of national reconciliation and ensure a climate for elections set for 1991. Doe observed his 10th anniversary in power last month. His relationship with the United States has been uneasy because of alleged human rights violations and economic policies that U.S. officials consider to be unwise. Liberia has been ineligible for U.S. development assistance for years because of failure to repay loans. Liberia was founded a century and a half ago by freed American slaves and generally has had close ties with the United States since then.

DOC.HEAD: Town Mourns Deaths of Three Volunteer Firefighters
DOC.TEXT: Residents of this rural town are mourning for three volunteer firefighters who died while trying to help a neighbor clean out a 38-foot well and were overcome by gas. The deaths were the first in the nearly 25-year history of the 170-member volunteer company in this mountainous region of south-central Pennsylvania, said Assistant Chief Robert Covert. ``They were good-hearted people,'' Covert said Wednesday while he and others lingered at the firehouse. ``That's why they got in trouble. They were too good-hearted. They would never tell anybody no.'' James F. Chestnut Jr., 20, and Richard L. Hershey, 40, both of Hustontown, and Thomas L. Lane, 39, of McConnellsburg, died Tuesday apparently from methane gas that had built up in the hand-dug well, state police said. About two dozen other people were treated at the Fulton County Medical Center, including at least six men who inhaled some of the gas, police said. The firefighters went to the home of Nellie Brown west of town on Monday to pump out her well. She had complained of the odor and suspected an animal had fallen in and died. The volunteers used the pump on their truck without success and returned Tuesday afternoon with a portable pump, state police said. Lane and Larry Traxler of Hustontown entered the well with the pump and took it about halfway down the 3-foot wide shaft. Traxler became dizzy and returned to the surface, but Lane was overcome. Traxler went back for him, but also lost consciousness. Hershey and Traxler's father, Clair, 41, went in, but Hershey was overcome. Others on the surface then called for additional help. One company member, Ed Karczewski, 23, was home with his 22-year-old fiancee, Pam Crouse, when he heard the call for help over the company radio. ``I heard him scream over the air that two men were trapped in a well,'' Karczewski said. He and Ms. Crouse got to the scene just as Chestnut was heading down to help. ``I watched Jimmy go down into the well and I heard this screaming like I never heard before,'' Karczewski said, his eyes filling with tears. He said he felt helpless. ``I mean our hands were tied. We can't be trained for everything. We did the best we could and it wasn't good enough,'' he said. Firefighter Howard Melott, 21, of Hustontown removed Chestnut and Traxler. Traxler was revived. Lane fell into water at the bottom of the well and was the last to be removed, three or four hours later. Covert said firefighters usually wear air packs when they enter areas that might be contaminated, but he said the men thought the problem in the well was caused by a dead animal. Lane and Chestnut were with the fire company since they were junior members, while Hershey joined about three years ago, Covert said. The mood in the town of about 400 people was quiet Wednesday. Clusters of people were at the firehouse. White puffs of spent dandelions perched on spindly shoots in the pale green fields that run to the ridges framing the narrow valleys. Firefighter Karczewski said he hopes other fire companies learn from their tragedy. ``They should step back and look at it,'' he said. The funerals are set for Friday and Monday. In the meantime, other companies are handling fire calls. Thomas Moriarty, who heads a stress-coping team from Shippensburg University, said he and others talked with about 65 firefighters and ambulance workers Tuesday night. ``We let them know that they are perfectly normal and they are not losing their minds and it's OK to hurt,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pays Taxes Omitted in Error
DOC.TEXT: President Bush had to pay an additional $7,497 in federal income taxes Wednesday due to an error in the reporting of his 1989 income, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. The president had to file an amended return because the one he sent to the IRS last month did not include income from deferred compensation he collected last year. He was eligible for that compensation when he turned 65 last June 12, under an arrangement with Zapata Corp., the now-defunct oil company he once headed, Fitzwater said. The added income was brought to the attention of the tax preparers after they had submitted his tax return last month, according to the explanation on his amended form. The deferred compensation was received in the form of a paid-up life insurance policy and should have been reported because it had a cash value. The life insurance policy was valued at $26,250. The president paid interest of $40.77, which accrued on the unpaid tax for 15 days since the income tax filing deadline, Fitzwater said. There was no penalty, Fitzwater said, because the mistake was deemed to be due to ``reasonable cause.'' With the mistake corrected, Bush paid total taxes of $108,879 on income of $483,030.

DOC.HEAD: Calls Rise For Feds to Fight Telephone Sales Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers, state attorneys general and consumer agency officials called on Wednesday for federal legislation that would make it easier to fight the $1 billion telephone sales fraud industry. ``For many people the telephone is becoming a way to reach out and rob someone,'' said Rep. Thomas A. Luken, D-Ohio. Janet Steiger, chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission, said consumers lose more than $1 billion annually to telemarketing scams. ``Current enforcement authority is not sufficient to swiftly and effectively deal with those who defraud the American consumer,'' said Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., as the Senate Commerce Committee's consumer subcommittee considered two bills to require the FTC to issue rules governing telemarketing. A House committee last fall approved similar legislation sponsored by Luken. Steiger said the agency already has increased efforts ``to attack the root of fraud, such as suppliers and other aiders and abettors'' of soliciting operations. Telephone fraud has grown widely in recent years for operations that offer phony prizes and try to sell shoddy merchandise, including supposedly rare gemstones coins. Steiger also said the FTC also has increased cooperation with the states. The proposed legislation would require the FTC to develop rules for and define telemarketing. It would allow states and individuals to file federal suit for alleged violation of those rules. Currently, they can only sue in state courts and the FTC sues in federal court. In addition, one provision would address what Bryan called ``buyer's remorse'' by giving consumers a ``cooling-off period'' or specified time in which they could change their minds before a telephone purchase became final. Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., said the problem requires a federal response because fraudalent telemarketers often evade prosecution merely by moving from one state to another. ``The nature of a telemarketing operation is not a fixed location,'' said Bryan, who heads the subcommittee. The National Association of Consumer Agency Administrators, the National Association of Attorneys General, the Direct Marketing Association and the National Tour Association support the proposed legislation.

DOC.HEAD: Chart Shows Poor Student Achievement, Fewer Graduates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf pvs `The test ...' with 1 graf to DELETE reference to states administering either the SAT or ACT
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Student Achievement-List
DOC.TEXT: Despite ballyhooed efforts at education reform, student achievement is continuing a decline that began three years ago, the government said Wednesday in a controversial report. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos said the annual state-by-state performance chart, popularly called the wall chart, ``makes it clear that, as a nation, we are still not seriously committed to improving education for all Americans.'' The chart has been criticized as promoting flawed data and making unfair state comparisons. Timothy Dyer, executive director of the National Association of Secondary School Principals, said American ``young people are simply too complex to hang on a wall.'' The chart, he said, ``has as much to offer educational improvement as the Edsel offered the automotive industry.'' Cavazos, however, defended the chart. ``It is the only national measurement of educational performance,'' he said. ``It's the best that we have. Until we develop other measures, we will have to rely on the wall chart.'' Officials say the White House argued for abandoning the 7-year-old practice this year because President Bush and the nation's governors had worked to develop national education goals and still are devising more accurate forms of assessment. The report found that the average American College Testing Program examination scores declined nationally by 0.2 of a point, to 18.6, from 1988 to 1989, while the average Scholastic Aptitude Test scores declined by one point, to 903, during the same period. A perfect ACT score is 36; a perfect SAT score is 1,600. The test scores are used by colleges and universities as one standard of admission. The report also found that the national high school graduation rate declined from 71.7 percent to 71.1 percent from 1987 to 1988; the percentage of public high school graduates who received a qualifying score on advanced placement examinations declined from 8.8 percent to 8.6 percent between 1988 and 1989. Bill Honig, California superintendent of public instruction, said the chart ``causes more mischief than benefit'' because much of the data is a rehash of statistics already made public. Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association, said the chart ``only continues to confuse and frustrate the public.'' Monty Neill, associate director of the National Center for Fair & Open Testing, said the chart should include a consumer protection label: ``Warning! Misuse of Standardized Test Scores Can Damange the Nation's Educational Health.'' Neill said the administration uses misleading and inaccurate scores from multiple-choice exams to rate the quality of education. He said using standardized test scores to compare school systems is a technique that even test manufacturers oppose. Of the 28 states that offer the ACT, the report said, North Dakota, Alabama, Nevada and Utah showed the greatest improvement between 1982 and 1989. Improving in SAT scores during the same years were South Carolina, Hawaii, the District of Columbia, Maryland and New Jersey. States showing a decline in ACT scores were Alaska, Minnesota, Nebraska, Wisconsin and Iowa. Declining in SAT scores were New York, Florida, Pennsylvania, Vermont and Delaware. However, the highest scoring states on the ACT were Iowa, Wisconsin, Montana, Minnesota, Colorado and Nebraska. Highest scoring states on the SAT were New Hampshire, Oregon, Maryland, Connecticut and California. The report said that the states with the highest graduation rates in 1988 were Minnesota at 90.9 percent, North Dakota 88.3 percent, Wyoming 88.3 percent, Montana 87.3 percent and Iowa 85.8 percent. States with the lowest graduation rates in 1988 were Florida at 58 percent, the District of Columbia 58.2 percent, Georgia 61 percent, Arizona 61.1 percent and Louisiana 61.4 percent. ``Too many people believe that the education deficit is somebody else's problem, that somebody else's schools are the ones that don't work, that somebody else's children are the ones who are failing to learn,'' Cavazos said.

DOC.HEAD: Gadhafi Reportedly Offered to Dismantle Poison Gas Plant
DOC.TEXT: The Libyan government secretly offered to dismantle a plant that U.S officials said produces poison gas shortly before a fire was reported there in March, diplomats said. The offer was contingent on Western countries paying ``compensation'' and agreeing to build a pharmaceutical factory to replace the plant, Western and Middle Eastern diplomats based in Tripoli said Tuesday and Wednesday. Libya has claimed the plant in Rabta, 60 miles southwest of Tripoli, produces pharmaceuticals. The offer was not accepted, but some diplomats say it is significant because it indicates Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi is moving to resolve the bitter clash with the United States over the plant. ``This shows that at least some Libyans (in the government) ... are keen to have the Rabta problem solved, in such a way that will not make Libya lose face,'' one Western diplomat said. He pointed out that the Rabta plant was an obstacle to Libya's recent efforts to end its international isolation. But other diplomats said the offer could merely have been an attempt to head off a possible U.S. military strike at the plant. The proposal comes at a time when Libya and the United States appear to have quietly resumed indirect contacts, said the diplomats, who spoke on condition their names not be used. Numerous requests for interviews at the Libyan foreign ministry were not granted and lower-ranking officials refused comment. The cause and extent of the March fire at Rabta are still unknown. The United States initially said the blaze caused heavy damage to the plant. But later news reports said U.S. authorities, after a review of satellite photographs, decided the fire was actually a hoax, apparently an attempt to head off any U.S. military action against the plant. The photos reportedly showed that burn marks were painted on the building. Diplomats said a Western European embassy employee who visited Rabta this week reported the building was still standing but appeared abandoned. Roadblocks near Rabta and missiles around it had been removed, according to the report, which could not be independently verified. Libya's version of the story changed in the opposite direction. Libya first told diplomats that the blaze had caused little damage. But later, it reported there had been a ``huge fire,'' and said it suspected the United States, Britain or West Germany of responsibility. The official Libyan news agency JANA said Wednesday that two West Germans were being interrogated about the blaze. A West Germany foreign ministry spokesman confirmed two employees of a German company that helped build the Rabta plant have been held by the Libyans since March 25.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Encouraged by Salvador's Promise in Jesuit Slayings
DOC.TEXT: El Salvador's promise to push for a trial in the murder of six Jesuits priests is encouraging, the Bush administration said Wednesday. However, Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson said the United States would closely watch how San Salvador responds to a congressional report that strongly criticized its investigation. ``There's a sense that (the investigation) has gotten stalled,'' Aronson said. ``The report raises serious questions that need to be addressed.'' A Salvadoran colonel and eight other military personnel have been charged in the Nov. 16 killing of the six priests in the Salvadoran capital. El Salvador said Tuesday that President Alfredo Cristiani hopes the case will go to trial within 90 days. The action comes in the face of growing criticism on Capitol Hill, where a new aid package for El Salvador is being considered. Secretary of State James A. Baker III will send the congressional report to Cristiani, Aronson said, adding that Baker has ``made it clear that the resolution of this case will be one important element in determining the nature of future U.S. assistance.'' The Bush administration wants $375 million for El Salvador next year, including $90 million in military assistance. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., appointed 19 members of Congress under the chairmanship of Rep. Joe Moakley, D-Mass., to examine the Salvadoran investigation. Aronson said El Salvador's statement about the case was ``a good step forward, but the questions that the Moakley report raised ought to be addressed.'' He also said the Salvadoran government announced it would question officers that the congressional report said should be interviewed. The report said Salvadoran officials, inclding the judge in the case, appear reluctant to ask questions or follow leads that appear to implicate high ranking military personnel. Baker told Congress on Tuesday that he would be open to a new bipartisan policy toward El Salvador that could include conditions on future aid. Such conditions might relate to the investigation in the Jesuit murder case and progress on United Nations-sponsored peace talks. With those talks still pending, the leftist rebels Tuesday launched a ferocious attack in San Salvador, cutting power to much of the city. Aronson said ``those attacks fly in the face and give the lie to (the rebel's) professed desire to negotiate.''

DOC.HEAD: Angry Judge Stiffens Fines For Underage Drinking and Loud Parties
DOC.TEXT: FARGO, N.D. _ After watching hours of raucus drinking and swearing at a party near his daughter's house, a judge tripled his fines for underage drinkers in an effort to ``take back the streets from the nightcrawlers.'' One attorney said Judge Thomas Davies' new policy ``smacks of age discrimination,'' but the judge called such talk ``absolute nonsense.'' Davies said that by raising the fines for minors in possession of alcohol and for violations of Fargo's loud party ordinance, he hopes to prevent young people from developing serious problems with alcohol when they are older. ``I decided somebody's got to do something,'' Davies said. ``Maybe if these kids start thinking of the beer they're holding in their hand as costing $300, they'll think twice about drinking it.'' Davies, 51, who has a reputation for being tough on young drinkers, said he watched for two hours Saturday night while high school and college men and women wreaked havoc in his daughter's neighborhood. The revelers were drinking, swearing loudly, running through people's yards and berating neighbors for calling the police, he said. ``When the party was done, I thought, `This is Fargo, N.D.?' I thought I knew my city. I thought I knew the kids,'' said Davies. The judge said he is responding by increasing the fine in his court for possession of alcohol by minors from $100 to $300 and the fine for noise violations from $350 to $500 _ the maximum fine allowed under city law. North Dakota's legal drinking age is 21. ``I want people in this city to know that there are people out there who do care, who want to take the streets back from the nightcrawlers,'' he said. Attorneys who have appeared before Davies declined to comment on the move, but they describe the judge as ``very strict'' on underage drinking and possession charges. Dwight Kautzmann, former president of the state Bar Association, said the stricter fines may provoke charges of age discrimination. ``I think the good judge might want to reconsider his position,'' he said. But Davies said he doesn't worry about how others view his sentences. ``I don't take an opinion poll on how they might be received by the public,'' he said. ``I basically operate from the gut.''

DOC.HEAD: Conference Calls for `Global Marshall Plan'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 5 grafs new material after 5th graf pvs, More than.
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON (AP) An international group of legislators called for immediate action to curb ``greenhouse'' pollutants Wednesday and recommended a ``global Marshall Plan'' to help developing countries cope with environmental problems. Concluding a three-day environment conference, the delegates from 42 countries urged nations to commit without delay to cutting the pollution that causes global warming by 50 percent over the next 20 years. The actions by the Interparliamentary Conference on the Global Environment are little more than suggestions for an environmental game plan and are not binding on any country. But many of the delegates to the conference, hosted by the U.S. Congress, said they would return home to push for legislative action along the lines outlined. The aggressive strategies on global warming contrasted to the approach favored by President Bush and senior White House officials. Bush two weeks ago told an international White House Conference on the environment that more research was needed before any commitments are made for specific pollution controls. More than 200 lawmakers from 42 nations, including the Soviet Union, most European countries, Japan and many developing nations, were participating in the conference. While participants promised to work on behalf of some of the conference goals and recommendations, few suggested the effort would produce new laws anytime soon. ``This conference has given us an agenda for action,'' said James Miruka Owuor, a conference co-chairman from Kenya. ``I think this is a message to the executive branch here in the United States'' and in other countries as well, said Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., the conference chairman. ``For any prime minister or president who says delay, we are saying ... the time is now to act.'' Gore did not name President Bush, but told a news conference that the three-day sessions ``stand in very sharp contrast'' to the White House conference on global warming two weeks earlier. ``We have come to a consensus agreement that the need for action is now, that the need for action is urgent,'' said Gore, who in the past has chided the Bush administration for failing to exert leadership on dealing with the ``greenhouse'' issue. The gathering agreed on a broad range of environmental goals, including actions aimed at protecting the ozone layer, reversing the loss of forests and committing greater resources to population control. The policy statements, however, provided few specifics on how some of these efforts would be paid for, including the proposed plan by industrial nations to help developing countries. This so-called ``global Marshall plan for sustainable development and the environment'' would be patterned on the post-World War II economic assistance efforts by the United States that helped Europe recover from the war, officials said. On global warming, the conference declared, ``The time to act is now. Delay exposes us, our children and their children to calamities which we will have made irrevocable by inaction in the present.'' In contrast to the recent international White House conference, the legislative delegates in their policy recommendations scarcely touched on the need for more research. Instead, the delegates called for setting a timetable for secific cuts in global warming pollutants by the year 2010, including a 20 percent reduction in carbon dioxide emissions, a product of burning fossil fuels; elimination of chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, and a variety of other ozone-depleting chemicals; and a 10 percent reduction in methane emissions. Altogether, that would amount to about a 50 percent reduction in global-warming pollutants by 2010, conference organizers said.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors And Hospitals Hampering Organ Donors' Wishes
DOC.TEXT: Organ donation efforts are hampered by physicians and hospital officials who decline to act on a patient's wish to be a donor until they have the family's consent, said a report released Wednesday. ``Even though a person wishes to donate, he or she may not do so after death unless his next-of-kin can be located and agree to the donation,'' said the report produced by a conference of 130 physicians, scientists and other medical and media experts. ``An individual's decision to donate should in every case be respected,'' the conference report said. The report noted that after years of increases in organ donors, the number has leveled off in recent years and dipped slightly in 1989 to 3,993 from 4,069 the year before. Each donor gives an average of three organs. Last year, 13,290 transplants were performed, about 5 percent more than the 12,669 done in 1988, according to the United Network for Organ Sharing, which contracts with the federal government to run a national organ distribution network and registry. Currently, 20,466 potential organ transplant patients are on the UNOS waiting list. For every 40 Americans who die, one donates an organ or tissue, according to Joel Swerdlow, a conference a public policy analyst at the Annenberg Washington Program in Communications Policy Studies, which is part of Northwestern University. If a patient has expressed a wish in the form of a donor card to give their organs after they die, physicians can act legally on that wish, Swerdlow said. But physicians and hospital officials are reluctant, fearing that family members might be upset and stir bad publicity for the hospital, he said. The conference report also recommended that a nationwide bone marrow donation network be created and that the existing organ donation networks be consolidated and coordinated into a single network. The existing organ donation system, which is carried out through several different networks and transplant centers, matches available organs with patients in need. ``We do that well, but we have to do that better,'' said Dr. Gary Friedlaender, chief of orthopedics and rehabilitation at Yale New Haven Hospital in Connecticut. The conference report also recommended better efforts to educate the public and health care professionals about the need for organ donors. The conference was sponsored by the Annenberg Center for Health Sciences, which is part of Eisenhower Medical Center in Rancho Mirage, Calif., the American Medical Association and the Annenberg Washington Program.

DOC.HEAD: Alexander The Great Just Got Better
DOC.TEXT: Alexander the Great got a posthumous addition to his empire Wednesday courtesy of George Bush. It came as the president was talking up his ``points of light'' initiaive to a group of 175 youths from the Washington area. Bush was extolling some of history's early achievers. ``By the age of 32, Alexander the Great's empire stretched from Indiana _'' said Bush, who caught his own gaffe and broke into laughter. ``Indiana? It included Indiana,'' he laughed, then corrected himself, ``From India to the Adriatic.'' ``Youth is no barrier to great achievements,'' Bush told the first Presidential Youth Leadership Forum, intended to encourage all young Americans to involve themselves in community service. Bush also pointed out that Joan of Arc was only 16 when she began her quest to drive the English from France, and Mozart had composed 250 pieces by the time he was 20. As a sendoff, Bush watched Riakos L. Adams, student body president of Banneker High School, use hand signals to lead the crowd through a chorus of sighs and grunts. ``He might be the next Mozart, but I don't know what the hell he's saying,'' quipped Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Says Boosting Farm Program Benefits Not in Cards
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Wednesday that advocates of congressional bills to boost farm program benefits ignore budget realities. ``Maybe these big high numbers make good campaign material back home, but the day of reckoning is coming,'' he said. A number of 1990 farm bill measures have been approved or are under consideration by subcommittees that exceed limits set by Capitol Hill and Bush administration budget cutters. Recent examples include action to sweeten programs for sugar, cotton and rice. Other commodities, including soybeans, wheat and feed grains, would be affected by supports or payments being tied to production costs. Yeutter said these proposals will be eliminated or watered down by the full agricultural committees, during floor debate or in meetings to settle differences between the House and Senate versions. The subcommittees are ``living in a dream world'' and will have to be pulled back to reality by pressures on federal spending, he said. Yeutter mentioned ``two-tier'' dairy price support proposals, which he said would contradict U.S. objectives to liberalize world trade through the ongoing Uruguay Round of negotiations. Yeutter also told a meeting of American Farm Bureau Federation leaders that he is ``not going to back off at all'' on the administration's proposal for more flexibility in the 1990 farm bill. The administration wants the measure, which will be a blueprint for U.S. farm policy over the next five years, to allow farmers more leeway in deciding the mix of crops they plant on their base acreages. ``I don't know of a single farmer who wouldn't like to have more flexibility in his operation,'' Yeutter said. The issue of federal crop insurance and disaster aid represents ``a tremendous dilemma'' for lawmakers and the administration, he said. Federal crop insurance has not been a successful program, and emergency disaster aid for drought and other weather problems has been a costly alternative in recent years. Thus, Yeutter said, the administration has recommended Congress switch to some kind of permanent disaster program. There is no clearly visible way to repair crop insurance without huge costs, he said. Yeutter said that if Congress insists on saving crop insurance, the money might have to come from reducing target prices for major crops. Those are used to calculate income subsidies, or deficiency payments, to farmers when market prices are low.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Wants to Link Pay to Performance
DOC.TEXT: A Bush administration plan to link federal employees' pay to performance would provide extra compensation for workers who live in New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco, officials said Wednesday. The proposal also would let the government ignore salary caps for hiring 400 ``world class'' experts for such fields as nuclear safety and medical research. ``We're having trouble recruiting and retaining people to run this government,'' Constance Newman, director of the Office of Personnel Management, said in releasing the administration's pay proposal, which would affect about 1.4 million white-collar workers. Similar pay-for-performance proposals have been rejected by Congress in the past, but Ms. Newman said lawmakers were beginning to realize the government's inability to compete with private industry. The administration's plan was introduced in both the House and the Senate this week. Last month, unions that represent government employees criticized the proposal, saying government pay cannot be reformed without additional money. The OPM's plan, which provides an additional $1.5 billion for the 1991 fiscal year, would award federal employee pay raises based on performance rather than tenure. In addition, the OPM, which handles personnel matters for the federal bureaucracy, is asking for congressional authority to eliminate the system that awards pay increases every year. The administration's plan, which makes dozens of changes that would not become fully effective until 1995, calls for providing geographic differentials to employees in certain cities where the federal government has the most trouble competing with private industry. The plan would eventually provide differentials of up to 25 percent above the worker's base salary level in cities with high labor costs and area-wide staffing problems. Though all of the cities that would fall under the geographic differential category haven't been determined, the plan calls for immediately providing 8 percent pay boosts to workers in New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco. Other high-cost cities such as Washington, D.C., and Boston might also be included if studies showed the differential was needed for recruitment, Ms. Newman said. The legislation would let the government pay as much as it wanted for experts in highly competitive fields such as medical or scientific research, Ms. Newman said. The cap on such pay now is $78,200.

DOC.HEAD: Visiting West German Head of State Assures Poland on Border
DOC.TEXT: West German President Richard von Weizsaecker reiterated Wednesday that Poland's western border is inviolable and said an agreement will be reached guaranteeing its permanence. ``We agree on the course we have to chart,'' he said. ``We want to bring settlement about and we will bring it about.'' Weizsaecker, the first West German head of state to visit Poland, began his four-day visit by meeting President Wojciech Jaruzelski and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. Weizsaecker's agenda also includes meetings with Solidarity leader Lech Walesa and Roman Catholic Primate Jozef Glemp, among others. He also will visit the former Nazi death camp at Treblinka, and Gdansk, the former Free City of Danzig, where the German army shelled the small Polish garrison to begin World War II. Weizaecker told Polish television, ``We cannot assess the modern times without preserving memories. ``I think that youth should have their share in the painful awareness that the Germans were the ones who had brought war, occupation and lawlessness to Poland, that they had done harm to many millions of Poles even though they bear no personal responsibility for that.'' With Weizsaecker was Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who met with Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski to discuss a treaty to be signed by a united Germany establishing the permanence of Poland's postwar western border. A representative of the East German Foreign Ministry will join talks on the treaty Thursday, the Polish news agency PAP reported. ``We have difficult years and difficult months behind us. ... The substance of the matter has been clarified,'' Weizsaecker said. His trip comes as Poland seeks security guarantees before the two Germanys unify, and it marks a new stage in the centuries of complex, often bloody relations between the neighboring nations. West Germany is Poland's largest Western trading partner, and its support is critical to the success of economic and political reforms undertaken by the new, non-communist government. But with an older generation that recalls the devastating World War II invasion and occupation, Poland harbors feelings of bitterness and distrust toward Germany. In the rush toward unification, embraced by powers worldwide, Poland has raised its concerns. Weizsaecker said, ``Against the backdrop of recent developments, we can all agree on ... how much depends on German-Polish relations, not only for our two nations but for the whole of Europe. ``We are all aware there are still problems of a psychological and material nature to overcome.'' Poland wants a seat at unification talks to guarantee its postwar western border, and wants a treaty with the two Germanys and the new government of a united Germany making it permanent. Drawn along the Oder and Neisse rivers, the boundary incorporates into Poland 40,000 square miles of land from the defeated Germany. The territory was to compensate Poland for a larger section annexed by the Soviet Union. Leaders in both Germanys offered promises concerning the border. This week, Poland submitted a draft treaty to the two Germanys and the four victorious World War II allies _ the United States, Soviet Union, Britian and France _ which will meet Saturday in Bonn to lay groundwork for unification talks. ``The border as it is today ... will be inviolable,'' Weizsaecker said in Warsaw. The president said Germany and Poland share a mutual interest in ensuring reform and avoiding instability in the Soviet Union. ``This German inspires confidence,'' read a headline in Wednesday's pro-Solidarity newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza, over a profile outlining Weizsaecker's long support for Poland's border concerns. Chancellor Helmut Kohl, head of the West German government, visited Poland last November.

DOC.HEAD: CDC: Report That One in Four NYC Men Infected Incorrect
DOC.TEXT: News reports suggesting that one in four younger men in New York is AIDS-infected are incorrect, the Centers for Disease Control said Wednesday. The publication Medical Tribune sparked a flurry of news stories with a report this week that ``in the New York City-New Jersey region, one in four men aged 25-44 is seropositive for AIDS.'' Other news reports said the figure applied to males 25-44 in New York City itself. Dr. James Curran, director of the CDC's Division of HIV and AIDS, said the news reports were triggered when a CDC AIDS researcher told a medical conference in Baltimore that a single hospital in the New York-New Jersey area had reported a 24 percent infection rate among men 25-44. ``That data is from one hospital,'' Curran said, adding that the rate was different at another participating hospital in the New York-New Jersey area and a third has yet to complete its reporting. ``It's correct for the prevalence at that one hospital,'' Curran said, but he added, ``A single hospital cannot be extrapolated to a city, particularly one of 8 million people.'' The CDC, in tracking AIDS trends across the nation, is conducting a study of AIDS infection rates at more than 40 hospitals nationwide to gauge infection rates among patients who come to the hospital with non-AIDS complaints. Editors at Medical Tribune said they are standing by their report, which cited findings as presented by the CDC researcher, Dr. Tim Dondero. Dondero was not available for comment Wednesday; he is currently in China, Curran said. CDC officials said the study of infection rates at various hospitals is continuing and results are expected to be compiled and released later this year. By their very nature, hospitals are a good place to examine the results of blood testing, Curran said. The CDC also is monitoring infection rates among groups including military personnel, prison inmates and even American Indians. ``It's meant to give us a broad look at HIV infection,'' he said. ``But there are wide variations of HIV infection.'' The CDC has yet to release findings from the hospital survey, and CDC officials would not identify the New York-New Jersey hospital with the high infection rate. Curran said even though the hospital survey findings should not be projected to the general population, ``we don't want to say it's not an important problem.

DOC.HEAD: Portrait of Ben Franklin Recovered
DOC.TEXT: A portrait of Benjamin Franklin, stolen from the Boston Public Library last month, has been recovered by the FBI. The painting, valued at $50,000, was returned through an intermediary, who said the man who took it did so as a prank, according to the FBI. The man is negotiating through an attorney for immunity from charges in exchange for returning the painting. His identity has not been disclosed to the FBI, the agency said. The portrait, painted by Joseph-Siffred Duplessis, was a gift to Boston in 1858. The artist painted the picture in Paris when Franklin, the U.S. ambassador to France, was 70. The painting was reported stolen April 13 after a library official noticed it was missing from its frame.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Honors Disabled American Of The Year
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday honored the 1990 Disabled American of the Year and plugged legislation to guaranteed civil rights for the handicapped because ``disabled citizens have waited long enough for equality.'' Bush presented the President's Trophy to David Schwartzkopf of Rochester, Minn., a high technology professional who has cerebral palsy and is legally blind. In remarks to the annual conference of the President's Committee on Employment of People With Disabilities, Bush called for speedy House action on the pending Americans With Disabilities Act which has been hailed as the most significant piece of civil rights legislation since the 1964 Civil Rights Act banned discrimination based on race, color, national origin, sex and religion. The bill guarantees access to transportation, telephone systems and businesses, professional services and employment. It would, for instance, make it unlawful to deny a job or a service to someone on the basis of that person's disability or perceived disability. ``No longer can we allow ignorance or prejudice to deny opportunities to millions of Americans with disabilities,'' Bush said. ``We welcome you the disabled into the mainstream of American life because it is your life as well as ours.'' More than two-thirds of the disabled Americans of working age are unemployed, Bush said, calling that statistic ``intolerable.'' ``Much of that unemployment stems from lack of opportunity,'' he said. ``Every American should be able to join the work force to the fullest extent of their abilities,'' he said. ``I look forward to signing a bill that will address the needs of our disabled citizens. And frankly, it is my view that disabled citizens have waited long enough for equality.'' The disabilities legislation, protecting all kinds of handicapped including AIDS victims, enjoys wide support in Congress, but Republicans have sought to change the pending House version as business interests, stew about sanctions that would imposed on employers found guilty of discrimination. The Senate passed its version last year. The president's committee on the disabled is a small government agency that focuses on developing employment opportunities. Schwartzkopf, the disabled American of the year, is program manager with IBM in Rochester, currently working for the state jobs department as assistant commission of rehabilitation services.

DOC.HEAD: Latvians Unveil Independence Plan, Without Moscow's Wrath
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Latvian Popular Front on Wednesday unveiled an independence plan that it hopes would bring the Baltic republic freedom within years without incurring Moscow's wrath. Deputies from the Popular Front told an evening news conference they believed they had enough votes to get the draft measure passed in a session of Latvia's Supreme Soviet parliament that opens Thursday. The Popular Front plan would declare independence as a gesture but actual independence would occur only after an unspecified transition period that deputies estimated would last several years. Estonia, like Lithuania an independence-minded Baltic neighbor, passed a similar measure March 30. Popular Front deputies said they agreed to the measure after watching Lithuania declare independence March 11 and then struggle unsuccessfully to persuade Moscow to begin negotiations. ``We didn't slam the door and then start to knock,'' said Romans Apsitis, a law professor. ``We're leaving the door open and still moving toward independence.'' Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov, expected to be re-elected Thursday, said the proposal took into account talks that already have begun with Moscow. The session also will vote on dropping the ``Soviet Socialist'' from Latvia's name, leaving it simply ``The Republic of Latvia,'' said Deputy Janis Krumins. The Popular Front proposal would leave most of the republic's Soviet-era constitution intact, but it would also assert Latvia's claim to independence on its historic territory and its right to re-establish its traditional parliament. Despite the conciliatory tone of the Latvian proposal, deputies said they were against following the guidelines for secession laid down in a Soviet law passed in April that makes it difficult for a republic to leave the union. Apsitis said at most Latvia would consider a role in a reconfigured Soviet confederation _ but only after gaining independence. Unlike Lithuania, where native Lithuanians make up 80 percent of the population, native Latvians make up about 54 percent of Latvia's 2.7 million residents. The rest are largely Russians who frown on secession. Despite their ethnic disadvantage, Latvian nationalists have been pushing full force for the parliament to emulate Lithuania. Of the 199 members of Latvia's new Supreme Soviet elected in March, 131 are popular front supporters and several more are sympathizers, a deputy said. They need 133 votes for the required two-thirds majority to pass the independence measure. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev recently warned Latvian delegates that he would offer the republic special status in a reconfigured federation but he would not accept Lithuanian-style outright secession. In the past year, Latvia has copied Lithuania's daring political moves. In December, it abolished the Communist Party's guarantee on power; in February it condemned the 1940 act that formalized its annexation by the Soviet Union; and last month a large segment of its Communist Party broke off from its Moscow-based parent party. All the moves came within months, sometimes weeks, of similar Lithuanian actions. Latvian activists have also created a shadow parliament to represent mainly native Latvians. The Latvian Citizens' Congress, representing 700,000 pre-1940 residents and their children, convened Monday and Tuesday to demand restoration of the independence the republic lost in 1940 when Latvia was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union along with Lithuania and Estonia. The congress claims the right to replace the Supreme Soviet during the transition to independence. If the parliament votes against independence, the congress plans to set itself up as an ``alternative authority,'' Tass said. A poll published Monday by the Soviet newspaper Izvestia said 92 percent of ethnic Latvians surveyed favor secession. Of the non-Latvian residents of the republic, 45 percent were for independence, said the poll. It did not specify its sample size or margin of error.

DOC.HEAD: German Unification Monetary Agreement at a Glance
With AM-Germany-Unification
DOC.TEXT: Here are some main points of the agreement Wednesday between the two German states on monetary union:

DATE _ Monetary union, a major step toward unification, will become effective July 2. Until then and effective at once, the official exchange rate for West Germans and foreigners going to East Germany will be two East German marks for one West German mark, instead of the 3-1 rate in force previously.

IMPACT _ West Germany's powerful currency will replace East Germany's mark, which is virtually worthless outside East Germany. This will give East Germans opportunity to travel widely and buy Western consumer goods. But it is expected to cause wide unemployment as East German companies are forced to close as demand for their products drops.

SAVINGS _ East Germany pushed for a 1-1 rate of conversion for savings, but not all savings will be converted at that rate. East Germans aged 14 and under will be able to convert up to 2,000 marks at 1-1. Those aged 15 to 59 will be able to convert 4,000 marks at 1-1, and people 60 and older, up to 6,000 marks. All other savings will be converted at two East German marks for one West German mark.
SALARIES _ Salaries will be converted at a 1-1 rate.
PENSIONS _ East German pensions will be brought to the West German levels, meaning most of them will be raised.
RENTS _ Also to be converted at 1-1 rate.
DEBTS _ To be converted at a 2-1 rate, more favorable to troubled East German companies.

DOC.HEAD: Still Planning for 14 Carriers
DOC.TEXT: The Navy is basing its aircraft purchase plans on the assumption it will have 14 carrier battle groups, even though Defense Secretary Dick Cheney says fewer are likely, a top officer told Congress Wednesday. ``Right now the guidance is 14 carrier battle groups,'' Vice Adm. Richard Dunleavy, assistant chief of naval operations, told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee. In announcing cuts in Pentagon plans to buy the B-2 stealth bomber and other sophisticated aircraft, Cheney recommended purchasing a smaller number of the Navy's A-12 all-weather medium attack planes _ a minimum of 620 instead of the original request of 858. The cuts could mean elimination of two of the Navy's 14 aircraft carrier battle groups, Cheney said. Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., chairman of the subcommittee on conventional forces and alliance defense, questioned Dunleavy on whether the Navy's acquisition plans for the A-12 and other aircraft is predicated on 14 or 12 carrier battle groups. ``Presumption of 14,'' Dunleavy responded. Fewer battle groups would limit the service's ability ``to be there and do exactly what you want at a moment's notice.'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, has suggested 10 or 12 carriers is appropriate. ``Below 12, you're becoming a very hollow force,'' Dunleavy said. A battle group consists of a carrier plus the escorting warships, usually four or five, without which it cannot fight. Cheney's plan to delay purchases of the Advanced Tactical Fighter may force the Navy to request additional production of the F-14D jet fighter, Dunleavy said. The F-14D, built by Grumman Corp., was a major point of contention between Congress and the Bush administration last year. Cheney proposed canceling it; Congress decided to buy 18 planes while requiring the manufacturer to sign a termination contract. ``We may come back to Congress and suggest reconsideration of new manufacture of F-14D to make it last until the follow-on fighter comes on,'' Dunleavy said. But if Cheney decides to reduce the carrier battle groups, additional F-14D fighters may be unnecessary, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Reed `Very Angry' That Hostages Remain in Lebanon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf `Reed, 57' to CORRECT duel to dual. Picks up 10th pvs, `I have...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WIE1,3
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. hostage Frank Reed revealed Wednesday he was held for months with two other American captives in Lebanon and said he was angry and embarrassed that they have not been freed. Reed, who was released Monday after 42 months in captivity, said he also was held with two British hostages. Reed was flown Tuesday to Wiesbaden for a battery of medical exams and questioning at the U.S. Air Force hospital. ``I have not seen Tom and Terry for a while and I don't know where they are,'' Reed said, referring to Terry Anderson, The Associated Press chief Middle East correspondent, and Thomas Sutherland, an American educator. ``For God's sake, it's nearly the sixth year for these men. I'm absolutely embarrassed I'm out before they are.'' Reed, in his first comments to reporters since arriving in Wiesbaden, said he spent ``the good part of two years with Tom and Terry.'' Anderson, the longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon, was kidnapped on March 16, 1985. Sutherland was seized June 9, 1985. ``I tell you, I'm very, very angry that Anderson ... Tom and Terry ... are not free,'' Reed said from the hospital balcony. Reed, pale and dressed in his blue hospital bathrobe, said he last saw Sutherland in February 1989. Sutherland on Thursday turns 59, marking his fifth birthday in captivity. Reed, 57, also said he spent three years in the intermittent company of Briton John McCarthy and Brian Keenan, a dual Anglo-Irish citizen. He said he saw them just before his release and they were ``well and alive.'' ``I have been with John and Brian since last October,'' Reed said. ``I've spent almost three years either with John and Brian or having them somewhere in the house with me.'' McCarthy, 33, a journalist for the London-based Worldwide Television News agency, WTN, was kidnapped April 17, 1986. Keenan, 39, disappeared while walking to work six days later. ``Those were the only people I knew'' in captivity, Reed said of the four hostages. The founder of a private school in Beirut, Reed was the second American hostage freed in nine days. Robert Polhill, freed April 22, went through the same medical tests and debriefing last week. A special State Department team questioned Reed for a second day Wednesday, seeking clues about the 16 remaining Westerners held hostage by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon. Six of the captives are American. President Bush thanked Syria and Iran for aiding both hostages' release but has said he will make no deals for hostages. Both Syria and Iran hope to establish closer ties with the West. But on Wednesday, Iran's spiritual leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei ruled out negotiations with the United States to end 11 years of hostility between the nations. It was not known what the anti-American stance meant for the possibility of any further hostage releases. Reed, who lost 60 pounds in his 3{ years of captivity said he initially had been angry with the U.S. administration that hostages were still being held. ``But I don't think I am now,'' he said. ``On the basis of information I have received ... it appears to me perhaps we are on the right track to getting these people out.'' Speaking earlier in the day, Reed's Syrian-born wife, Fahima, said that while in captivity her husband was kept blindfolded and bound for most of the time. For about 90 minutes during the evenings he was allowed to watch television or read magazines or books but he refused, she said. ``These things were so trivial compared to the things that were snatched away,'' Mrs. Reed said. The boisterous, lanky Reed was cheered by dozens of journalists as he appeared on the balcony for what was supposed to be a no-questions photo opportunity. But Reed, in a jocular mood, readily fielded reporters' questions. Standing on the balcony with his wife and their 9-year-old son, Tarek, Reed smiled and affectionately tousled his child's hair, saying it was ``just great'' to be reunited with his family. Reed said he was ``feeling good'' but tired. ``I'd like to stay another week or two, but they want me out of here on Friday,'' he joked. Asked what he wanted to do when he gets back to his home in Massachusetts, Reed said: ``Hide,'' but then rethought the question, and said: ``I'd like to have a big Maine lobster, about three pounds.'' Reed has taken advantage of his new-found freedom to telephone the kin of other hostages to relay what he knows about their condition. Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, said Reed told her: ``Terry was in reasonably good health, although he had been having physical problems. ... He said Terry's attitude was still feisty, as far as the guards go, and he was always screaming for something to read.'' In London, a group pressing for release of McCarthy said Reed telephoned the hostage's father to say both Keenan and McCarthy are well: ``They have some minor health problems. They exercise daily and read voraciously.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Soviet Officials to Testify
DOC.TEXT: Soviet and U.S. arms control officials will testify next week before a Senate Armed Services subcommittee, Sen. Edward Kennedy said Wednesday. Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev, the Soviet Union's top arms control adviser, will discuss naval arms control Tuesday. Adm. Carlisle Trost, chief of naval operations, and Ronald Lehman, director of the arms control and disarmament agency, will appear Friday. Kennedy, D-Mass., is chairman of the Armed Services subcommittee on projection forces.

DOC.HEAD: More Deadly Floods In Texas; Snow In Southern Rockies
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms extended from New Mexico to Kentucky on Wednesday, producing flooding that killed three people in Texas, and snow continued falling in the southern Rockies. Temperatures hit record highs in the Southeast, but a record low was reported in Minnesota. Showers and thunderstorms continued into the afternoon, extending from New Mexico across northern and central Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, northwestern Mississippi, western and central Tennessee into Kentucky, the National Weather Service said. Heavy rain in north-central Texas flooded streets and highways and forced the evacuations of dozens of people from homes in low-lying areas, authorities said. Some areas had up to 7 inches of rain in 24 hours. Downtown Gainsville, about 40 miles north of Dallas, was completely closed due to flooding. Authorities in Fort Worth evacuated more than 70 people from three mobile home parks and other residences. Seventy-six people were taken to shelters in Fort Worth. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.62 inches at Abilene, Texas; 1.59 inches at Altus, Okla.; 1.32 inches at Oklahoma City; and 1.28 inches at Tulsa, Okla. Snow continued falling Wednesday over the mountains of southern Colorado, but it was expected to end during the night. Snow also fell at higher elevations of north-central New Mexico. Temperatures hit record highs in the Southeast, including 94 at Augusta, Ga.; 95 at Charleston, S.C.; and 95 at Savannah, Ga. But in Minnesota, Rochester hit a record low for the date at 26 degrees. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 19 at Laramie, Wyo. Frost and freezing temperatures were expected during the night in sections of eastern New York state and Vermont. Elsewhere, showers extended over western Montana and from northwestern Oregon along the Washington coast. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 34 at Las Vegas, N.M., to 100 at Fort Stewart, Ga.

DOC.HEAD: Main Bush-Gorbachev Talks Will be in Washington
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be held in Washington but may conclude with a private get-together elsewhere, the White House said Wednesday. Bush and Gorbachev are to meet May 30-June 3 in their second summit in six months. There has been speculation the president would take Gorbachev to the Bush vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine, or that their talks would be held at Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains. ``We've said the main meetings would be here in Washington, but there might be a private day at the end. And that's still the case,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. There is a strong possibility that a NATO summit will be held after the talks so Bush can report to the allies about the meeting, Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Die as Heavy Rains Pelt Already-Soaked North-Central Texas
DOC.TEXT: Violent thunderstorms roared across northern Texas for the second time in two weeks Wednesday, flooding roads, forcing scores to evacuate and killing three people. Some areas got up to 7 inches of rain in 24 hours. Forecasters said the heavy rain and flooding would continue through Thursday morning. The deaths bring this spring's death toll from heavy rain and flooding in north-central Texas to nine; five people were killed by flooding last week and another died in mid-April. Last year, 22 people died in flooding and strong thunderstorms in the area. The storms snarled traffic throughout the Dallas-Fort Worth area late Tuesday and early Wednesday. Numerous roads were closed and rescue workers and wreckers were used to haul people out of cars that became stranded in deep water. Seventy-six people were taken to shelters in Fort Worth. Downtown Gainsville, about 40 miles north of Dallas, was completely closed by flooding. Also in Gainsville, 36 elderly people were evacuated from the Turner Hotel, a five-story apartment complex, when electricity went out as the basement flooded. They were taken to a Red Cross shelter, said volunteer Nona Sluder. Authorities in Fort Worth evacuated more than 70 people from three mobile home parks and other residences. The Army Corps of Engineers monitored the rise of Lake Texoma at the Texas-Oklahoma border, which had climbed above 639 feet _ a foot below the overflow mark. Mike McCoy, a park manager, said engineers expected the lake to rise into spillways sometime during the night for only the second time since the dam was built, and crest at 641 feet on Thursday. In Abilene, the National Weather Service reported a rainfall total of 3.16 inches by Wednesday afternoon. Abilene school officials closed schools as a precaution. Residents of the Horseshoe Bend area along the Brazos River repeated emergency drills they became familiar with last week, said Mike Pascal, Parker County Fire Marshal. Pascal said the evacuations went smoothly Wednesday. Nearly 1,000 people were evacuated from Horseshoe Bend because of serious flooding last week. But authorities evacuated fewer than 400 Wednesday, Pascal said. Two men died early Wednesday when flash flooding swept through Fort Worth. Both were swept away when they apparently left a vehicle after trying to drive across a flooded creek, said Police Sgt. Jon Grady. Their bodies were found two miles downstream. ``Any of those creeks are normally dry but the level is way up now so any sweeping water is something to stay away from,'' said Police Capt. Greg Givens. A fire captain was swept downstream while trying to rescue the men. But he managed to grab a tree and was later rescued, Deputy Fire Chief K.D. Laymance said. Elsewhere in Fort Worth, street department workers found the body of a missing woman late Wednesday at a park.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan's Defense Minister Named Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: President Lee Teng-hui tapped his defense minister to become Taiwan's new prime minister in a surprise move Wednesday that was greeted with hostility and suspicion by the opposition. Lawmaker Chen Shui-pien of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party denounced Lee's choice of Hau Pei-tsun, the country's only four-star general, as ``a move to drive Taiwan's democracy backward.'' Lee is expected to formally announce the appointment May 20, when he is sworn in for a new six-year term as president. The Legislature will have to approve Hau's nomination. Hau, 71, belongs to the old guard of the governing Nationalist Party that fled to Taiwan with Chiang Kai-shek in 1949 after losing a civil war to communist forces on mainland China. He is among the Nationalist conservatives who still dream of returning to China to overthrow the communists. Hau said he accepted the offer to lead the government at a meeting with the president Wednesday. He would replace Lee Huan, 73, in about two weeks. The general said in an interview with Taiwan's three TV stations, ``President Lee said the country needs me. I thought I should not defy him.'' Hau would be the first general to become prime minister in 27 years. He was appointed defense minister last year after being chief of the 500,000-member armed forces for eight years. He said his selection does not mean the military would interfere in politics _ ``There are many such precedents in democratic countries.'' But opposition leader Jiang Peng-chien called the appointment ``odd and inappropriate ... an apparent compromise with the military.'' Jiang said he feared ``the military would interfere more in politics. The military has mistaken our society's newly emerged pluralism as social chaos and wants to stamp out opposition voices.'' In recent years, the Nationalists have gradually loosened their tight reins here _ lifting martial law, allowing opposition political parties and giving more government posts to the native Taiwanese, who account for 85 percent of the island's 20 million people. The selection of Hau stirred political speculation about its possible impact on the easing of restrictions on contacts with mainland China, which has resulted in hundreds of thousands of Taiwan residents traveling there.

DOC.HEAD: Paroled `Onion Field' Killer Jimmy Lee Smith Arrested for Assault
DOC.TEXT: Paroled ``Onion Field'' police killer Jimmy Lee Smith was arrested for allegedly threatening a man with an 8-inch kitchen knife, police said Wednesday. Smith, 59, was arrested Tuesday in the San Fernando Valley and was booked for investigation of assault with a deadly weapon, said police Lt. John Bradbury. ``He was also under the influence of a substance, probably heroin, at the time of his arrest,'' said Van Nuys police Lt. Warren Knowles. It was the latest in a series of arrests since Smith was paroled in February 1982 after serving 19 years in prison for his role in the March 1963 slaying of Los Angeles Police Officer Ian Campbell. Campbell and Officer Karl Hettinger were abducted by Smith and Gregory Powell and taken to an onion field, where Powell killed Campbell and shot at Hettinger, who escaped. The slaying and trial were recounted in Joseph Wambaugh's best-selling 1973 novel ``The Onion Field,'' which was made into a movie. Powell and Smith were twice sentenced to death for the killing, but the sentences were reduced to life in prison when the state Supreme Court ruled tht the death penalty was unconstitutional. Powell is serving a life term. Most of Smith's post-parole encounters with police involved narcotics arrests. His latest brush with the law occurred April 18 in Van Nuys, when he argued with his female roommate and she ordered him to move out, Bradbury said. When a male friend intervened, Smith ``drew an 8-inch knife and said he would cut him,'' the lieutenant said.

DOC.HEAD: Breaux Succeeds Matsunaga
DOC.TEXT: Sen. John Breaux, D-La., was chosen Wednesday to succeed the late Sen. Spark Matsunaga, D-Hawaii, on the Senate Finance Committee. Sen. Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., was selected by the Democratic steering committee to take Matsunaga's seat on the Labor and Human Resources Committee. At least three Democrats in addition to Breaux _ Kent Conrad of North Dakota, Robert Graham of Florida and Richard Bryan of Nevada _ had expressed interest in the seat on the Finance Committee, which has jurisdiction over taxes, trade, Social Security and half of all government spending.

DOC.HEAD: New Test Approved For Hepatitis C
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday licensed the first test to screen blood for hepatitis C, a somtimes fatal disease spread mostly through blood transfusions. About 170,000 Americans contract the disease annually, and about half the cases progress to chronic hepatitis. The hepatitis C virus is responsible for about 90 percent of the hepatitis spread through blood transfusions. Ortho Diagnostic Systems, a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, received approval to make and market the test, said Robert Kniffin, a company spokesman. ``The test is being shipped to blood centers across the country and they will use it to screen blood immediately,'' Kniffin said. The test is already sold in Australia, Belgium, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Spain and Finland, Kniffin said. The FDA is recommending that all U.S. blood banks use the test, said FDA spokeswoman Faye Peterson. About 20 percent of the hepatitis C cases that progress to chronic hepatitis then progress to cirrhosis, which can be fatal, Kniffin said. This virus is also associated with liver cancer, he said. The federal Centers for Disease Control reported 28,500 cases of hepatitis A were diagnosed in 1988. This hepatitis virus, which does not progress to chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis of the liver, is spread primarily by contact with contaminated food and water. Hepatitis B, with about 300,000 new cases occurring each year, is spread mostly through sexual contact, most commonly among homosexuals, and among intravenous drug users. About 5 percent to 10 percent of these cases progress to chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Officials Just Say No to James Brown Benefit Concert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs with organizers saying location of concert has been moved from Charleston to Aikin, but Corrections Department still saying no to plans, other details. Pickup penultimate graf.
DOC.TEXT: Plans for soul singer James Brown to perform in a benefit concert this month while he serves time in a work-release program were nixed twice Wednesday by the state Corrections Department. On Monday, a Los Angeles promoter said Brown would hold a concert May 16 the King Street Palace in Charleston with Gladys Knight, Little Richard, Jermaine Jackson and others. The Corrections Department said no go. A New York concert organizer then said Wednesday that the benefit concert had been moved from Charleston to Aikin. Nope, the Corrections Department said again. Proceeds from the ``James Brown and Friends'' concert were to have gone to the non-profit Aiken-Barnwell Counties Community Action Commission, where Brown works as a counselor, said Peter Paul of the Stephen Cooper Entertainment Corp. in Los Angeles. Brown, serving a six-year sentence for aggravated assault, has been working for the commission since shortly after his April 14 transfer from prison to a work-release program. Corrections Department spokesman Francis X. Archibald said Wednesday the concert ``is not going to happen.'' ``This is inconsistent with his employment with the Aiken-Barnwell community agency. We didn't allow him to perform while he was in prison and we can't let him perform down there just because he's been sent to a work center,'' he said. Archibald said the concert was a commercial venture and not all proceeds would go to the commission. The event was to have been filmed as part of a television special on Brown's life, according to Paul. ``As part of being in prison, your liberties are restricted and you're taken away from your commercial life,'' Archibald said. ``That applies to entertainers, stockbrokers, bankers and anyone else who goes to prison.'' Officials with the King Street Palace and community action center did not return telephone calls from The Associated Press seeking comment. Brown will only respond to written inquiries, center officials said. Later Wednesday, Larry Myers of the Universal Attractions booking agency in New York said concert organizers were now going ahead with plans for a May 16 benefit performance in Aiken instead of Charleston _ despite the department's stance. The concert is to be held at the University of South Carolina-Aiken, said Myers, whose agency has booked concerts for Brown for more than 25 years. The change in location notwithstanding, Archibald said the department was firm in its position. ``Any entertainment Mr. Brown does has to be related directly and solely to his job,'' he said. ``We cannot allow some small benefit (for the commission) ... to be used as a cover for a larger, commercial exploitation.'' Brown, who turns 57 Thursday, was imprisoned in December 1988 to serve concurrent six-year sentences in Georgia and South Carolina for failing to stop for police, aggravated assault and weapons violations stemming from a two-state car chase in 1988. He becomes eligible for parole in South Carolina in May 1991 and in Georgia in March 1992. Brown is known for such hits as ``Papa's Got A Brand New Bag,'' ``I Got You (I Feel Good),'' and more recently ``I'm Real'' and ``Living in America.''

DOC.HEAD: Airline Official: Smelled Alcohol on Pilots After Flight
DOC.TEXT: A Northwest Airlines supervisor testified Wednesday he smelled alcohol on three flight crew members just after they had flown a Northwest passenger jet. ``I smelled alcohol on each of them as I introduced myself and it seemed they had been drinking,'' Bradley Berntson testified before U.S. Magistrate J. Earl Cudd. Blood tests taken about 90 minutes after the plane landed showed the three had blood-alcohol levels higher than allowed by the federal government. The Federal Aviation Administration then revoked their pilot licenses and the airline later fired them. Defense attorneys contend the blood-alcohol tests were obtained unconstitutionally. Cudd is hearing pretrial motions to suppress the test results of the three, who face federal charges of operating an airplane while under the influence of alcohol. Another witness, Douglas McKeen, an attorney for the Minnesota-based airline, said Wednesday he was consulted by company officials before the blood tests were performed. ``I clearly believe we had reason to believe it was necessary,'' McKeen said. Berntson, service manager in charge of Northwest's control center operations, said he was asked by Federal Aviation Administration officials to meet the crew of Flight 650 at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport on March 8. Officials had received an anonymous tip that the crew was drinking heavily at a bar the night before the early-morning takeoff, Berntson said. The charges against Capt. Norman Prouse, 51, of Conyers, Ga., first officer Robert J. Kirchner, 35, of Highland Ranch, Colo., and flight engineer Joseph Balzer, 34, of Antioch, Tenn., stem from a flight that left at 6:25 a.m. from Fargo and went to Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport. The Boeing 727 carrying 91 passengers landed without incident. After meeting the flight crew at the passenger gate, Berntson said they took an elevator to a Northwest conference room upstairs. ``There was a very strong odor of alcohol in the elevator,'' he said. Defense attorneys also claim that citizen's arrests by an FAA official at the Minnesota airport were unlawful.

DOC.HEAD: Gilliam Says Developer's Meeting With Bush Led to $500,000 Grant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 16th graf: ``Steve Hart,'' with White House response
DOC.TEXT: A former housing official said Wednesday that Samuel R. Pierce Jr. was deeply involved in steering federal grants to friends while HUD secretary, and that one grant was arranged after a developer appealed to then-Vice President George Bush. DuBois L. Gilliam, once deputy assistant secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development and now serving a federal sentence for corruption, linked Bush to a $500,000 federal grant for a Hispanic trade center in Kansas City, Mo. Gilliam, who admits taking bribes, testified for a second day before a congressional panel investigating the HUD scandal. Speaking with a grant of immunity from further prosecution, Gilliam detailed how he and others manipulated programs to direct lucrative subsidies to friends, including members of Congress _ sometimes before any formal applications were made. Gilliam said he arranged to profit himself and secretly removed incriminating documents from the agency in a medicine bag for destruction. When he left the agency under a cloud in 1987, Gilliam said he asked for and was given approval from Pierce through an aide to receive grants for low-income housing renovations _ in effect a severance payment worth a million dollars or more in resale value to developers. He ultimately did not receive the grants. ``I'm touching upon the truth,'' Gilliam said when his credibilty was challenged. ``I have no reason to lie, no reason whatsoever.'' Gilliam's mention of President Bush was disclosed beforehand by the chairman of the panel, Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., who has spent more than a year investigating the scandals at HUD during the Reagan presidency. Gilliam did not accuse Bush of directly ordering the HUD grant go to a political ally.
