But Gilliam said he took unusual steps to award the grant in 1985 after Hector Barreto, then president of the U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce and a supporter of Bush and President Reagan, met with the vice president. Gilliam said he told Barreto that his proposal for a feasibility study was not eligible for funding by HUD under the secretary's discretion program. But Barreto, he said, left saying he would meet with the vice president. Later that same afternoon, Gilliam said, he was told by Pierce's executive assistant Deborah Gore Dean that Barreto met with Bush. ``She indicated to me that she had received a call from the vice president's staff people indicating their support and wanted to get the project funded,'' he said. Gilliam said he then persuaded a Kansas City assistant city manager, James I. Threatt, to provide the grant from the city's Community Development Block Grant funds provided by HUD. In turn, Gilliam said he arranged to have a special grant from the secretary's discretionary fund go to Kansas City to replace that money. ``In other words, let's make a deal _ you do this and I'll do this,'' Gilliam said. Gilliam said he was unsure of the connection but that Dean had also mentioned ``something about Hector being on the vice president's plane.'' Before the testimony, Lantos charged the project was funded ``in order to get a Hispanic leader to accompany the then-vice president on a plane trip to Puerto Rico.'' Steve Hart, a White House spokesman, was asked for a response to Gilliam's account. He replied, ``We don't know anything about it.'' Pierce is the object of a special prosecutor's investigation into his handling of HUD's section 8 moderate rehabilitation subsidies program for low-income housing renovations. Pierce testified before the panel once last year and later invoked his constitutional rights not to incriminate himself to avoid further testimony. His lawyers have attacked Gilliam's testimony, saying he was trying to win early release from prison. Gilliam said he is eligible for parole at any time, and his 18-month sentence is up later this year. Dean and two other former top aides to Pierce have also refused to testify on constitutional grounds. Gilliam said Pierce accepted huge cuts in HUD's overall budget while fighting White House efforts to cut his own secretary's discretionary fund. Gilliam said that fund was used to reward friends and help political allies in election years. He described one case in which Pierce told him he wanted a grant to go to Tougaloo University in Mississippi, where a Pierce friend sat on the board of trustees. Their proposal for a $300,000 grant did meet eligibility standards, Gilliam said, so he reached agreement with the mayor of a nearby town, Ridgeland, to accept the grant and pass it on to the college _ with an additional $50,000 for the town's use. ``A handling charge,'' Lantos called it. Gilliam said he was shocked to learn other top aides to Pierce kept records that listed supporters of pending grants, including his own support of four projects. One of those was for a proposed Selma, Ala., project. Gilliam said that when he left the agency in 1987 he arranged to recieve a $20,000 consultant's retainer and one-third ownership of the project, from which he expected $600,000 to $700,000 upon completion.

DOC.HEAD: Hawaiians Accept Volcano Goddess' Angry Ways
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th & 7th grafs, bgn ``Ed Lorenz,'' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with two more houses burned, add that other houses burned outside Kalapana.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XHIL10
DOC.TEXT: Hawaiians stood by stoically Wednesday morning as the angry volcano goddess Pele cut a fiery path toward the heart of this dying coastal town. It may be foolish to deny the natural process that created Kilauea Volcano and now pumps tons of molten lava from it, but it's just as ridiculous to deny the ways of Madame Pele. Like the volcano, she is respected for her awesome power. The goddess' large presence in Hawaiian folklore shows how much respect the Hawaiian people have for their land, a product of ancient volcanic eruptions. Most kamaainas, or local residents, don't worship Pele exclusively, but pay homage to her for the beauty they live in. ``It's more a respect for the land and the volcano than a religion,'' said Reggie Okamura of the National Volcano Observatory. ``I have some belief. It's inherent to anyone born and raised here.'' Legend says if Pele is not shown proper respect through the bestowing of gifts, or if people try to ruin the land she has formed, she'll roar out of Kilauea to vent her wrath. Ed Lorenz has lived in the shadow of Kilauea Volcano most of his 60 years and watched, along with others, as homes have been torched by the fiery lava. Two homes were destroyed Wednesday and five Tuesday, bringing to 128 the number burned down since Kilauea began erupting in January 1983. More than 50 were destroyed in the past month. In this community alone, where 125 homes once stood, only 31 homes remain. Others burned along the path from the volcano to Kalapana. Several more homes were in danger of falling Wednesday. The volcano, about six miles away, has spewed lava to within less than 270 yards of the heart of the town: the Kalapana Store and Drive-In. Lorenz, a believer in Pele's power, says the goddess is as angry as he's ever seen. `If she wasn't mad, she wouldn't damage any houses,'' Lorenz said. ``I've seen a lot of flows, but this is one of the worst.'' Lorenz says Pele is upset with real estate developers, geothermal energy drillers and marijuana growers for profiting off her land and not offering her sacrifices. The east side of Hawaii Island is one of the few remaining places in the state where land is reasonably priced, and many are looking to settle here. Geothermal companies are drilling in the Wao Kele O Puna rain forest, looking to convert heat from the volcano into energy. Many say Pele will not stop her destructive ways until geothermal exploration stops. ``They're growing pakololo (marijuana) and making big money off her land,'' Lorenz said. ``Now she's taking it all away. ``How many millions of dollars are they making and they're not going to offer her nothing _ not even a feast and bring it to her. What a bunch of dummies,'' he said. Walter Yamaguchi, who owns the Kalapana Store and Drive-In, makes food offerings to Pele daily. His store has been spared on several previous flows. ``Let her take it if she wants it,'' said Yamaguchi, 82. ``She can do what she wants. It's hers if she wants it.'' Even Gov. John Waihee, who toured the area Tuesday, said the fate of Kalapana is in Pele's hands. ``Nobody can tell Madame Pele when it all ends,'' the governor said. ``Nobody can tell her what to do.'' Legend also says Pele gets upset when people try to run away from her and that she will find and destroy them. This doesn't seem to scare officials at Star of the Sea Church. Workers are preparing to relocate the renowned ``painted church'' from destruction. Not all in the congregation want to move the church. They say it shows a lack of faith by the congregation and a lack of respect for Pele. In contrast, the Kalapana Mauna Loa Congregation Church, originally built in the 1800s and located at its present site next to the store for 102 years, is not moving. Deacon Ed Kahanu said the church's foundation is rotted with termites and isn't worth moving anyway. ``If God wants to save it, He will,'' Kahanu said. ``It's His church, He can do what He wants.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Budget Panel Adds to Democratic Defense Cuts
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 6th graf: ``At the,'' with White House response
DOC.TEXT: The Democratic-controlled Senate Budget Committee on Wednesday made the deepest cut yet in proposed Pentagon spending, approving a 1991 budget that pares President Bush's military plans by $9.9 billion. The panel adopted the $1.2 trillion spending plan, which says it will reduce next year's deficit by $43 billion, on a 14-9 vote. Sen. Charles Grassley of Iowa was the only Republican to join the committee Democrats in voting for the package. Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., who pieced together the proposal, called it ``a clear and clarion call to the White House to get behind some real deficit reduction.'' Bush's budget seeks $36 billion in deficit reduction. Sasser said his package could serve as a benchmark should negotiations be held this year between the White House and congressional leaders. Democrats are split over whether there is a need for formal budget talks with Bush, while Republicans argue such bargaining is a necessity. At the White House, spokesman Steve Hart said: ``We are not prepared to respond to specifics. We still feel the president's budget is the best proposal up there. It will continue to be the basis of any discussions we have.'' The administration and congressional Democrats have been dueling all year over how Pentagon spending should be adjusted as a result of political changes in Eastern Europe. The White House has urged a cautious approach, while Democrats are eager to use some military dollars for social programs and to reduce the deficit. The $293.9 billion the panel recommended for defense is $1.6 billion less than the amount the House included in the budget it adopted Tuesday. It's $4.1 billion below the amount Senate Armed Services Committee Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga., has said is needed next year. Nunn is one of Capitol Hill's most influential Democrats on defense matters. The Senate figure is $13 billion less than the amount military programs would need next year to keep up with inflation. Bush proposed $303.8 billion for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. Sasser said his committee's budget addresses ``a new era in which economic vitality will be the true measure of the strength of the nation, rather than just solely military strength.'' Republicans called it an unrealistic proposal that by itself stands little chance of accomplishing the deficit reduction it claims. ``I believe we're going to end up with minimal deficit reduction in spite of this budget, unless there are major negotiating sessions with the president and congressional leadership,'' said the panel's ranking Republican, Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico. The budget, which lays out the government's financial plans, does not need the president's signature. But later spending and tax bills will, and proponents of negotiations with the White House say the president will veto deficit-reduction measures he opposes. Overall, Sasser's plan says it will produce a deficit of $58.6 billion next year. The Gramm-Rudman law requires a shortfall of no more than $64 billion. The measure would raise $13.9 billion in new tax receipts, the same figure Bush proposed, and $6.2 billion in user fees and other revenues. It would limit the growth of benefit programs such as Medicare by $5.6 billion and cut other domestic and foreign aid programs by $3.6 billion. Sasser said there are eight to 10 domestic programs he would cut or eliminate to produce the savings, including the superconducting super-collider, foreign aid and grants to renovate rental housing units. ``We've got to realize every single program in the federal budget is not sacrosanct,'' Sasser said. In contrast, the House-passed budget would increase domestic and foreign aid programs by $5.6 billion next year. The House approved its spending plan 218-208, with all 174 voting Republicans opposing the package. The Senate committee's budget also embraced a plan to collect another $11.1 billion in taxes by waiving penalties for tax-dodgers and beefing up the Internal Revenue Service. That money, however, was not formally included within the $43 billion savings package. Sasser said the budget should be considered by the full Senate within 10 days.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Immigration Activists Warn of Impending Catastrophe
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Jewish immigration activists warned an Israeli minister Wednesday that Israel was close to a ``catastrophe'' in its handling of a wave of Soviet newcomers. The heated television debate came just a day after immigration officials said a record 10,500 Soviet Jews had arrived in April. That same day hundreds of Soviet immigrants rallied in a coastal resort town, demanding employment and housing. Immigrants have also complained of a lack of job opportunities. Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz, facing the angry activists, tried to appear upbeat and said that ``Israel deals with absorption exceedingly well, including permanent housing.'' But Natan Sharansky, the human rights champion who spent nine years in Soviet labor camps before immigrating to Israel in 1986, sharply disagreed. ``We have lines of people seeking apartments, and it's already clear that we would not have a single apartment in a few months. For a year we speak about construction and we are not building.'' The Israeli media has reported 30,000 Soviet Jews have arrived so far in 1990. Officials say they expect about 100,000 Soviet immigrants this year, compared to 12,000 Soviet Jews who arrived in 1989. Sharansky, who heads the Soviet Jewry Zionist Forum, a public organization that helps absorb Soviet immigrants, gave a much higher estimate: ``We expect 250,000 immigrants this year and at least 500,000 next year... This is a real evacuation. What's good for us is that they feel it's more dangerous to stay in Russia despite all the difficulties of absorption.'' ``But we will really have a catastrophe with absorption. ... There would be pressures on America'' to open its doors for Soviet Jews and lift current visa restrictions, he warned. The lack of housing, employment problems and the stifling absorption bureacracy are felt throughout Israel. In the northern port of Haifa on Wednesday, an AP photographer saw hundreds of immigrants waiting in line for processing at an absorption center. In the coastal resort of Netanya on Tuesday, hundreds of Soviet Jews demonstrated, holding signs that read: ``We want work, we want apartments,'' and ``Absorption Minister, go home.'' Peretz said the government has approved plans to build 30,000 new apartments and that work has started on 6,000. But he said it could take 15 months until the first of the new apartments are on the market. ``We will have a difficult transition period,'' Peretz said. The mass immigration comes at a time when Israel faces almost 10 percent unemployment. The unemployment is especially severe in remote areas, where apartments are abundant, but Soviet Jews are reluctant to live. Yermiyahu Branover, a Beersheba University physicist who also runs an immigrant-oriented company in Jerusalem, argued that Israel had no clear plan on providing employment for Soviet Jews. ``Fifty percent of them have academic degrees. ... The state should have a professionally devised master plan, and till this very day we don't have such a plan,'' Branover said.

DOC.HEAD: Expert Witness: Sewage Dumping Doesn't Hurt Water Quality
DOC.TEXT: A water quality expert testified Wednesday that Amtrak's practice of dumping raw human waste from its trains has no significant impact on water quality in the St. Johns River and Rice Creek. Dr. Robert Harris, a consultant hired by Amtrak, testified in the third day of a hearing before U.S. District Judge Howell Melton on whether the state can prosecute the national passenger rail service for dumping raw sewage in Florida. Assistant State Attorney Dennis Bayer, who prosecuted the railroad in Putnam County for commercial littering, said the hearing, originally scheduled to end Wednesday, probably would continue through Friday. Harris estimated the amount of waste dumped by Amtrak trains crossing bridges over the river and creek and determined ``there was no significant impact on water quality.'' He estimated that the amount of waste dumped into the waterways by the railroad was the equivalent of the daily discharge of one person for a day. If anything, Harris said, his assumptions overestimated the amount of waste dumped from Amtrak trains. Last December, Amtrak was convicted by a jury in Palatka on four state felony charges of disposing of wastes into the two streams. Amtrak could face up to $20,000 in fines if the federal judge determines that the railroad is bound by state pollution laws, rather than federal laws that allow it to dump. Sentencing for the state conviction was delayed pending Judge Melton's decision. Fishermen had complained that they were sprayed with sewage while fishing under rail trestles as Amtrak trains passed overhead. Amtrak conductor Carl E. Harris testified Wednesday that passengers are now asked not to flush train toilets when passing over waterways near Palatka. Amtrak officials have said they would have to suspend service to Florida if train toilets cannot be flushed onto the roadbed.

DOC.HEAD: London Mugger Seizes $478 Million in Financial Certificates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details, problems caused in money market, CHANGES dollar value in line with closing rate. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A mugger with a knife robbed a messenger of $478 million in financial certificates on Wednesday, forcing the Bank of England to come to the London money market's rescue. Although no cash was involved, it was a British robbery record, far above the estimated $48 million haul from a looted London safe deposit store in 1987. The state-run Bank of England said it had to inject into the money market an amount equivalent to the face value of the stolen certificates. It said this was to avoid problems for their owners and eliminate the risk that a shortage of liquidity would increase overnight lending rates. The Bank said a ``remote'' chance existed that the certificates could be used illegally to secure a bank loan but it would be ``extraordinarily difficult'' to use the missing paper to raise cash. ``Anyone trying to cash or use these documents would need to demonstrate he has good title to them,'' said a bank spokesman, who refused to be identified. The Bank of England said that within 45 minutes of the robbery's being reported, the Bank warned money market firms and banks and sent descriptions of the missing property to the London offices of foreign central banks to circulate around the world. Police said a briefcase containing the certificates was snatched from 58-year-old messenger John Goddard as he walked from Sheppards money brokers to another finance house in the City financial district. Goddard, a longtime employee, was unhurt. Sheppards refused to comment. Police said the robber was black, in his late twenties and wielded a knife. Unescorted messengers in the densely crowded City have been robbed before and the system has often been called archaic. The Bank of England said the messenger system, which is more than 100 years old, was ``plainly unsatisfactory,'' and by the end of this year it expects to have on line a new computerized system for settling money transactions. Wednesday's haul consisted of certificates of deposit with a face value of 121.9 million pounds (nearly $200 million) and Treasury bills worth 170 million pounds ($278 million) that mature for payment on July 30. The paper is regularly traded between banks and some finance houses. Certificates of deposit are issued to companies in exchange for depositing large amounts of money with a bank or finance house over a fixed period and companies can buy and sell them as a way of raising money. Treasury bills are a form of IOU issued by the government to raise short-term money. Their face value can be claimed when they mature on a fixed date. In January, a City worker found four bond certificates each worth $1.6 million and stated to be as good as cash lying in the gutter outside the Stock Exchange. They were handed back to the owners.

DOC.HEAD: Maxwell to Sell European Weekly in United States
DOC.TEXT: British publisher Robert Maxwell announced Wednesday that The European, the weekly English-language newspaper he plans to launch in Europe on May 11, will be available in the United States after Labor Day. Maxwell said the newspaper would sell on newsstands throughout the country for $1 or $1.50, with the same news content as the European edition but perhaps some different advertising. The weekend newspaper will appear on newsstands in Europe on Friday mornings, but might be later than that in parts of the United States, he said. He said he plans to talk to the Gannett Co., publisher of USA Today and many other American dailies, about printing the American edition. Maxwell said he hopes to expand to daily publication. The newspaper will be 64 pages, with three sections. Two full-size sections of 16 pages each will cover European news, politics, business and sports. A 32-page tabloid will cover European culture and lifestyle. A prototype issue distributed at Maxwell's news conference featured a front-page story on the effects on German reunification of the attempted murder of West German opposition political leader Oskar Lafontaine. Inside were stories on pressures keeping European air fares high, the development of the tunnel under the English channel and a controversial Spanish cycling star, Pedro Delgado. A profile of opera star Tizziana Fabricini highlighted the tabloid section. The prototype was long on analysis and profiles and made generous use of color photographs. Maxwell said more than 100 million people speak English in Europe and he needs to sell about 300,000 copies to make a profit. More than 1 million copies will be printed, he said. The publisher said The European will have news bureaus in Washington, New York and on the Pacific Coast, and will depend on news services for other coverage of North America. It will have a staff of more than 100 journalists.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Mining Worker Who Was Abducted in Ecuador Remains Missing
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials said there was no new information on the whereabouts of an American mining company worker believed abducted by Colombian rebels who crossed into Ecuadoran territory. ``At the moment, there's nothing new about the case,'' said Patricia Norman, a spokeswoman for the U.S. embassy in the Ecuadoran capital. ``We don't know if there is any demand for a ransom.'' The kidnap victim, identified by embassy officials as Scott Heimdal, 27, heads a dredging operation for Iminco Co., a gold-mining company near the Ecuadoran-Colombian border. Heimdal's hometown is Peoria, Ill. He was captured by rebels believed to belong to the Popular Liberation Army of Colombia. ``We have not received any calls from the people who took him. We are in contact with Heimdal's parents in the United States,'' said Jeffrey J. Fino, general manager of Iminco. Ecuadoran armed forces launched an air-and-land search Sunday, but U.S. officials said they believe Heimdal is being held in neighboring Colombia. The U.S. Embassy in Bogota and Colombian police said Wednesday that they had no information on Heimdal's abduction. Ecuadoran reports said Heimdal was traveling with three Ecuadorans and a Colombian boat pilot to a support camp in the jungle when their boat was stopped by a group of guerrillas wielding automatic weapons. The guerrillas opened fire killing the boat pilot, Julio Torres, and wounding one of the Ecuadoran passengers. The guerrillas then kidnapped Heimdal and an Ecuadoran student, Edwin Rodrigo Teneda, 29. The kidnappers later released Teneda with two letters written by Heimdal, one to his family and the other to his company. The letters' contents were not revealed. Authorities said Heimdal was last seen on a boat moving up the Rumiyacu River, a heavily jungled area that crosses into Colombia. The southern Colombian border region is a frequent crossing ground too for drug-traffickers.

DOC.HEAD: Police Find Gang Uses Business Cards
DOC.TEXT: Possibly inspired by its corporate-sounding name, a gang that calls itself Damage Inc. has printed up business cards for members. Police working at recent downtown carnival made the discovery as they talked to members of several different gangs. Authorities said several Damage Inc. members opened their wallets, pulled out the business cards with the gang name and proudly displayed them. Officers described the cards as ``professional-looking.'' ``It was hilarious,'' one unidentified patrol officer said. ``These guys actually had these things printed up somewhere and they were carrying them on their person.'' Police say Damage Inc. got its name from the title of a concert tour by the heavy-metal rock group Metallica about two years ago. Members of the gang range in age from 14 to 16. They are suspected in a number of assaults, criminal mischief cases, auto thefts and shootings, and some have been arrested at schools for carrying guns, police said. San Antonio police Capt. Al Philippus said the police department wants to study local gangs to determine what impact they are having on the city's crime. The department has applied for a $148,000 federal grant to form a gang unit and should know within 60 days whether it will receive the money.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Clash with Police, Union Leaders Vow to Fight
DOC.TEXT: About 1,500 striking workers clashed with police Wednesday near a shipyard where union leaders barricaded inside a giant crane threatened ``an extreme fight'' unless arrested unionists were freed. Also Wednesday, police continued searching for dozens of fugitive labor leaders involved in strikes at the shipyard, a broadcast network and other work sites. At least 80 policemen and 14 workers have been injured and 500 people arrested in labor unrest throughout the country. The violence and arrests began after police stormed the Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. shipyard, the nation's largest, over the weekend to end a three-day strike. At the shipyard in Ulsan, an industrial city 200 miles southeast of Seoul, about 120 union leaders remained atop a giant crane and vowed Wednesday to fight until the arrested labor leaders were released. On nearby roads, sporadic clashes continued between bands of shipyard workers armed with stones and steel pipes and riot troopers guarding the shipyard. Police opened fire with tear gas and one protester was hospitalized after fragments from the tear gas shell struck his face and hand. The shipyard strike initially began over demands to release four union leaders jailed for instigating earlier protests. Banks and factories were closed Wednesday for a national holiday, but sympathy strikes continued. Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon and senior economic and labor ministry officials met Wednesday to discuss the unrest. The government has demanded an end to what it calls illegal strikes and says the already slumping South Korean economy might suffer further damage unless labor unrest eases. A prolonged labor dispute in 1987 slowed exports and led to increased unemployment. Also Wednesday, police brought charges against 11 of the 333 workers at the Korea Broadcasting System arrested Monday. The other KBS workers were released after vowing not to stage protests, police said. On Monday 2,400 police staged a midnight raid to end a 19-day protest against the network's new president. About 500 KBS workers held a rally at the nearby Munwha Broadcasting Co. network, where about 1,000 Munwha workers walked off their jobs for the second-day of a sympathy strike. Munwha union leaders said Wednesday they would extend their sympathy strikes until Sunday and other networks announced similar sympathy strikes. At the Hyundai shipyard, workers atop a 240-foot crane said they would only come down only if the company dropped charges against the arrested union leaders. ``If police come, we will stage an extreme fight,'' Lee Kap-yong, 31, told reporters inivted to a news conference aboard the crane Tuesday night. ``We have made full preparations against a police raid by helicopters.'' The Hyundai Motor Co., the nation's largest automaker, and 11 other Hyundai subsidiaries in Ulsan decided to resume production Thursday regardless of the union strikes.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop Tutu Calls Pretoria-ANC Talks `Mind Boggling'
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop Desmond Tutu called ``mind-boggling'' Wednesday's first talks between the South African government and the African National Congress and said too much was at stake for either side to be ``bloody-minded.'' The black Anglican archbishop of Cape Town, an anti-apartheid campaigner and 1984 Nobel Peace laureate, said he didn't expect important agreements to emerge from the preliminary talks in Cape Town which end Friday. ``I just think what most of the people in our community would like to hear is a real commitment on all sides to talks,'' he told a news conference at Exeter University. ``And that we want to go in to substantive negotiations, that would be important and give hope to people who are tired of the violence of apartheid and the counterviolence of those who oppose apartheid.'' Tutu came to Britain Wednesday for a three-day visit shortly before the talks began. He lectured Wednesday night in this university city in southwest England. Asked by reporters at London's Heathrow Airport if he believed much could be achieved in the first round, he said: ``I am very hopeful. I don't think that any of those people, on both sides, are going into those talks bloody-minded. We've got too much at stake. Too many people have already died, too many people have suffered.'' Tutu said South African President F.W. de Klerk knew that unless he settled with the black majority ``the whole question of sanctions and apartheid economy will be exacerbated.'' Tutu commented, ``It's actually almost mind-boggling to think that they are now sitting across the table with the people they tried to demonize.'' ``On the ANC side, they know that most of their supporters would like to see an end to violence,'' the prelate said. He called South Africa's racial-segregation system ``one of the most vicious the world has seen.'' Tutu criticized British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for opposing sanctions on South Africa. ``We admire her eloquency in condemning apartheid. We just wish there was a matching consistency in action,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Governor Vetoes $4.7 Billion Roads Bill
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bob Martinez vetoed a $4.7 billion transportation tax hike and construction bill Wednesday as roadbuilders ringed the Capitol with heavy equipment to protest his decision. The first-term Republican governor, who is still trying to make voters forget his aborted support of a highly unpopular services tax in 1987, said the bill's 4-cent-a-gallon gas tax increase was unacceptable. ``I believe Floridians don't want to be taxed just to spend,'' said Martinez, who trails both Democratic gubernatorial hopefuls in the latest statewide poll. Martinez favors allowing local governments to make the tax decision, and he said the Legislature's bill allowed the people no voice in imposing the levy. ``I fear the framers of this legislation have lost sight of the fact that there are limits to how deeply the people of Florida are willing to reach into their pockets to pay for questionable projects,'' added Martinez. He said the proposed tax would not pay for local road needs and spent too much for mass transit. Counting both the gas tax and a boost in the gasoline sales tax, the bill would have raised the overall tax on gasoline from 9.7 cents a gallon now to almost 15 cents. In addition, auto title fees would have risen from $3 to $24, and a surcharge on rental cars would have increased from 50 cents to $2. A ``new wheels on the roads'' fee would have gone from $30 to $100; that is aimed at additional cars, such as new residents bringing in cars from elsewhere or people adding a second or third car to their garage. The bill would have raised $3.6 billion over six years for roads, bridges and mass transit as well as authorize $1.1 billion in bonds to expand the turnpike system. Protest organizers said about 85 trucks and tractor-trailer rigs, many hauling bulldozers and asphalt spreaders, honked horns and displayed signs such as ``Please Governor _ My Job is in Your Hands'' and ``Today the Highway, Tomorrow the Repo Lot.'' ``They're willing to drive hundreds of miles to save their jobs,'' said state Sen. Howard Forman, a co-sponsor of the bill. ``It's got to be worth something.'' The truck protest was the latest effort by the Floridians for Better Transportation group to pressure Martinez into signing the bill. The group, made up mainly of roadbuilders, also made hundreds of telephone calls and sent some 1,500 letters to the governor's office. Earlier Wednesday, House Speaker Tom Gustafson and Senate President Bob Crawford implored Martinez not to kill the package, which was 1{ years in the making. ``I believe we're at the end of our stack of cheap, easy, painless solutions,'' Gustafson said. ``This is still needed legislation.'' The speaker claimed the veto could paralyze the construction industry and that Florida's roads would become more dangerous. ``This plan is the Legislature's compromise, and it is our bottom line,'' Gustafson said. Martinez replied: ``There's still four weeks to go in this session. One thing we should never do in government is come up with an ultimatum, all or nothing.'' Neither Republicans nor Democrats in either the House or Senate believe a veto override is possible. While the bill passed both chambers by the necessary two-thirds margin, many GOP lawmakers who voted for the package said they would not join an override attempt. House Minority Leader Dale Patchett said Republicans will offer a plan containing elements Martinez can support, such as increased motorist fees and bond sales for turnpikes.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Convicted of Sex With Teen-Ager Says He's in Race to Stay
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 7th graf, ```I apologize...,' to UPDATE with campaign stops later Wednedsay. Picks up 8th graf, `Robert Bennett, ...
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Donald Lukens apologized Wednesday for ``a dumb mistake'' and announced he is actively seeking re-election even though his appeal on a conviction of having sex with a teen-ager is pending. The state's chairman of the Republican Party, however, repeated a call for Lukens to resign from Congress. ``We don't have much time,'' Lukens said in making his announcement in this western Ohio village, 30 miles north of Dayton. The GOP primary election is Tuesday. He had said since his conviction last May that he would not decide on his political future until after the outcome of his appeal. Although he filed for re-election to put his name on the ballot, he had not campaigned and never announced he was running. The 59-year-old divorced congressman was convicted of a misdemeanor charge of contributing to the unruliness of a minor. He was accused of paying a girl to have sex with him at his Columbus apartment in November 1988, when she was 16. A judge sentenced Lukens to 30 days in jail and fined him $500. He has been free on bond pending his appeal. ``I apologize. I made a dumb mistake. I'm sorry,'' Lukens said. ``I'm paying a big price for that mistake.'' In Greenville, Lukens repeated his message to about 20 people, saying in spite of his ``stumble,'' he's never stopped working for his constituents. Lukens wrapped up Wednesday evening in his hometown of Middletown, where he spoke briefly to about 50 supporters outside an American Legion Hall. ``The people know men and they know my record, let them judge,'' Lukens said. ``Nobody knows any politician in the country better than you know me.'' Robert Bennett, chairman of the Ohio GOP, said Lukens displayed ``a lapse of morals'' and had abused the trust of his constituents. ``This is not a political matter; it's a moral matter. Congressman Lukens has never denied having sex with a child, and on that issue alone he should not represent the people of the 8th District,'' Bennett said. Lukens faces opposition from three other Republicans: Thomas Kindness, who held the 8th District seat before Lukens was elected in 1986; state Rep. John Boehner, and Mort Meier, a bond underwriter. Three candidates are running in the Democratic primary. Lukens served two terms in Congress from 1967 to 1970, when he made an unsuccessful attempt to gain the Ohio GOP gubernatorial nomination. After 15 years in the Ohio Senate, he was returned to Congress in 1986, when Kindness stepped down to run against Democratic U.S. Sen. John Glenn. Lukens was re-elected in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Deports Suspect in Mexican Journalist's Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A Mexican man wanted in connection with the murder of a journalist was arrested in the United States and turned over to Baja California state judicial authorities, Gov. Ernesto Ruffo Appel said Wednesday. Ruffo told a news conference in the state capital Mexicali that Antonio Vera Palestina was picked up Tuesday afternoon by police in El Monte, Calif., where he was living as an illegal alien under an assumed name. The suspect was deported to Mexico the same evening, Ruffo said. Vera Palestina is wanted for the April 20, 1988, fatal shooting in Tijuana of Hector Felix Miranda, a muckraking columnist and co-publisher of the weekly newspaper Zeta, also known as ``El Gato'' or The Cat. Felix Miranda received death threats several times for denouncing corruption in the Baja California state government while the Institutional Revolutionary Party was in power. Ruffo, a member of the conservative National Action Party, was elected last year and took office Dec. 1. He was the first opposition candidate to be elected governor of a state in Mexico since the Institutional Revolutionary Party came to power 61 years ago. Vera Palestina is being held for trial in Tijuana, across the border from San Ysidro, Calif., where he was arraigned Wednesday on first-degree murder charges at the Baja California 2nd Criminal Court, Ruffo said. Victoriano Medina, a former member of the state judicial police, is also in a Tijuana jail awaiting trial in connection with the slaying. Felix Miranda was the last of 30 Mexican journalists assassinated during the previous six-year administration of President Miguel de la Madrid. Zeta has offices in Tijuana and Mexicali.

DOC.HEAD: White Tiger Born In Circus
DOC.TEXT: A rare white tiger was born among a litter of three cubs at the Clyde Beatty Cole Brothers Circus, a spokesman said Wednesday. Circus spokesman Jeff Chalmers said that the cub was born Tuesday night. The mother and the litter were doing well, he said. The cub will stay with the circus for about two weeks until it is weaned from the mother and then will be taken to a private compound for care, Chalmers said. Ron Tilson, coordinator of a Siberian tiger species preservation program, said white tigers are born once in about 4,000-5,000 births. All white tigers in North America can be traced to a single male named Mohawk, and are the result of cross-breeding between Bengal and Siberian tigers, said Tilson, who is director of conservation at the Minnesota Zoo in Apple Valley, Minn. White tigers are white with brown stripes and blue eyes, but are not albinos, Tilson added. He said there are at least 40 in North America.

DOC.HEAD: Two Crewmen Eject as U.S. Air Force Jet Crashes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to UPDATE with airmen identified. Picks up 5th pvs, `I understand...'
DOC.TEXT: Two U.S. Air Force crewmen ejected safely Wednesday moments before their F111-F jet fighter crashed into a wheat field in eastern England, the Air Force said. The jet was on a routine attack training mission when it crashed near Binham, 120 miles northeast of London, said Air Force Master Sgt. Michael Devine. Norfolk police said two buildings in the area were slightly damaged by debris. Capt. David F. Ratcliffe, the pilot, and weapons systems operator Lt. Brian W. Kirkwood were taken to their base hospital at Lakenheath, a World War II Royal Air Force airfield 60 miles northeast of London, the Air Force said. Their ages and hometowns were not given. ``I understand one had a strained back, but that's all,'' said Norfolk Police Inspector Ted Steward. Witnesses said the jet was flying very low just before it crashed. Binham sub-postmaster George Bird said he saw ``a ball of fire in the air.'' An Air Force spokesman explained that the ball of fire was probably caused by the rockets that eject the cockpit from the plane. The Air Force said a board of officers would investigate the crash.

DOC.HEAD: Cable TV Regulation Won't Slow Cable Growth, Ted Turner Says
DOC.TEXT: Cable television tycoon Ted Turner said Wednesday more regulation of the industry doesn't necessarily mean less growth. ``I don't see it as any sort of a serious threat,'' Turner told a New York Television Academy luncheon. Turner asserted the real push for cable regulation is coming from network broadcasters and phone companies, with the former ``trying to restrain cable any way they possibly can.'' Virtually all cities with cable have had essentially no regulation of cable systems since 1985 because a federal law that generally freed local cable systems of rate regulation. But with some critics charging that cable has become an unregulated monopoly, there now are proposals before Congress to regulate the industry. According to A.C. Nielsen Co. estimates, cable serves more than 57 percent of the nation's 92.1 million homes with television. The National Cable Television Association, on whose board Turner serves, said it will cooperate to work out an acceptable regulation bill. But in Senate testimony in March, NCTA president James P. Mooney warned that reregulation of cable rates would ``choke off'' funds for programming and they would ``prefer'' the cable industry remain unregulation. Turner, whose Turner Broadcasting System owns four cable networks, including Cable News Network, said he spent considerable time talking with key members of House and Senate subcommittees about regulation proposals. ``So far, they haven't come up with anything that they think they can get through at the current time,'' he said. ``But I don't think it will slow cable up if they do. I don't think it will be that bad if they do. ``So I'm not too worried about it. ... I don't see it as any sort of a serious threat.'' Turner also asserted the ratings of networks and broadcast stations will decline and those of cable will climb. He predicted that cable would be in 70 percent of the nation's households 2{ years from now.

DOC.HEAD: Spy Ship Officer To Accept Heroism Medal 15 Years After Spurning Award
DOC.TEXT: The former No. 2 officer aboard the USS Pueblo, who spurned a U.S. Navy heroism award 15 years ago, says he'll accept a medal honoring him and other crewmen as prisoners of war. Former Lt. Ed Murphy Jr. said he refused the Navy combat commendation because other Pueblo crew members had not been recognized for their heroism during 11 months of captivity in North Korea in 1968. ``The reason I rejected the medal was that some other crew members who deserved awards for heroism were not recommended,'' Murphy said. He said he changed his mind after the Defense Department decided last month to bestow new U.S. prisoner-of-war medals to the crew. He will accept that award this weekend to make peace with the Navy, he said. Murphy won't receive the same medal he rejected, said Bob White, director of San Diego County Veterans Services. ``We've never been asked by Mr. Murphy to re-present that medal,'' he said. When the POW medal was authorized by Congress in 1988, the crew of the USS Pueblo specifically was excluded from eligibility because the United States was not engaged in an armed conflict with North Korea when it seized the spy ship. A Pentagon legal adviser at the time ruled that the Pueblo crew was merely detained, meaning they should not get the medal. Murphy, who lives in San Diego County, said 61 of the 82 surviving Pueblo crewmen so far have indicated they will attend the POW medal presentation ceremony Saturday afternoon. He blamed the Pueblo's skipper, retired Navy Cmdr. Lloyd ``Pete'' Bucher, for deciding not to recommend other crew members for the heroism medal. He and Bucher were at odds before the seizure and during their captivity. ``I had to obey orders,'' Murphy said. ``If I had been in command, I would have followed the course I recommended to Bucher _ get out of there at flank speed (about 25 mph).'' Murphy is the Pueblo's most senior officer to be offered a decoration for performance of duty as a North Korean POW. Navy officials say Bucher, the former commanding officer who also lives in San Diego County, will receive the POW medal but not a heroism award. The Pueblo was gathering intelligence about radar and other defense installations on Jan. 23, 1968 when it was fired on by North Korean naval vessels and captured in international waters. One Pueblo sailor was killed. The crewmen were tortured and suffered public humiliation before they were freed in December 1968. Despite a formal Navy court of inquiry, many questions remain about the Koreans' motives for seizing the ship and why no U.S. forces responded to calls for help before Bucher surrendered the Pueblo and its crew. Bucher, Murphy and another Pueblo officer were recommended for courts-martial at the time of the inquiry, but the move was vetoed by John Chafee, then Secretary of the Navy. Bucher has accused the Navy of putting the ship in a dangerous position and then failing to provide support.

DOC.HEAD: Museum Art Theft Re-created For ``America's Most Wanted''
DOC.TEXT: The television show ``America's Most Wanted'' will broadcast a re-enactment of the theft of artworks from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, as part of the effort to solve the $200 million crime. At the urging of the FBI, museum officials allowed camera crews on Monday to recreate the March 18 crime, using actors to play the thieves and museum guards and enlarged photographs of the artwork made from museum slides. The weekly series on the FOX network re-creates unsolved crimes and provides telephone numbers for viewers to call in with tips. Anne Hawley, museum director, said the FBI has asked the museum to cooperate ``in the hope that it would result in the return of the stolen artwork.'' John Kavanaugh, the segment's producer, said the FBI, police and museum officials worked together to piece together details of the crime in which two men posed as police officers, bound two museum guards and made off with 13 works thought to be worth more than $200 million. Composite drawings of both thieves will be shown during the program, tentatively scheduled for broadcast May 13.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Seek U.S. Help Cleaning Pollution Blamed on Red Army
DOC.TEXT: Visiting Czechoslovak government officials said Wednesday they are appealing for U.S. help cleaning the environment, including military sites polluted by departed Soviet forces. Czechoslovakia has long realized that industrial waste made it one of the world's worst polluted countries but an unexpected problem has appeared at some of the sites occupied by the Soviet Army since 1968, Deputy Prime Minister Petr Pithart told a news conference. Environment Minister Bedrich Moldan said ``the big surprise was ... finding hydrocarbons, chemicals of unknown origin and unprotected sewer systems that have polluted the ground and the drinking water around the sites.'' The wastes have not been fully analyzed and it is too early to say whether they include any chemical warfare substances, he said in answer to questions. Soviet forces have vacated three of 150 sites they occupied since the 1968 Warsaw Pact intervention in Czechoslovakia, leaving behind ripped up underground fuel tanks, craters covered with dirt and gravel and pipelines feeding unidentified substances into streams and waterways, Moldan said. Moldan said cleanup costs were estimated at $2.5 million per site in a preliminary survey of a vacated Soviet military base at Frenstat, Moravia, by Martech USA, an American company. He said Martech is opening an office in Prague and forming a joint venture with Geo Test, a Czechoslovak engineering enterprise. ``Martech officials tell us that the sites can be cleaned up to meet your Environmental Protection standards but there is a great deal of work to be done,'' he said. ``We need scrubbers and filters to help clean up our air, we need to develop hazardous waste storage sites and to clean up our waterways.'' The ministers, members of Czechoslovakia's first democratic government in more than 40 years, said officials of the U.S. State Department and Environmental Protection Agency listened sympathetically to their needs and would study the problems.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Back Down from Demand that President Resign
DOC.TEXT: About 2,500 anti-government demonstrators occupied a downtown square Wednesday for the eleventh consecutive day and protest leaders softened their demands that interim President Ion Iliescu resign. One of the protester's key demands is that the government adopt a proposal excluding former Communists from politics. This would exclude Iliescu who held several high-ranking positions in the early 1970's under deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. But Wednesday the rally organizers emphasized that Iliescu was not the focus of their demands. ``It may not be too late for Iliescu to again represent the interest of the people,'' said Mihai Lucian, a leader of one of the protest groups. ``We initially supported Iliescu after the revolution, and our main complaint against him now refers to what he has done since.'' Porotests claim that Iliescu, one of the leaders of the December revolution that deposed Ceausescu, has brought former Communists into the government. At a press conference the leaders of the four groups that organized the round-the-clock protests in University Square said their demands included freeing radio and television from government control, establishing a commission for ``cleansing'' the government of former Communists and investigating police abuses. Opposition groups have repeatedly said that Iliescu's National Salvation Front, which dominates the interim government, has an unfair advantage in the May 20 national elections because the government controls television and radio stations. On Monday five major opposition parties threatened to boycott the elections accusing the National Salvation Front of monopolozing power. On Tuesday, the government guarateed equal chances to all parties contesting the elections and offered to meet with opposition parties to discuss their criticisms. Protest organizers said they had received information that Vice Prime Minister Gelu Voican-Voiculescu had ``expressed willingness'' to open a dialogue with them. Voican-Voiculescu could not be reached for comment, but government spokesman Vasile Nastase said the government was ruling out negotiations with the protesters. At University Square, protest leaders continued to collect signatures for a proclamation calling for the exclusion of former Communist functionaries from politics. They claim to have gathered 5 million signatures. The claim could not be independently verified. In another development, Roman Catholic nun and Nobel Peace Prize winner Mother Theresa arrived in Bucharest Wednesday night for a visit of undetermined length.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Prime Minister to Plead Cause to Bush in Person
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 13-14: ``Before leaving,'' with Prunskeine comment in Canada. Please Note a0720 should have been slugged 2nd Ld, not 1st
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene will plead the cause of Lithuanian independence Thursday to President Bush whose failure to penalize Moscow for an economic blockade was decried by Lithuania's president as a second ``Munich.'' ``The act of independence ... is untouchable,'' Mrs. Prunskiene said Tuesday as she began her North American swing in Toronto, Canada. Still, the prime minister's trip comes as Lithuanian leaders signal a willingness to slow the independence drive in exchange for an easing of the Kremlin's punishing economic blockade. In a letter to West German and French leaders, outlined Wednesday to the parliament in Vilnius, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis proposed that Western countries play a role in proposed negotiations with the Kremlin. Landsbergis, in a separate letter released by Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., also said that ``the danger of violence or provocations of some sort remains very real'' in his republic and that shortages of consumer goods ``will eventually lead to unrest in large segments of the population.'' President Bush could help by heeding Congress' call for diplomatic relations with Lithuania, he wrote. ``If this is still not possible at the present moment, when will it become possible? Under what conditions?'' Bush, who has agreed to a low-key, non-official meeting with Mrs. Prunskiene on Thursday, has urged the Soviets and the Lithuanians to open a dialogue to resolve their differences. Bush on Wednesday proposed easing restrictions on sales of sophisticated computers and other high tech products to the Soviet Union and East Bloc. Just last week Bush decided to let trade talks with the Soviets proceed despite the crackdown on Lithuania. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater defended the timing of the latest move, saying it was dictated by the changes in Eastern Europe as well as the Soviet Union, as well as pressure from America's allies to east the restrictions. He said Bush remains ``very concerned'' about the Lithuanian crisis. The U.S.-Soviet trade talks ``are progressing,'' Fitzwater said, ``but it's still an open question.'' On Tuesday Fitzwater said Bush was meeting with Mrs. Prunskiene not as prime minister of an independent Lithuania but rather as ``an acknowledged and freely elected representative of the Lithuanian people.'' Mrs. Prunskiene, who arrived Wednesday evening in Washington, is also scheduled to meet with congressional leaders and with ranking State Department officials and to testify at a public hearing of the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, the Helsinki Commission. Before leaving Toronto for Washington, she met with Canadian business leaders to lay a foundation for future trade agreements with Canada. She declined to identify the companies represented, but said, ``They are very substantial of all types and sizes and the meetings with them have been truly substantial and productive ones.'' Bush has declined to recognize the republic's independence before it achieves control over its territory and institutions. Lithuania and two other Baltic republics were forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940. Bush has also deferred a decision on sanctions against the Kremlin in the Lithuanian dispute in order to avoid both increasing the political pressure on Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and complicating the prospect for talks. Lithuanian President Landsbergis initially called Bush's decision a political ``Munich,'' a disparaging comparison to the bid by Britain and France in 1938 to appease Nazi Germany at the expense of Czechoslovakia. Landsbergis told the Lithuanian parliament on Wednesday that he was pleased Bush would meet with Mrs. Prunskiene and added: ``We hope that Mrs. Prunskiene will more completely inform President Bush about the situation in Lithuania in the days of blockade.'' Gorbachev has declared the March 11 declaration of independence by Lithuania's parliament invalid and illegal under the Soviet Constitution and has said there can be no dialogue until it is rescinded. In Toronto on Tuesday, Mrs. Prunskiene said that the cities of Moscow and Leningrad have agreed to help Lithuania ease the pressure of the Soviet embargo. She did not say exactly what assistance was offered. But Lithuania sent a delegation to Leningrad last week to explore a possible direct exchange of goods either for hard currency or barter. Mrs. Prunskiene told reporters that reform municipal councils in Leningrad, Moscow and elsewhere in the Soviet Union offered to assist Lithuania ``because they receive many of their food supplies from us.''

DOC.HEAD: Campaign Launched for U.S. Infrastructure Restoration
DOC.TEXT: Sponsors of a nationwide ``town meeting'' radio broadcast Wednesday night urged that savings from the end of the cold war be used to restore American roads, bridges, schools and other deteriorating infrastructure rather than merely helping to reduce the federal deficit. Concrete planning for conversion from a military-driven to a civilian economy will be needed to restore the United States as a first-class industrial country, they said. The message was being aired at simultaneous meetings in 64 cities Wednesday, followed by the two-hour broadcast over more than 30 radio stations from coast to coast, said Jonathan Feldman, spokesman of the National Commission for Economic Conversion and Disarmament, a private advocacy group. Author Studs Terkel was moderator of the program, which scheduled appearances by political and civic leaders including New York Mayor David Dinkins, Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., former Democratic presidential candidate George McGovern, Southwestern Bell Finance Director Susan Fox and George Korpius, president of the Machinists Union. Commission Chairman Seymour Melman, economist and retired Columbia University industrial engineering professor, has long argued that military spending was bleeding the United States of the resources needed for roads, schools, housing and other investments. Melman, 72, has been saying in lectures, articles and interviews that by the end of the 1970s the United States was no longer a first-class industrial economy by virtue of investing a smaller proportion of gross national product in its civilian economy than European countries or Japan. ``Some voice the opinion that whatever savings accrue from a military wind-down should be used only to reduce the size of the federal debt,'' he said in a New York Times article last December. ``That is a sure vote for a third-rate economy,'' he added.
Eds: Technical trouble has delayed the evening weather tables. We expect to be able to move them within 30 minutes.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Attorney for Bus Driver Accused in Shootings Says He Was Frustrated
DOC.TEXT: A city bus driver accused of shooting one person to death and wounding three others was frustrated with his job and angry at police for failing to capture his daughter's attacker, his attorney said Wednesday. Paul Bellazain, 46, was charged with two counts of attempted murder in the wounding of two police officers in Daly City, a southern suburb, on Tuesday. He had not been charged by Wednesday night in the random fatal shooting of a bicyclist and the wounding of a motorist the same day in San Francisco. On Tuesday morning, the gunman cruised Interstate 280 and side streets in San Francisco, killing a bicyclist at McLaren Park and firing at cars during a 45-minute morning rampage that finally ended in a shootout with police outside crowded Westlake Shopping Center in Daly City. Bellazain, who was shot in the thigh by police and then tackled, was listed in good condition under police guard at San Mateo County Hospital Wednesday. Attorney Melvin Belli said Bellazain, a municipal bus driver on disability for a hand injury the past five months, had been scheduled to be in his office Tuesday to give a deposition. Bellazain had filed a civil lawsuit in connection with the January 1988 drive-by shooting of his daughter, Shari, then 17, who lost a kidney and part of her intestine. ``He got the days mixed up so he came over here the day before the shooting,'' Belli said. ``He seemed OK, but a little upset. ... I think he was upset with the police system because they were unable to locate the person who shot his daughter.'' Bellazain filed a civil suit against the owner of the Rolladium Roller Rink in San Mateo where his daughter was shot. He claims rink employees didn't let his daughter inside when she sought help. Bellazain was also frustrated because he had been unable to get early disability retirement for a 1988 back injury, Belli said. The former bus driver union president, who recently lost a re-election bid, was removed from his post in 1981 after he allegedly hit another driver with a pool cue. The dead man in Tuesday's shootings was identified as James Vaszko, 43, of San Francisco, a copy editor at the San Francisco Examiner. The motorist, James Neumann, 41, of San Francisco, remained in serious condition at San Francisco General Hospital, suffering from shotgun wounds he received in his arm and chest while traveling on I-280. Officer Gary Smith, who tackled Bellazain and was injured in the left arm by a .38-caliber handgun, was in good condition at Seton Medical Center. Daly City Police spokesman Jim McHenry said Smith was being considered for a commendation for heroism. The second officer, Sgt. Ralph Warren, was released from Seton Wednesday following treatment for a gunshot wound to his left arm. ``There were quite a few rounds fired,'' said McHenry, who estimated that the gunman spent up to 20 shells. ``This guy was cranking off rounds with several weapons.'' Officers recovered a shotgun, rifle and .38-caliber pistol from Bellazain. Before the Daly City shootout, Bellazain held chiropractor Gene Martin and his receptionist hostage, Martin said. Bellazain told them he wanted to get back at police because they were investigating him for allegedly molesting his children, the hostages said. He told his hostages he was ``sick of the system, knew he was going to die and wanted to take some cops with him,'' they reported. Bellazain's daughters, who have been living with him for the past few years, had called a Seton Medical Center crisis center before the rampage began at 8:56 a.m. No one was home when Daly City police arrived after 9 a.m. By then, the shooting had begun. Bellazain told police last week he was going to check himself into a mental health center, said San Francisco police Capt. Bob Fife.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Panel Working on Limiting Medicaid Coverage
DOC.TEXT: A panel has completed a ranking of 3,000 medical treatments that health officials said Wednesday will be used to help the state decide what operations are to be eliminated from Medicaid in the future. Oregon is the first state in the country to consider limiting the types of treatments that will be paid for by Medicaid. Officials said skyrocketing medical costs have forced the state to make a choice: Either reduce the pool of those who can receive Medicaid, or stop payment on certain expensive treatments, like transplants. It has chosen the latter. The Health Services Commission compiled a 167-page list of of 3,000 medical treatments ranked under a cost-benefit formula that divides the cost of the procedure by the benefit in years of life and improvement of life. The commission and a panel called Oregon Health Decision developed the list after holding 11 public hearings, 50 community meetings, and telephone interviews to find out which illnesses Oregonians fear the most. Over the next two weeks, the committee will weigh aspects such as quality of life, personal choice and the community's sense of compassion, said Paige Sipes-Metzler, chairwoman of the 11-member panel. On May 15, it will factor together these criteria with the cost-benefit analysis to make a final list. Under the current Medicaid system, the number of people who are eligible depends on the amount of money that is available to treat them. When money gets tight, the state rewrites its eligibility requirements, knocking more people off the Medicaid list. Those who are left, generally the poorest, enjoy a relatively rich package of benefits. The new program, while eliminating some services, would add about 77,000 Oregonians to basic Medicaid rolls that now number about 130,000, officials said. The bottom line on which treatments are excluded from Medicaid will be made by the Legislature in January. Among the most likely procedures are transplants, which can run into hundreds of thousands of dollars. Oregon must get permission from the federal government to modify its Medicaid program before it can implement the program. The changes were proposed by state Senate President John Kitzhaber, who is an emergency room physician. In 1987, the Legislature halted Medicaid funding for most organ transplants, using the money for other health needs such as prenatal care. Only two other states, Virginia and Arizona, exclude transplants from Medicaid. Congress designed Medicaid to provide health care to the poor, but medical costs have forced states to adjust their eligibility standards to exclude many poor people. Other states are watching Oregon's program to see if they can adapt aspects ot it. U.S. health-care spending this year is expected to exceed $600 billion, about 12 percent of the gross national product, up from 7 percent in 1970, officials say. About 31.5 million people in the United States have neither health insurance nor Medicaid coverage, according to the Census Bureau.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Appeals Panel Upholds Constitutionality of Illinois Death Penalty
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court Wednesday upheld the constitutionality of Illinois' death penalty statute, striking down the earlier ruling of a federal judge. The three-member 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reversed the decision of U.S. District Judge Harold Baker, who had ruled in 1989 that the state's death penalty was unconstitutional on the grounds that it allowed prosecutors too much leeway on whether to seek capital punishment. Some 120 men are on death row in Illinois. Among them is John W. Gacy, convicted of killing 33 young men and boys in the worst multiple-killing case in U.S. history. Because of prolonged appeals, no one has been executed under the 1977 statute. Attorneys for convicted double murderer Charles Silagy had challenged the constitutionality of the law, saying their handling of the case was hampered by not knowing whether prosecutors would seek the death penalty. The Illinois attorney general's office asked the federal appeals court in January to overturn Baker's ruling. The 53-page decision Wednesday by Judges Michael Kanne, John Coffey and Frank Easterbrook was the first time the federal appeals panel has ruled specifically on the current Illinois death penalty law. It rejected Baker's contention that state laws allowed prosecutors to be ``arbitrary and capricious'' and thereby hindered defense attorneys. ``We do not agree,'' wrote Kanne in the appellate decision. Instead, the law ``permits the prosecutor to weigh all of the evidence,'' Kanne wrote, ``in his assessment of the propriety of seeking the death penalty.'' Although Illinois prosecutors can wait until after a conviction to announce whether they will seek the death penalty, they still have to prove the case warrants capital punishment, Kanne said. Assistant Illinois Attorney General Jack Donatelli argued before the appeals court in January that the state statute was neither arbitrary nor capricious, but is specific about who is eligible for the death penalty and includes safeguards meant to correct any mistakes an overzealous prosecutor might make. Wednesday's decision came two days after the U.S. Supreme Court cleared the way for the execution of convicted murderer Charles Walker by ruling that five people who initiated a challenge to Walker's death sentence had no standing in the case. Walker, sentenced to die in 1983 after he pleaded guilty to killing Sharon Winker and Kevin Paule in southern Illinois' St. Clair County, stands at the top of the list of the state's death-row inmates. Walker has said he wants to die and has abandoned all appeals. The Illinois Supreme Court has yet to set Walker's execution date.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Army Dynamites Clandestine Airstrips in Amazon Jungle
DOC.TEXT: The government on Wednesday began dynamiting the first of 110 clandestine airstrips cut by gold miners on Amazon jungle lands inhabited by the Yanomami Indians, the world's largest primitive tribe. More than 250 army soldiers, air force officials and federal police blew up the first airstrip Wednesday, a 600-yard runway in the tropical rain forest near the Venezuelan and Guyanan borders. The military used 374 pounds of explosives to blast open 40 holes, each 13 feet in diameter and four feet deep, said Federal Police spokesman Joao Martins. The rest of the airstrips will be destroyed before May 18 to prevent the 40,000 prospectors from returning to Indian lands, Martins said in a telephone interview. He said the work will cost $800,000. President Fernando Collor de Mello ordered the destruction of the airstrips following a visit to the Yanomami reservation soon after he took office on March 15. In addition to evacuating the miners, who first invaded the 1 million acre reserve in 1987, Collor promised to blow up the illegal landing strips to stop planes from supplying the miners and transporting gold and diamonds. Martins said two airstrips will be left intact for the National Indian Foundation and the army, which maintains border outposts in the region to combat drug trafficking and smuggling along Brazil's 4,000-mile northern frontier. He said troops seized one small plane loaded with cocaine on the airstrip just before the dynamiting operation began. Police say drug traffickers used the clandestine airstrips as transhipment points between Colombia and Bolivia. The rush to Yanomami territory began three years ago after government studies revealed the presence of gold, diamonds, tin and bauxite in the region. Prospectors flocked to the area, leveling rain forests, chasing off fish and game, polluting rivers with mercury used in gold panning and spreading diseases previously unknown to the isolated tribe. Since 1987, the tribe has dwindled from about 9,000 to 7,500, due to malnutrition, venereal diseases and malaria. Others have been killed in clashes with miners. Under international pressure, the government of former President Jose Sarney announced a $4 million campaign in early January to expel the prospectors, by force if necessary. There are about 220,000 native Indians left in Brazil, down from an estimated 5 million when the Portuguese first landed here in 1500. The government has been steadily carving up Indian lands, leaving the Yanomamis 19 scattered reservations totaling 5 million acres in Brazil's northwest Amazon territory.

DOC.HEAD: House Calls For $5 Billion Limit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 7-8: ``The Energy,'' department comment
DOC.TEXT: The House voted Wednesday to limit the federal government's spending on the super collider atom smasher to $5 billion. Current Energy Department estimates of the ultimate cost of the collider range up to $8 billion. The bill, approved 309-109 and sent to the Senate, gives the department specific authority to build the particle accelerator. Since the department already could undertake the project under other general authority to support scientific research, the specific authority is important mostly as a sign of political support. The collider, a 54-miles-around tunnel in which beams of protons will smash together to explore the secrets of matter, will be the largest scientific instrument ever built. It is planned for a site about 30 miles south of Dallas. Under the legislation approved Wednesday, costs above $5 billion would be left to Texas, which has pledged $1 billion, and other sources, including foreign contributors. The Energy Department did not mention the spending limit in a statement by Deputy Secretary Henson Moore welcoming the House action as an ``important victory.'' ``We are pleased with the 3-1 margin which demonstrates support in Congress for this exciting project,'' said Moore. Actual spending must be approved in annual congressional appropriations. The Bush administration sought spending authority of $318 million for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, up $100 million from the current year. Robert Roe, D-N.J., chairman of the Science, Space and Technology Committee said the five-year authorization gives the collider ``the stability and continuity that it needs to flourish.'' But much of the afternoon's debate on the bill centered on making sure the federal share would not rise if the total cost of the project did. ``When the House votes for this legislation today, it is going on record that the SSC will not cost the taxpayer one dime more than $5 billion,'' said Rep. Robert Walker, R-Pa., the ranking minority member of the Science, Space and Technology Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Palace Worker Accidentally Killed, Panamanians Deny Coup Rumors
DOC.TEXT: A guard accidentally shot and killed a presidential palace employee during a training exercise, a spokesman said Wednesday. The incident set off rumors of a coup against President Guillermo Endara, now visiting the United States, but palace spokesman Rene Hernandez denied the allegations. Cabinet Minister Julio Harris also denied the rumors: ``There were a series of rumors and speculations concerning unusual movements at the Las Garzas Palace, but these were due to training exercises by the presidential guard.'' Hernandez told reporters Jose Cubilla, 23, was accidentally shot several times by a palace guard during training maneuvers by the president's security detail. Cubilla died soon after the incident. Endara is expected back in Panama City on Thursday. Endara was sworn in as president on Dec. 19, hours before U.S. forces invaded Panama to oust dictator Manuel Noriega. Endara oppposed Noriega in elections last May but results of the balloting were annulled by Noriega.

DOC.HEAD: Stunt Man's Widow Loses Negligence Suit Over His Death
DOC.TEXT: A jury Wednesday threw out a negligence lawsuit by the widow of a Hollywood stuntman who died after plunging off an embankment on a motorcycle during the making of a film. The jury, after seven weeks of testimony, decided that the film producers, Dino De Laurentiis Productions, DEG, De Laurentiis Film Partners and Productions Ltd., could not be held responsible for Dar Robinson's death during the 1986 filming of ``Million Dollar Mystery.'' Linda Robinson burst into tears after the separate verdicts for each company were announced. She said outside court that she would continue to pursue the case. ``I had just hoped this would be the end,'' she sobbed. ``This was the final burying of my husband for me. Now I can see it's going to be a long time. That's the injustice of it.'' ``It's a really sad thing,'' said juror Linda Burrow. ``Somebody died and it's really sad, and we did feel there was some responsibility on the part of `Million Dollar Mystery.''' But Ms. Burrow said the legal instructions given to the jury gave them ``no choice'' but to find for the defendants. Mrs. Robinson's lawyer, Jerry Kroll, maintained that Robinson died because an ambulance was not available at the remote desert location where he was filming ``Million Dollar Mystery'' on Nov. 21, 1986. The attorney said it took two hours to get Robinson to the nearest hospital after his motorcycle ran off U.S. Highway 89A and he fell down a 40-foot embankment. Robinson, 39, suffered massive internal injuries. During the trial, Kroll called movie stars Danny Glover and Burt Reynolds to testify about Robinson's reputation as a top stuntman and about safety on the sets where he worked. ``The evidence was overwhelming that DEG and the other defendants were negligent,'' Kroll said. Attorneys for DEG and Productions Ltd. argued that there was no ambulance on the set because Robinson felt it was ``bad luck'' and an insult to his stunt abilities to have one around. Attorney John Hager, who represented Delaurentiis, DEG and Film Partners, said, said his clients had offered ``a significant settlement'' to Mrs. Robinson before trial but it was rejected. Attorney Joe Deems, who represented Productions Ltd., said the company followed Screen Actors Guilty rules for safety and ``they are sound rules.''

DOC.HEAD: Reed Reports on Two British Hostages
DOC.TEXT: The families of a British and an Irish captive in Lebanon got word from freed U.S. hostage Frank Reed on Wednesday that the two are alive and well, the first concrete assurance they had received since the 1986 abductions. Reed told reporters in Wiesbaden, West Germany, he had been with Briton John McCarthy and Brian Keenan, a dual Anglo-Irish citizen, since October. He phoned a hostage group in Britain to report he saw them Saturday, two days before he was freed. Reed telephoned McCarthy's father, Pat, and McCarthy's friend, Jill Morrell, and said, ``They are both well. They have some minor health problems. They exercise daily and read voraciously,'' the group said. Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie said he was encouraged, even though Reed had no news of Terry Waite, the Anglican leader's envoy. Waite disappeared Jan. 20, 1987, after leaving his Beirut hotel to negotiate with Islamic Jihad for the release of U.S. hostages. No group claimed to hold him, but Waite, 50, is widely believed held by Islamic Jihad. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd told reporters before flying to Brussels Wednesday night he hoped the release of Reed and fellow American Robert Polhill last week ``is part of a movement which will get them all out.'' ``I shall be talking to James Baker, the American secreary of state, and comparing notes with him in the morning in Brussels,'' he said. Joan Willows, a spokeswoman for the group, the Friends of John McCarthy, said: ``Mr. Reed said John had grown a beard and keeps fit by performing squat thrusts and press-ups (push-ups), and as far as his captors could be they are quite good. He is not being tortured.'' Ms. Morrell said on BBC radio that Reed told her McCarthy, 33, was aware of the campaign for his release ``and was getting the messages that we put to him in the newspaper in Beirut.'' ``It's just the best thing I've heard in four years. It's amazing,'' she said. She told Independent Television News after talking to Reed: ``They are chained and blindfolded most of the time _ chained to a radiator apart from this period in the morning when they can exercise in the room.'' McCarthy, a journalist for the Worldwide Television News agency of London, was kidnapped April 17, 1986, as he drove to Beirut Airport to leave Lebanon. Keenan, 39, is from Belfast in British-ruled Northern Ireland. An English-language teacher at the American University in Beirut, he disappeared while walking to work April 11, 1986. He was traveling on an Irish passport. No group has claimed to be holding either man. Other missing Britons are Jack Mann, 75, an ex-pilot who disappeared in west Beirut a year ago, and Alec Collett, 68, a New York-based journalist on assignment for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, who was kidnapped March 25, 1985. Six Americans, an Italian, two West Germans and two Swiss also are believed held captive. The longest held, Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, was kidnapped on March 16, 1985.

The Senate, upset over President Bush's decision not to punish the Soviet Union for its actions in Lithuania, is urging him to put the brakes on a new U.S.-Soviet trade agreement. By a 73-24 vote, the Senate passed a resolution Tuesday seeking a halt to any trade agreement that would grant the Soviet Union lower tariffs as long as the crackdown on Lithuania continues. The non-binding resolution urges Bush not to act on any trade agreements until the Soviets lift their economic blockade against Lithuania and enter into negotiations aimed at independence for the republic.
