In a political twist, the measure was introduced by a fellow Republican _ Sen. Alfonse D'Amato of New York _ and supported by most GOP senators. Only Republican Sens. John Warner of Virginia and Alan Simpson of Wyoming voted against the measure.

All American hostages must be freed before the United States can move beyond the ``small gestures'' of thanks already given to Iran, President Bush's spokesman says. To a suggestion from an Iranian newspaper that the next move should come from the United States, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Tuesday, ``The ball has always been in their court, and will be as long as there are hostages yet to be released.'' Fitzwater refused to disclose the oral message that freed hostage Robert Polhill brought to Bush in a private meeting Monday. But a senior administration official indicated it hewed closely to what the world has heard in the past from the kidnappers.

Parents and teen-agers cried and held hands and counselors were placed on 24-hour call as a shocked community attempted to recover from the suicides of three high school students in two days. Counselors were assigned to every classroom at Sheridan High School today after a 17-year-old was found dead of a gunshot wound Tuesday. On Monday, two of his schoolmates shot themselves to death. One of them killed himself in front of a history class after professing his love for a girl. Scott Stamper, 16, said the latest suicide shook up most students. ``People who didn't even know him were crying. It was quiet. I walked in school today and saw zombies,'' he said.

State police sealed off a Mohawk reservation to outsiders and moved in to keep the peace today after two Indians were shot to death in a 9-month-old battle over casino gambling. The slayings were the first fatalities in the dispute that has torn apart the 14,000-member reservation with gunfire and arson. Up to 600 Mohawks fled to a refugee center in Ontario last week after a week of nightly violence. Early Tuesday, 22-year-old Matthew Pyke, a casino opponent, was slain while walking in the reservation in Snye, Quebec, during a gun battle between pro- and anti-gambling factions. The reservation straddles the U.S.-Canadian border. Later Tuesday, J.R. Edwards, 30, a member of the pro-gambling Warriors Society, was found dead next to his house, not far from where Pyke was shot.

The Pentagon, touting the contribution its new radar could make in the drug war, is seeking money for the high-tech system that Congress wouldn't buy for its military value. The $242.8 million radar, which would scan deep into Mexico to find drug-smuggling aircraft, has resurfaced as the costliest item in the Defense Department's 1991 counter-drug budget. Congressional investigators question whether moving the system to the popular and growing anti-drug budget is a maneuver to save it. ``I categorically deny it,'' said Michael A. Wermuth, deputy assistant secretary of defense for drug enforcement policy.

What's the good word? According to the American Dental Association, it's ``jussive'' or maybe ``grisaille.'' A three-member team from the ADA spelled those words, as well as some others like ``cataclasm,'' ``oubliette'' and ``bireme,'' to beat 49 other corporate teams in an adults-only spelling bee. The ADA team spent nearly three hours late Tuesday beating out the rest of the top 20 teams in the second annual Olsten Corporate Great Grown-Up Spelling Bee _ an event that raised an estimated $20,000 for the Literacy Volunteers of Chicago. Officials said it was about 10 percent of the annual budget for the volunteers, who teach reading to adults.

DOC.HEAD: Baptist Futurist Sees Fluid Religious Atmosphere Ahead
DOC.TEXT: Looking ahead, Baptist specialists on other faiths see a changed American religious environment coming, an atmosphere of floating allegiances, blending of practices and greater variety. At the same time, Protestant denominations were seen as becoming more and more alike, with distinctions fading and a casual flow of memberships among them. ``In the future we're going to see less loyalty to a particular denomination and more fuzziness between denominations,'' said Gary Leazer, an interfaith officer of the Southern Baptist Home Missions Board. ``Individuals will increasingly feel free to construct their own worldview from many options present in society rather than being bound by the orthodoxy of their particular faith.'' Leazer was among three leaders of the denomination's interfaith witness department addressing a recent conference on the chaplaincy, long a field that demands working among mixed religious outlooks. He told the conference at Golden Gate Theological Seminary in Mill Valley, Calif., that people increasingly will take the attitude of ``religious consumers'' and shop around for denominations and religions. ``If one denomination does not offer a particular item, people will go to another faith to find it,'' he said. Leazer said the mega-trend of pluralism will further swell the shifting of members among denominations. Already, Gallup poll statistics show a whopping increase in that phenomenon. For example, in 1955, only one in 24 Americans left the faith of childhood to join another denomination, but by 1985, that migration had grown to one in three _ a third of all members. Concurrent with that trend, Leazer said denominations are becoming more alike, as differences in educational and economic status of members narrow. Closer ecumenical relations also furthered that process. Although Southern Baptists have remained formally outside the major ecumenical bodies, other denominations for years have discussed doctrinal emphases and practices for greater understanding and mutual enrichment. As a consequence, worship of the different denominations has become more alike, including that of major Protestant denominations and Roman Catholics. In some cases, close attention is needed to tell them apart. Some formerly non-liturgical churches have gradually become more liturgical, and some once formally liturgical churches have added freer, spontaneous notes, making for greater resemblance. Leazer, director of the Home Mission Board's interfaith witness department, said formerly regional denominations also are moving into new areas, including the Southern Baptist expansion outside the Bible Belt into all 50 states. At the same time, he noted that Roman Catholics have grown immensely within the Bible Belt, a region where they once were few. Leazer said the biggest challenge to Christians in the decade ahead will come from the New Age movement, a mix of pantheism, self-enhancement techniques and occult spirituality, and from Islam. Islam will become part of the nation's religious establishment, along with Judaism and Christianity, he said. Currently, he said there are about 4.l7 million Moslems in America, but that about 4,000 Americans, mostly blacks, join Islam each year, plus Moslem immigrants. Presently there are about 5.9 million U.S. Jews. Leazer also said Eastern religions and occult spirituality will tend to become mainstream, gaining more acceptance in society, their influence felt in the churches. ``People will go to a study group on Hinduism on Friday night and then come to church on Sunday and try to interject those ideas into Bible study,'' he said. He said New Age ideas ``will continue to influence the way Americans think and do religion.'' He also foresaw a splurge of end-of-time prophecies as the end of the century nears. For many Southern Baptists, cooperating ``with people of other religions is one of the most difficult responses to religious pluralism,'' Leazer said, but added: ``You cannot demand the right to be heard by people of other faiths. Interfaith witness allows you to build relationship with people so they will listen to your gospel.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Fri PMs May 4.

DOC.HEAD: US-Japan Trade Issue Has Makings of GOP Trouble
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Conservative Republicans are keeping a wary watch on the Japan trade issue, a sleeper some think could awaken and hurt them. It is complex, contentious, delicate and yet deceptively simple when boiled into the shorthand of campaign politics. That volatile mix came up earlier this year at a forum on the Republican future, where campaign consultants agreed that it has the makings of GOP trouble. ``A George Wallace-type Democrat could have a field day with the issue,'' said Kevin Phillips of the American Political Report. Paul Weyrich of the Free Congress Foundation said a national candidate who made effective use of trade problems and protectionism could come on strong in a future presidential campaign. Japan-bashing sells, he said. ``It sounds macho.'' Rep. Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, now the House majority leader, tried it as a presidential candidate in 1988 and flopped. Gephardt thinks trade barriers, and Japan in particular, might be a more potent issue now. After long, intense negotiations that produced Japanese agreement to open its markets more widely to U.S. supercomputers, lumber and commercial satellites, with the promise of more to come, the aministration dropped the Japanese from its list of countries with trade barriers that pose problems. Under the 1988 trade act, the government annually lists countries it considers to have unfair trade practices against U.S. exports. That is supposed to lead to negotiations on affected industries and products, with the threat of sanctions if the offending practices are not changed. The new list _ a short one; India is the only country left _ produced immediate protests in Congress and a Senate proposal to take away the president's authority over the process. The measure would require that the target list include any country accounting for more than 15 percent of the U.S. international trade deficit, a description that fits only Japan. The United States ran a $49 billion deficit with Japan in 1989, accounting for 45 percent of the total trade imbalance. President Bush said Monday that dropping Japan from the priority negotiation list didn't mean the trade problem has been resolved. ``We know that we could sell more American product if Japan's markets were truly open,'' he told the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. ``But we've been working hard on that, and I think with impressive results. ``Over the past few months, we have made more progress on trade issues with Japan than at any other time I can recall,'' he said. ``Now we are going to continue to press for progress.'' Bush told the businessmen if that doesn't happen, he still has the target list and other options ``to open markets and ensure fair treatment for American products, services, American investment and ideas.'' He said his top priority is to negotiate a strengthening of the general agreement on tariffs and trade, in talks with a December deadline aimed at opening markets in nearly 100 countries. The talks are being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. ``We've got to strengthen GATT as a matter of principle, as a sign to the emerging democracies in eastern Europe and in this hemisphere that free trade is the wave of the future,'' Bush said. Politically, though, and therefore in Congress, there seems to be more interest in staying mad and trying to get even. ``Our hackles get up,'' said Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W. Va., one of the sponsors of the target list system, after the administration dropped Japan from the list. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee and a potential Democratic challenger to Bush in 1992, said after the U.S.-Japan trade agreement was reached late last month that prior deals have produced scant results. ``We thought we came home with the so-called silver bullet agreement and we finally found out we were firing blanks,'' he said. ``Results are what counts, not just agreements,'' Byrd told the Senate on Friday. Then he put the case in terms that may be heard again from political platforms: ``The technology that the Japanese use so well in many instances originates here, in the United States. We develop the technology ... with our very fine American brains, and then the Japanese pick up the technology and they commercialize it and they outsell us... ``My mind boggles with admiration for the Japanese, their ingenuity, their resourcefulness,'' he said. ``They just take our trade negotiators' shirts, and that has been the case for a long time.''

DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 26 years.

DOC.HEAD: Making a Big Deal Out of Shannon's Deal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT to WCBS.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA2
DOC.TEXT: Whoa, somebody reign in the critics. They're out of control. NBC's ``Shannon's Deal'' needs an ace in the hole. In last week's Nielsen Co. ratings, it cashed in at No. 52. But you'd never know it by the reviews. ``You gotta love a lawyer with a screwball mojo attitude,'' raved Mike Duffy of the Detroit Free Press. ``The show appears bound for glory,'' enthused Barry Garron of The Kansas City (Mo.) Star. ``Don't miss `Shannon's Deal,''' said David Zurawik of The Evening Sun of Baltimore. Why such a big deal about ``Shannon's Deal?'' Maybe it's because the show's creator is novelist-screenwriter-filmmaker John Sayles (``Return of the Secaucus 7,'' ``Baby, It's You,'' ``Matewan'' and ``Eight Men Out''). Maybe it's because Grammy-winner Wynton Marsalis does the show's jazz score. Perhaps it's because ``Shannon's Deal'' is just plain peculiar. The down-and-out protagonist, Jack Shannon (played by Jamey Sheridan) is a disillusioned corporate attorney who leaves big business _ and hopefully, his gambling addiction _ to hang out his shingle in a blue-collar Philadelphia neighborhood. Life is not easy for Shannon, who has bad guys on his trail trying to collect gambling debts. He also has a teen-age daughter he feels guilty about not spending enough time with. He runs around saying things like: ``If I told you the truth, I'd be a hypocrite. I never lie.'' Go figure. In a recent episode titled ``Words to Music,'' an unknown songwriter comes to Shannon claiming a country music star has stolen her song. Sample weirdness: _ Rock star David Crosby sitting in an abandoned swimming pool shooting empty bottles. _ Sayles playing a crazed redneck whose gait looked as if he had just finished a two-day cattle drive. _ And the unknown songstress uttering the immortal line, ``I'm about to split a gut. Is there a bathroom in here?'' Weaving in and out of the show was a collection of background music that included ``Me and Mrs. Jones,'' ``At Smokey Joe's Cafe'' and ``If You Don't Know Me by Now.'' The making of ``Shannon's Deal'' is almost as odd as the show itself. Sayles (as writer) did two episodes and the two-hour pilot, shown April 13. Then he left. ``Right now I'm just watching it,'' Sayles said from New Jersey, where he is scouting locations for a new feature film. ``This is something I always kind of planned on. My idea was, `Let's see if I can start the ball rolling and step away.''' So Sayles and executive producer Stan Rogow offered the jobs of writer and director as cameo roles. Tom Rickman, who wrote ``Coal Miner's Daughter,'' has done an episode. So has the co-writer and director of ``The Razor's Edge,'' John Byrum. There's another oddity in the hour-long series at 10 p.m. on Mondays. In a show about an attorney, there is never a courtroom scene. Sayles said he wanted to focus instead on ``the amount of law that was done outside of court and how much it is like a poker game _ the plays, the bluffs, knowing when to fold and how long to stay at the table.'' This is not the first time Sayles, 39, has tried television. In 1980, he wrote ``A Perfect Match,'' about a woman with a mysterious illness who must locate the daughter she gave up for adoption. The 1986 TV movie ``Unnatural Causes,'' also written by Sayles, depicted a dedicated Veterans Administration benefits counselor struggling to link Agent Orange with a patient's illness. Does Sayles like the little screen? ``It's a good place to work if you can pick your spots.''

Elsewhere in Television: DONNARAMA: On Monday night, cable TV's ``Nick at Night'' will start showing ``The Donna Reed Show.'' So? So this means the start of ``The Seven Day Donna-Thon,'' in which all 140 episodes of Reed's uplifting series will be shown for seven nights from 8 p.m. to 6 a.m. EDT. It will end on Mother's Day with a special called ``How to be Donna Reed.'' OUR FUNNIEST NEWS VIDEOS: That's what WCBS-TV in New York promised Wednesday night _ a showing of videotaped flubs by its reporters. ``Tonight,'' WCBS said in a newspaper ad, ``we go to the vaults and unearth our usually stellar news team stuttering, spluttering and trying to make the best of video disaster.'' It must be ratings sweeps time. ...
DOC.NOTE: End advance PM Thurs May 3

DOC.TEXT: A Pentecostal pastor and his typically exuberant Pentecostal congregation, the Church of Christ the King, have joined a formally liturgical denomination, the Episcopal Church. That blending of ``charismatic expressiveness and high-church dignity'' was celebrated April l5 in a ``dynamic synergism'' of both that ``inspired standing ovations and joyous praise,'' reported The Ledger-Enquirer of Columbus. ``Flanking a procession of miters and copes and incense were jean-clad couples beating tambourines and young men scissor-kicking and throwing up their hands,'' wrote reporter Skip Connett. The Pentecostal pastor, the Rev. Stan White, seeking deeper roots for his congregation through a historic denomination, arranged the combination in lengthy planning with an Episcopal pastor, the Rev. Jacoba Hurst of nearby Tifton, and Georgia's Bishop Harry Shipps. Terming the uniting service ``perhaps unprecedented,'' Episcopal Bishop John Howe of the Diocese of Central Florida said the Pentecostals, ``known to be on fire for the Lord Jesus,'' have come ``to put your fire into the Episcopal Church's fireplace. May you flame ever more brightly.''
President Bush has agreed to be the commencement speaker May 12 at graduating exercises for Liberty University, school founder and chancellor the Rev. Jerry Falwell announced.

The central committee of the World Council of Churches has declared its ``unconditional opposition to the death penalty'' and urged governments to ratify an international covenant to abolish that penalty. The council had not previously explicitly rejected capital punishment, but in 1971 had urged churches to promote abolition efforts ``as a significant expression of our belief in the sanctity of life.''

The United Jewish Appeal-Federation is helping organize a group of recovering Jewish compulsive gamblers and their families. The step came as a result of a report that 40 percent of Gamblers Anonymous members in the New York area are Jewish, but usually meet in churches because of an assumption that Jews don't gamble.

With the number of U.S. Catholic priests at a record low and the number of seminarians dwindling, the church is observing a ``World Day of Prayer for Vocations'' to religious life on May 6. Bishop Elden F. Curtiss of Helena, Mont., head of the U.S. bishops' vocations committee, said the occasion will be a witness to the Lord's command, ``Pray to the Lord of the harvest to send laborers into the harvest.''

Broadcaster Bill Moyers, named ``Communicator of the Decade'' at a once-in-a-decade gathering of 1,400 religious communicators from around the world April 18-22, told them: ``Any journalist worth his or her salt today knows the real story is to define what it means to be spiritual. This is the biggest story not only of the decade but of the century.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, May 4

DOC.HEAD: Bishops Criticize Vatican Catechism Draft
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of U.S. Roman Catholic bishops have sharply criticized a proposed ``universal catechism'' prepared by the Vatican, calling parts of it unbalanced, out of context and superficial. It's supposed to be a guiding summary of faith, but ``reads too much like an encyclopedia,'' the bishops say. It ``needs a more positive spirit'' and ``should inspire as well as inform.'' Yet sometimes even the information is distorted, the bishops say, such as in instances implying consensus when ``consensus is in fact lacking.'' The proposed document is the first attempt at a church-wide doctrinal compilation since 1566 and is regarded as the most significant project of the world's bishops since the Second Vatican Council of 1962-65. A fundamental problem with the draft is failure to differentiate adequately between essential and secondary teachings, U.S. bishops say. ``The lack of such distinctions ... can lead to serious misunderstanding.'' The bishops say the 434-page document misuses Bible quotations in a ``proof-text'' manner, subordinates the role of the laity, discounts ecumenical ties with other churches and oversimplifies some concepts. ``Those familiar with the complexity of the issues will judge the catechism superficial and may be led to think the same of Catholic doctrine,'' the bishops say. They also say the proposed title, ``Catechism for the Universal Church'' is inappropriate and confusing, since the document is not meant to be a catechism itself but a doctrinal guide for producing regional catechisms. A substitute title is recommended, namely: ``A Compendium of Catholic Doctrine for the Preparation of Catechisms.'' A commission headed by Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, chief of the Vatican's doctrinal office, drew up the proposed document at the behest of a 1985 international synod of bishops. The draft was distributed ``sub secreto'' (under secrecy) last December to the world's 2,500 bishops, asking their reactions by May 31. ``The time alloted for consultation is insufficient,'' the U.S. bishops say in their 51-page critique, asking that the period be extended, and that later a a second draft be subjected to further feedback. The analysis was prepared by a six-bishop review committee headed by Bishop Oscar H. Lipscomb of Mobile, Ala., in consultation with 30 other experts, and relayed by the bishops' conference to the Vatican. Individual bishops also were expected to send in their own assessments. The joint response says the proposed document ignores contemporary biblical scholarship and principles of interpretation and uses New Testmanet texts out of context in support of particular points. ``Such an approach would be highly detrimental to catechetical and theological practice,'' the bishops say. ``This defect works itself out in a deleterious fashion throughout the catechism ... various quotations from Scripture are cited in a `proof-text' manner without regard for their proper meaning within their proper context.'' The bishops also say the document tends to equate central and marginal teachings, saying: ``The text presents doctrines that are not fully certain and are peripheral to the faith (such as about angels and Christ's descent into hell) on the same level as central and certain and defined truth,'' the bishops say. They also questioned the draft's portrayal of Jesus as having divine ``infused knowledge,'' leaving little room for his developing self-consciousness on earth. ``Any possibility of consequence for the humanity of Jesus is thus excluded,'' the bishops say. They also say the document ``seems to establish a false separation between science and faith,'' denigrating ``legitimate claims of science.'' The bishops observe pointedly: ``The opposition between evolution and creation is obvious only if one adopts a fundamentalist point of view toward the creation accounts.'' Concerning lay people, the draft seems to cast them ``in a passive, receptive role'' rather than recognizing their active initiatives, the bishops say. On this and other matters, the draft was seen as reflecting attitudes pre-dating reforms of the Second Vatican Council. Regarding the draft's treatment of ecumenical efforts for Christian unity, the bishops say: ``As the text stands, it tends to emphasize disunity and appears to suggest that the principal reason for dialogue is to overcome heresy and schism.'' The bishops point out another apparent retreat from Vatican II's view that the Christian church ``subsists'' in Catholicism, but isn't limited to it: The draft says the church ``has its existence'' in Catholicism. That's close to the terminology the Vatican Council rejected as limiting Christianity to Catholicism, the bishops note, implying the draft hints a throwback to that insular view.

DOC.HEAD: Debate Over Daimler Plan Illustrates Concern About Central Berlin
DOC.TEXT: A neglected piece of land next to the crumbling Berlin Wall has become the focus of controversy over how to rebuild what once was the center of a vibrant capital. It is the spot on Potsdamer Platz, one of Europe's most elegant squares before World War II, that the giant Daimler-Benz wants to erect a new headquarters. Fears have grown in both West and East Berlin that the shopping spree for land is about to start and that large, rich Western companies will determine the city's future landscape. ``What Berlin does not need is quick projects thought up in an illusory and short-lived reunification euphoria,'' East Berlin architect Bruno Flierl said in an interview. One of East Berlin's chief planners has expressed concern about possible economic ``colonialism'' by the West. After much internal bickering, the West Berlin city council has agreed to take competitive bids in July for a contract to rebuild the former central district. East Berlin will play a role in the decisions only after the election May 6 of its first democratically chosen city council. This has caused complaints that East Berliners will have little time to study documents affecting their part of the city. Since the Berlin Wall was built in 1961, Potsdamer Platz on one Western side of it and neighboring Leipziger Platz on the other have been desolate symbols of a divided country. Together, they had been the hub of Berlin and one of Europe's busiest districts. That ended with the destruction of World War II, the city's division and the building of the wall. Since the wall began falling in November, Potsdamer Platz has become a major pedestrian crossing point. Motor vehicles use a newly completed section of four-lane highway linking East Berlin with streets in the West that were dead ends for a generation. Makeshift souvenir stands in Potsdamer Platz sell chunks of the wall and Soviet military uniforms to tourists. Circus tents and vans have sprouted on nearby land that is empty most of the year. Construction of an apartment block on Leipziger Platz was halted last fall, when demonstrations and protest ended 40 years of Stalinist rule. An East German border guard said the work stopped when hopes were aroused that the area might become the center of the city again, not just another place to build housing complexes. He said the West German chain store Wertheim planned to put its head office on the foundation of the unbuilt apartment house. Asked how he felt about Western companies taking choice sites, he shrugged and said of the planners: ``I just hope they leave us some green spaces.'' Other East Germans feel more strongly. ``It would be unfair if all the high-tech went to West Berlin while the East was used for cheap production and storage facilities,'' said Guenther Stahn, East Berlin's ranking planners. ``That would be a colonialist concept.'' West Berlin's Social Democratic Party wants to attract investment to the city as quickly as possible and has welcomed the Daimler-Benz plan to build a headquarters for 8,000 employees. ``We can't afford to keep such an investor waiting,'' Mayor Walter Momper of West Berlin told his city council recently. The Alternative List, coalition partner of the Social Democrats in the council, does not agree and said in a statement: ``Daimler is not the star around which Potsdamer Platz plans revolve.'' Representatives of the Alternative List, the equivalent in West Berlin of the environmentalist Greens Party, say the Daimler building would be too dominant in the square. They also argue against a company that makes armaments occupying such a prime site. If construction of the headquarters goes forward as intended in 1992, the Alternative List demands it house a permanent exhibition on ``the role of the concern during the Nazi years'' and on the possibility of converting arms production to peaceful uses. West Berlin council members agreed in April on the basic outline of future plans for the city, including priority treatment of public transport and provision of open, green spaces. They did not give Daimler a firm commitment, but said they and the new East Berlin council elected in May would consider it.

DOC.HEAD: No Censorship, but Control Is Another Question
DOC.TEXT: Censorship ended with the fall of Nicolae Ceausescu in December, but the opposition says state control of television and major newspapers, and of newspaper distribution, is just as effective. Spokesmen for independent news outlets and parties say telling the opposition story is extremely difficult as Romania approaches its first free elections in 44 years, scheduled for May 20. The chief target of criticism is the National Salvation Front, which dominates the interim government and is suspected by many of seeking to bring back a milder form of communism. Many ranking members of the Front, including interim President Ion Iliescu, are former Communists who had been critical of Ceausescu. Front leaders profess democratic ideals, including a commitment to freedom of the press. The Human Rights Law Group, based in Washington, D.C., said after a fact-finding tour in late April that many Romanians believed the Front controlled the government. It said the Front's advantages ``are amplified by the government's control of television, printing presses and newsprint, distribution of national and opposition print media, international communications networks, and air and ground transport.'' ``There are widespread complaints that the newspapers distributed by the government, especially those of opposition parties and certain independent papers, often fail to reach their destination, are not delivered promptly or are returned when they could have been sold,'' the monitoring group said. Several journalists working for independent dailies or opposition party papers echoed those concerns in recent interviews. On television, ``representatives of opposing political parties . .. have three minutes to tell their story from scripts held in their hand,'' said Petre Mihai Bacanu, president of the 4,000-member Independent Journalists Union. ``Mr. Iliescu could grin on the screen all day and nobody at the television would mind,'' he said. Supporters of the Front say Iliescu and other senior officials get more coverage because national leaders make more news than obscure candidates for Parliament. Several journalists said even coverage of news events was biased in the Front's favor. One example cited was a demonstration organized by the Liberal Party at which the camera dwelt at length on barefooted gypsies in the crowd. Most Romanians think of gypsies as idlers and thieves. Images of roses, flattering graphics and stirring music were added to taped coverage of a Front rally, the journalists said. Distribution of independent or opposition daily newspapers was one of the problems mentioned most often. Bacanu is a member of the group that publishes Romania Libera, which has a circulation of 850,000 and is the largest paper regularly critical of the government. He snorted when asked whether copies were reaching readers in the provinces. ``People on the train simply throw them off,'' Becanu said. Gelu Netea, manager of the Liberal Party paper Vitorul, said state trucking companies were run run by ``neo-Communists,'' meaning supporters of the Front, who did not honor contracts to deliver the newspaper nationwide. In Bucharest, ``the press distributor regularly either doesn't take our copies or only a small amount,'' Netea said during an interview in his office. He gestured at stacks of newspapers several days old. Other government companies with agreements to distribute 80,000 copies nationally ``will take only 40,000 on a given day and then will wait up to five days to take them to newsstands,'' he said. Officials and supporters of the government denied the charges. Both sides agree the state-run presses, which turned out only a half-dozen dailies in Ceausescu's day, are woefully inadequate for printing the more than 700 newspapers now being published. Some typesetting machines at the central printing plant date from the 1940s and much of the lead is melted in an antiquated gas-fired furnace. ``Welcome to Gutenberg's era,'' a foreman on the printing floor told a Western reporter who was touring the plant.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thursday AMs, May 10

DOC.HEAD: Infiniti Q45 Blends Style, Power
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: No offense to Mother Nature and the folks who brought us those Zenlike Infiniti ads, but the car can more than hold its own against rocks and trees. The 1990 Infiniti Q45 is, in fact, a delightful car that impresses as subtly as nature does. There's the understated, yet warm and inviting interior of the Q45. No burl walnut here, but there is plenty of smooth leather, soft roofing material and functional, well-arrayed gauges. There's the controlled but powerful 4.5-liter, 32-valve V-8 teamed with four-speed automatic overdrive transmission. Because of advanced electronics this engine doesn't spin the wheels but purposely propels the car with controlled ease. The powerplant responds almost effortlessly and seems to never be taxed, even at high speeds and in demanding manuevers. There's the car's moonmobile exterior, with door handles that mirror the shape of the auto and front hood lines reflecting the rounded profile of the vehicle. It's sleek. Nissan is justly proud of its flagship. For while the car's early advertising _ showing rocks and trees but no vehicle _ may have missed its mark, the Q45 definitely has not. Positioned against the high-priced European sedans such as the $39,700 Jaguar XJ6 and Toyota's $35,000 new Lexus LS400, the Q45 _ with a base price of $38,000 _ is a solid competitor. The money buys plenty of performance in every area, including standard antilock four-wheel disc brakes that produce stable, sure stopping. It's impressive to stomp on the brakes and find hardly any diving movement at the front end. In the test car there was just a gradual dip in the front even when I stopped suddenly from high speed. Because the test car had the optional High Capacity Actively Controlled Steering, the Q45 also barely showed any body roll, or yaw in sudden lane changes and side moves. This option provides four-wheel steering that briefly turns the rear wheels in the opposite direction of the front wheels when needed and then switches them to the same direction at high speeds. Infiniti engineers worked wonders with the Q45 suspension. It seemed a bit more taut and less cushiony than that of the Lexus, yet I barely noticed bumps. The Infiniti's 4.5-liter, 278-horsepower engine will push the car from 0-60 mph in 7.5 seconds, says Nissan, which limited top speed to 150 mph via electronic controls to ensure drivers don't vault into the next galaxie. The 4-liter Lexus produces 250 horsepower and reaches 60 in 7.9 seconds. The downside is that the Q45's fuel economy is lower than that of the Lexus LS400: 16 mpg in the city versus 18 mpg for the LS400, making the Infiniti subject to a $500 gas guzzler tax at purchase. The Q45 exterior is nearly as aerodynamic as the Lexus: .30 drag coefficient versus .29 for the Lexus, though the front end of the Lexus seems a bit more square. All metal seams on the Infiniti test car were lined up with impeccable precision. Inside, the Q45 has wide, soft front seats that are adjusted electronically and have two memory settings. Stitching in the leather seats lines up with back and leg muscles for maximum comfort. The thick, leather-wrapped steering wheel (with air bag) telescopes upward and tilts to the desired position electronically. The standard Bose sound system was terrific, with big buttons for easy adjustment. A sunroof, cruise control, heated outside mirrors and sun visors that had to be released from the ceiling by pressing a button were other features. Sitting in the back seat, I tucked my toes under the front seats when they were all the way back on their tracks. But my knees still didn't touch the seat backs, and legroom was decent if the front seats were moved up a bit. The middle passenger in back would have to contend with the large hump in the floor that accommodates the Infiniti's rear drive mechanisms. The trunk was flat and deeply spacious. BMW and Mercedes-Benz owners make up the largest group of early Infiniti buyers. Infiniti reports that 50 percent of the trade-ins have come from owners of those German makes. Another 25 percent of the trade-ins are domestic models such as Cadillac and Lincoln, and the rest are Japanese cars, such as Maximas, Accords and Cressidas. More than 3,350 Q45s were sold in the first five months after the car was introduced in November. Infiniti says it does not have projections for expected sales. The typical buyer is male, median age 42, the company says. A majority are married, and most have household incomes approaching $100,000 a year. At least 90 percent have college educations. Because the Q45 is a new model, Consumer Reports magazine does not list owner reports of trouble.
