DOC.HEAD: HAPPY BIRTHDAY BUGS: Wascally Wabbit Marks 50th, Doc
LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: He may be 50, but that doesn't make Bugs Bunny an old gray hare. The wascally wabbit and long-time torturer of Elmer J. Fudd hits the half-century mark this year, and the carrot-chomping star with the Brooklynese tongue is aging as gracefully as ever. ``Everybody knows who I am, Doc. I don't cayuh where dey are or who dey are. Even in Mars dey know about me. Heh heh heh,'' Bugs once said in an interview with The Associated Press. Success didn't come easily for Bugs; he had to change his name and work underground before making it big. But he's enjoyed a career many Hollywood stars _ living or sketched _ would envy. He surfaced this year as a presenter on the Academy Awards; in 1958, he won his own Oscar for best animated short feature, ``Knighty Knight, Bugs.'' The rabbit since has become a Saturday morning cartoon fixture, and makes more prime time appearances each year than Bob Hope. On Dec. 21, 1985, Bugs received a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame _ admittedly, not in the best spot. He sits between cowboy actor Rory Calhoun and actress Lurene Tuttle, who made such memorable movies as ``The Clonus Horror,'' ``White Mama'' and ``Final Chapter _ Walking Tall.'' The brash bunny was the consumate of cool. Always undersized, he's outwitted grouchy gremlins, Daffy Duck and gun-toting galoots. In ``Haredevil Hare'' he defends the honor of Earth against a Martian with high-top sneakers named Commander X-2. He's sung opera and tweaked the nose of pompous tenors. He outraced tortoises and hounded hunting dogs. And his rabbit hole was his castle, to be defended to the death against developers and intruders. ``Of course, you realize, this means war,'' Bugs would say to those who provoked him. You'd never see Bugs with a girlfriend, and like Milton Berle, he'd flirt in drag to confuse a foe. But Bugs was his own rabbit _ fiercely independent and fresh. Bugs' encounters with frequent foil Fudd are regarded as classics. The easily-frustrated Fudd was battered by Bugs from infancy to old age in a series of shorts. After tormenting Fudd in one episode, Bugs turned to the audience and clucked: ``I do dis kind of stuff to him all through the picture.'' Rarely did Fudd ever turn the tables on his animated adversary. Once is a story in which Elmer portrays a millionaire who's gone off the deep end. He and his shrink keep repeating the same tagline throughout the cartoon: ``My name is Elmer J. Fudd, millionaire. I own a mansion and a yacht.'' The oft-repeated line finally gets to Bugs who checks into a mental hospital. In another cartoon, a Wagner send-up, Fudd, clad in Viking horns, sings to the strains of ``Ride of the Walkueres'': ``Kill the wabbit, kill the wabbit ...'' The Bugs-Fudd battles _ most featuring Elmer as a befuddled hunter _ have recently been honored in a Museum of Modern Art exhibit and preserved at the Museum of Cartoon Art. The latter is planning an anniversary retrospective for Bugs. The 50th birthday will also be marked with widespread release of Bugs video collections, a prime-time special and a special Bugs magazine produced by LIFE magazine. It's been more than his lucky rabbit feet that have kept Bugs on top through the decades. He's outlived the Flintstones, seen a future without the Jetsons and continues to ride high in the age of the Simpsons. So what is it about Bugs that makes him timeless? ``Bugs is a natural person leading a normal life until someone aggravates him. Then he fights back,'' explains Chuck Jones, now 77, who directed more than 50 Bugs shorts. ``In other words, he's a sort of counter-revolutionary.'' Bugs is hero to many of us. He does the things we'd like to do but don't have the ``noive'' to carry through. His vintage cartoons are currently seen all over television by a third generation of kids. In addition to Saturdays, he appears daily on national cable stations Nickelodeon and TNT and is the top-rated show on both. Jones admits Bugs can be a bully or a nuisance, so he took great care in setting the rabbit in situations in which he would remain a sympathetic figure. Mel Blanc, the man of 1,000 voices who gave life to Bugs, would defend the rabbit's honor if he didn't like a script, telling the writer, ``Bugs wouldn't do that,'' or ``Bugs would never say that.'' It was Blanc who changed ``Happy Rabbit,'' a nice-guy bunny of the late 1930s, into the rough and tumble rabbit we've come to know and love. Blanc ditched the wimpy name, added the ``dese'' and ``dose'' of streetwise Brooklyn and rechristened the character Bugs. The west, as they say, is histowy. Bugs debuted on July 27, 1940, in the short ``A Wild Hare,'' and he was off and running. Early on, he became part of the World War II propaganda pitch, turning up a a draftee, a superpatriot Marine _ ``a real Superman'' _ a ``Rabbit the Riveter'' assembly line worker. Today, he's joined the ``Just Say No'' war on drugs, appearing in an anti-drug cartoon that aired last month. Through the years he's become even more underdog than he was in the beginning, increasingly opting for brains over brawn. Such adaptability has served him well. In dozens of shorts, Bugs has remained a Hollywood trendsetter: _ Long before Sigourney Weaver battled ``Aliens,'' Bugs went mano-a-mano with Commander X-2. _ Forget ``Field of Dreams'' and other baseball flicks. ``Baseball Bugs'' featured a slow-balling Bugs playing all nine positions and defeating the Gas House Gorillas. Bugs scales the Empire State Building for the game-saving catch. _ Robert De Niro as untouchable Al Capone? The rabbit took on legendary tough guys Edward G. Robinson and Peter Lorre in ``Racketeer Rabbit.'' And Bobby D.'s turn as Jake LaMotta in ``Raging Bull'' had little on Bugs' showdown with boxing brute The Crusher. There's much, much more: Bugs as the straight hare in a Jekyll and Hyde send-up, Bugs evading two Robinson Crusoe types bent on turning him into roast rabbit, torturing two French chefs with similar intent, outwitting a rabbit-bashing witch on Halloween. And there's more than a touch of bad boy in Bugs; in addition to his Fudd abuse, he frustrated Yosemite Sam to the point where Yosemite screams ``great horney toads,'' driven Daffy Duck near daft and dispatched dozens of animated assailants. ``Ain't I a stinker?'' he says in one cartoon. But it hasn't been all good news for the rabbit over the last 50 years. The death last year at age 81 of Blanc, who had been the voice of practically all the Warner Bros. Looney Tunes-Merrie Melodies characters, was a blow to fans around the world. But Blanc didn't take the rabbit's ``What's up, Doc?'' with him. His son, Noel, and actor Jeff Bergman have taken over as the bunny's voicebox, and Bugs is still going strong. To anyone who might think an aging Bugs has seen his best days, well, as Bugs might say: ``He don't know me vewy well, do he?''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for weekend editions, May 4-6

DOC.TEXT: The U.S. industrial sector expanded slightly during April for the first time in a year, led by sharp gains in new orders and exports, the nation's purchasing managers said in a survey. The National Association of Purchasing Management said Tuesday its economic index rose to 50.2 percent in April from 48.8 percent the previous month. A reading above 50 indicates the manufacturing economy generally is expanding; below 50, that it is generally contracting.

OPEC needs cut to oil production by as much as 1.5 million barrels a day to help crude prices recover from their recent slide, OPEC's president said as cartel ministers arrived for an emergency meeting. The cartel's president, Algerian Oil Minister Sadek Boussena, made the comment Tuesday on the eve of a meeting to try to curb overproduction and boost prices that have dropped by more than 20 percent since January.

The Bush administration backed a measure that would triple civil fines for employers who violate workplace safety laws, but balked at a plan to expand criminal penalties. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole's call Tuesday for higher fines was viewed by organized labor supporters as a sign she's committed to worker safety and that the Bush administration is improving the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Organized labor considered the agency neglected under the Reagan administration.

Chrysler Corp. said its first quarter profit tumbled 79.8 percent from last year, and Wall Street analysts said that without a company cost-cutting program the slide would have been even worse. A slumping auto market and the soaring costs of incentives helped push Chrysler's net income down to $71 million, or 32 cents a share, in the quarter from $351 million, or $1.50 a share, in the first quarter of 1990. The company released its results Tuesday.

The Food and Drug Administration approved irradiation of poultry to control salmonella and other bacteria that cause food-borne illnesses. But the industry said it had no plans to use the procedure. The FDA said Tuesday irradiation is safe and effective in eliminating most bacteria in chicken, turkey and other fresh and frozen birds, making poultry safe for longer periods under refrigeration. But poultry companies said they do not plan to use the technology because of consumer opposition, among other things.

The Federal Aviation Administration and airline industry joined forces to oppose legislation that would increase the federal role in inspecting aging airliners. Anthony Broderick, FAA associate administrator, told a House hearing Tuesday that the bill would increase government liability and could cost between $1 million and $2 million per aircraft. It would take five years to hire and train the needed inspectors, he said.

The White House said it would not resist the resignation of savings and loan bailout boss L. William Seidman. Seidman, 69, is chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., which guarantees bank and S&L deposits, and of the Resolution Trust Corp., the agency charged with disposing of failed thrifts. His term expires in October 1991. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Tuesday, ``Bill has indicated he's not going to stay the whole term, and we are interested in getting new leadership there that would carry on an aggressive program when the time comes.''

The costs of caring for the elderly will soar in the coming decades without advances in the prevention and treatment of illnesses such as Alzheimer's disease, researchers reported. As baby boomers age and medical advances increase their life span, a larger group of Americans will be at risk of developing the debilitating diseases that rob the elderly of their independence, the researchers said Tuesday. ``This is where the challenge of aging (research) lies,'' said Dr. Jack M. Guralnik, an epidemiologist at the National Institute on Aging and co-author of a report in this week's Journal of the American Medical Association.

Burger King Corp., the nation's second-largest hamburger chain, is switching to Coca-Cola Co. as the official soft drink supplier for its U.S. stores, ending a six-year association with Pepsi-Cola Co. ``We selected Coca-Cola because of its ability to provide a powerful mix of global brand strength, state-of-the-art technological capabilities and distinctive service,'' Chief Executive Barry J. Gibbons said Tuesday. Burger King said Coca-Cola products such as Coca-Cola Classic, Diet Coke, Sprite and Minute Maid orange soda will replace Pepsi-Cola's soft drink lineup in its restaurants over the next several months.

Stocks prices advanced Tuesday as the Dow Jones industrial average picked up 12.16 to close at 2,668.92. Bond prices fell, pushing key interest rates over 9 percent. The dollar ended mixed in light trading. Soybean futures prices fell moderately; grain futures ended mostly lower; energy futures rose sharply; copper futures surged; precious metals advanced; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Burger King Switches to Coca-Cola from Pepsi-Cola
DOC.TEXT: Sometime this summer, a Burger King customer may leave an opening for a quick-witted clerk by simply ordering ``Cheeseburger, Pepsi.'' ``No Pepsi, Coke,'' the order-taker will be able to say, in a variation on the line that the late comedian John Belushi made famous years ago. Burger King Corp., the nation's second-largest hamburger chain, said Tuesday it is switching to Coca-Cola Co. as its official domestic soft drink supplier, ending an association that started in 1983 with Pepsi-Cola Co. Miami-based Burger King said Coca-Cola products such as Coca-Cola Classic, Diet Coke, Sprite and Minute Maid orange soda will replace Pepsi-Cola's soft drink lineup in its restaurants over the next three months. Analysts said the loss of the high-profile account is a blow to Pepsi-Cola's prestige, but it would have minimal impact on earnings for either soft-drink company. Pepsi-Cola, based in Somers, N.Y., said the loss of the Burger King account ``was not entirely unexpected'' in view of recent management changes at Burger King. It was acquired by the British conglomerate Grand Metropolitan PLC in January 1989 and switched advertising agencies last year. ``We selected Coca-Cola because of its ability to provide a powerful mix of global brand strength, state-of-the-art technological capabilities and distinctive service,'' Burger King Chief Executive Barry J. Gibbons said. Atlanta-based Coca-Cola controls an estimated 65 percent of the fountain portion of the U.S. soft drink business and is the primary supplier for most of the major fast-food chains, including leader McDonald's Corp. Recently, Wendy's International Inc. said it was planning to switch to Coca-Cola at its 1,100 company-owned restaurants when its agreement with Pepsi-Cola expires at the end of the year. Pepsi-Cola still has some major restaurant accounts, including Pizza Hut, Taco Bell and Kentucky Fried Chicken, all owned by its parent, PepsiCo Inc. It also serves the Dunkin' Donuts, Subway, Shakey's and Ground Round chains, according to spokesman Tod MacKenzie. MacKenzie said Pepsi hopes to continue serving franchisee-owned Burger King restaurants. But Burger King spokeswoman Cori Zywotow said her company's franchise agreements require licensees to go along with its choice of a soft drink supplier. There are about 5,400 Burger King restaurants in the United States, including 800 owned by Burger King and 4,600 owned by franchisees. Neither Burger King nor Coca-Cola would estimate the value of the soft-drink account. Burger King awarded its soft drink account to Pepsi-Cola in 1983 after years with Coca-Cola, and reaffirmed its intention to stay with Pepsi only last June. But Ms. Zywotow said both soft drink companies were asked for new proposals recently and the company decided to switch. She said Coca-Cola will work with Burger King on new drink dispensing technology and marketing programs. Emanuel Goldman, who follows the soft drink business for PaineWebber in San Francisco, estimated Pepsi-Cola sales at Burger King amounted to about 65 million cases, or about 13.5 percent of Pepsi's annual fountain volume. The switch would boost Coca-Cola's fountain volume by 6.5 percent, he said. Goldman said the switch should cut annual earnings of PepsiCo by no more than a penny a share, while adding 1.5 cents a share at most for Coca-Cola. But in addition to lost sales volume, the switch costs Pepsi a valuable opportunity to have people to sample its products. ``A lot of people go into Burger King and see the name Coke or Pepsi. How does that spill over into supermarket sales? That is the part of it that isn't known,'' Goldman said. Jesse Meyers, editor of the trade publication Beverage Digest, estimates the switch could add a percentage point to Coca-Cola's 40.5 percent share of the overall U.S. soft drink market while cutting Pepsi-Cola's 30.7 percent share by the same amount. The market is valued at $27.4 billion wholesale. Meyers said Burger King's decision to switch may be a response to the recent rapid growth of PepsiCo's restaurant operations. ``While PepsiCo is selling chicken, tacos and pizza, Burger King is saying `That competes with the share of stomach we are trying to fill,''' he said. Pepsi's MacKenzie said there is ``more myth than reality'' to that line of reasoning.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts: Chrysler Cost-Cutting Working Despite 80-Percent Earnings Drop
DOC.TEXT: An 80 percent drop in Chrysler Corp.'s first-quarter earnings wasn't nearly as bad as expected and shows the company's cost-cutting program may be taking hold, analysts say. The nation's No. 3 automaker reported Tuesday it earned $71 million, or 32 cents a share, on revenues of $7.56 billion during the first three months of this year. It earned $351 million, or $1.50 a share, on revenues of $9.66 billion in the same period last year. That's good news, Chairman Lee Iacocca said. Wall Street appeared to agree. Chrysler stock closed up 75 cents Tuesday at $15.75 on the New York Stock Exchange. Monday's closing price was a 52-week low. As recently as late last week, analysts were speculating that Chrysler's results would flirt with the break-even point. ``Our surprise is that we got as much cost-savings benefit as quickly as we did,'' said analyst Charles Brady of Oppenheimer & Co. of New York. Last October, Chrysler began a program aimed at slicing $1.5 billion from its annual costs by the end of 1990. Analysts said Tuesday it appears the company is on track to reach that target. ``They are well on their way to accomplishing their $1.5 billion cost-reduction goal,'' said analyst Scott Merlis of Morgan, Stanley & Co. of New York. ``It seems like Chrysler's management is delivering. ``They already have put their money where their mouths were.'' Analysts have forecast earnings declines of more than 75 percent for General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. when the nation's two largest automakers report their first-quarter results later this week. ``I think the street is beginning to think that Ford and GM may have some cost-cutting surprises for this quarter or the next one,'' Merlis said. Analysts estimated that Chrysler cut $200 million out of its standing costs during the first quarter. ``It shows the leanness and the meanness of management hammering home on the cost-cutting front,'' said analyst John Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody & Co. of New York. Not everything was rosy with Chrysler's financial picture. The company spent about twice as much on incentives during the first quarter and the automaker continues to fight a tough battle to hold on to its share of the U.S. market. Chrysler eked out a slim $8 million profit on its car operations in the quarter. ``People still want to see the product side improve,'' Kirnan said. The next major product change Chrysler has on tap is its new minivan, which hits dealerships this fall. Chrysler, which derives much of its profit from minivan sales, sells more of the popular vehicles than all other minivan makers combined but competitors have begun to nibble away at its market share. This summer, the company will be shutting down both of its minivan assembly plants for four weeks for retooling. That could spell trouble for the company's second and third quarters. ``I would not be surprised to see a red number for the third quarter,'' said analyst David Healy of Barclays-BZW of New York, ``but the second quarter should be profitable, probably a good bit better than the first quarter.'' The company also said its Chrysler Financial Corp. subsidiary posted an $89 million profit for the first quarter, up from $86 million in the fourth quarter of last year.

DOC.HEAD: Home Owners Could Be Tip of Iceberg
DOC.TEXT: New England's slumping economy and real estate market have pushed many banks to the brink of failure and eventually could force them into government hands, analysts say. Last week, regulators seized control of Home Owners Federal Savings Bank _ the largest savings and loan in Massachusetts. Analysts said Tuesday this action was a signal of things to come. ``Are we going to see a rash of closures in the next few months _ probably not,'' said Gerard Cassidy, a banking analyst at Tucker Anthony Inc. ``But when this thing finally washes out, three, four, five years from now, we're going to look back, and there probably is going to be at least two dozen.'' The sinking economy, combined with a declining real estate market, has given many banks a staggering amount of troubled loans. Banks have had to divert money into reserves while watching their capital shrink to precarious levels. James McFarland, deputy regional director of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said there would probably be a ``handful'' of failures this year. But he stressed that well below 10 percent of the banks in New England have poor ratings from the government. In Massachusetts and Connecticut, 32 banks at the end of 1989 were losing money so fast it would deplete their equity within one year, according to Veribanc Inc., a Wakefield, Mass., firm that monitors the industry. ``It's a good bet there will some seizures among them, especially with the economy going the way it is,'' said Warren Heller, research director for Veribanc. Analysts say the direction of the economy will be the most important factor in determining whether weak banks survive. Bank of New England Corp., for example, lost more than $1 billion last year, due largely to its real estate portfolio. The bank now is operating under government orders and has instituted a plan to improve its financial health, but executives have acknowledged the recovery hinges on the New England economy. Other banks have admitted they are in peril. Home National Corp. of Milford, Mass., has disclosed its subsidiary Home National Bank is seeking financial assistance from the federal government to continue operating. Eliot Bank in Boston reported a $30 million loss for the fourth quarter of 1989 and said it expected regulators to ``take such actions as they consider appropriate'' if the bank could not raise capital. Another teetering company is One Bancorp of Portland, Maine, which has $26 million in capital but $290 million in troubled loans. One Bancorp, like many savings banks in New England, converted to stock ownership in the 1980s amid the boom on Wall Street. That provided them with billions of dollars in new capital, which many used to move into the then-booming construction market. ``The only thing they knew how to do was lend money in real estate,'' said James Moynihan, senior vice president of Advest Inc. in Boston. ``They were all tripping over each other to find projects.'' This created several problems for savings banks. Many had been accustomed to home construction lending but felt pressure to move into other commercial loans to get better returns and improve their shareholder earnings, McFarland said. But when the real estate market declined, poor loans were exposed and the losses mounted. Heller, at Veribanc, said some savings institutions were already in weak condition before they raised money by converting to stock ownership. ``This was a one-time capital infusion,'' Heller said. ``They had their one chance and they blew it.''

DOC.HEAD: Campbell Soup Co. Eliminates 364 Jobs At Headquarters
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co.'s chief said the company's sluggish performance has forced it to slash its headquarters staff and turn aggressive to stave off a possible sale or merger. ``We want to have winning results which is in terms of earnings, returns and cash that would make any raider look at us and gasp,'' said David W. Johnson, president and chief executive officer. Campbell's announced Tuesday it would eliminate 364 positions from its headquarters staff, a cut of 19 percent, in a bid to strengthen its bottom line and pacify disgruntled shareholders. ``Fundamentally the company has not been delivering the kind of financial performance investors, shareholders and Wall Street would like it to have. Our record is very poor,'' Johnson said. The company also decided to halt plans for a new $35 million headquarters proposed for the city's waterfront, said Johnson, the first outsider to head Campbell in its 121-year history. The financially strapped city has been counting heavily on the plan as the lynchpin of its economic revival. ``A $35 million high-prestige world-class headquarters at a time when we are financially embattled would have been irresponsible,'' said Johnson. ``I think it is not understood how embattled we are.'' Johnson, chosen in January to take over Campbell because of his experience at beleaguered companies, said 267 employees received ``pink slips'' Tuesday morning. He said 97 positions at the headquarters had been eliminated through attrition since Jan. 1. ``We cut out those jobs to become leaner and more productive and more effective,'' Johnson told reporters at a news conference outside company headquarters in Camden. The cutbacks, effective immediately, will save about $17 million over the first full fiscal year and reduce Campbell's headquarter's staff to 1,588 employees. Johnson, who was chosen to head Campbell because of the changes he spearheaded at Gerber Products Co., did not rule out additional layoffs in Camden and elsewhere if the performance does not improve. The announcement came nearly two months after Campbell's closed its historic 121-year-old manufacturing plant in Camden, eliminating 940 blue-collar jobs. Johnson said Campbell's plans to maintain a presence in Camden. He says the company is considering seeking an outside builder for the waterfront project and leasing office space to other businesses. Camden Mayor Aaron A. Thompson, who met with Johnson several months ago, remained optimistic Campebell's will play a role in the city's $500 million waterfront revitalization project. ``Their commitment to the waterfront is an unaltered commitment,'' Thompson said Tuesday. But not everyone shared Thompson's confidence that the company will reamin in the economically depressed city of about 85,000 residents. ``That is an enormous impact on this economy,'' said Camden County Freeholder Director Robert Andrews. ``We know they're going to be leaner because they're laying our people off,'' said Andrews. ``But how do we know they're going to stay here?'' Johnson said Campbell's is facing some tough times of its own with earnings lagging at nearly half the rate of other food competitors. In December, some members of Campbell's founding family put their stake in the company up for sale and said they would push for a sale of the entire company. But three children of longtime Chairman John Dorrance Jr., who received control of their father's 31.3 percent share of the company, have vowed to maintain their ownership and keep Campbell independent. Under Johnson, Campbell has closed three domestic plants and two overseas plants, a distribution facility in Chicago and integrated Canadian and American operations since January. Campbell also has put its Juice Bowl business up for sale. ``We are really in the middle of a fight back to remain strong and independent and headquartered in Camden,'' said Johnson.

DOC.HEAD: Baxter Says It Cleared Israel Plant Sale With Commerce Department
DOC.TEXT: Baxter International Inc. said it cleared the sale of a manufacturing plant in Israel with the Department of Commerce to avoid the appearance of a conflict with U.S. law. Nevertheless, the world's largest hospital supply company now finds itself the target of allegations by a former employee that it sold the plant to get off the Arab League's blacklist of companies doing business with the Jewish state. That would violate a U.S. law forbidding American companies from participating in foreign boycotts. Baxter has agreed to build a similar plant in Syria to synthesize intravenous body fluids. Baxter spokesman Les Jacobson said Tuesday the company has higher hopes for a profitable operation in Syria than in Israel, where he said skyrocketing inflation helped make the plant a money-loser. Company officials didn't seek to curry favor with the Arabs by selling the plant in Israel, he said. Jewish leaders are demanding an explanation from Baxter, headquartered in Deerfield, north of Chicago. The issue arose from a memorandum about Baxter's Middle East operations that is purportedly on file in the Arab League's boycott office in the Syrian capitol of Damascus. The memo suggests the 1988 sale of the Israeli plant and the removal of Baxter from the Arab boycott list were linked. Jacobson said Baxter officials repeatedly sought opinions from former Secretary of State Cyrus Vance and from the Commerce Department on its Middle Eastern operations beginning in 1982. He said Baxter had received assurances it was doing nothing improper in selling the Israeli plant, which was built in 1971 and employed about 200 people. ``Because the law is unclear in many respects, we felt we needed some clearance and guidance,'' Jacobson said. ``We went to them and said `Here's what we're doing in the Middle East, is this OK? They said they'd see no problems with that.'' The anti-boycott law was enacted in 1977, when Vance was in office, to discourage corporations from seeking Arab business by promising to avoid commerce with Israel. Jacobson said the law is ``murky'' in defining the conditions under which it would be proper for a U.S. company to provide to an Arab country information about its dealings in Israel. He said Baxter probably discussed with Syrian government officials its plans to sell the Israel plant, not as a condition of being dropped from the Arab League blacklist but rather in the context of negotiations that resulted in their April 13 agreement to jointly build a plant in Syria. The plant is scheduled to open late next year. Jacobson questioned the authenticity of the Arab League memo, copies of which were sent to Baxter directors and to The Wall Street Journal by Dr. Richard Fuisz, is a Washington-area businessman and former chief executive officer of Baxter's Middle Eastern Medcom subsidiary. Fuisz sued Baxter in 1985 for wrongful termination and defamation after he was ousted from his job and demoted, Jacobson said. The lawsuit was settled, but Fuisz reportedly remains bitter toward his former employer. Fuisz could not be reached for comment. Telephone calls to his home in Great Falls, Va., went unanswered. Neither the Commerce Department nor the Securities and Exchange Commission, which are reviewing the company's Middle East activities, would comment. The memo says Baxter promised not to do any more business with Israel. Jacobson said Baxter continues to distribute a variety of products in Israel and has no plans to stop doing so. ``The memo implies that we agreed to halt any further commercial activity in Israel, which is flatly untrue,'' Jacobson said. ``We know very well that would be illegal.''

DOC.HEAD: Information Technology Touted As Way To Cut Healthcare Costs
DOC.TEXT: Hospitals must rely on greater technology to combat rising health-care costs, but the gadgets will take their cue from the supermarket and banking industries, experts say. A consulting firm on Tuesday unveiled a prototype of its ``Hospital of the Future'' crammed with information, not medical, technology to help keep track of and treat patients. Designed by Andersen Consulting with the help of the American College of Healthcare Executives, the prototype uses everything from bar codes to handheld computers, from ``smartcards'' to pneumatic tubes, from voice recognition to fiber optics to cut time and money spent shuffling around information. ``Forty percent of a nurse's time is spend doing administrative and clerical chores,'' said Jay Toole, Andersen's partner in charge of healthcare. Hospitals have lagged behind industry in taking advantage of technology, Toole said. They spend only 3 percent of their budgets on information handling compared to 8 percent to 10 percent for the banking and insurance industries. The technology may be directed more towards saving money than saving lives, Toole said, but it nevertheless would give healthcare workers time to practice their craft and improve the quality of care. While most hospitals already have their financial operations computerized and may use computers in clinical or patient care, there has been little communication among the areas, said Gene Handley, education director of the American College of Healthcare Executives. ``We have to achieve greater economies in the area of information technology,'' he said. ``We're looking for economies that allow one system to communicate with another system.'' Andersen Consulting, a subsidiary of the accounting firm Arthur Anderson & Co., invested $7 million in its ``Hospital of the Future'' display, which opened Tuesday at Dallas's Infomart technology market. More than 40 different vendors, including Digital Equipment Corp., Hewlett-Packard Co. and NCR Corp., have been linked with programming that allows the normally incompatible systems to ``talk'' to each other. A patient's introduction to the system begins in admitting, where financial information is taken and rooms assigned. That information is transmitted immediately to the floor where the patient will be taken and to the business office. At the same time, the patient's medical and financial information is put on a ``smartcard,'' a credit-card-sized piece of plastic that can hold up to 1,000 pages of text. Later, when tests or medication are ordered, the laboratory and pharmacy systems ship results or records back and forth. The system also keeps better tabs on billing, designers said, so that fewer charges are lost. Information can be entered through bedside or handheld computer terminals, or at a nurse's station. There's even a system that converts X-rays into computer language, allowing the images to be transmitted not only around the hospital but to a doctor's office, for example, for outside consultations. Other systems help keep track of operating room schedules and supplies. Physicians also can tie in to computer databases, which contain the latest medical information. The technology also reaches into homes through a portable computer than can remind patients when and what medicine to take, and can transmit that information back to a physician or home healthcare agency.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Hearings Begin in Ames Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge has approved an interim plan giving Ames Department Stores Inc. a new leader and allowing the discount retailer to borrow $40 million to keep operating. The new chief executive officer, Stephen L. Pistner, would be paid $1.5 million a year, plus a bonus of $500,000, to take on the job of trying to bring the company out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The $2 million in total compensation is more than twice what the chief executive at K mart, the nation's largest discount chain, received in 1989 and more than $400,000 above what the top executive received last year at Sears, the nation's largest retailer. But U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Howard C. Buschman III on Tuesday gave the company's plan interim approval, saying he was comfortable that the salary is within the range that any executive would demand to take on the Ames job. The Rocky Hill retail chain also got the court's approval to borrow up to $40 million from Chemical Bank during the next week to begin paying its bills and start restocking its 680 stores. During nearly a nearly five-hour hearing, Buschman heard testimony about Ames's need for a new leader and money to keep the company operating. ``The board members of this company have determined that the company is a ship without a rudder,'' Buschman said. ``They have determined that there is low morale within the company and with creditors of the company, and that the appointment is needed to begin to address the problems faced by the company.'' Ames filed for bankruptcy court protection here last week, listing assets of $1.67 billion and liabilities of $1.44 billion. The company said it had to file because it could not get new financing from its bankers and because suppliers had stopped shipping merchandise to its stores. Ames Chairman James A. Harmon testified that the company began searching for a new chief executive officer in early March. He said Ames also hired a consultant specializing in executive compensation, and was told that the company would have to pay a substantial salary to attract an executive willing to take on the challenge of returning Ames to profitability. Harmon did not mention Ames' former chief executive officer, Peter B. Hollis, who resigned Monday after more than three years at the helm. Hollis engineered the 1988 acquisition of the Zayre stores, which ultimately forced Ames into Chapter 11. Hollis received $889,053 in total compensation in 1988, the most recent figure made public. But Harmon did say that Ames's board of directors was convinced that the company needed a new chief executive officer quickly. ``There was general concern about the morale at the company,'' he said. ``With suppliers upset, shareholders distressed, creditors concerned, there was a great deal of pressure on the executives and the company was deteriorating quite rapidly. It was important that we move to bring in a new CEO.'' Harmon said Ames decided to hire Pistner, 58, because of his experience in turning around troubled retailers. Pistner has headed the Target, Dayton Hudson, Montgomery Ward and McCrory chains during more than 20 years in the retail industry. Buschman signed an interim order Tuesday authorizing Pistner's appointment. In order to give Ames's creditors more time to study Pistner's background and comment on his hiring, Buschman said a final hearing on the matter will be held May 15. Buschman also signed an order Tuesday allowing Ames to borrow nearly $40 million from Chemical Bank during the next week. Ames officials testified that the money was needed to begin ordering new merchandise for the company's stores in time for the important back-to-school and Christmas seasons. Buschman scheduled another hearing May 8 to rule on whether Ames can borrow up to $250 million from Chemical Bank while it works to reorganize its business.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up, Dollar Slightly Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rose sharply today on expectations that the market would strengthen after the current holiday week, while the dollar edged down against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Index gained 483.81 points, or 1.63 percent, closing at 30,173.64. It was the first time since April 9 that the index, which rose 105.03 points on Tuesday, closed above 30,000. Traders said the yen's strength against the dollar boosted investors' optimism. ``Investors had been reassured by the market's recent stability despite uptrends in overseas interest rates, and now they believe the market will be even stronger after the holidays,'' said a trader with Nomura Securities Co. Japan's financial markets were open only today and Tuesday this week because of the ``Golden Week'' series of national holidays. They will reopen Monday. An estimated 480 million shares changed hands on the exchange's first section today, up from 245 million Tuesday. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 158.55 yen, down 0.35 yen from Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Airlines Add to Anti-Terrorism Reward
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government and the airline industry are offering $3 million for information leading to the arrest, conviction or thwarting of air terrorists. In a move praised by relatives of terrorism victims and endorsed by three government agencies, the Air Transport Association on Tuesday added $1 million to a government reward program that already totaled $2 million. And in another joint step Tuesday, airline officials and the Federal Aviation Administration opposed proposed legislation that would increase the government's role in inspecting aging airliners. Of the anti-terrorism reward, ATA President Robert J. Aaronson said: ``This should be a powerful incentive for people within, or close to, terrorist organizations to reveal plots before they are hatched.'' Aaronson said the airline trade group would match any government reward up to $1 million if it involves a threat or attack against a U.S. airline, and the money also would be available through the FBI to match rewards designed to combat domestic air terrorism. Morris D. Busby, State Department ambassador for counter-terrorism, said at an ATA news conference that rewards already have been paid in the government's program, but details would not be disclosed. FAA Administrator James B. Busey said the increased rewards send a strong message to terrorists that ``the United States and the aviation community are fully committed to this battle against terrorism.'' William Baker, FBI assistant director, said investigators are meeting every day with foreign authorities in an effort to ``keep the pressure on'' to solve the December 1988 bombing of Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, that took 270 lives. No one has been charged or arrested, but authorities have said they believe Middle East terrorists planted plastic explosives inside a radio cassette player that became part of checked-in luggage. Meanwhile, FAA Associate Administrator Anthony Broderick told a House hearing that the proposed aging-airliner bill would increase government liability and could cost between $1 million and $2 million per plane. Robert E. Doll, a United Airlines vice president who heads an ATA-sponsored industry and government task force on aging airliners, said adding inspection duties for the FAA could impair other safety efforts. The bill, sponsored by Democratic and Republican leaders of the House Public Works aviation subcommittee, would require the FAA to thoroughly inspect each airliner during the last year of its economic design life. Unless they pass an FAA inspection, planes would be grounded after they reach a pre-determined life span.

DOC.HEAD: Costs to Farmers Up, Along With Other Americans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A year ago, the average price of a 20-inch chain saw of the type used by many farmers was about $365, says the Agriculture Department. Today, the same saw is around $375. That's an increase of less than 3 percent, but it illustrates that the creep of inflation is still gnawing at consumers, including the nation's farmers. Overall, the department's National Agricultural Statistics Service reported this week, the April index of prices paid by farmers for commodities, services, interest, taxes and hired labor was up 3.4 percent from April 1989. The agency reports prices for a list of items periodically during the year. Some are listed quarterly, others twice a year or at other intervals. By whatever time period that is used, most products are currently more expensive than before. Two general exceptions to the price creep, according to the latest report, are prices for field seeds and fertilizer. For example, a year ago the USDA said timothy was $82.10 per 100 pounds, compared with $132 in April 1989. Tall fescue dropped to $85.10 from $111 a year ago, and ``public and common'' alfalfa seed was $157 per hundredweight against the year-earlier price of $180. The index for fuels and other energy prices was up 1.6 percent from a year ago, although some items showed sharp declines from earlier this year. Bulk delivered diesel fuel, for example, averaged 80.7 cents per gallon in April, down 20.3 cents from January but up 1 cent from a year ago. Prices collectively for automobiles and trucks were up 3.5 percent from April 1989, although new trucks in the 1.5- to 2-ton class and used cars were down slightly. All other vehicle prices were higher. Feeder livestock prices were up 15 percent from April 1989, the report said. Prices of feeder pigs, at $134 per hundredweight, were up $41.50 from January. For tractors, two-wheel-drive models in the range of 50 to 59 horsepower were shown at $17,700 each, compared with $17,300 last October and $17,400 a year ago. The 110-129-horsepower models were $45,300, compared with $44,600 last fall and $43,200 a year ago. But the larger four-wheel-drive tractors in the range of 170 to 240 horsepower were reported at $76,600 each, down from $79,500 last fall and $79,700 a year ago.

The government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility says rain has improved the winter wheat outlook in the northern Great Plains and Pacific Northwest but that more is needed. Soil moisture was ``adequate or adequate to surplus'' in the central and southern plains, while in Arkansas, Missouri and parts of Texas, rain continued to slow field work, the facility reported Tuesday. Overall, the 1990 winter wheat crop was said to be in ``mostly good to fair'' condition during the week of April 23-29, with an estimated 15 percent of the crop headed, which was average for this time of the season. ``Winter wheat was mostly good in Colorado and Montana, good to fair in Nebraska, and fair to good in South Dakota,'' the report said. The crop was reported good to excellent in Kansas, good in Oklahoma, and fair to good in Texas. Planting of spring wheat was reported 54 percent completed, nine percentage points ahead of normal. Seeding was 95 percent completed, in South Dakota, 32 points ahead of normal. In North Dakota, planting was 37 percent completed, one point ahead of the usual pace. Corn planting was said to be 21 percent complete, five points behind the average for this time of year. Planting was under way in all of the major corn states. Planting lagged more than 15 percentage points behind normal in Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri, the report said. The facility is operated by the Agriculture and Commerce departments. Weekly reports cover crop conditions but do not include production forecasts.

The Agriculture Department is proposing to relax the current rules on the imports of some meat and milk from countries that are free of foot-and-mouth disease and rinderpest. Under current regulations, shipments of fresh, chilled and frozen meat, and milk and milk products must be sealed in the country of origin, and the seals must be intact when the shipments arrive in the United States. If the shipments stop in countries that have foot-and-mouth and rinderpest, the cargoes are denied U.S. entry if the seals are broken. James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said the proposal to be officially published today would recognize that the current method of bulk packaging and containerized shipping is one of the safest means of handling meat and dairy products. The proposal would allow the seal to be placed on a container, rather than on the entire hold or compartment of a carrier. It also would establish certain conditions under which the meat or milk products could remain eligible for U.S. entry if the seal has been broken or replaced. Public comments on the proposal can be sent by July 2 to: Chief, Regulatory Analysis and Development, PPD, APHIS, USDA, Room 866, Federal Building, 6505 Belcrest Road, Hyattsville, Md. 20782.

DOC.HEAD: Board Authorizes Possible Sale of Plants
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific Corp.'s board has given management approval to explore the sale of up to 20 of its mills and box plants to pay down debt from its $3.74 billion acquisition of Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. Timberland required to support the plants also may be sold, said Georgia-Pacific Chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr., who said the properties ``may not it our long-term strategy.'' The board approved the measure at a meeting here Tuesday in conjunction with the Atlanta-based forest products company's annual shareholders meeting. Hahn said no final decisions have been made about which plants will be sold. Company spokeswoman Sheila Weidman declined to place a value on the plants that may be sold, although the company said last month it would sell at least $1 billion in assets to cut costs, raise capital and reduce debt. Analysts quoted in today's editions of The Wall Street Journal said three mills alone that might be sold could fetch as much as $1.2 billion. Weidman stressed that Georgia-Pacific is not in need of cash to complete the Great Northern deal. ``The financial arrangements for the merger weren't based on the sale of assets,'' she said. The company said it was considering selling a linerboard mill at Valdosta, Ga.; a linerboard, corrugating medium and kraft paper mill at Toledo, Ore.; a corrugating medium mill at Tomahawk, Wis.; and box plants in East Point, Ga.; Garland, Texas; Milan, Mich.; Modesto and Los Angeles, Calif.; Newark, Ohio; Newberry, S.C.; Rutherfordton and Salisbury, N.C.; Milwaukee; Minneapolis; Olympia, Wash.; Buffalo, N.Y.; Grafton, W.Va.; Miami; Bristol, Pa.; and Gas City, Ind. Weidman said the plants were chosen because of a ``geographic or product redundancy'' that resulted from the acquisition of Norwalk, Conn.-based Great Northern. Meanwhile, Weidman said the acquisition of Great Northern's outstanding shares should be complete by the end of June. So far, Georgia-Pacific has acquired about 96.5 percent, or 53 million, of the outstanding shares, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Current Account Surplus Drops Sharply in Fiscal '89
DOC.TEXT: Rapidly growing imports pushed Japan's current account surplus down 30.8 percent to $53.5 billion in the fiscal year ended March 31, the Finance Ministry reported Wednesday. It was the third consecutive year that there has been a decline in the surplus in Japan's current account, the widest measure of its trade flows. The surplus was well below the level forecast by government economists. In February, the Economic Planning Agency predicted it would register $61 billion. Economists attributed the decline largely to the weak Japanese yen and its impact on prices. While a lower yen reduces the value of Japanese exports, there is a time lag before lower prices result in higher volume. In addition, higher crude oil prices, measured in dollars, added to the cost of imports. For March, the current account surplus grew to $8.1 billion from $6.3 billion a year earlier. In March 1989, there had been an unusual surge in imports before a 3 percent sales tax took effect the next month, the ministry said. Exports were virtually unchanged in fiscal 1989 at $267.9 billion, compared with $267.4 billion the previous year. Imports surged 14.9 percent to $197.7 billion in the third consecutive year of double-digit growth, the ministry said. Both were measured on the basis of settled contracts. Robert Alan Feldman, an economist and vice president of Salomon Brothers Asia, predicted that Japanese exports would revive in the coming year, sending the current account and trade surpluses higher. He said export volume was likely to begin growing this summer as the weaker yen makes Japanese products cheaper overseas. In March, the U.S. dollar averaged 148.90 yen, 14 percent higher than its level a year earlier. Meanwhile, in the first 20 days of April, Japan posted a $11.5 million trade deficit, compared to a $3.1 billion surplus a year earlier, the ministry announced. Japan's trade surplus totaled $7.1 billion in March, the latest full reporting period, up from $6.6 billion a year earlier. The current account includes trade in goods and services and transfer payments, while the trade balance records only trade in goods. Exports and imports in the current account are measured when contracts are settled.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: grafs 1-7 NEW to UPDATE with ministers holding plenary session, then breaking up into smaller groups, uppicks 6th graf pvs: Iraq's oil ...
DOC.TEXT: OPEC ministers began an emergency meeting today in an effort to curb overproduction to help oil prices recover from their recent sharp drop. Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ministers began a plenary session at about 1 p.m. local time. About half an hour later, they broke up into smaller negotiating groups, a tactic they sometimes find more productive. All OPEC countries were represented at the session, except Iran, whose oil minister was expected, said Kemal Saiki, OPEC information officer. ``It is an ongoing circle of consultations,'' Saiki said. The gathering was expected to last one or two days. Ministers made offered no comments as they began the session. But they said when they arrived Tuesday that they were aiming for a quick agreement on voluntary, short-term cuts during May and June. How much output to trim and how the reduction should be allocated among the cartel's 13 members have to be decided. Iraq's oil minister, Issam Al-Chalabi on Tuesday pegged current output at between 23.7 million barrels a day and 24 million barrels a day, well above the ceiling of 22.1 million barrels a day. Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates are the main quota violators, analysts say. The UAE's oil minister, Mana Saeed Otaiba, said Tuesday that his country was observing its quota. The overproduction has caused a glut just when demand traditionally slackens in the second quarter, and that has depressed prices 20 percent since January and well below OPEC's minimum reference price of $18 a barrel. North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, fetched a spot price of $16.60 a barrel in London this morning, up 10 cents from late Tuesday. The average price of a basket of seven crudes monitored by OPEC stood at $15.37 per 42-gallon barrel last week, down from $17.12 a barrel in the first week of April, and well below the $18 minimum reference price. OPEC needs to cut its surplus output by as much as 1.5 million barrels a day to achieve an oil-price recovery, OPEC President Sadek Boussena said Tuesday. Boussena, who also serves as Algeria's oil minister, said: ``The single target is clear, how to eliminate the surpluses existing in the market in order to allow a price recovery. It is a single target and I'm certainly hopeful we can achieve that target.'' Asked how much output needed to be cut, he responded: It certainly is something between one and one and a half million barrels a day.'' Asked if such a cut would come from current production, he replied affirmatively. Iraq's Chalabi said he was willing to consider reducing the official production ceiling for the remaining two months of the half-year, and that all members should contribute to an output cut. ``We are prepared to even discuss lowering the ceiling at the present,'' Chalabi said, adding, ``We are not exceeding our quotas. We are good guys.'' The ministers hadn't been expected to address their official quotas and minimum reference price until they held their full, regular meeting on June 25. Indonesia's oil minister, Ginandjar Kartasasmita, said OPEC ``needs to solve its problem of overproduction quickly. Those overproducing will have to cut.'' Saudi Arabia's influential oil minister, Hisham Nazer, said he wasn't happy with current price levels. ``Yes, we want them higher,'' he said. OPEC's members are Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Slightly Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: will be led after closing
DOC.TEXT: Share prices rose at midday Wednesday on the London Stock Exchange. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 21.9 points at 2,139.8 _ its highest of the day _ at about noon local time. Midday volume totaled 260.8 million shares, up from 226.2 million the same time Tuesday. Dealers said stronger overnight performances in Tokyo and Wall Street helped London open higher and good corporate results in the morning session improved the position.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Dealer Goes Bankrupt
DOC.TEXT: A major speculative stock dealer has gone bankrupt as a result of the sharp plunge of Japanese stock prices this year, a private credit research agency confirmed Wednesday. Akebono Kikaku Co. of Tokyo has accumulated debts exceeding $1.33 billion and has issued bad notes twice since March 28, said Teikoku Data Bank Ltd. The agency said it was one of the largest bankruptcy cases on record in Japan. Akebono Kikaku's downfall followed the Tokyo market's sharp plunge this year. Teikoku Data Bank said Akebono was unable to meet margin calls because of the steep fall in stocks. The 225-share Nikkei Stock index has skidded 8,742.23 points, or around 22 percent, from its highest level of 38,915.87 last Dec. 29. Many market participants fear that the demise of a few speculator groups could bankrupt some small securities companies or cause another selling frenzy on the financial markets. Last month, Yamaichi Securities Co., one of Japan's 17 major securities companies, said it faced a $24 million loss due to one customer's bankruptcy in March. Akebono, founded in 1979 and headed by Komei Tai, dealt in speculative trading in about 20 stock issues, including those of chemical, electric power and pharmaceutical companies, while managing hotels in the downtown Tokyo district of Shinjuku, according to the Kyodo News Service.

The stock market edged upward today as traders awaited details of the government's financing plans. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 8.56 to 2,677.48 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers held a slight edge on losers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 377 up, 336 down and 511 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 21.12 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Late today the Treasury was schedule to lay out plans for its quarterly sale of bonds and notes next week, in which it is expected to offer more than $30 billion worth of those securities. The size of the ``refunding'' and the reception it gets from investors are seen as pivotal factors determining the near-term course of interest rates. Rates have been climbing lately, in part because of uneasiness about the Treasury auctions. In the credit markets today, prices of long-term government bonds fell about $2.50 for each $1,000 in face value, increasing their yields to the 9.05 percent-9.10 percent range. Chrysler rose [ to 15] in active trading on top of a }-point gain Tuesday, when the company reported an 80 percent decline in first-quarter earnings. Some analysts had expected the profit showing to be worse than it turned out. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .34 to 2,677.48. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .10 at 343.42. On Tuesday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.16 to 2668.92. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by about 6 to 5 on the NYSE, with 811 up, 676 down and 464 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 149.02 million shares, against 122.75 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Appliance Maker Forms Overseas Unit
DOC.TEXT: Whirlpool Corp. said Wednesday it is combining several units into one subsidiary that will handle marketing outside North America and Europe. The new unit, Whirlpool Overseas Corp., will combine the company's Benton Harbor-based export sales group with its overseas business group in Comerio, Italy. It also will include four wholly owned sales companies in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Thailand and Australia, the company said. The Comerio operation had been part of Whirlpool International B.V., formed by Whirlpool's joint venture with N.V. Philips of the Netherlands in 1989. The four sales companies also were acquired in the joint venture. ``The distinct focus of Whirlpool Overseas Corp. makes it neither an exclusively North American export nor European export organization but rather one responsible for market penetration of all corporation brands in overseas markets,'' said Lawrence J. Kremer, senior vice president for global technology and operations. Appliances marketed by the overseas group include KitchenAid, Whirlpool, Roper, Ignis, Bauknecht and those carrying the dual Whirlpool and Philips brand. Whirlpool manufactures appliances in 10 countries and markets them in 45. The company reported consolidated net earnings of $187.2 million on consolidated net revenues of $6.29 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Indicators Rose 0.9 Percent in March
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs to include factory orders report after 8th graf: Indeed; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government's chief economic forecasting gauge rose 0.9 percent in March, its biggest increase in nearly two years, the government said today. The gain in the Index of Leading Economic Indicators, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in the future, meant the gauge nearly regained the 1.0 percent loss it suffered in February. It was the steepest increase since a 1.6 percent gain in June 1988. Before dropping in February, the index had risen for three straight months. But while the gauge was up in March, some analysts were concerned that rising inflation, if it does not force the Federal Reserve to increase interest rates, certainly will not encourge the central bank to lower them. High rates would slow further the already sluggish construction, auto and manufacturing sectors of the economy. ``We're looking for a slowdown in activity in the second and third quarters due primarily to high interest rates,'' said Paul Getman, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. ``We'll have an extremely sluggish construction sector and lackluster activity elsewhere, including business investment, which has been pretty good,'' he added. Indeed, construction, which relies on low-cost loans, slowed even before the start of the second quarter. The Commerce Department reported on Tuesday that construction spending dropped 1.4 percent in March, its steepest decline in more than a year. But in a second report today, the department said orders to factories for manufactured goods rose 3.8 percent in March, continuing to rebound from a 5.5 percent decline in January, the steepest fall since a 7 percent decrease in December 1974. The March gain was the largest in more than a year and, together with February's 1.8 percent advance, offset the January decline. Six of the 11 forward-looking statistics contributed to the increase in today's leading indicators, led by a gain in new plant and equipment orders. Other positives were an increase in the price of raw materials, an increase in orders for consumer goods, higher stock prices, slower business delivery times and a drop in weekly unemployment claims. Negatives included a decrease in building permits, a decline in the backlog of manufacturers unfilled orders and a drop in the money supply. Two of the components were unchanged: the average workweek and an index measuring consumer confidence. The various changes left the index at 145.2 percent of its 1982 base of 100. The index edged up 0.1 percent from October through March on top of a 0.2 percent gain the previous six months. Although many analysts see slow growth ahead, there is virtual unanimity that the economy has avoided a recession. ``The business cycle trough is pretty much behind us,'' contended Kermit Baker, director of economics at Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass. ``Any risk of recession prettty much ended with the first-quarter (GNP) report. You're not going to hear too many recession forecasts cropping up over the next few months.'' The first-quarter gross national product _ the nation's total output of goods and services _ rose 2.1 percent, compared to a 3.0 percent increase for all of 1989, according to a Commerce Department report last week. That was much stronger growth than many economists had predicted as the year began. At that time, many forecast GNP growth would be little improved from the fourth quarter's 1.1 percent rate, the slowest in three years. Some even said the economy could topple into a recession. But despite the surprising strength, the report also contained bad news on the inflation front _ a 6.5 percent annual rate, the steepest increase since 1981 and up sharply from the 4.5 percent in 1989. Interest rates were pushed up starting in December 1988 by the Federal Reserve as it sought to curb inflation by tightening credit. As inflation seemed to moderate, the central bank permitted short-term rates to ease during the second half of 1989. But many economists now fear the Fed may have no choice but to retighten credit to keep inflationary pressures under control.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Rise On China News
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices rose this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade after the Agriculture Department announced it had targeted China for sales of 2 million metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Soybean futures were lower while corn futures were narrowly mixed in early trading. The USDA had been rumored to be planning large offers of export bonus wheat to several countries, including China. But the size of the offer announced this morning was `` a little higher than they had anticipated,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc., a commodity research firm in Chicago. The wheat market drew further support from extremely wet weather in the Southern Plains that threatens to delay the winter harvest and possibly reduce crop yields, Karlin said. Soybeans were down slightly after Tuesday's rollercoaster action that saw prices zoom to nine-month highs and then collapse to close lower. In early trading, wheat futures were 1{ cents to 3 cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.69 a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to { cent higher with May at $2.83{ a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to \ cent higher with May at $1.65 a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents lower to 1{ cents higher with May at $6.26{ a bushel. Live cattle were .05 cent to .35 cent higher with June at 73.57 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .03 cent to .20 cent higher with May at 82.75 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent lower to .23 cent higher with June at 63.75 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .25 cent lower to 1.20 cents higher with May at 69.85 cents a pound. DOC.NOTE: $adv03
For Release PMs Thurs May 3
DOC.HEAD: Another Bad Trip For Bond Funds
DOC.TEXT: If you put your money in a conservative, high-yielding investment that offers convenience, liquidity and diversification of your money, how can you lose? For one answer to that question, ask the legions of people who have owned shares of bond funds and other income mutual funds through the first four months of 1990. While these funds, which have aggregate assets of $300 billion, have been earning current yields of 8 percent to 9 percent or more from their holdings of such things as Treasury securities and high-grade corporate bonds, their typical ``total return'' to investors of late has been less than zero. From Jan. 1 through April 26, an index of 535 income funds calculated by Lipper Analytical Services Inc., assuming reinvestment of dividends, showed a loss of 2.57 percent. What went wrong for these funds was a rise in the general level of long-term interest rates that almost no one had predicted. Going rates on long-term Treasury bonds climbed from below 8 percent at New Year's to 9 percent in late April. Increasing rates on new fixed-income securities coming to market forced the prices of existing bonds downward by about 10 percent or more, in turn depressing the net asset values of the funds that owned those bonds. Yield-conscious investors with a true long-term perspective might be inclined to take all this in stride. They continue to get their current income, after all, and they retain the hope that their principal will recoup its lost value should interest rates turn downward again. But they have no assurance that those hopes will be fulfilled within any given period of time. The interest-rate volatility of the late 1970s and 1980s, quite apparently, has persisted into the early months of the 1990s undiminished. ``Once again, an unexpected rise in long-term interest rates confounded experts who were anticipating a totally different set of events,'' said Vincent Agnew, an investment manager at Chicago Title and Trust Co. For people considering new fund investments, the latest developments have their positive side. Because of the rise in rates, their money now can command higher current yields than before. Perhaps even more important, rates on short-term securities like Treasury bills have risen only slightly while long-term rates jumped. So for the first time in two or three years, the yield curve representing the range of maturities in the credit markets is no longer flat. Thus, investors in interest-bearing securities are starting to see at least some modest extra reward for taking the risk that goes with tying up their money for an extended period of time. As of the beginning of May, yields on Treasury bonds exceeded yields on bills by more than three-quarters of a percentage point. But if that improves the odds a little, it still gives no assurance of any sure bets for mutual-fund investors. If long-term rates keep rising, income funds' net asset values will keep losing ground. Wright Investors Service of Bridgeport, Conn., argues that high-quality bonds are attractive right now on the basis of ``good potential for sharply lower yields and higher bond prices by yearend.'' At Chicago Title, analysts take a warier view: ``The argument for lower U.S. interest rates was predicated on a sluggish economy accompanied by declining inflationary pressures. ``It's possible that the consensus view might still prevail. But don't count on it.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Thurs May 3

DOC.HEAD: Trade Representative Says Trade Talks in Crucial Period
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 8 grafs new with speech; picks up 4th graf pvs, The talks; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said today that world trade talks had entered a crucial period with a variety of disputes still to be resolved. Hills was in California for talks with trade ministers from Japan, the 12-nation European Community and Canada over ways to resolve contentious issues blockikng completion of a round of trade-liberalization talks. The trade officials hope the three days of discussions will inject a new sense of urgency into the negotiations, which have been under way since 1986. If common ground is not reached, there are fears that the most ambitious round of trade-liberalization talks ever undertaken could end in failure. ``1990 is a pivotal year for the world economy,'' Hills said. ``Down one path lie open markets, expanded trade, economic growth and prosperity. Down the other lie closed markets, nations turned inward and gravely diminished prosperity for all.'' Hills, speaking to a convention of business reporters and editors, appealed to the news media to do a better job of covering trade issues. She said reporters over-emphasize stories on trade frictions with such countries as Japan and downplay more significant stories such as the effort to negotiate a new global trade agreement. Hills appeared before the Society of American Business Editors and Writers before the trade talks got underway at a resort in Napa, Calif. The talks, which were launched almost four years ago in Uruguay, are being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 96-nation group that governs world trade. The Uruguay Round is scheduled to be completed in early December, but with a little over 200 days left, deep disagreement still divides the negotiators. The Bush administration has made a new global trade agreement its top trade priority this year, and Hills has portrayed possible failure of the talks in stark economic terms. She has warned that without major reforms the trading system that produced four decades of global prosperity could disintegrate into protectionism and shrinking living standards for both industrial and developing countries. ``The accords we seek are essential to our future prosperity,'' Hills said. ``It may be the last, best chance this century to create the trading rules we need for the next century.'' The administration is counting on the reforms to attack a U.S. trade deficit that has topped $100 billion for six consecutive years. Hills has estimated that tearing down protectionist farm barriers worldwide could boost U.S. farm exports by $11 billion annually _ amounting to $3,400 for every farmer. Similarly, strengthening rules to protect against patent and copyright piracy could pump $60 billion annually into U.S. corporate coffers, the administration estimates. The other big item on America's wish list is removal of barriers to trade in services, a fast-growing part of world trade where experts believe the deficit could be lowered by opening foreign markets to U.S. banks, securities firms and insurance companies. But the U.S. negotiating package has met with resistance. The 12-nation European Community, with its politically powerful collection of small family farms, is strenuously resisting the American call for a timetable to phase out all trade-distorting farm subsides. Third World countries, led by India and Brazil, are fighting the effort to remove barriers blocking foreign banks and other service companies for fear that giant multinational firms will overwhelm their domestic institutions. There was no clear indication what will come from the three days of discussions, being held at a plush resort in Napa, Calif. Officials hope, at the very least, to come closer to common ground in some areas to give guidance to lower-level negotiators, who will meet in Geneva, Switzerland, in July for a critical drafting session. It is quite likely that some of the thorniest problems will have to be taken up when President Bush hosts America's major allies at the seven-nation economic summit this summer in Houston. The final negotiations will be held Dec. 3-7 in Brussels, but without substantial movement before that time, there are concerns that the final round of talks could collapse, given the complexity of the issues being addressed.

DOC.NOTE: $adv03
For Release PMs Thursday, May 3
DOC.HEAD: Corporate Management Myths
DOC.TEXT: It is still true that the surest way to the top of a large American industrial corporation is to find a relatively low level job and work your way up. No, it is not a myth. The myth, created in recent decades, is that it's now more common to move into the top job by bouncing from one company to another, eventually leveraging into the chairman's office. But Eugene Jennings, examining his research all the way back to 1939 _ it is the largest corporate mobility data base of its kind _ finds that it is now far more common to name a chief from within the company. That finding upsets what has become a ``given'' in many popular accounts of making it to the top. But it is conclusive. Jennings, who pioneered so-called mobility studies, says that three out of four individuals named to the top spot in the 1980s were what he calls natives, compared with only 48 percent in the decade of the 1960s. The professor _ professor emeritus of management, Michigan State University _ set out in the late 1940s to study mobility patterns, or ascendancy routes in industrial America. In effect, his interest was ``making it in America.'' Because this was his intent, he excluded ``birth elites'' and ``privileged elites'' _ namely founders, children of founders and investors and their proxies, who probably entered the company by raiding it or buying it. With these exclusions, he was able to concentrate on mobility patterns and trace the routes to corporate success. He found that in every category he defined, natives were more likely than so-called migrants to head America's large industrial corporations, and that the pattern was becoming even more pronounced. He found, for example, that natives outscore migrants in every age group, among the early arrivals or those who achieve the top job at 49 years or younger, normals (age 50 to 57.5 years) and late arrivals (58 years or more). In spite of what some executive recruiters might like to hear, he found that even when migrants assumed the top job, they rarely did so without first becoming subordinates and working their way up from there. Age and experience, he found in his review, remain extremely important in naming a chief. The widely held notion that chief executive officers are younger these day is also a myth. The fact is precisely the opposite. To illustrate: Since the 1960s, the average age at which chiefs are appointed has risen steadily and is now more than 58 years. In that time, the number of younger chief executives has declined. Tenure has risen; chiefs remain in the job longer than they used to. Tenure during the 1960s was less than seven years on average. It is now more than nine years and rising. Increasingly, boards waive compulsory retirement rules. It is a myth too, says Jennings, that corporate boards turn to migrant chiefs when the company is in trouble. No, he says, they turn to natives. The facts suggest older, experienced, home-grown chiefs are treasured by boards. A popular notion is that more chiefs of U.S. industrial companies have had global experience, the better to deal with the emerging global economy. To some extent, the impression is false. Jennings found, for instance, that fewer rather than more chiefs have had the experience of living and working abroad for the company. No, he says, while they have experience running foreign operations, they've done it from home. As popularly described, he says, ``The global manager is a myth.'' He finds instead that industrial companies have been developing native managers who report to the U.S. office rather than sending home-office managers abroad. Jennings, who for three decades has advised corporate chairmen on the grooming of potential successors, began his studies with live data in 1949 and researched records back to 1939. From that data have come numerous books, including the seminal ``Mobile Manager'' in 1964, and ``Routes To The Executive Suite'' and ``Executives in Crisis'' in the 1970s.

DOC.HEAD: EC Proposes Anti-Pollution Measures for Trucks
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's executive Commission proposed measures Wednesday to significantly reduce pollution from diesel trucks. Carlo Ripa di Meana, EC commissioner for the environment, said if approved by EC governments and the European Parliament, the proposal would force all trucks in the 12-nation trade bloc to cut their emissions of carbon dioxide by more than half. Hydrocarbons also would be cut by half and nitrogen oxides by slightly less than half, making EC diesel trucks as clean as those from Austria and Switzerland. In the two Alpine nations, trucks producing more than 82 decibels are banned between 10 p.m. and 5 a.m., and Ripa di Meana plans to propose similar curbs on noise pollution this fall. New anti-pollution norms will be introduced in Austria and Switzerland on Oct. 1, 1991. EC hauliers were worried the new norms would affect their transit through the two nations. Ripa di Meana said his proposal had been ``prepared in full consultation with the truck industry.'' These talks had revealed that the technology to reduce pollution from diesel engines was available in the 12-nation trade bloc so new norms could be mandatory by Oct. 1, 1991. Ripa di Meana said he would also propose legislation to cut the amount of sulphur in diesel this fall.
