DOC.HEAD: Dollar Ends Mostly Higher, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mostly higher Wednesday in quiet trading following a mixed performance overseas. Gold prices fell slightly after rising in Europe and Asia. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $369.50 a troy ounce, down 50 cents from late Tuesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $369.70 an ounce, off 30 cents. Currency dealers said the markets had little reaction to the latest set of government data, which pointed to continued strength in the economy. The Commerce Department said its Index of Leading Economic Indicators rose 0.9 percent in March, nearly offsetting a 1 percent drop the previous month. It was the steepest rise since a 1.6 percent gain in June 1988. In another report, the department said factory orders rose 3.8 percent in March, rebounding from January's worst decline in 16 years. ``The numbers were within expectations,'' said Gabriele Schmitt, a corporate trader for the Bank of New York. ``Most of the figures were pretty much priced in.'' She said traders also shrugged off news that East and West Germany had agreed on key terms of their July 2 monetary union, since that announcement contained few surprises. In Tokyo, where global trading begins, the dollar eased to 158.55 yen from 158.90 yen late Tuesday. The dollar traded at 158.25 yen in London, and at 158.015 yen in New York, down from 158.845. The dollar was mixed against the British pound from late Tuesday. Sterling sold for $1.6435 in London, up from $1.6385, and for $1.6425 in New York, down from $1.6445. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.6848 West German marks, up from 1.6805; 1.4550 Swiss francs, down from 1.4555; 5.6530 French francs, up from 5.6370; 1,234.75 Italian lire, up from 1,231.75; and 1.16715 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16455. Late European dollar rates compared with Tuesday: 1.6823 West German marks, up from 1.6785; 1.4535 Swiss francs, down from 1.4545; 5.6425 French francs, up from 5.6365; 1.8910 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8892; 1,232.25 Italian lire, up from 1,231.25; and 1.1672 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1635. In London, gold closed at $369.25 an ounce, up from $368.50. The closing Zurich bid was $368.85 and ounce, up from $367 late Monday. Zurich markets were closed Tuesday for May Day. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $370.55 an ounce, up from $369.45. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.988 a troy ounce, down 2.5 cents from Tuesday. Silver rose in London to $5.02 an ounce from $4.97.

DOC.HEAD: Smith Pension Could Double Under Proposal Up for Vote
DOC.TEXT: The pension of departing General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger B. Smith could double under a proposal that could add $42 million to the automaker's costs for executive pensions in its first year alone. The proposal, up for the vote of shareholders at GM's annual meeting May 25, would base pensions for GM's top 3,350 executives on an average of total cash compensation rather than just salary. The proposal comes during an aggressive cost-cutting campaign adopted in 1987 aimed at cutting up to $13 billion from the automaker's costs by the end of this year. The shareholders meeting in Detroit will be the last one chaired by Smith, whose nine-year tenure has been criticized for focusing too much on financial matters and too little on developing new cars and trucks. United Auto Workers President Owen Bieber on Wednesday criticized the pension change as unjustifiable. ``In view of GM's largess to its executives there will be no excuse for the corporation to be less than fully responsive to the needs of our older members and retirees,'' Bieber said. There are about 400,000 retired UAW members. The UAW is to begin contract bargaining with GM in July. The current pact expires Sept. 14. GM executives' pensions now are based on a formula keyed to their average salaries in the past 10 years. Under the proposed system, bonuses would be included in the formula. Last year, Smith's $1.1 million salary grew to $2.6 million with bonuses, stock options and other compensation. Smith, who retires Aug. 1, stands to see his annual pension rise to $1.1 million from about $550,000 under the new plan. Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. base their executives' pensions on salary alone. Ford also has the option of giving the executives added annuities. There is a growing movement in the UAW to add cost-of-living allowances to hourly worker pension plans. Such a proposal, which analysts have said would be extremely costly, was turned down at a recent meeting of the UAW Skilled Trades Department. The issue is likely to attract a good deal of attention when the UAW holds a three-day bargaining convention in Kansas City beginning May 21. Executive salaries, bonuses and retirement packages have prompted harsh criticism from the UAW in the past. ``It's outrageous, ridiculous,'' said Whitey Hale, a member of UAW Local 326 in Flint who is a leader in the movement for cost-of-living increases for retirees. ``How can they turn their back on our members that actually made the money, to give (themselves) the bonuses?'' ``They'll get that every year, a million dollars, and our people are getting $1,500 a month,'' he said. Smith will be succeeded by GM President Robert Stempel, who came up through the company's engineering and marketing ranks. His move into the chairmanship was praised by analysts who had criticized Smith. When Smith became chairman on New Year's Day 1981, GM's share of the U.S. car and truck market stood at 44.1 percent. At the end of last year, its share was 34.6 percent. Also during Smith's tenure, the automaker took a back seat in profits to smaller Ford Motor Co. Last year, GM regained the title as the nation's most profitable automaker.

DOC.HEAD: American General Puts Itself Up For Sale; Stock Jumps Higher
DOC.TEXT: American General Corp. surprised shareholders and one suitor Wednesday by putting itself up for sale, in an auction expected to fetch $7 billion for the nation's fourth largest insurance company. The company's stock price jumped sharply higher after the announcement at American General's annual shareholders meeting, where the anticipated event had been a showdown with hostile suitor Torchmark Corp. Harold S. Hook, American General's chairman, said the company decided to put itself up for auction because it was vulnerable to a possible takeover at a discount price and wanted to realize the maximum value for its stockholders. American General finished up $7.50 at $47.62{ a share as the most actively traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange. Company officials and analysts said they expected the bidding for American General to reach about $7 billion, or more than $55 per share. Birmingham, Ala.-Torchmark had made an unsolicited $6.34 billion, or $50 per share, cash and stock buyout offer for American General in March. But Torchmark later withdrew the offer, opting instead to wage a proxy fight to elect its own five nominees to the 15-member board. Since then each company vigorously has been urging shareholders to support its board nominees. Torchmark also asked shareholders to approve two resolutions calling for American General to hire an investment banking firm and to appoint a committee of independent directors to evaluate acquisition proposals. ``We are confident we elected our slate of directors,'' Hook said to the loud applause of the 650 shareholders attending the meeting. ``I wish that was the end of the story,'' he added before reading a statement announcing the sale. Torchmark Chairman Ron Richey said he was pleased with American General's announcement. ``From the outset, our objective has been to negotiate a transaction with American General, and we look forward to sitting down with them to discuss a merger proposal,'' Richey said. ``Based on today's announcement, regardless of the proxy vote, we intend to make another proposal to combine Torchmark with American General.'' The decision to sell the company was made about 6 p.m. Tuesday in a meeting with the entire board, Hook said. He would not say if the board's decision was unanimous. The sale announcement could not be made public until the company's proxy vote had ended, he said. American General has subsidiaries that operate in 50 states and Canada. The much-smaller Torchmark is best known for its Liberty National Mutual Insurance subsidiary. American General has assets of $32 billion. Torchmark has assets of $5 billion. Hook said the board would rather sell the company in one piece, but would be prepared to sell off operating subsidiaries separately if that wasn't possible. Asked if Torchmark's original offer was adequate, Hook said, a $50 a share offer would be considered a discount price. He said he expects about 50 potential bidders initially. First Boston Corp. will lead the company's selling effort. Analyst Hebert Goodfriend, with Prudential Bache Research in New York, said he believed several companies would be interested in American General, but would not name any. Torchmark's adamant interest in acquiring American General ``made a lot of other people aware that we were vulnerable,'' Hook said. He said many companies have called wanting to discuss the situation but reiterated that the company was not in search of a ``white knight'' to thwart the bid. The outcome of Wednesday's proxy vote will not be known for up to two weeks, said American General spokesman John Pluhowski.

DOC.HEAD: President Proposes Private Banking System
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT spelling of spokesman's name to Ffrench from French. Ffrench is cq.
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari sent a proposal to Congress today to modify the constitution and re-establish a private banking system in Mexico, the government announced. Former President Jose Lopez Portillo nationalized the country's 35 private banks shortly before leaving office in 1982, claiming that bankers had helped Mexicans take money out of the country, worsening an economic recession. ``Once again there would be mixed banking, private banks and public (owned) banks,'' said Leonardo Ffrench, a presidential spokesman. The bill would allow 100 percent private ownership of commercial banks. ``A change in social realities in the country, in economic structures, of the state's role in the financial system, change the circumstances that brought about the nationalization of banks,'' a government statement said. ``We cannot allow a state as owner, with so many resources invested in banking, in a country with so many urgent social needs,'' it said. ``The government could take advantage of its funds and free its resources to assist infrastructure and services which are the essential role of the state.'' A constitutional change must be approved by two-thirds of the 500-member Congress. That would require a coalition between the governing Institional Revolutionary Party and opposition parties. Mexico's 1917 Constitution had decreed a mixed banking system.

DOC.NOTE: $adv06
For release Sunday May 6
DOC.HEAD: Consumers May Feel Pinch as Insurers Cut Back on Personal Insurance
DOC.TEXT: A growing number of major insurers are slashing or abandoning personal lines of insurance because of what they call declining profits and increased meddling by state regulators and lawmakers. Insurance industry analysts say this reduction could spell serious trouble for consumers who need automobile, homeowners and health policies. Some may be unable to find coverage. Xerox Corp.'s Crum and Forster insurance division announced last month that it was exiting the personal insurance market altogether, joining at least seven others who have reduced or eliminated their personal insurance offerings. Those include Travelers Corp., Aetna Life and Casualty Co., and The Hartford Insurance Group in the nation's insurance capital; Philadelphia-based Cigna Corp.; The New Hampshire Insurance Group; and Continental Corp. in New York. Insurance executives center much of their frustration on the regulation of auto insurance. Many blame laws such as California's Proposition 103, which would place restrictions on auto insurance premiums, and New Jersey's new law effectively reducing auto insurance premiums 20 percent, for the withdrawal from personal insurance. ``You take any business in any industry and you tell them they can't make any money, you don't have to be in insurance to know what the business will do,'' said David Seifer, a researcher who follows the insurance industry for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a New York investment firm. ``It's price setting by the legislature,'' said Robert Brian, a vice president of Hartford-based Conning and Co., a research firm. ``There's only one result and that's total economic chaos. The arithmetic just doesn't add up. They're destroying the personal insurance market.'' California, New Jersey, Nevada, Pennsylvania and South Carolina have all passed laws mandating some sort of a rate rollback. The Massachusetts Legislature has been criticized for setting what industry experts say are artificially low rates. On April 30, Aetna sued Massachusetts, claiming a provision of the state law that penalizes insurers who want to stop selling auto policies there is unconstitutional and amounts to extortion. There have been threats of rate rollbacks in Connecticut and at least 15 other states, said Terry Tyrpin, assistance vice president with the American Association of Independent Insurers, an Illinois-based group. Joan Bianca, a Crum and Forster spokeswoman, said regulatory restrictions were largely responsible in the company's decision. Three-quarters of the company's business is done in states undergoing insurance reforms. Hartford-based Travelers Corp. has withdrawn from the automobile insurance field in California, affecting 18,000 customers. The company also has stopped writing new policies in New Jersey and is carefully choosing customers in other states. ``The business is extremely competitive, profits are very slim so we are concentrating on areas we feel are more viable to us,' said Dan Kaferle, a spokesman for Travelers. ``We don't see a bright future in a business with regulations restricting price.'' Kaferle said Travelers predicted it would have lost about $20 million between 1989 and 1991 in California, where rates have been frozen at 1989 levels as lawmakers study proposed legislation. The company also predicted losses in Pennsylvania, where auto insurance reform is underway. Travelers has also stopped selling new individual major-medical health insurance policies. Aetna is scaling down in states where profits are poor. The company has dropped some independent agents and reduced commissions. Aetna plans to reduce personal auto insurance business by 20 percent over the next three years. The company also will stop selling new individual health insurance policies in May. The company wrote $1.8 billion in premiums in 1989 and lost more than $80 million, said spokesman John Hawkins. ``We've not thrown in the towel completely,'' said Hawkins. ``But we've made the decision that we are not going to grow the business (in those states where we are unprofitable).'' Insurance analysts say the trend was predictable, especially in the deteriorating auto insurance field where some states have regulated premiums to what the industry calls an unprofitable level. More companies feeling the squeeze are expected to follow suit. ``It's just the beginning,'' said Brian. ``They've just finally run out of hope. The multi-line companies have decided that they can't be everything to everybody.'' Industry experts say the upheaval means many consumers will find it tougher to buy individual health insurance or insurance for their cars and homes, especially in states where regulation of insurance rates is especially stiff or where legislation is pending. Moreover, as companies cut back and competition decreases, so will the quality of insurance, said Larry Kibbee, a vice president with the Alliance of American Insurers, an insurance industry lobbying group. Analysts predict that many consumers will have to fall back on substandard insurers. Getting claims processed may become a consumer nightmare, they say. Others predict increased rates for some consumers, especially in states with no restrictions, as insurers raise rates to offset losses in other areas where rates are regulated. Industry executives assert that the state regulations attack the symptom rather than the causes of high rates, which they blame on problems ranging from fraudulent claims to the high cost of repairs and litigation. ``Legislators are going to have to look more at some of the root causes as to why the rates are as high as they are, especially in the auto insurance industry,'' said Kibbee. Last year the Alliance did a survey and found, for example, that it cost $60,000 for replacement parts for a 1989 Nissan Maxima with a $17,000 sticker price, said Kibbee. The Washington-based American Insurance Association, an industry lobbying group, has been pushing for better laws to keep insurance claims out of court. Dave Snyder, an official of the organization, said hefty attorney fees have pushed up insurance rates tremendously. He suggested other solutions, like capping medical fees, increasing automobile safety standards, and cracking down on traffic violators to reduce accidents. ``Quick fix solutions like rate roll backs is not going to help,'' said Terri Malenfant, a spokeswoman for the Alliance of American Insurers. ``The only way is to hold down the costs of repairs, medical costs and litigation costs.'' Kaferle, of Travelers, said artificially low rates will hurt the consumer in the long run. ``If you hold down those rates for no other reason other than to hold down rates, eventually all those costs will have to catch up with the consumers and they are going to have a major rate shock,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday May 6

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Plans to Auction $30.5 Billion in Securities
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury Department announced Wednesday it plans to borrow $30.5 billion from the public next week in a series of debt auctions to replenish the government's coffers. ``We are offering $30.5 billion of notes and bonds to refund $18.1 billion of privately-held notes and bonds maturing on May 15 and to raise approximately $12.4 billion of cash,'' Treasury Undersecretary Robert Glauber told a news briefing. Glauber said the auctions next week would include: _ $10.5 billion in three-year notes in minimum denominations of $5,000 to be auctioned on Tuesday; _ $10 billion in 10-year notes in minimum denominations of $1,000 to be auctioned on Wednesday, and, _ $10 billion in 30-year bonds in minimum denominations of $1,000 to be auctioned on Thursday. These notes and bonds are regularly sold during the large debt auctions held four times a year.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Strike, Greyhound Unveils Summer Ad Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs, `The union... to CORRECT that Greyhound has said it will be able to make payment; PICKS UP 10th graf pvs, `Ms. Hale...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Greyhound
DOC.TEXT: Undaunted by a 2-month-old strike, Greyhound Lines Inc. on Wednesday unveiled a summer radio advertising campaign touting bus travel as ``a window seat on America.'' Greyhound also announced a reduced fare program for some Northeast and Midwest markets where recovery has been lagging. The Dallas-based company, which operates the only nationwide bus system, was struck by 6,500 drivers and some 3,000 clerical and maintenance employees March 2. The company and union said Wednesday they would resume negotiations Saturday in Washington. Greyhound spokeswoman Liz Hale said that although the company has been operating reduced schedules during the strike, recent expansions have restored service to about 86.9 percent of pre-strike locations. Further expansions are planned as the busy summer traveling season approaches. The ad campaign ignores the strike, instead stressing service. ``We're offering so much service now,'' Ms. Hale said. ``The strike has not hampered our ability to bring back service to most markets that we were serving before the strike started, so most of our passengers are finding that they can go to their destinations.'' About 3.5 million passengers have ridden Greyhound since the strike began. In recent days, loads have been running between 53 percent and 58 percent of the same day last year, the company said. Union officials have disputed Greyhound's figures on restored service, putting it at about 20 percent of pre-strike levels. The union claims Greyhound faces a mounting cash crunch. The company, created through a 1987 leveraged buyout, has a $9 million interest payment due May 15. Greyhound has said it will be able to make the payment. Ms. Hale, citing company policy, would not disclose the cost of the ad campaign. Greyhound's past owners have used television campaigns, but Ms. Hale said the current owners have used radio exclusively because ``it fits our demographics.'' Greyhound says its passengers tend to be students or from low-income families. The campaign, which debuts Monday and is to run through August, features three versions of a jingle. The ads will run on nationwide networks serving more than 3,000 stations and in 11 large metropolitan areas. The jingle, in gospel, rock and blues versions, urges travelers to ``take a window seat on America, take a Greyhound cruise, don't need a lot of money to be traveling in style.'' The reduced fare promotion puts a $99 cap on one-way fares with no advance purchase requirements. The fare is good Friday through June 13 and includes Chicago plus Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and Vermont. Greyhound also lowered round trip fares in a dozen New England markets. The promotion is the second to target the Northeast since the strike. During the Easter travel period, Greyhound offered free tickets in some markets if buses did not run on time.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Hopes for a respite from the recent rise of interest rates helped the stock market stage a moderate advance Wednesday. Analysts said some traders apparently were buying on expectations that a forthcoming financing by the government might draw a better response than has been feared. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 20.72 to 2,689.64, stretching its gain since the start of the week to 44.59 points. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 7 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 864 up, 612 down and 478 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 141.61 million shares, against 149.02 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 171.08 million shares. After the market closed the Treasury spelled out plans for its quarterly sale of bonds and notes next week, saying it would auction a record $30.50 billion in new securities. The size of the ``refunding'' and the reception it gets from investors are widely seen as pivotal influences on the near-term course of interest rates. Rates have been climbing lately, in part because of uneasiness about the Treasury auctions. In the credit markets Wednesday, prices of long-term government bonds declined slightly in early trading, but then recovered to finish little changed. American General was the day's most active issue, up 7{ at 47| on turnover of more than 7.1 million shares. The company, after asserting that it had won a proxy battle against Torchmark, announced plans to seek other prospective buyers. Xerox fell 1\ to 46}. The company denied rumors that it was considering a cut in its dividend on the heels of its recent report of lower-than-expected quarterly earnings from continuing operations. Halliburton, which posted higher earnings for the first quarter, gained ~ to 44[. Chrysler rose { to 15} in active trading on top of a }-point gain Tuesday, when the company reported an 80 percent decline in first-quarter earnings. Some analysts had expected the profit showing to be worse than it turned out. Other gainers among the blue chips included Exxon, up } at 45~; International Business Machines, up 1[ at 109[; General Motors, up { at 44}, and Boeing, up } at 73. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $19.45 billion, or 0.61 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks climbed 1.12 to 183.34. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 2.73 to 389.81, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 2.23 at 334.48. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 1.73 to 423.58. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 344.23, up .91.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Fall as OPEC Meeting Hits Snag
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices fell Wednesday as OPEC's latest attempt to curb overproduction stalled. The market moved higher in early trading on anticipation that an agreement to limit output might be reached. But when traders heard reports that ministers meeting in Geneva could not agree on how to allocate production cuts, prices fell back. The June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude oil, slipped 13 cents to close at $18.68 a 42-gallon barrel after trading as high as $19.10 early in the session. Home heating oil for June delivery fell 1.11 cents to 51.86 cents a gallon, and June unleaded regular gasoline dropped 0.08 cent to 60.95 cents a gallon. Natural gas for June delivery rose to $1.575 per million British thermal units, from $1.565 Tuesday. One delegate source at the Geneva meeting said the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ministers were far apart in their positions and no one idea emerged from the talks. Ministers held a full plenary session for about half an hour early Wednesday afternoon and then broke up to negotiate in small groups in their hotel rooms. But plans to resume the full session were postponed twice and then delayed ``until further notice to allow for further consultations'' among the ministers, OPEC said. Andrew Lebow, an analyst with E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., said news of the postponement dashed the oil market's hopes for a quick agreement. Traders have been anxious for new production limits to support prices, which have fallen 20 percent since January. But analysts have doubted OPEC could achieve enough of a production cutback to have a significant impact on prices. OPEC is producing an estimated 23 million to 24 million barrels a day, well above its self-imposed ceiling of 22.1 million barrels a day. The excess output came ahead of a seasonal drop in demand, causing a glut on world markets.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Rally Resumes As Crop Futures Climb Sharply
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 17th graf pvs, `Copper settled... to CORRECT price change; PICKS UP penultimate graf, `Also on...
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices resumed their 3-month-old rally Wednesday as traders ignored bearish supply factors and again took their cues from price movement charts that suggested the market had room to move higher. Grain futures also rose sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade while on other markets, oil, copper and precious metal futures fell and most livestock and meat futures advanced. Soybean futures settled 6{ cents to 9\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in May up 9 cents at $6.36{ a bushel. Wheat futures settled 4 cents to 6 cents higher with May at $3.73{ a bushel; corn was 2{ cents to 4\ cents higher with May at $2.87} a bushel; oats were 3} cents to 6 cents higher with May at $1.68{ a bushel. The price of soybeans for near-term delivery has risen about 15 percent since Jan. 9, when the market began its climb from $5.53{ a bushel. The buying has been spurred at times by fundamental factors such as Brazilian soybean harvesting delays and strong domestic demand for soybean meal. But observers said the powerful advance of the past week, totaling about 27 cents in the last six trading sessions _ has been led by speculators that trade according to their interpretation of price charts, known as technical analysis. Based on the charts, analysts said, the market looked ripe for a rally Wednesday after Tuesday's modest decline. Funds operated by the big trading companies Tudor Investment Corp. and Refco Inc. were said to be big buyers despite forecasts for beneficial rain in the Midwestern corn and soybean belt and indications that the Brazilian soybean harvest is advancing rapidly. ``It was a purely chart-driven market,'' said William Biedermann, director of research for Allendale Inc., a Chicago-area trading firm. ``If you want to come up with a fundamental reason, you'd have to dream something up like anticipation of adverse weather and stronger export demand, but that's really fishing for something,'' he said. The wheat market was supported by some fundamental news. The Agriculture Department announced Wednesday morning that it had targeted China for sales of 2 million metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Wheat futures also were boosted by concerns that heavy rains in Texas and Oklahoma could cause winter wheat harvest delays and crop losses, analysts said. Oil futures dipped on the New York Mercantile Exchange, erasing early gains, after OPEC ministers meeting in Geneva postponed a second full plenary session about ways to cut their oil production and raise crude oil prices. The ministers, meeting in emergency session, were finding it difficult to agree on how much to trim production and how to allocate the cuts among cartel members, sources told The Associated Press. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 11 cents to 21 cents lower with June at $18.68 a barrel; heating oil was .89 cent to 1.12 cents lower with June at 51.85 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was unchanged to .15 cent lower with June at 60.95 cents a gallon. Copper futures ended lower on New York's Commodity Exchange following reports that the Peruvian government had ordered back to work employees of the Southern Peru Copper Corp. who have been on strike since March 12. Copper settled .60 cent to 1.5 cents lower with May at $1.213 a pound. Also on the Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled 70 cents to 80 cents lower with June at $372 a troy ounce; silver was 2.5 cents to 3 cents lower with May $4.988 a troy ounce. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle finished .15 cent to .38 cent higher with June at 73.60 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .35 cent higher with May at 82.72 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .43 cent higher with June at 63.87 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .30 cent lower to 1.12 cents higher with May at 69.77 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: President Asks Congress to Allow Return to Private Banking
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari on Wednesday proposed a constitutional amendment to reopen banking to private ownership, but said the government would retain some nationalized commercial banks. The president said his proposal to Congress for the amendment reflected the economic changes since President Jose Lopez Portillo nationalized the nation's 35 private banks in 1982 at the outset of Mexico's financial crisis. Lopez Portillo claimed the banks were helping Mexicans get money out of the country, worsening an economic recession. ``Circumstances have changed,'' Salinas said in a communique. ``The development policies have been modified and transcendental transformations have been carried out in the economic structures. ``The country has made an enormous effort to overcome the crisis and, at the same time, to respond to the challenges of the last decade of the 20th Century: to respond with justice to the demands of society and confront with sovereignty a transformed, more competitive, technologically revolutionized world of still uncertain perspectives.'' Since Lopez Portillo nationalized the banks, the banking system has been reopened to 34 percent ownership by private investors, independent government agencies or corporations. A presidential spokeswoman said that under the Salinas proposal 100 percent private ownership would be possible. Salinas' bill faces a tougher time in Congress than the constitutional amendment that allowed the nationalization. In 1982, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, held a two-thirds majority in Congress and rubber-stamped presidential bills. It lost that advantage in 1988, when Salinas won by the slimmest presidential margin in the party's 60-year history. Leftist parties, which oppose Salinas' program to privatize state-owned industry and business, quickly criticized the bill. Ricardo Pascoe Pierce of the Democratic Revolutionary Party, the largest leftist party, said the proposal was a ploy to try to win popularity in national and foreign financial circles. With 123 of the 500 seats in the lower house, they could not defeat the bill, but are likely to try to slow it down and arouse nationalistic sentiment. Support for the bill is likely from the pro-business National Action Party. The PRI reached a deal with the party in 1989 to pass electoral reforms. Salinas has sold or put up for sale major companies including the national airline, steel mills and its stock in the telephone monopoly. But he had not yet ventured into sectors set aside for the government in the Constitution, including banking, oil and electricity. He skirted the Constitution in the petrochemical area, reclassifying some basic petrochemicals to secondary, thus allowing private and foreign investment. Salinas said many of Mexico's social needs can be met with money the government no longer will spend on banking and with money raised by the sale of bank stock. Under the bill, ``the state proposes that it not be the majority owner of each and every one of the banking institutions,'' he said. ``However, it will retain a participation in commercial banking and will strengthen those institutions oriented to development of specific priority activities.'' A presidential statement noted that France and Portugal, among other countries, had made similar banking reforms and that eastern European countries were preparing similar changes. Salinas did not mention foreign banks and it was not immediately clear how, or if, they would be affected. One foreign banker, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the proposal was ``very fuzzy'' and did not ensure that existing banks would be sold. Eduardo Garcia Suarez, president of the National Association of Chambers of Commerce, said the country needs an exclusively private, rather than mixed, system to be able to compete internationally, the government news agency Notimex said.

DOC.HEAD: Criticism of Golden Parachutes Draws Applause at Annual Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Control Data Corp.'s new chief executive told shareholders Wednesday he has purged the computer company of bureaucracy, wasteful spending and arbitrary bonuses. At an annual meeting punctuated by shareholder criticism of multimillion-dollar severance and retirement packages, Lawrence Perlman said changes in the company's ``culture'' should lead to ``consistent profitability.'' ``The Control Data of the past was not always a company that thought in terms of building shareholder value,'' said Perlman, who became chief executive in January after the company posted a net loss of $680 million in 1989. He said stockholders, employees and customers have been asked to ``endure a great deal'' during the last five years, in which the company lost $1.5 billion. But Perlman defended the company's board for signing a contract in 1986 that gave former company head Robert Price $5.31 million in severance, retirement and bonus money. Price also will get $450,000 a year under a three-year consulting contract and receive a $300,000 annual pension. Two shareholders took the floor at the meeting to criticize Price's contract and previous large payouts to retiring senior executives. ``I'm outraged,'' said Edward Diesing, a former Control Data employee who termed the compensation ``exorbitant payoffs'' and ``payola.'' ``It's called greed,'' said Diesing, who was applauded by fellow shareholders. ``There is way too much of this attitude in the U.S. and quite possibly at Control Data. What do you think happens to employees' morale when these disturbing sins are reported?'' Perlman said Price's contract was ``reasonable'' at the time it was signed four years ago. But senior executives signing such agreements today are entitled to less, he said. For instance, senior executives no longer are entitled to severance payments if they leave voluntarily, Perlman said. Price announced last month that he would not stand for re-election to the company's board of directors. The company lost $924 million during his four-year reign. Perlman said all consulting contracts at the company are under review because some have been ``abused,'' and he said no employees will receive bonus money unless they achieve profits for the company. In some cases under the old bonus system, payments were ``quite subjective,'' he said. ``I want people to be able to produce a number,'' Perlman said. In his remarks to shareholders, Perlman made repeated references to Control Data's past. Once self-described as the world's most innovative company, Control Data grew wildly and profited in the 1960s and '70s before stumbling in the '80s. ``Buoyed by the large gross margins of the 1970s and the early 1980s, the company did not build into its culture the discipline of constant attention to controlling expenses and reducing costs,'' Perlman said. He said corporate overhead was ``out of hand several years ago,'' but has been controlled by a reduction in corporate staff to 250 from about 3,000 in 1985. ``People are beginning to treat the company's money as if it were their own,'' he said. He also said investment decisions will be ``based on financial analysis and reasonable expectations of returns on investment _ not on hope, not on emotion.'' Perlman and Price last year shut down Control Data's supercomputer subsidiary, ETA Systems, at a cost about $335 million. Control Data founder William C. Norris, who headed the company until 1986 and still sits on the board of directors, said he wasn't offended by Perlman's portrayal of the company's past. ``I didn't take it personally,'' Norris said after the meeting. ``The company had problems from time to time. The thing that hurt us more than anything else was the Japanese.'' Analysts have predicted Control Data's net income for 1990 at $1 a share to $1.50 a share. Perlman said he is not comfortable with the prediction beyond ``the midpoint of that range.''

DOC.HEAD: Mitsubishi Acquires Value Rent-A-Car
DOC.TEXT: Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America Inc. announced it had agreed to acquire a controlling interest in Value Rent-A-Car, which will be stocked mostly with Mitsubishi cars. The value of the deal was not announced Tuesday. Mitsubishi plans to keep Value's current management and add some Mitsubishi managers. ``Gaining control of a rental car company will provide Mitsubishi with several advantages on behalf of its growing dealer network,'' said Richard D. Recchia, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America. Mitsubishi intends to increase Value Rent-A-Car's fleet of Mitsubishis from 10 percent to 85 percent. Mitsubishi also intends to sell used Value cars at Mitsubishi dealerships, said Recchia. Value Rent-A-Car operates 25 outlets in Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Arizona, Colorado and Nevada. Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America distributes Mitsubishi cars made in Japan and in Normal, Ill.

DOC.HEAD: Former Chairman Testifies About Plan To Sell Documents to Iran
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Atkins testimony; ADDS details; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Former Ashland Oil Co. Chairman Orin Atkins testified Wednesday that he never personally benfited from a scheme to sell confidential Ashland documents to Iran's national oil company. Atkins took the stand in the U.S. District Court trial of attorney Charles Barnett, 38, of Palm Beach, Fla., who is charged connection with the 1979 conspiracy. Atkins pleaded guilty to related charges last September and agreed to cooperate. ``I never received any money from any Iranian at any time,'' Atkins said. In opening arguments Monday, Assistant U.S. Attorney Herve Gouraiage described Barnett as an instrumental player in the conspiracy to sell the documents to the Iranian National Oil Company for use in a civil lawsuit against Ashland. ``Barnett was the person who thoroughly familiarized himself with the contents of the stolen Ashland documents so he could explain their usefulness to the Iranians,'' Gouraiage said. The papers dealt with the 1979 sale of $283 million of crude oil from the Iranian company to a subsidiary of the Kentucky oil concern, Ashland Overseas Trading Ltd. Iran sued Ashland in 1985 for not paying for the oil, and Ashland settled the case last year by agreeing to pay $325 million. Prosecutors said Atkins initiated the plan in 1982 after being forced to resign his executive position in 1981. He continued to work for Ashland as a highly paid consultant until 1984. Atkins, in his guilty plea, admitted that he improperly obtained 259 corporate documents and tried to sell them to the Iranians in return for a cut of any damages Iran won in the lawsuit. On the witness stand, Atkins said he and others involved in the deal also tried to sell his consulting services, which would have involved identifying Ashland employees who were potential witnesses in the lawsuit. He said he met only once, in 1982, with ``unofficial representatives'' of the Iranian company. Atkins said negotiations with the Iranians were handled by former Ashland consultant Roy Furmark, Barnett and others. Furmark, who also will testify, pleaded guilty in the scheme in March. He admitted showing some of the documents to representatives of the Iranian company at a meeting in London. Atkins faces up to 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine when sentenced later this year for conspiracy and wire fraud. The first witness at Barnett's trial was Dustan McCoy, an Ashland attorney, who said the company had refused to pay Iran for the oil because it believed Iran had breached the contract. Barnett's attorney, Marvin Segal, told the jury in opening remarks that Barnett's actions were part of a ``legal enterprise to help the Iranian oil company collect the money it avowedly was owned.'' The indictment against Barnett said he, Atkins and others made numerous attempts to sell the documents to the Iranians between 1982 and 1988. Prosecutors have not said whether the Iranians bought any documents. Furmark was a marginal participant in the Iran-Contra scandal and gave testimony during investigations by House and Senate committees and special prosecutor Lawrence Walsh. Barnett's attorneys are seeking to obtain transcripts of Furmark's testimony about the Iran-Contra affair to use in Barnett's defense. U.S. District Judge John E. Sprizzo has said he will review the testimony before ruling on its admissibility as evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Ford President Acknowledges Regulation Has Brought Improvement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co.'s new president acknowledged Wednesday that improvements in the auto industry have followed government regulations which were not always received gracefully by the industry. Philip E. Benton, who became Ford president and chief operating officer March 1, also said he expects the world auto industry in 10 years to include only about a half dozen dominant companies, down from about a dozen today. ``Critics of the U.S. auto industry viewed us as fighting just about every regulatory initiative that Washington and the state capitals could come up with'' in the 1960s and 1970s, Benton said in a speech. ``We clearly gained a reputation for intransigence.'' He said the industry often sought only to alter timetables or the stringency of particular standards, and did not oppose the principles behind government initiatives. Automakers now have gone through a tough transition from focusing on consumers and competition to ``worrying about regulatory complexity and compliance,'' he said, ``And, in some instances, we didn't make it very gracefully.'' But Benton said Ford is pleased with its progress in installing airbags, manufacturing full-sized cars that get as much as 25 miles per gallon, reducing auto exhaust emissions and beginning to phase out chlorofluorocarbons _ all the result of government regulation. ``We've invested heavily and aggressively in the technology and human resources that have allowed us to come this far toward resolving environmental and safety concerns, and we're prepared to do our part in the future in cooperation with government,'' Benton said. He said changes are creating a new world which will no longer be defined by military strength but by the ``economic strengths and interrelationships'' of North America, Europe and Asia. Benton said he did not believe in ``Japan bashing'' or in ``the habit of some to bash the home team.'' But he said the U.S. auto industry has been shaken up by the entry of Japanese companies. ``As a result, the stability of the North American market (once dominated by Ford, Chrysler Corp. and General Motors Corp.,) for the time being, is gone, and North America is up for grabs,'' he said. Worldwide consolidation will likely occur with more partnerships, purchases and absorptions, he said. He noted that Chrysler bought American Motors in 1987, General Motors bought about half of Saab's car business last year and this year Ford bought Jaguar while Renault and Volvo announced a far-reaching alliance. Ford will be one of the surviving strong half-dozen companies, Benton said, declining to predict who the others might be.

DOC.HEAD: Southern Co.: Earnings Down Due to Mild Winter, PSC Decision
DOC.TEXT: Southern Co. said higher production costs, a mild winter and an unfavorable Georgia rate decision combined to depress the utility's first quarter earnings by more than 40 percent. The company Wednesday reported earnings of $113 million for the first three months of 1990 or 36 cents a share, down from $197 million or 62 cents a share in the same period of 1989. President Edward L. Addison said a decision last fall by the Georgia Public Service Commission was a key factor in the earnings slippage. The commission awarded $218 million of the $413 million sought by Southern's Georgia Power Co. subsidiary to recover construction costs from Unit 2 of nuclear Plant Vogtle. Addison said Southern's total electricity sales were down 1.2 percent as a result of a warm winter. Southern Co., based in Atlanta, is the parent firm of five electric companies in the Southeast: Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power and Savannah Electric.

DOC.HEAD: GM Announces Incentives
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. announced car and light truck incentive programs to include cash rebates ranging from $500 to $2,500 and an interest rate as low as 7.9 percent. The incentives, which vary from car to car and truck to truck, run until Aug. 2 for some Buick, Pontiac and Oldsmobile vehicles and either June 11 or July 9 for certain Chevrolet vehicles, the company said Wednesday. The program, which extends incentives on some models, is effective Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Contractors Angry At Taj Mahal For Delayed Payments
DOC.TEXT: Contractors have asked the Casino Control Commission to help force the Taj Mahal Casino Resort to complete payment for work on Donald Trump's new casino, a commission spokesman said. The commission has yet to receive a formal complaint to refer to the state Division of Gaming Enforcement, however, said the spokesman, Tom Flynn. Taj Mahal spokeswoman Karen Tuso said she could not comment on the complaints and referred all questions to Ed Tracy, who supervises Trump's three Atlantic City gaming halls and other properties in the city. Tracy did not return telephone calls immediately. The Philadelphia Inquirer reported Wednesday that about $35 million is owed to about 100 contractors for work on the casino, which cost $1 billion. The contractors said they had pushed to meet the casino's April 2 opening and felt they should be paid in full now. Tracy told the newspaper that Trump ``made a simple business decision'' to hold back 10 percent of contract amounts until an audit determined if the contractors had submitted inflated invoices. ``Granted, it's slighlty after the fact,'' Tracy said. `It would be negligent not to do an audit given the size of the project.''

DOC.HEAD: Farah Files Suit Against Farah Inc.
DOC.TEXT: William F. Farah, who managed apparel manufacturer Farah Inc. for 43 years, accused the company of ignoring his experience and expertise in a lawsuit to get back his job as board chairman. Farah was replaced as chairman of the Farah Inc. board last week. He is seeking a temporary restraining order against the company in county court. He wants the court to stop the board of directors from ousting him from his plant office and barring him from company facilities. In the suit, Farah calls the board members ``spiteful conspirators'' who want to destroy him financially. The suit says the board members have threatened to terminate Farah's consulting services. Farah is the company's largest stockholder. According to the suit, the disagreement between Farah and the board stems from a three-year consulting agreement that went into effect July 1. The contract is part of a long-term employment agreement that Farah and the company entered into after Farah resigned as president and chief executive officer last July 6. Farah alleges that the board ignored his suggestions and ideas to the detriment of the company and its shareholders. He said the company has suffered substantial financial losses as a result. Richard Allender, company president, was out of town and did not return phone calls.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Asks City Council to Enact Mandatory Water Conservation
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Tom Bradley on Wednesday proposed mandatory conservation measures requiring all water customers to cut use by 10 percent from 1986 levels to cope with California's worsening drought. The state is experiencing its fourth consecutive drought year and ``the situation is serious,'' Bradley said at a news conference at City Hall. The regional Metropolitan Water District, which provides about half the water needed by 15 million people in Southern California, has forecast a 10 percent shortfall in its supplies this summer. The city's Department of Water and Power, which is getting 60 percent of its water supply from the Metropolitan Water District this year, serves 3.4 million residents. The mayor's request was ``a judgment call,'' said James F. Wickser, the department's water chief. Available water supplies for the city appear adequate at least through December, and consumption last month was 14 percent below April 1989, Wickser said. Bradley said there is a need to step up a voluntary water conservation program in effect since 1988. Although the measures Bradley proposed are the most restrictive since the state's record drought of 1977, they pale in comparison to those in Santa Barbara, where officials are trying to cut water use by 45 percent. In a letter to the City Council, Bradley sought changes in a 1977 drought ordinance that set out five increasingly stringent steps for conservation. Council approval likely will take six weeks at least, mayoral aides said. ``We can no longer delay in informing the citizens of Los Angeles that because of the lengthy statewide drought we have no choice but to require water-reducing actions by every resident, business and corporation,'' Bradley said in a statement. Council President John Ferraro agreed that the measures are needed and said the proposal has already been scheduled for the appropriate council committee. The two-year-old city drought ordinance's first phase calls for a voluntary 10 percent cutback. It forbids people from hosing down sidewalks and driveways, and restaurants and hotels from routinely serving drinking water. It has not been widely observed or enforced, although the Department of Water and Power reported total water use last summer fell about 8 percent. Commonplace first phase violations prompted the mayor to seek the mandatory 10 percent reduction, aides said. The mayor also recommended a ban on watering gardens and lawns between 10 a.m. and 5 p.m. and prohibiting water from overflowing onto sidewalks or streets. Bradley's proosal would assess surcharge penalties for excess water use. The bimonthly bill for an average residential customer who fails to cut water use by 10 percent would jump from about $50 to about $70 on the first offense, said John Stodder, a mayoral aide. Additional penalties would be heaped on customers who continue to use too much water, including the installation of water flow restriction devices or a service shut-off for repeat offenders. Under existing law, a City Council resolution is needed to implement the penalty aspects of the conservation ordinance. The mayor said that those who voluntarily have cut back 10 percent of their 1986 water use, when water was plentiful, would not be required to make additional reductions.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Continue to Rebound Strongly
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices on the Seoul Stock Exchange continued to rebound strongly Thursday morning with the compostite index rising 31.94 points or 4.4 percent to 750.39 points. It was the year's biggest single-day gain and followed Tuesday's 29.79 points rise, which brought the index up from an 18-month low of 688.82 on Monday. The market was closed Wednesday, a national holiday. The two-day rally was prompted by the government's announcement of market boosting measures aimed at saving the market from imminent collapse. In a midnight meeting of economic ministers Monday ordered by President Roh Tae-woo, the government decided to force business conglomerates, security and insurance firms to sell their land held for speculative purpose and use proceeds to buy stocks. Newspapers reported Thursday that the government has ordered the top five business conglomerates to sell their land holdings within six months and invest proceeds in stocks. It warned that otherwise they face punitive actions such as a cutoff in fresh bank loans and severe taxes. It has been reported that many business companies have been engaged in rampant real estate speculation at the sacrifice of investment in production facilities in anticipation of high inflation. They also have shunned investment in existing and new business projects concerned about waves of protracted labor strikes demanding steep wage hikes and more union rights. The country's economy has been sagging since early last year because of a slowdown in exports and rapid price increases.
